summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Friday, driven by gains in tech stocks following reported talks between Chinese and US regulators that could prevent delistings in New York. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.01% to 20,170.04, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.31%. The gains came despite global markets experiencing volatility, with US stocks near record highs despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore steps up crypto questioning as firms brace for changes
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is intensifying its scrutiny of cryptocurrency-related firms ahead of planned regulatory changes. The regulator has sent a questionnaire to some applicants and holders of its digital-payments licence, seeking detailed information about their business activity and holdings. The questions focus on gauging the financial soundness of firms and their interconnectedness, and may lead to broader regulations covering more activities, including risk-based capital and liquidity requirements. This comes after several entities, including hedge funds and platforms, have defaulted due to a lack of extensive risk management rules for digital asset companies.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB raises Grab target to US$4.10 as sentiment on business model improves
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for Grab to US$4.10, citing a strong Q2 results performance that beat estimates and improved its perception on the economic viability of on-demand services' business models. Grab's revenue surged to an all-time high of US$321 million, driven by a 30% growth in gross merchandise value. The analyst believes the easing competitive landscape will enable Grab to accelerate its path to profitability, with a potential break-even in its core food and deliveries segment 1-2 quarters ahead of previous guidance.

site_title: Australia: Resources, banks help shares close higher, all eyes on Fed comments
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.8% on Friday, closing at 7,104.1 points, for a third consecutive session, driven by gains across all sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index edged lower for the week, snapping its 5-week rally. Investors are focusing on US Federal Reserve's comments on future rate hike bets, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell's speech later in the day expected to influence market sentiment. Key sectors included miners and energy stocks, which rose 1.1% and 1.3% respectively, while gold stocks fell 2.8%.

images.alt_text: Leading gains on the resource-heavy bourse, domestic miners added 0.8 per cent on strong underlying iron ore prices.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals rise for 6th straight month in July to post-Covid record of 726,601
summary: Singapore reported a record 726,601 tourist arrivals in July, surpassing the post-Covid record of 726,601, marking the 6th consecutive month of growth. The top source of arrivals was Indonesia, followed by India and Australia. Despite the growth, visitor numbers remain below pre-pandemic levels. Analysts attribute the slowdown to rising inflation and competition from other Asian markets, but expect arrival numbers to recover with upcoming events and the year-end holiday period.

images.alt_text: Some 543,732 visitors arrived in Singapore in June, hitting a new record since the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: AvePoint sets up R&D hub, and will hire over 500 digital professionals
summary: AvePoint, a Microsoft 365 data-management solutions provider, has set up a S$100 million R&D hub in Singapore, strengthening global cloud resilience and supporting regional businesses. The facility will hire over 500 digital professionals by 2026, tripling its existing team, and provide professional development opportunities. The hub will focus on developing new products and solutions, advancing IT and digital infrastructure, and ensuring local businesses are supported. The investment is supported by EDBI and Digital Industry Singapore, and AvePoint aims to anchor the development of new products for Singapore and the global market.

site_title: Christie's to auction Microsoft co-founder Allen's US$1b art collection
summary: Christie's plans to auction the US$1 billion art collection of late Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, comprising over 150 pieces spanning 500 years of art, including works by Cezanne, Johns, and Monet. The auction, set for November, will support charitable causes, aligning with Allen's philanthropic wishes. The sale is expected to be "the largest and most exceptional art auction in history."

site_title: India bond markets rally on bets of index inclusion
summary: India's bond markets rallied on Friday, August 26, driven by bets of inclusion in global indexes. The benchmark 10-year government bond yield rose 11 basis points to 7.2181%, its highest level in six sessions. The yield increase was attributed to reports of progress in including local bonds in global indexes, such as Goldman Sachs' expectation of India's inclusion in 2023 and JPMorgan's talks with investors on adding India to its emerging-market bond index. This has led to passive inflows of around $30 billion and has boosted investor confidence.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets end higher as tech shares gain
summary: Tokyo stock markets closed higher on Friday, led by gains in tech-related shares. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.57% to 28,641.38, while the Topix index rose 0.15% to 1,979.59. Tech shares, including Tokyo Electron and Advantest, jumped following gains in the US Nasdaq index. site_title: China recovery wobbles as drought, global slowdown add to risks
summary: China's economy continued to recover in August, with its aggregate index of 8 early indicators remaining unchanged at 5, indicating steady momentum. However, the recovery is threatened by drought-induced power shortages, weakening global demand, and a property market slump. Sales continued to plunge in China's top 4 cities, and mortgage rates are expected to be cut to a record low of 4.1% to boost housing demand. Economists warn that the measures may not be enough to counter the damage from Covid lockdowns and the property market slump, and business confidence has slipped due to ongoing disruptions.

site_title: 'No regrets' as badminton world champion Loh loses crown
summary: Singapore's reigning badminton world champion Loh Kean Yew lost his title defence to Thailand's Kunlavut Vitidsarn in Tokyo, falling 21-12, 17-21, 21-8. Despite the loss, Loh expressed "no regrets," attributing his struggles to the environment inside the Tokyo Metropolitan Gymnasium. He had previously stated he felt no pressure defending his crown after winning the title last year. Loh, 25, remained optimistic about his performance, describing the tournament as "fine."

site_title: Japan’s wage growth to lag inflation over next 12 months: poll
summary: Japan's economy faces a slowdown due to a global downturn, with nominal wage growth unlikely to outpace inflation over the next 12 months, according to a Reuters poll. Almost 80% of economists predicted this, citing a slowdown in the US, China, and Europe. This could lead to households tightening their purse strings, further hurting the economy. Japan's average wages have not increased since the early 1990s, and the country's economy is projected to expand at a slower pace than initially thought, with growth estimated at 2.0% for the 3 months through September.

site_title: Swiss brace for looming power shortages
summary: Switzerland is bracing for potential power shortages and blackouts this winter due to its reliance on Russian gas and French nuclear power, both of which are in short supply. The country's hydropower plants, which produce more than enough power in summer, are insufficient to meet demand during winter months. A new pumped-storage hydroelectric plant, Nant de Drance, is set to open next month, but it's unlikely to alleviate the issue. Experts warn that Switzerland's lack of gas storage and reliance on imports from the EU will exacerbate the problem, with potential power cuts and shortages.

site_title: China’s US$1 trillion infrastructure megaprojects
summary: China is investing $1 trillion in infrastructure projects, including renewable energy, high-speed rail, water tunnels, and data centers, to boost its economy and become a more urbanized, high-income nation. The projects, which could be completed by 2030, are expected to provide employment relief and stimulate economic growth. China is focusing on building green cities, with plans to allocate 70% of urban areas for green spaces and water. Cardiac MRI is considered the gold standard for cardiac pump assessment and is useful in evaluating congenital heart disease.

Properties such as a district 9 freehold project sold at S$2,064 psf, and a non-landed home in Ang Mo Kio sold at S$2,110 psf, are now within budget. This is contrary to the common misconception that such homes are out of reach. The availability of these properties may encourage buyers to explore alternative options.

images.alt_text: Huttons Asia’s senior research director Lee Sze Teck attributed July's jump in sales for the outside central region to “astounding sale results” for AMO Residence.
Private properties along Paterson Road
AMO Residence is the first notable launch in the Outside Central Region (OCR) this year, as well as the first major project in Ang Mo Kio in over eight years.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher following solid Wall Street gains; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3254.55 points, driven by solid gains on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all increased. FJ Benjamin was the most actively traded counter, up 19.2%. US economic data boosted market sentiment, with the Federal Reserve repeating its intention to raise interest rates to combat inflation.

site_title: Webb telescope finds CO2 for first time in exoplanet atmosphere
summary: The James Webb Space Telescope has detected carbon dioxide in the atmosphere of an exoplanet, WASP-39, for the first time. The discovery, made using the telescope's infrared sensor, provides insight into the exoplanet's formation and gas composition. Although WASP-39 is a hot gas giant, the detection of CO2 gives researchers hope for future studies of rocky, potentially habitable planets. The finding is a significant milestone in exoplanet sciences and could lead to new discoveries about the formation and evolution of planets in our galaxy.

images.alt_text: The 8-day mission would mark the final test mission before Nasa can certify Starliner for routine astronaut missions.

site_title: Hong Kong’s exodus shrinks workforce in threat to financial-hub status
summary: Hong Kong's workforce has shrunk by 6% since August 2018, reaching a decade-low of 3.75 million, due to an exodus of residents, mainly younger workers and families, amid anti-government protests and travel restrictions. The population outflow is accelerating the city's aging, with the proportion of retirees increasing and the birth rate at a record low. This threatens Hong Kong's status as a major financial hub, with firms shifting staff to rival hubs like Singapore.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong reported 7,884 new Covid-19 cases on Wednesday (Aug 24), the highest number since the end of March.

site_title: Europe: Energy, tech stocks keep shares afloat amid recession worries
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Thursday amid rising oil and tech stocks, despite recession concerns. Energy shares jumped 1.2% to 12-week highs as crude prices climbed due to supply concerns. Russia's halt of Nord Stream 1 natural gas supplies for 3 days from August 31 added pressure. Money markets now price in 100 bps of ECB rate hikes by October, indicating growing concerns over the energy crisis and potential recession.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index of major blue-chip companies won 0.6 per cent to 7,516.33 points, compared with the closing level on Wednesday.

site_title: China’s energy shortage could boost copper and aluminium demand: ANZ
summary: China's energy shortage may boost copper and aluminum demand as the power constraints highlight the need for increased grid investments. ANZ analysts predict copper demand growth to 3.6% in 2022 and 6.5% in 2023 due to increased investment in renewable energy projects, which will also drive demand for aluminum, growing 3.1% in 2022 and 4% in 2023, putting further upside pressure on aluminum prices.

site_title: Oil prices sink US$2 a barrel on possible Iran oil exports, rising interest rates
summary: Oil prices dropped by about $2 a barrel on Thursday, with Brent crude settling at $99.34 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $92.52 a barrel. The decline was driven by concerns about the possible return of Iranian oil exports to global markets and rising US interest rates, which may weaken fuel demand. Talks between the EU, US, and Iran to revive the 2015 nuclear deal continue, with Iran saying it received a response from the US to the EU's final text.

images.alt_text: Both crude oil benchmark contracts touched 3-week highs earlier on Wednesday after the Saudi energy minister flagged the possibility of cutting production.

site_title: Abercrombie cuts sales forecast as Hollister falls out of fashion
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch Co cut its full-year sales and margin forecasts after reporting a surprise quarterly loss due to increasing competition and surging inflation. The company plans to revamp its inventory by eliminating casual and athleisure apparel, focusing on dressier styles ahead of the holiday season. Sales at Hollister, a 50% of the business, fell 15% in the second quarter, while the main Abercrombie label saw a 5% increase. The company now expects net sales to decline mid single digits in fiscal 2022 and full-year operating margin to range from 1-3%.

images.alt_text: Abercrombie & Fitch film on Netflix is latest tale of corporate misdeeds

site_title: US: Shares end with solid gains on positive data
summary: US stocks ended with solid gains on Thursday, boosted by upbeat economic data, despite Federal Reserve officials' warnings of continued interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.0%, the S&P 500 gained 1.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index increased 1.7%. Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's speech on inflation and interest rates was seen as having little impact, with markets interpreting his message as non-surprising, leading to a relief rally. Initial jobless claims fell unexpectedly, and GDP contracted less than initially reported.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has risen 60.04 points, or 0.18 per cent, at the open to 33,029.27 on Thursday (Aug 25).

site_title: India’s top refiner to spend 2 trillion rupees to cut emissions
summary: India's state-owned oil refiner, Indian Oil, plans to spend 2 trillion rupees (S$34.8 billion) to achieve carbon neutrality by 2046. The company aims to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 60% through mitigation and offsets, with the rest achieved through purchases of carbon credits. Indian Oil will also invest in green products and fuel cells, with a focus on hydrogen production, to achieve its goal. The company's decarbonization plan aligns with India's national goal of reaching net zero by 2070.

site_title: S&P Global is 3rd corporate investor in Handshakes
summary: S&P Global has invested in emerging data tech company Handshakes, taking a 15.87% stake in the company. This latest round of funding, led by S&P Global and Nikkei Inc, values Handshakes at US$63 million. The platform, which specializes in corporate intelligence, increases corporate transparency by providing access to complex corporate data. Handshakes has a strong regional client base in audit, banking, and investigation, utilizing AI technologies to reconcile entities across multiple data sources and jurisdictions.

site_title: Grab narrows Q2 loss to US$547m with record-high revenue, exits dark stores
summary: Grab, a South-east Asian tech giant, narrowed its Q2 loss to US$547 million despite a 79% surge in revenue to an all-time high of US$321 million. The company attributed the growth to a 30% increase in gross merchandise value, driven by a recovery in the mobility business and on-demand delivery. Grab also exited its delivery-only warehouses, or "dark stores," in 3 markets, and reduced incentives to slash costs. The company's recent acquisition of Malaysian retail chain Jaya Grocer contributed to the revenue surge.

images.alt_text: The growth potential of Indonesia has helped GoTo outperform Grab, which became a publicly traded company through a merger with Brad Gerstner’s Altimeter Growth Corp in December.

site_title: Biden signs order on US$52b chips law implementation
summary: US President Joe Biden signed an executive order on the implementation of the US$52.7 billion "Chips and Science" law, aiming to boost US semiconductor chip manufacturing and research. The law includes a subsidy for chip plants, estimated at US$24 billion, and an investment tax credit. A 16-member interagency council will oversee implementation, and Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo has committed to a transparent and fair process. The program will include rigorous reviews and compliance requirements to protect taxpayer funds.

site_title: Relief for shippers as spot rates decline – though not to pre-Covid rates
summary: Spot shipping rates are declining, but not dramatically, amid weakening global growth and slowing consumer demand. Rates have fallen 20-30% over the past few months, with some routes seeing significant decreases. Despite this, long-term contract rates remain high, and shippers are signing shorter contracts. Analysts expect spot rates to continue declining, but at a slow pace, and for long-term rates to follow suit with some lag. Global export growth is expected to slow, with Asia's exports expected to cool further over the next year, according to Oxford Economics.

images.alt_text: “Asian exports are often a bellwether of global growth and Neli’s pointing to a darkening outlook,” Subbaraman said.

site_title: Facebook is building a customer-service group to field content complaints
summary: Meta, Facebook's parent company, is building a customer-service group to address complaints from users about unexpected post or account removals. The effort comes after the Oversight Board, an independent body set up in 2020, received over a million appeals from users, including many related to account support. Meta has struggled with customer service, relying heavily on artificial intelligence for content moderation decisions, which sometimes lead to mistaken account removals. The company aims to improve responsiveness to users and provide more effective support.

It resolved claims that Facebook violated California law and its own privacy policy by gathering data from users who turned off Location Services on their mobile devices.
Meta did not disclose the size of the offering but said it would use the proceeds for capital expenditures, share repurchases, acquisitions or investments.

site_title: Cash-rich Germany criticised by watchdog over money laundering
summary: Germany has been criticized by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) for failing to adequately tackle money laundering, despite being a major cash center. The country prosecuted only about 1,000 people for money laundering in 2020, despite opening over 37,000 inquiries. FATF highlighted issues such as a disjointed supervision system, lack of personnel, and insufficient control over those handling large sums of money. Germany's Finance Minister has pledged to centralize control, install additional staff, and modernize authorities' technology to address these shortcomings.

site_title: Indian IT firms cut staff bonuses as US, European clients tighten budgets
summary: India's top IT services firms, including Infosys and Wipro, are cutting staff bonuses as US and European clients tighten budgets amid recession fears. Infosys reduced variable pay, while Wipro withheld variable pay for mid- and senior-level employees and fixed payouts at 70% for junior employees. The move aims to eliminate discretionary spending and protect margins, with analysts predicting a softening growth outlook.

site_title: Djokovic says he will miss US Open
summary: Novak Djokovic, the unvaccinated Wimbledon champion, has withdrawn from the US Open due to the US government's restrictions on unvaccinated foreigners. Djokovic, who has had Covid-19 at least twice, has refused to get vaccinated, citing it as a personal decision. He expressed gratitude to his fans and announced he will stay in good shape and wait for an opportunity to compete again. This decision comes after Djokovic's stalemate with the US government, which has lifted many travel restrictions but still bars unvaccinated foreigners from entering the country.

site_title: US jobless claims fall for second week in sign of labour strength
summary: US jobless claims fell for the second consecutive week, decreasing by 2,000 to 243,000 in the week ended Aug 20. This suggests robust labor demand despite economic uncertainty, as companies try to attract and retain workers amid worker shortages. However, some employers, particularly in the technology sector, have been laying off staff or freezing hiring, which could continue as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates to curb demand and tame inflation.

site_title: China’s July net gold imports via Hong Kong at 9-month high
summary: China's net gold imports via Hong Kong reached a 9-month high in July, with 48.773 tonnes of gold imported, a 19.5% increase from June. Total gold imports were up 23.7% to 53.91 tonnes. This surge is attributed to Beijing's efforts to revive the economy, which has been hit by a resurgence of Covid cases. Chinese gold imports from Switzerland also rose, while re-exported gold stood at 48.82 tonnes. The increase in gold imports suggests continued demand, despite concerns about the economy and potential new Covid restrictions.

site_title: Amazon signs green hydrogen supply deal with Plug Power
summary: Amazon has signed a deal with Plug Power to supply 10,950 tons of green hydrogen annually starting 2025, replacing grey hydrogen, diesel, and other fossil fuels. The green hydrogen will power 30,000 forklifts or 800 heavy-duty trucks. This deal is part of Amazon's efforts to increase its use of hydrogen to power 20,000 fuel-cell propelled forklifts by 2025. Plug Power's shares rose over 12% following the announcement, which is expected to help the company grow towards its revenue goal of $3 billion in 2025.

site_title: US mortgage rates soar to 5.55%, renewing squeeze on homebuyers
summary: US mortgage rates surged to 5.55%, the highest since June 2013, pushing out would-be homebuyers and chilling transactions. This rise follows a jump in 10-year Treasuries yields and is expected to prompt the Federal Reserve's next interest rate move. As a result, home prices are moderating, and consumer confidence is low, with some non-bank lenders struggling to stay in business. The average 30-year mortgage now costs $1,713 per month for a $300,000 loan, up $430 from last year.

images.alt_text: Many independent lenders have managed their risk well, and for lenders that work extensively with government-backed companies like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the situation is less dire.
High home prices and a run-up in mortgage rates this year have pushed home ownership out of reach for many would-be buyers in US.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz’s new EQS SUV begins production in US
summary: Mercedes-Benz has begun production of its new EQS SUV at its plant in Tuscaloosa, Alabama, marking the company's first all-electric SUV built in the US. This production milestone is part of Mercedes' plans to produce 8 all-electric vehicles at 7 sites on 3 continents this year. The EQS SUV will be supplied with batteries from a nearby factory, and the EQE SUV is also set to go into production at the Tuscaloosa plant later this year.

site_title: US: Wall St ticks up at open with all eyes on Jackson Hole meet
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Thursday, driven by megacap growth and technology stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 60.04 points, or 0.18%, to 33,029.27. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 12.49 points, or 0.30%, and 74.84 points, or 0.60%, respectively. The focus shifted to the Federal Reserve's annual Jackson Hole symposium for clues on monetary policy.

site_title: China drops some Covid reporting rules for cross-border travellers at customs
summary: China has relaxed some COVID-19 reporting requirements for cross-border travelers at customs, shortening the quarantine period and removing some testing and self-isolation requirements for inbound travelers. However, travelers from many countries still need to report COVID-related information to Chinese embassies before boarding flights. These changes aim to make cross-border travel less onerous, but the policies for international travelers remain strict.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won rise on central bank's rate hike; bond yields soar
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.22% on Thursday, driven by a central bank's interest rate hike in line with expectations, which had a neutral impact on the market. The benchmark Kospi index ended at 2,477.26, with technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix advancing 1.19% and 0.97% respectively. The won strengthened, and bond yields surged as the Bank of Korea lifted its inflation forecasts, signaling more policy tightening.

images.alt_text: Among heavyweights, technology giant Samsung Electronics inched down 0.17 per cent and peer SK Hynix lost 0.43 per cent, but battery maker LG Energy Solution rose 1.35 per cent.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q2 net profit up 27% on exceptional gain
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Malaysian hospital group, reported a 27% rise in net profit for the second quarter ended June 30, driven by an exceptional gain of RM295.5 million due to restating financial statements in Turkey. Core business recovered as patients returned, offsetting the anticipated melt-off in Covid-19 related services. Net operating income fell 32% to RM317.5 million, while revenue grew marginally by 2% to RM4.37 billion. The group expects near-term headwinds but remains confident in providing long-term value for stakeholders.

images.alt_text: DBS’s target price on IHH Healthcare’s Malaysian listing was RM7.90 (S$2.45) while Raffles Medical had a target price of S$1.64.

site_title: Chinese delivery firm ZTO Express raises US$870m in convertible bonds
summary: Chinese delivery firm ZTO Express raised US$870 million by issuing convertible bonds to bolster its logistics operations. The bonds carry a coupon of 1.5% and a 30% conversion premium. The deal comes after ZTO clarified it had no intention to conduct fresh fundraising, following erroneous references in its unaudited first-half results. The funds will be used to support the company's logistics operations, providing a boost to its financial resources.

site_title: Key US growth measures diverge, complicating recession debate
summary: US growth measures diverge, complicating recession debate. Inflation-adjusted GDP decreased at a 0.6% annualized rate in the April to June period, while gross domestic income climbed at a 1.4% rate. The gap between the two measures is large, fueling debate on the economy's health. Consumer spending, a key driver, expanded 1.5% in the second quarter, but private inventory investment and residential fixed investment were revised lower. The Federal Reserve is raising interest rates to combat inflation, and economists expect GDP to bounce back in the third quarter, but recession fears remain elevated.

images.alt_text: Bookings for commercial aircraft climbed 14.5 per cent after Boeing reported 130 orders in July, up from 50 in June.

site_title: Euro bounces back to parity as investor sentiment improves
summary: The euro briefly regained parity with the US dollar on Thursday as investor sentiment improved, driven by a decline in global growth concerns and a more hawkish tone expected from Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell. However, the euro fell back below parity after a closely watched index showed Germany's business morale had fallen to its lowest since June 2020. The US dollar index remained near its highest since 2002, while the euro gained 0.1% to US$0.9978.

site_title: Citigroup to shut Russia consumer and commercial banking businesses
summary: Citigroup will close its consumer and commercial banking businesses in Russia, affecting 2,300 employees across 15 branches, starting this quarter. The estimated US$170 million cost will be mainly incurred over the next 18 months. This move follows the bank's departure from some overseas markets, including retail banking, which began in April 2021. The closure is part of Citi's broader exit from Russia after Russia's invasion of Ukraine in March.

site_title: Chinese stocks in US jump as new stimulus lifts investor mood
summary: Chinese stocks in the US have surged, with US-listed tech giants including Alibaba Group, JD.com, and Pinduoduo rising at least 3.5% in premarket trading on Thursday. The gains follow Beijing's pledges of fresh stimulus, lifting investor sentiment. The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index is set to extend its winning streak, following a 6% rally in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Tech Index. This marks the best day for the Hang Seng Tech Index in nearly 4 months, contributing to a 3.6% gain for the Hang Seng Index.

images.alt_text: The number of Alibaba shares held by the Asia-focused funds increased 311 per cent during the period, while that of Sea jumped by 110 per cent.

site_title: Wing Tai FY2022 full-year net profit soars 222%
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a 222% surge in full-year net profit to S$140.2 million for FY2022, driven by higher contributions from its associated and joint-venture companies. Revenue increased 12% to S$514.6 million, while earnings per share rose to 16.6 cents. The company attributed the jump to higher profits from Uniqlo in Singapore and Malaysia, as well as Wing Tai Properties Limited in Hong Kong. Despite a potential impact from property cooling measures and rising interest rates, the group expects to continue generating revenue from development properties.

images.alt_text: 知名服饰品牌“优衣库”（Uniqlo）设在淡滨尼广场的两层楼门店。

site_title: Transactions with Sembmarine beneficial to all parties, says Sembcorp
summary: Sembcorp Industries and Sembmarine have proposed a recapitalization and demerger to strengthen their financial positions. Sembcorp provided a $2 billion subordinated loan to Sembmarine in 2019, but the company's stressed balance sheet prevented further injections. To address this, Sembcorp and Sembmarine jointly proposed a $2.1 billion renounceable rights issue and demerger in 2020, enabling Sembcorp to focus on energy and urban businesses and Sembmarine to build on its core engineering capabilities. The transaction was approved by shareholders, with Sembcorp repaying its loan and Sembmarine strengthening its balance sheet.

site_title: Even from jail, Najib will remain a kingmaker in Malaysia
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak will remain a key figure in the country's politics despite being imprisoned for 12 years on corruption charges related to the 1MDB scandal. Najib's influence in the ruling United Malays National Organisation (Umno) party ensures he will continue to be a "kingmaker" in the next parliamentary battle. Umno officials plan to hold elections in November, with Najib's imprisonment potentially benefiting Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob, who must maintain his alliance with Najib loyalists to keep his seat. The next election must be held by September 2023, with the outcome determining Malaysia's stability and economic status.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak, is greeted by his supporters as he arrives at the Federal Court in Putrajaya, Malaysia, 23 August 2022.

site_title: Tesla shares in the limelight as 3-1 stock split kicks in
summary: Tesla shares rose 1.5% to US$301.5 in premarket trading after the company's 3-for-1 stock split took effect, making individual investors more accessible. The stock closed at US$891.29 on Wednesday. Analysts note that investors tend to scale back purchases of splitting stocks after the effective split date, but the split aims to retain retail investor support. Tesla's shares have fallen 11% since the company announced a share increase plan in March.

images.alt_text: User apps show charging stations are down in Chengdu in Sichuan province and the nearby city of Chongqing.

Tesla’s Full Self-Driving (FSD) system has been controversial  because it requires active supervision and doesn’t make the company’s vehicles autonomous. It last raised the cost of the system from US$10,000 to US$12,000 in January. From Sep 5, it will cost US$15,000.
Tesla has shortened the delivery waiting time for the Model Y in China to four to eight weeks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 28.23 points to 1,495.49. The index saw 2.642 billion lots worth RM2.108 billion change hands, with 663 gainers outnumbering 293 losers.

site_title: Counting greens and staying green: The rise of the chief finance and sustainability officer
summary: Singapore's CapitaLand Investment appoints Beh Siew Kim as chief financial and sustainability officer for lodging, marking a growing trend of companies integrating financial and sustainability roles. According to an industry study, more companies will create similar positions to translate sustainability reporting into meaningful outcomes. Beh, a former Ascott Residence Trust executive, obtained a formal sustainability education certificate from Singapore Management University two years ago, reflecting a shift towards formalizing sustainability skills in accounting and audit professionals.

The linkage between ESG and financial performance is more evident as investors and lenders integrate ESG into potential investments and debt issuance assessments.

site_title: China Life says profit falls amid market decline, lockdowns
summary: China Life Insurance, the nation's largest life insurer, reported a 38% decline in profit to 25.4 billion yuan (S$5.2 billion) in the first half of 2022 due to market declines and lockdowns. New business value, a measure of profitability, slid 14% in the first half. Chairman Bai Tao faces pressure to boost profitability amid the pandemic and economic slowdown. The decline in profit is attributed to eroded investment returns and reduced policy sales.

site_title: Crypto takes leading role in illegal South Korea currency trades
summary: South Korea's regulatory probes into cryptocurrency trades have led to a significant increase in illicit foreign-exchange transactions dominated by crypto-linked deals. Four cases this year, worth 1.5 trillion won (S$1.6 billion), have been sent to the prosecutor's office, nearly doubling the 827 billion won reported last year and a 70-fold jump from 2020. Nearly 75% of violating transactions are crypto-linked, down from 61% last year, amid a decline in enthusiasm for digital tokens following the crypto rout.

site_title: Sony hikes PS5 prices in some markets
summary: Sony has recommended raising the retail price of its PlayStation 5 console in several markets, including Europe, the UK, Japan, China, Australia, Mexico, and Canada, due to "high global inflation rates and adverse currency trends." The price hikes will see the PS5 Digital Edition retail for 449.99 euros, £389.99, and 49,478 yen, up from previous prices. US consumers will be spared from the increases. The price rises are aimed at addressing a supply crunch that has made the console difficult to buy.

images.alt_text: A new DualSense Edge wireless controller for the PlayStation 5.

site_title: Premier League clubs shatter summer spending record
summary: Premier League clubs have shattered the summer spending record, with £1.5 billion spent by 20 teams, surpassing the 2017 record of £1.43 billion. This is more than the £1.44 billion spent in the previous season. With a week left until the window closes, the all-time record of £1.86 billion could be broken. The high spending is attributed to rebounding business models post-Covid, but experts warn of the need for clubs to balance competitiveness with sustainable spending policies.

site_title: US consumers borrow at record levels as car prices surge
summary: US consumers are taking on more debt to buy new cars, with the average new vehicle loan reaching a record US$40,290 and monthly payments rising 15% to US$667. Used car loans also increased, with the average loan amount rising 18.7% to US$28,534. Despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, car prices continue to rise, with the average new car or truck price hitting a record US$46,259 in August. This trend is driven by shortages of semiconductors and supply chain issues, leading to increased demand for used vehicles.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Automobiles are shown for sale at a car dealership in Carlsbad, California, U.S. May 2, 2016. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: UK retailers report surprise jump in sales in August: CBI
summary: British retailers reported their strongest August sales in 9 months, defying forecasts of a decline due to the cost-of-living squeeze. The CBI's July retail sales balance for August jumped to +37 from -4 in July. Economists had expected a fall to -7, indicating a surprise increase in sales.

images.alt_text: British credit and debit card spending in “delayable” and “social” areas, are down by 8 and 4 points respectively.

site_title: Eurozone is already in recession on energy squeeze, UBS says
summary: The eurozone economy is expected to shrink by 0.1% in the third quarter and 0.2% in the fourth quarter, entering a "shallow" recession triggered by surging energy prices. UBS economists predict a technical recession, with a full-year growth forecast of 0.8% compared to 1.2% previously. Higher energy prices and uncertainty over supply are expected to persist into 2023-24 winter, with a potential recovery driven by private and public investment.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng appoints new COO
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng has appointed Ong Yuh Hwang as its new Chief Operating Officer (COO), effective September 5. Ong will assist the group CEO in managing operations and executing strategic plans. He previously held positions at Suntory Garuda Beverage Indonesia and Procter & Gamble. This comes after the company announced the resignations of its Chief Finance Officer and Malaysia, Indonesia, and Brunei CEO in May.

site_title: Five great shows at Gillman Barracks
summary: Singapore is celebrating its 57th birthday with a month-long exhibition at Gillman Barracks featuring 15 local artists showcasing their works in various galleries. The exhibition includes a mix of established and emerging artists, with themes ranging from pop culture and classical Chinese art to environmental concerns and queer identity explorations. Notable artists include Jane Lee, Marvin Tang, and Hu Qiren, who use mediums such as paint, sculpture, and photography to express their unique perspectives on Singapore's natural environment and cultural identity.

site_title: Indonesia's wealth fund to invest in expansion of Sumatra port
summary: Indonesia's state-owned port operator Pelindo and a consortium of the Indonesia Investment Authority and Dubai-based DP World have agreed to invest in the expansion of the Belawan port in Sumatra island. The $7.5 billion partnership aims to transform the port by increasing terminal capacity and direct calls, with plans to double its capacity to 1.4 million TEUs in 6 years. The expansion is expected to strengthen Belawan's position in the Malacca Straits and improve connectivity with other small ports. The deal is part of a broader partnership between the INA and DP World.

site_title: Maybank’s net profit down 5.4% in Q2, as expected credit loss doubles in view of tough times ahead
summary: Malayan Banking (Maybank) reported a 5.4% decline in net profit to RM1.86 billion in the second quarter of 2022, due to higher net impairment losses. The bank's expected credit loss for loans and securities more than doubled to RM1.16 billion, citing a sluggish global environment. Despite this, net operating income rose 10.7% to RM6.83 billion. Maybank expects loan growth of above 5% this year, despite rising interest rates, and announced its first interim dividend of 28 sen per share. The bank's asset quality also improved with a decline in gross impaired loans ratio to 1.81%.

site_title: STI up 0.4%, as Asia tracks Wall Street gains
summary: The Singapore market closed higher on Thursday, tracking a slight Wall Street rebound. The Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,247.8 points, with 321 gainers outnumbering 187 losers. Regional markets also climbed, with Japan, South Korea, and Australia rising between 0.6-1.2%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index surged 3.6% due to tech stocks. The market is awaiting US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole Symposium on Friday.

site_title: Boom time for fitness business
summary: Singapore's fitness industry has experienced significant growth since the pandemic, with over 238,000 people using ActiveSG gyms in May 2022, a 6% rise from 2019. New businesses, such as luxury fitness equipment retailers Cycling Bears and Technogym, are catering to the demand for high-end home gyms. Core Collective, a fitness and wellness centre, has opened its 4th location at Amara Sanctuary Resort Sentosa, marking a new partnership with the hotel. The Gym Pod, a homegrown startup, has expanded to 52 pods in Singapore and 3 in Chicago, while activewear brand Kydra has seen year-on-year revenue growth of over 40% since the pandemic. Meanwhile, wellness centre Soma Haus offers an unique combination of ice baths and infrared saunas, promoting a holistic approach to health and wellness.

site_title: How history will remember the Fauci era
summary: Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, is retiring after a career spanning decades. He has advised US presidents since Ronald Reagan on infectious disease outbreaks, including AIDS, SARS, and Covid-19. Fauci's era has been marked by a shift from optimism to pessimism, as the current administration has prioritized short-term political gains over scientific evidence and public health advice. Critics argue that Fauci's legacy is being defined by his inability to sway politicians during the Covid-19 pandemic, and that his retirement marks the end of an era in infectious disease control.

images.alt_text: “While I am moving on from my current positions, I am not retiring,” Fauci said.

site_title: PropertyGuru’s Q2 net income in the black for the first time since US listing
summary: PropertyGuru, a Singapore-based startup, has reported its Q2 net income for the first time since listing on the US market, turning a profit of S$3.8 million. Revenue increased 43.6% year-over-year to S$33 million, driven by growth across all markets and business segments. The company's Malaysia marketplace segment saw the highest revenue growth, while its adjusted Ebitda was S$3 million, reversing a loss from the same period last year. PropertyGuru maintains its full-year revenue growth outlook of approximately 44% and expects to return to full-year positive adjusted Ebitda.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close more than 3.6% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 3.63% on Thursday, driven by China's latest economic stimulus. The Hang Seng Index rose to 19,968.38, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.97%. However, the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.24%. The gains came despite typhoon-shortened trading sessions, as investors responded positively to China's stimulus.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singtel agrees to sell a 3.3% stake in Bharti Airtel for S$2.25 billion, expecting to net a gain of S$600 million. This sale is part of the company's efforts to divest its regional associate.

site_title: UK consumers, facing inflation leap, cut spending on cards again
summary: UK consumers reduced spending on credit and debit cards by 4 percentage points over the week to Aug 18, according to the Office for National Statistics. The largest declines were in "delayable" and "social" spending, down by 8 and 4 points respectively. This follows signs of households feeling the impact of high inflation. Britain's economy is forecast to enter a recession later this year due to surging energy bills.

site_title: PetroChina’s profits climb to record on global energy rally
summary: PetroChina reported a record 82.39 billion yuan (S$16.7 billion) in net income for the first half of the year, up 55% from 2021, driven by soaring global energy prices averaging US$105 a barrel. The company benefits from increased oil production and gas output to match China's cleaner fuel goals. Despite rising import costs and weaker demand, PetroChina plans to accelerate its transition to lower-carbon fuels, aiming to increase gas and renewable production by 2035 and shift half of its output to hydrogen by 2050.

site_title: UK housing crisis sparks investor bet on homeless accommodation
summary: Investors are betting on homeless accommodation in the UK amid the country's deepening housing crisis. Home Reit, a £700 million portfolio of homeless accommodation, has been expanding rapidly and was among the best-performing Reits in the UK. Keith Breslauer plans to raise £200 million to convert residential property into homes for battered or homeless women. Investors are drawn to inflation-linked, long-term leases and non-profit renters backed by the government, filling a societal gap created by declining public housing stock.

images.alt_text: The two candidates vying to succeed Boris Johnson as Conservative party leader and UK prime minister, Liz Truss and Rishi Sunak have differing approaches to the most pressing problem right now facing Britons- cost of living.

site_title: Vietnam Jan-Aug FDI inflows up 10.5% yoy
summary: Vietnam received US$12.8 billion in foreign direct investment (FDI) in the first 8 months of 2022, a 10.5% increase from the previous year. FDI pledges dropped 12.3% to US$16.8 billion, with 63.9% targeting manufacturing and processing, and 20% real estate. The top sources of FDI pledges were Singapore and South Korea.

images.alt_text: Workers labor on a VinFast Impes electric scooter on the assembly line of the automaker's factory in Haiphong, Vietnam, on Wednesday, Sept. 16, 2020. Vietnamese billionaire Pham Nhat Vuong, the founder and chairman of Vingroup JSC, wants to help his nation’s 96 million motorbike riders go green, replacing their noisy gas guzzlers with electric scooters. Subsidiary VinFast has a new $3.5 billion, 36.1 million-square-foot factory in Haiphong, where it’s building e-scooters, electric buses, and electric cars. Photographer: Linh Pham/Bloomberg

site_title: Honda to cut output by up to 40% at Japan plants on supply disruptions
summary: Honda plans to cut production by up to 40% at its Japan plants due to supply chain and logistical issues. The Saitama assembly plant will reduce production by 40% in early September, while the Suzuka plant's two lines will reduce production plans by 30%. This move aims to mitigate the impact of ongoing disruptions.

site_title: John Lim’s family office backs Savills IM strategy for £200m UK build-to-rent platform
summary: Savills Investment Management (Savills IM) has secured £200 million in funding for a UK build-to-rent platform through its partnership with The Land Managers (TLM), the real estate arm of John Lim's family office. The platform aims to develop and forward-fund single and multifamily residential assets in regeneration areas with favorable renter demographics. Savills IM's strategy seeks to deliver high-quality, future-proof housing stock in the underserved UK market, capitalizing on the growing demand for quality rental properties amid rising rental growth.

images.alt_text: Across London, the cost of leasing a place rose 23 per cent in the 12 months through July, Foxtons says in a report.

Savills appoints managing director of industrial and commercial leasing services

site_title: German business confidence falls as economy nears standstill
summary: German business confidence fell to 80.3 in August, down from 80.4 in July, as inflation and recession fears intensified. The economy showed resilience in the second quarter, growing 0.1% despite a decline in July and August. The outlook for the next six months is "clearly pessimistic" due to uncertainty among companies and a risk of contraction in the third and fourth quarters. Inflation may reach 10% by year-end, and the Bundesbank expects stagnation in third-quarter output.

images.alt_text: Analysts polled by Reuters had expected the economy to stagnate quarter on quarter in the 3 months to June, in line with the statistics office’s earlier flash estimate.

site_title: Designed and made in Singapore
summary: Singapore's manufacturing industry produces items like Energizer lithium batteries and Dyson motors, but often due to lower production costs, these products are made overseas. Local designers Timo Wong and Priscilla Lui of Studio Juju are exploring the possibility of having everyday products designed and made in Singapore, challenging the conventional notion that outsourcing production to foreign manufacturers is financially viable. They have worked with international brands and are now investigating the feasibility of producing homeware and furniture locally.

images.alt_text: The Paper Empress makes beautiful outfits for dolls.

site_title: Australian BNPL firm Zip annual loss widens as inflation chokes
summary: Australian BNPL firm Zip reported a wider annual loss of A$1.11 billion, compared to A$678.1 million last year, due to reduced customer spending and rising interest rates. The company's valuation has been squeezed, and its funding costs have increased. Zip's shares ended a session 2.1% lower, following a volatile day. The company recorded an impairment charge of A$821.1 million for the year, amid a challenging market environment.

site_title: Geely premium EV brand Zeekr is exploring IPO options, sources say
summary: Zeekr, a premium EV brand backed by Geely, is exploring initial public offering (IPO) options, including the US and Hong Kong. The company has asked investment banks for proposals and hasn't decided on the IPO size. Zeekr raised $500 million in its first external funding round, valuing it at about $9 billion, and plans to introduce 6 different models within 5 years, aiming for 650,000 units by 2025. The IPO timeline has not been set, and Zeekr could opt to raise another round of funding first.

site_title: Europe: Equities climb at open
summary: Europe's stock markets opened higher on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.6% to 7,516.33 points, and Frankfurt's DAX index adding 0.8% to 13,330.51 points. This follows Asian gains ahead of a speech by Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell, which may provide clues about future US rate hikes. The Paris CAC 40 also advanced 0.6% to 6,427.86 points.

site_title: Companies ‘most important’ in enabling employment of persons with disabilities: Lawrence Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of companies in enabling employment opportunities for persons with disabilities. He stated that companies play the most significant role in supporting employment, and that the government aims to achieve a 40% employment rate for people with disabilities by 2030. Wong noted that technology, flexible work arrangements, and existing government support can help increase employment rates, but companies must see the benefits of disability-inclusive hiring as a business opportunity.

images.alt_text: Making disability inclusion part of every firm's DNA

site_title: New exclusive art club targets the well-heeled
summary: A new art collectors' club in Singapore has been launched with the goal of promoting art collecting among new audiences. Founder Dr. Jie Li-Elbraechter hosted a masquerade party at a Mount Pleasant bungalow, inviting select art collectors to "unmask" their enthusiasm for art. The club aims to raise the level of hype around art collecting in Singapore, where collectors tend to be reticent about revealing their collections. The club's mission is to encourage more people to get into art collecting, with the ultimate goal of increasing engagement and community around the art scene.

images.alt_text: After a 2-year partial hiatus, Art Jakarta expects strong sales owing to pent-up demand and revival of economic activities.
The facade of National Museum Singapore features a projection mapping by Maxin10sity which looks at the history of the area.

site_title: China’s Baidu reveals its first quantum computer called Qianshi
summary: China's Baidu has revealed its first quantum computer, Qianshi, with a 10-quantum-bit (qubit) processor. The company has also developed a 36-qubit quantum chip and plans to make the technology available to external users. Baidu joins the global race in quantum computing, which is seen as a key technology for future computing power. Other major players, including IBM and Google, are also investing heavily in quantum computing, with IBM aiming for a 4,000-qubit processor by 2025 and Google aiming for 1,000,000 qubits by the end of the decade.

site_title: Australia: Stocks end higher on broad-based gains
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.7% to 7048.1 points, driven by broad-based gains across sectors, with miners and mining sub-index leading the way. The gains were partly due to the upcoming US Federal Reserve comments at the Jackson Hole symposium. Other sectors, including gold stocks, technology, and energy stocks, also saw significant increases, while Whitehaven Coal declined 1.3%. Airliner Qantas Airways and fund manager Pendal Group also posted notable gains.

images.alt_text: Market participants await US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell’s speech at the Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium on Friday.

site_title: German economy beats expectations with 0.1% growth in Q2
summary: Germany's economy grew 0.1% in Q2, beating analyst expectations, driven by household and government spending. Despite high inflation and an energy crisis, household expenditures rose 0.8% and government consumption grew 2.3%. However, analysts warn that the economy remains vulnerable, citing a contraction in the S&P Global PMI and forecasted decline in the Ifo business climate survey. The economy's growth is seen as a temporary reprieve, with concerns about a recession still present.

images.alt_text: “High inflation and a waning post-Covid boost to demand has led businesses and consumers to cut back on discretionary spending,” said Joe Hayes, an economist at S&P Global.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb on strong earnings, boost from miners
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.6% to 7041.8, driven by strong earnings from miners and retailers, despite a 4.6% drop in Woolworths. Gold stocks led gains, with Newcrest Mining up 2.7%, while energy and mining stocks also surged. Positive earnings reports from companies like IDP Education and Qantas lifted the market. The market awaits US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium for interest rate hike clues.

images.alt_text: Export-centric miners jumped 1.3 per cent after China’s iron ore prices rose on prospects of strong demand ahead of peak construction season.

site_title: Japan sees economy picking up modestly, flags looming risks
summary: Japan's economy rebounded at an annualized 2.2% in April-June from the Covid-19-induced doldrums, according to the government's monthly economic report. The government described the economy as "moderately picking up," while flagging risks of a global downturn due to overseas monetary tightening and rising inflation. Household wage growth is expected to slow, and the government is prepared to take steps to prevent infections as socioeconomic activity normalizes. The overall assessment remains unchanged from the previous month.

images.alt_text: Japan’s government has been considering a new expansion of nuclear power after struggling to contend with the impact of extreme weather and a global fuel shortage on electricity supply.
Before the pandemic, the country known for its vibrant cities and unique culture was in the midst of a tourism boom, with inbound visitors reaching a record in 2019.

site_title: Asia: Markets gain, investors anxious for US rate hike clues
summary: Asian markets gained, with the MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan rising 0.3% as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's annual Jackson Hole conference for clues on future interest rate hikes. The dollar was slightly weaker, while US stocks ended with mild gains. Investors expect the Fed Funds rate to peak at 3.80% in March 2023, and interest rate futures imply a 60% chance of a 75 basis point Fed hike in September.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, ending a 5-day losing streak. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.58% to 28,479.01, and the Topix index rose 0.48% to 1,976.60. The gains followed overnight US gains ahead of a meeting of global central bankers that may influence interest rate hikes.

site_title: China property developers to see marginal ease in liquidity pressure: UOBKH
summary: China's property developers are expected to see a marginal ease in liquidity pressure as supply policy shifts from hawkish to modestly supportive, according to UOBKH analysts. The central government's joint support for policy banks to grant special loans to projects with delivery issues indicates an inflexion point on supply-side policy. Despite weak sales momentum, analysts expect property sales in core cities to recover in the next 2-3 months, driven by continuous policy easing on the demand side.

images.alt_text: The State Council said the economy won’t be flooded with excessive stimulus and China won’t overdraw on its future policy room, reiterating officials’ relatively cautious stance on stimulus this year.

The PBOC said that in addition to supporting the real economy, banks should enhance credit support for small- and micro-enterprises, green development, scientific and technological innovation and other fields.

China’s policymakers have been trying to stabilise the property sector, after a string of defaults among developers on their bond repayments and a slump in home sales, which threaten further economic turbulence.

site_title: Hong Kong scraps morning trading because of storm warning
summary: Hong Kong's stock market was delayed due to tropical storm Ma-on, with the morning session scrapped and the afternoon session starting at 1.00 pm. The storm warning was lowered to No 3, and trading was affected by the delay, including the debut of China Tourism Group Duty Free. Schools, Covid-19 vaccination centers, and some public services were also suspended, with one person injured. The last time Hong Kong cancelled trading and closed schools due to a storm was in October 2022.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange delayed the start of trading Thursday because of Typhoon Ma-On.

site_title: BOJ policymaker vows to keep ultra-low rates, warns of economic risks
summary: Bank of Japan policymaker Toyoaki Nakamura has reiterated the need to maintain ultra-low interest rates to support Japan's economy, which is still recovering from the pandemic. A renewed spike in Covid-19 cases and slowing global demand pose economic risks, and Japan's output gap remains negative. Nakamura warns that shifting to monetary tightening would hurt the economy and restrict household and business activity, making targeted fiscal measures more suitable to address rising raw material costs. The BOJ has maintained low interest rates for nearly a decade to achieve its 2% inflation target.

images.alt_text: Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes fresh food prices, rose 2.4 per cent in July from a year earlier.
The overhaul comes at a time when Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's support rate is falling.

site_title: Klarna’s earnings to show how new credit firms cope under stress
summary: Klarna, a buy now, pay later (BNPL) giant, is facing budget pressures as it prepares to publish its half-year results. The company, which has 150 million customers, is experiencing rising credit losses and administrative expenses due to higher inflation and liquidity issues. Despite raising $800 million, Klarna's founder and investors express concerns about its ability to reach profitability. The company's business model is seen as vulnerable to defaults, particularly as interest rates rise and unemployment increases. Klarna's chairman believes the firm is at its strongest since its early days, but others question the sustainability of the BNPL model.

site_title: Taiwan proposes 12.9% on-year rise in defence spending for 2023
summary: Taiwan has proposed a 12.9% year-on-year increase in its defence budget for 2023 to T$415.1 billion, marking the island's sixth consecutive year of growth since 2017. The proposal comes amid heightened tensions with China, which has increased military activities near the island. The budget includes an additional T$108.3 billion for fighter jets and equipment, aimed at modernizing Taiwan's armed forces, which are dwarfed by China's military. The proposal must be approved by parliament.

images.alt_text: Taiwan is determined to defend itself and invaders will incur a “heavy price”, President Tsai Ing-wen said on Tuesday(Aug  23) on the anniversary of a confrontation six decade ago in which Taiwanese forces beat back Chinese attackers.
Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen meeting Indiana Governor Eric Holcomb at the presidential office in Taipei on Monday (Aug 22).

site_title: Business in 67 Shanghai-traded ETFs halted by Hong Kong typhoon delay
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange halted business in 67 Shanghai-traded ETFs due to a trading suspension in Hong Kong caused by Tropical Storm Ma-on. The suspension, requested by asset managers, affects ETFs that invest in Hong Kong-traded shares. Trading in the affected ETFs, including ChinaAME Hang Seng Technology ETF, will resume in the afternoon as the typhoon signal 8 is lowered. This incident highlights the increasing integration of the Shanghai and Hong Kong markets.

site_title: Revolut appoints Raymond Ng as Singapore CEO
summary: Revolut appoints Raymond Ng as its new Singapore CEO to accelerate business growth in the country. Ng joins from Liquid Group, a payment network company, with over 20 years of experience in mobile, payment, and travel tech sectors. His appointment follows Revolut's recent launch of crypto products in Singapore and in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to provide digital payment token services. Ng will lead expansion plans and develop the fintech company's local business strategy.

site_title: UK energy crisis risks squeezing households more than 2008 crash
summary: The UK is facing a severe energy crisis that could push over half of households into energy poverty this winter, with soaring bills expected to surge 80% from October. Average annual energy bills are forecast to exceed £3,500, or 11% of a household's median disposable income. The crisis could have a bigger impact on households than the 2008 financial crisis, with the government facing pressure to provide more help, including a possible 2-year price cap freeze estimated to cost £100 billion.

images.alt_text: Investors are attracted by inflation-linked, long-term leases and non-profit renters that are backstopped by the government.

site_title: Gold inches higher as dollar softens ahead of Powell speech
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,753.01 per ounce ahead of US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole symposium, where investors expect an aggressive tightening message. The dollar slipped, making gold less expensive for foreign buyers. Higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, while boosting the dollar. Spot silver eased 0.2% and platinum dropped 0.1%, while palladium rose 0.5%. Investors anticipate Powell to double down on inflation-fighting measures, potentially boosting the dollar and gold prices.

images.alt_text: The dollar rose 0.2 per cent against its rivals, making gold more expensive for buyers holding other currencies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Thursday, Aug 25, 2022, as mainland Chinese stocks opened higher due to Beijing's economic boost measures. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index both rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 8.26 points, or 0.26%, to 3,223.46. Trading was delayed at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange due to Typhoon Ma-On.

site_title: Some Chinese financiers cold-shoulder Beijing's property rescue call: sources
summary: China's state-backed financial institutions are resisting Beijing's calls to support the struggling property sector due to concerns about potential losses. Senior executives are wary of engaging with cash-strapped developers without explicit financial backstop from Beijing. This reluctance stems from the increasing accountability of employees for poor lending and investment decisions, with signing off on financial support seen as a high-risk move.

site_title: Honda says China plant remains shut as power cuts are extended
summary: Honda's plant in Chongqing, China remains closed due to extended power cuts ordered by local governments to curb power use and shut factory operations amid severe heat and drought. The power cuts, which have disrupted operations of global companies including Tesla and Apple, are expected to last until the situation develops and a decision is made. The Chongqing region, which relies heavily on hydropower, faces a severe shortage, with temperatures routinely topping 40 deg C and the Yangtze River at its lowest level since 1865.

TESLA reported 273 vehicle crashes involving advanced driving assistance systems like Autopilot since July, while Honda Motor identified 90, data from US auto safety regulators released on Wednesday (Jun 15) showed.

site_title: New Zealand’s weak retail sales raise technical recession risk
summary: New Zealand's retail sales volumes declined 2.3% in the second quarter, adjusting for inflation, and 0.9% in the first quarter, raising the possibility of a technical recession in the first half of 2022. This follows a 0.2% decline in the first quarter, and economists say no one predicts a slump. Despite this, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand still forecasts 1.8% growth and is expected to raise interest rates further. Economists believe capacity pressures will keep inflation in check, despite weaker-than-expected economic activity.

images.alt_text: New Zealand’s high grocery prices reflect the fact that 2 companies - Foodstuffs New Zealand and the local unit of Australia’s Woolworths - form a dominant duopoly.

site_title: Once South-east Asia's most valuable startup, Grab falls US$13b behind GoTo
summary: Grab, once Southeast Asia's most valuable startup, has fallen behind GoTo Group, its Indonesian rival, in the public markets. GoTo's market value of $26 billion is twice that of Grab, despite both companies being unprofitable. The growth potential of Indonesia has helped GoTo outperform Grab, with GoTo's home-grown brand and synergy with Tokopedia giving it an advantage in the food-delivery market. Grab is set to report second-quarter results, while GoTo will release results on August 30.

site_title: New age of consumers demand hybrid customer experience
summary: Asian consumers increasingly prefer hybrid customer experiences, combining digital and human support. While self-service options are convenient, many consumers still rely on live agent support, particularly in phone and online chat interactions. Businesses should design hybrid experiences that balance digital channels with human agent engagement, as human touch remains pivotal in customer satisfaction. Companies must consider this when creating their next customer experience map, ensuring accessibility to human support while optimizing digital channels.

images.alt_text: Luxury salespeople need to develop new skills, to become more agile, less focused on the brand, and more focused on customers.

site_title: People facing acute food insecurity reach 345 million worldwide: WFP
summary: The World Food Programme (WFP) reports that 345 million people worldwide face acute food insecurity, more than doubling since 2019 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, conflict, and climate change. Regional Director Corinne Fleischer notes that environmental challenges drive food scarcity, conflict, and mass migration. The Middle East and North Africa are particularly vulnerable, with Yemen relying on Black Sea imports. The WFP supports 13 million of the 16 million in need, but their assistance only covers half a person's daily needs due to funding constraints.

images.alt_text: The cost of grains, cereals and oils has returned to levels last seen before the war began.

site_title: Singapore needs appropriate laws, enforcement mechanisms to handle debacles like Noble bust
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority, Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority, and Commercial Affairs Department have imposed a S$12.6 million civil penalty on Noble Group for publishing misleading information in its financial statements from 2016 to 2018. However, the penalties seem inadequate considering the billions of dollars in market value lost by investors. The lack of appropriate laws and enforcement mechanisms to deal with modern financial market chicanery is a major concern, with some arguing that a single law enforcement agency is needed to actively hunt for wrongdoing and bring perpetrators to book.

images.alt_text: Noble and its subsidiary were discovered to have applied an incorrect accounting treatment to long-term marketing agreements by classifying them as financial instruments instead of service contracts.

The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has imposed a civil penalty of S$12.6 million on Noble Group for publishing misleading information in its financial statements for the fiscal years ended December 2012 to 2016.

site_title: Bank of Korea balances inflation battle against growth risks
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) raised its 7-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 2.5%, its first hike since February, to balance inflation and growth risks. The central bank also increased its inflation forecast for the current year to 5.2%, its highest projection since 1998, while nudging down its growth forecasts for this year and next year. The decision aims to curb inflation, which has been stronger than expected, while minimizing the impact on economic growth.

images.alt_text: The verbal warning helped the currency rebound from losses before it again slid to trade near an earlier low of 1,345.20 per dollar.
Inflation in South Korea accelerated to an almost 24-year high in July of 6.3 per cent.

site_title: Google to roll out anti-disinformation campaign in some EU countries
summary: Google's Jigsaw subsidiary will launch an anti-disinformation campaign in Poland, Slovakia, and the Czech Republic targeting narratives about Ukrainian refugees. The campaign, in partnership with local non-government organizations, aims to build resilience against misinformation. The research-backed campaign will run for a month and use 90-second clips to "inoculate" people against emotional manipulation and scapegoating on social media. The campaign is a pilot experiment that could be scaled to other countries, with the goal of reducing the spread of misleading information in the US and Europe.

The Alphabet unit, whose revenues mainly come from online advertising, should ask Gmail users for their prior consent before sending them any direct marketing emails, noyb.eu said.

site_title: Thousands throng to Iran museum with Western art masterpieces
summary: Thousands of people have visited the Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art to view 132 works by 34 world-famous contemporary artists, including multi-million-dollar pieces. The exhibition, which features minimalist and conceptual art, has attracted over 20,000 visitors, with many seeing Western art masterpieces for the first time. The museum's collection, amassed before the 1979 Islamic Revolution, is considered the greatest outside Europe and the US, offering a glimpse into the country's pre-revolutionary art scene.

images.alt_text: The Museum of the Bible returned a gospel that is more than a thousand years old to the Greek Orthodox Church after determining it had been looted.

site_title: Boeing says plans to build on existing investments in India
summary: Boeing plans to expand its investments in India's aerospace and defense industry, anticipating a $3.6 billion economic impact over the next 10 years. The company is offering its F/A-18 Super Hornet fighter jet for sale to the Indian navy, which could boost investments in the country's defense industry. This move comes as India seeks to diversify its defense imports, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government aiming to manufacture $439.6 million worth of defense equipment domestically. Boeing's plans follow India's status as one of the world's largest arms importers, spending $12.4 billion between 2018 and 2021.
