site_title: Qatar wealth fund to invest US$3b in Pakistan
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund plans to invest $3 billion in Pakistan's economy, primarily in key sectors such as airports, renewable energy, power, and hospitality. This investment aims to ease Pakistan's funding crunch and risk of default, following a meeting between Qatar's Emir and Pakistan's Prime Minister. The move comes as Pakistan seeks support ahead of an IMF board meeting that could release $1.2 billion in financing. Qatar's investment is part of a broader package of support, including $1 billion in oil financing from Saudi Arabia and similar investments from the UAE.

images.alt_text: Staff work on March 28, 2022 at the Aspire security command centre for the Fifa World Cup Qatar 2022, near Khalifa International stadium in Doha, where operation and security teams will be able to monitor all the stadiums during the World Cup.

site_title: China’s unemployment insurance payouts hit record high in June
summary: China's unemployment insurance payouts reached a record high of 37.2 billion yuan in June, a 256.6% increase from the previous year. The fund's deficit widened to 22.74 billion yuan, as the country's labor market continues to struggle due to the impact of Covid-19 outbreaks and a property crisis. The youth unemployment rate reached a record high of 19.9% in July, despite a slight easing of the urban jobless rate to 5.4%.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on August 19, 2022 shows a man visiting a job fair in Fuyang in China's eastern Anhui province. (Photo by CNS / AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Biden to cancel student loans for millions of US borrowers
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to announce a plan to forgive $10,000 in student loans for millions of US borrowers, a move expected to boost support for Democrats in midterm elections. The debt cancellation is estimated to free up hundreds of billions of dollars for new consumer spending, potentially increasing inflation. The decision comes after Democrats pushed for up to $50,000 in debt forgiveness, arguing it hinders younger Americans' ability to save for big purchases. The move is expected to disproportionately help borrowers earning higher incomes.

site_title: Opec nations line up behind Saudi call to act if necessary
summary: OPEC nations, including Saudi Arabia, have expressed support for reducing oil production to stabilize global markets. Following Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz Salman's comments that action may be needed, fellow members Iraq, Algeria, Kuwait, Equatorial Guinea, and Venezuela released statements backing the move. The move aims to address the "disconnect" between international futures contracts and supply-demand fundamentals, resulting in "extreme" volatility in oil prices. OPEC and its partners are prepared to reduce output to bring market equilibrium.

images.alt_text: Oil has soared in 2022, coming close in March to an all-time high of US$147 after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine exacerbated supply concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong may consider tighter curbs as Covid cases rise
summary: Hong Kong reported 7,884 new Covid-19 cases on August 24, the highest number since March, putting pressure on the city's healthcare system. To address this, health officials are considering tighter social distancing restrictions. The city's Chief Executive, John Lee, has pledged to restore Hong Kong's global standing, but easing travel restrictions has been a tentative step. If healthcare capacity continues to be overwhelmed, the government may be forced to tighten social distancing rules, impacting residents.

site_title: Crypto firm Coinhako is hiring to woo institutions, wealthy
summary: Coinhako, a Singapore-based cryptocurrency exchange, is hiring amid the downturn to grow in South-east Asia and expand into institutions and wealthy investors. The firm, launched in 2014, is aggressively hiring in institutional sales and trading to boost business with bigger firms and high-net-worth investors. Coinhako sees the current market downturn as an opportunity for forward-looking institutions to invest in digital assets, with the goal of supporting the next step-up in digital assets adoption.

site_title: Euro slips towards 2-decade low as high gas prices adds to growth fears
summary: The euro slipped towards a 2-decade low as high gas prices and recession fears fueled by a possible energy supply crunch continue to weigh on the currency. The euro briefly reached US$1 on Tuesday but fell back to US$0.99175, barely above its 20-year low of US$0.99005. The US dollar recouped losses after softer-than-forecast data, while European growth concerns stem from its greater exposure to Russian gas supplies. The Federal Reserve's upcoming symposium may also impact currency markets, with traders pricing in a 50 basis point rate increase at the next meeting.

site_title: Weary but unbowed, Ukraine marks Independence Day amid fears of new attacks
summary: Ukraine marks its 31st Independence Day amidst fears of new Russian attacks. Despite the somber mood, citizens celebrated with a display of Russian military vehicles, while the government warned of a powerful response if Moscow launches fresh attacks. The public holiday was marked by a more subdued atmosphere due to the ban on public events, with residents expressing a mix of grief and optimism over the ongoing war. Fears of winter shortages and the looming winter season also loomed large, with many anticipating the worst since 1991.

images.alt_text: Ukraine's national flag in central Kharkiv. The United States on Tuesday(Aug 23) urged its citizens to leave Ukraine, saying it believed Russia was preparing to target civilian and government infrastructure in the next few days as the war reaches the six-month mark.

site_title: BT Explains: What it means to base a loan on Poseidon Principles
summary: Singapore's OCBC is the only Singapore bank listed as a signatory to the Poseidon Principles, a set of guidelines aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions from shipping activities. The principles, approved by the International Maritime Organization in 2019, require lenders to assess and report on their shipping portfolios' climate alignment. Signatory banks, including DBS, MUFG, and Natixis, must track carbon intensity and report annually, with scores made public in December. This framework does not impose restrictions on borrowers, but rather influences lenders' decisions on financing and refinancing.

images.alt_text: The facility is guaranteed by Olam Group with Olam Agri subsidiaries, Olam Global Agri and Olam Global Agri Treasury, as co-borrowers.

site_title: China tightens green bond rules to align them with global norms
summary: China has tightened its green bond rules, requiring 100% of proceeds from green bond issuances to be invested in green projects such as clean energy, aligning with global norms. The move aims to eliminate "greenwashing" and make China a leader in global green bond regulation. The changes are part of China's efforts to develop green finance and achieve its twin goals of peak emission by 2030 and carbon neutrality by 2060. The updated rules, which were published last month, follow China's publication of its own Green Bond Principles, largely based on international standards.

site_title: Metals sector woes caused by power crunch set to deepen
summary: The industrial metals sector is facing deepening uncertainty due to power crunches caused by high energy prices. Smelters in Europe, including Norsk Hydro's Slovakia smelter and Nyrstar's Dutch plant, have announced closures or suspensions, leading to supply chain disruptions. The crisis is exacerbated by a heatwave curtailing energy supplies, and a looming winter is expected to worsen conditions. While demand is slowing in China and Europe, prices are expected to remain high due to limited capacity and tight supply conditions. The global energy crisis is also affecting oil prices, with Brent at triple digits of US$100 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Zinc surged after one of Europe’s largest smelters announced it would halt production next month as the continent’s energy crisis threatens to hobble heavy industries.
In the US, at least 2 steel mills have started suspending some operations to cut energy costs.

The prospect of a global recession and doubts over economic stimulus in China, the world’s biggest user of raw materials, add to the challenges of mining companies as they grapple with energy costs, raising the risk of downsizing and layoffs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Masks will remain mandatory on public buses and trains, but will be optional indoors from Aug 29, except in healthcare settings. The Monetary Authority of Singapore fined Noble Group Limited S$12.6m for publishing misleading financial statements. Regulators should prioritize inclusive sustainable finance, according to a panelist. 57 Singapore manufacturing companies will receive IP training from the World Intellectual Property Organisation. The Singapore market closed 0.4% lower on Aug 24 amid mixed regional trade.

site_title: When privacy is all but gone
summary: The US has become a world where privacy no longer exists, with most people being surveilled, tracked, and monitored for profit. Despite the lack of robust privacy legislation, tech companies are taking steps to protect user data, but there are too many entities tracking individuals. The erosion of privacy has been accelerated by the Supreme Court's decision in Dobbs, which eliminated the federal right to abortion and allowed for the collection of sensitive information. As a result, Americans are being forced to confront the reality of a world where their phone location data, internet searches, and purchase history are all fair game for law enforcement.

images.alt_text: It resolved claims that Facebook violated California law and its own privacy policy by gathering data from users who turned off Location Services on their mobile devices.
The Alphabet unit, whose revenues mainly come from online advertising, should ask Gmail users for their prior consent before sending them any direct marketing emails, noyb.eu said.

site_title: Fitness businesses boom
summary: Singapore's wellness industry is experiencing a post-pandemic boom, with fitness businesses and entrepreneurs seeing a surge in demand for luxury home-gym equipment and expanded gym outlets. This trend is driven by the pursuit of work-life balance, with homeowners investing in high-end fitness facilities. The industry's growth is also reflected in the rise of art clubs, revamped dining experiences, and zero-waste initiatives, showcasing the evolving lifestyle of Singaporeans. As a result, entrepreneurs are capitalizing on the trend, driving growth and innovation in the wellness sector.

site_title: A growing appetite for Melvados’ frozen gourmet meals
summary: Melvados, a Singaporean food manufacturer, is expanding its operations with plans to open its 9th and 10th stores in November, aiming for 15 stores in two years. The company, co-founded by Manmeet Singh and Raymond Foo, offers "clean label" frozen gourmet meals and snacks without artificial additives or preservatives. Following the COVID-19 pandemic, Melvados' consumer brand saw a surge in online sales, and the company is now focusing on strengthening its brand presence in Singapore before expanding to other markets.

images.alt_text: SaladStop! aims to have all its stores in Singapore turn net zero by 2025, and all international locations by 2030, said chief executive officer Adrien Desbaillets. The company is working with partners like Unravel Carbon to achieve this target.

site_title: Singtel Q1 profit up 41.3% to S$628m on better performance, ‘exceptional gains’ from Airtel
summary: Singtel's Q1 profit rose 41.3% to S$628 million, driven by better operational performance and "exceptional gains" from India's Bharti Airtel. Despite a 2% fall in Ebitda and 5.6% decline in operating revenue, the company expects to stay nimble amid rising inflation and interest rates, which may impact costs and bottom lines.

images.alt_text: Force yourself to look beyond the superlatives spilled Wednesday about the new iPhones and their turbocharged software brains.

site_title: Malaysia's Najib has few 'get out of jail' cards left to play
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has begun a 12-year jail sentence after losing his final appeal in a case linked to a multi-billion dollar corruption scandal. Najib, who served as prime minister from 2009 to 2018, has few options to obtain an early release, including a review of the decision by the Federal Court. He faces more cases related to graft, including four other cases that carry jail terms and heavy financial penalties, and could also apply for a pardon, which would require approval from the king and the prime minister.

images.alt_text: Elder statesman Mahathir Mohamad said ex-premier Najib Razak was likely to ask for a pardon if he were convicted on the criminal charges for corruption, money laundering and criminal breach of trust. “There is that 50-50 chance that he will succeed in getting a pardon and return to politics. He will come back, and he wants to become the prime minister once again,” said Mahathir.

site_title: Honda considering decoupling supply chain from China: Sankei
summary: Honda is considering building a separate supply chain to reduce dependence on China, following the impact of Covid-19 lockdowns and tensions between the US and China. The move would see 40% of Honda's automobile production remain in China, while a new 1 is established for markets outside China. This comes after Mazda Motor also announced plans to diversify production outside China, citing lockdowns that forced a 11-day shutdown in April and May. The decision is seen as a response to the challenges faced by Japanese companies in China, with the government offering incentives for companies to bring production back to Japan.

site_title: Six months into Ukraine war, will European unity hold?
summary: The European wall of support for Ukraine in the war against Russia is beginning to show cracks six months into the conflict. While the EU has imposed seven economic sanctions packages, significant differences exist between Western European states and those on the East, with some nations, like Hungary, being more outspoken in their criticism. A European Council on Foreign Relations poll revealed a split between a 'Peace' camp (35%) and a 'Justice' camp (22%) on longer-term goals, with the Peace camp being larger in most countries. The resilience of European democracies will depend on sustaining public support for policies in Ukraine, which will be challenging as the gap between government statements and public mood grows.

site_title: Mobile World plans sale of US$1.5b Vietnamese grocery business
summary: Mobile World Investment Corp, a Vietnamese conglomerate, plans to sell its Bach Hoa Xanh grocery chain for over $1.5 billion, making it the country's second-largest deal. The sale, expected to complete by 2023, is part of the company's efforts to cut costs and boost profitability. Bach Hoa Xanh, founded in 2015, is the country's second-largest modern grocery retailer by revenue, with over 1,700 stores. The sale is likely to attract interest from local and international retailers, as well as financial investors, amid Vietnam's post-pandemic economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Customers at a cafe along the Saigon River in District 2 in Ho Chi Minh City. Vietnam's tourism sector is poised for strong growth over the next 5 years, with international tourism receipts expected to surpass pre-pandemic levels in 2024.

site_title: TDCX Q2 net profit up 19.6% to US$19.3 million
summary: TDCX, a digital customer solutions provider, reported a 19.6% increase in its Q2 net profit to US$19.3 million, driven by a 23.3% year-over-year rise in revenue to US$116.6 million. Clients from high-growth industries accounted for 93% of its revenue, and the company saw 25 new client sign-ups since the start of the year. Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) also rose 35.5% to US$36.1 million. The company's full-year revenue outlook remains unchanged, with expected growth between 17.1% and 21.6%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.20% to 19,268.74, due to investor uncertainty over the next US interest rate hikes. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Index slipping 1.86% and the Shenzhen Index dropping 3.01%. The declines were attributed to market concerns over US-EU trade tensions and the impact on global markets.

site_title: Sri Lanka widens import ban as economic crisis persists
summary: Sri Lanka has widened its import ban to over 300 additional items, including home appliances, tools, and sports gear, amid a dire economic crisis that has led to months of shortages and a 8.0% projected economic contraction. The island nation, suffering from a lack of foreign currency, has also defaulted on some of its US$51 billion external debt pile. An IMF delegation is set to continue talks on a bailout, but IMF assistance could be delayed if creditors, including China, refuse to restructure loans.

images.alt_text: People line up to visit the presidential secretariat in Colombo on July 11, 2022, after it was overrun by anti-government protestors.

site_title: German 10-year yields hit fresh 8-week high on inflation concerns
summary: Germany's 10-year government bond yield rose to a fresh 8-week high at 1.362%, driven by inflation concerns and expectations of an aggressive monetary tightening path by the European Central Bank. Analysts predict the ECB will raise rates to tame inflation, despite a possible recession. Energy prices, particularly Dutch wholesale gas, are seen as key drivers of inflation expectations, with prices rising 3.8% on Wednesday. The ECB minutes and German Ifo business data are expected to provide further insight into monetary policy.

site_title: Privacy complaint targets Google over unsolicited ad emails
summary: Austrian advocacy group noyb.eu has filed a complaint with France's data protection watchdog, alleging that Google breached a European Union court ruling by sending unsolicited advertising emails to Gmail users without prior consent. The emails, which include the word "Ad" in green letters, do not include a date and appear similar to normal emails. This action is seen as a breach of the 2021 EU court decision requiring consent before sending direct marketing emails.

site_title: Princess Diana's one-of-a-kind Ford Escort goes up for auction
summary: A 1985 Ford Escort RS Turbo S1 car, formerly driven by Princess Diana, is set to be auctioned off at Silverstone Auctions on August 27, 2022. The car, one of only 130 made in black, was painted black at the request of Diana's royal family police guard for discretion. With just under 25,000 miles, it's expected to fetch over £100,000. The auction marks 25 years since Diana's death in a Paris tunnel crash.

images.alt_text: Demand from collectors in Singapore and South-east Asia has grown "exponentially," Auction house Sotheby's said.

site_title: How Chinese private equity firms got scammed by their own sales teams
summary: Dozens of small and midsize private fund management firms in China have been scammed by con artists hired to sell fund products, with losses totaling up to 1 million yuan (S$203,000). The scammers, mostly men aged 28-35, fake work experiences and promise high sales figures to secure jobs, but fail to deliver. Many firms don't perform background checks, and some even pay their own social insurance fees, making it easier for scammers to work for multiple firms simultaneously. The affected firms have compiled a blacklist of "scammer employees" to alert fellow firms, but face risks of privacy violations.

images.alt_text: Victims have reported being lured to countries such as Myanmar, Cambodia, Thailand and Laos on false promises of romance or high-paying jobs, and then held against their will and forced to work.

site_title: Thai PM suspended from duty; deputy PM is caretaker leader
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha was suspended from duty on Wednesday, August 24, after the Constitutional Court decided to hear a petition seeking review of his 8-year term limit. Deputy Prime Minister Prawit Wongsuwan will act as caretaker leader until a final ruling is made. The suspension comes amid a petition by the main opposition party arguing that Prayut's time as head of a military junta should count towards his term, which could potentially extend his stay in power until 2027.

images.alt_text: The opposition had needed more than 239 of the 477 parliamentary votes to oust the prime minister.

site_title: Masks optional in most indoor settings from Aug 29; businesses have no plans for separate rules
summary: Singapore's masks will become optional in most indoor settings starting Aug 29, with businesses not planning to implement separate rules. The multi-ministry taskforce announced the change, ending quarantine requirements for non-fully vaccinated arrivals. Masks will still be required in public transport, healthcare settings, and some events. Venue operators can encourage mask-wearing, but are not obligated to do so. The decision aims to align with government guidelines and allow patrons to make their own choices.

images.alt_text: MTF added that the current requirement for non-fully vaccinated long-term pass holders and short-term visitors aged 13 and above to apply for entry approval to enter Singapore will also be lifted from Aug 28.
The Health Sciences Authority has authorised the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine for children, including those as young as 6 months old.
A total of 3,406 new local Covid-19 cases were reported on Aug 23, with 359 hospitalised.

site_title: Seoul: Shares snap 5-session losing streak on robust foreign inflows
summary: Korean shares rose 0.5% on Wednesday, snapping a 5-session losing streak, driven by foreign buying and a strengthening Korean won. The benchmark Kospi index closed at 2,447.45. Despite caution ahead of inflation data and US Federal Reserve cues, tech giant Samsung Electronics fell 0.17%, while peer SK Hynix lost 0.43%. However, battery maker LG Energy Solution rose 1.35%. The dollar's easing and rising bond yields also contributed to the market's recovery.

images.alt_text: Semiconductors are South Korea’s No 1 export item.

site_title: Europe: Markets dip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined in initial trade on Wednesday, August 24, 2022, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's interest rate plans. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.4% to 7,458.65 points, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also declined 0.2%. Investors are watching for a key speech by Fed chief Jerome Powell on Friday, expecting further interest rate hikes to combat inflation.

site_title: Singapore sees more US-listed Chinese companies coming to its shores
summary: Singapore's stock exchange, SGX, expects more US-listed Chinese companies to list in the city-state amid regulatory risks in the US. Following Nio's technical listing in May, other companies may follow suit, with SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye citing supportive market conditions as a factor. The exchange has signed an accord with the New York Stock Exchange to facilitate dual listings, and has attracted at least 11 China-domiciled firms with listings in both the US and Singapore.

images.alt_text: Koh begins his duties as chairman on Jan 1, 2023.

site_title: Fed won’t influence Thailand’s rate path, governor says
summary: Thailand's central bank Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput stated that the Bank of Thailand will maintain its "gradual and measured" policy tightening path despite peers increasing interest rates to combat inflation. The Fed's rate hikes and actions of emerging Asian peers do not concern the BOT, which is on track for a sustainable recovery with tourism expected to exceed 8 million visitors this year and GDP growth of around 3-4%. The governor is closely monitoring core inflation and demand-side pressures, but rates are unlikely to increase aggressively unless a wage price spiral is observed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput speaks during his first briefing on the economy and monetary policy after taking office in Bangkok, Thailand October 20, 2020. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo

site_title: STI down 0.4% amid mixed regional trade
summary: The Singapore market's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.4% to 3,233.48, with losers outnumbering gainers 260 to 225. Major indices in Hong Kong and Japan fell 1.2% and 0.4% respectively, while South Korea and Australia rose 0.5%. Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust, OCBC, and UOB traded lower, while DBS rose 0.2%. The quiet economic calendar contributed to the lack of catalysts, with some investors waiting and seeing.

site_title: IMF team hold talks with Sri Lanka on debt restructuring
summary: Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe held talks with IMF officials to finalize a bailout package, including debt restructuring of about US$29 billion. The talks come amid the nation's worst financial crisis in over seven decades, with inflation, economic contraction, and shortages of essential items. The main sticking point is finding a sustainable track for Sri Lanka's unwieldy debt, which stands at 114% of GDP. The IMF team will meet again on Friday to discuss technical issues with the Central Bank.

images.alt_text: A protester sits in a camp site, after police asked them to leave from a seafront tent camp that became the focal point of months-long nationwide demonstrations, amid Sri Lanka's economic crisis.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap 2 days of losses aided by resources stocks
summary: Australian shares snapped a 2-day losing streak, rising 0.5% to 6,998.1 points, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks. Export-centric miners jumped 1.3% after China's iron ore prices rose, while sector giants BHP Group and Fortescue Metals Group added 1.1% and 0.4%, respectively. Energy stocks led the rally, rising 2.8%, with Santos and Woodside Energy Group gaining 2.1% and 3.4%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index had risen 0.6 per cent to 7,001.7 by 0101 GMT on Wednesday, after shedding 2.2 per cent in the previous two sessions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on interest rate worries
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on August 24, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.49% at 28,313.47, due to renewed worries over US rate hike plans ahead of a central bankers' meeting in Jackson Hole. The broader Topix index fell 0.22%.

site_title: China probes property executives for possible law violations
summary: China is investigating at least 4 top executives from state-owned real estate companies, including chairman Zhuang Yuekai, for "serious" law violations. The probes signal a widening of the government's crackdown on misconduct in the financial and technology sectors, which has already led to the dismissal of over 40 officials at state banks and regulators. The investigations may impact investor confidence and internal governance of state-owned enterprises, but the impact on companies may be limited due to multiple decision-makers.

images.alt_text: Shanghai-based Shimao first missed a public offshore bond obligation last month.

China’s policymakers have been trying to stabilise the property sector, after a string of defaults among developers on their bond repayments and a slump in home sales, which threaten further economic turbulence.

site_title: Tesla, Nio suspend EV charging services as China power cuts bite
summary: Tesla and Nio have suspended some electric vehicle charging services in China due to power cuts caused by a severe drought and heatwave. User apps show charging stations are down in Chengdu and Chongqing, with some stations being temporarily closed or restricted. Nio is asking users to share home chargers and trading fully-charged batteries for almost-dead ones to help fellow owners. The power crisis has also affected other manufacturers, including Toyota Motor and Contemporary Amperex Technology, which have shut factories. The situation is expected to continue until the power authorities request a shutdown of some facilities.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s Full Self-Driving (FSD) system has been controversial  because it requires active supervision and doesn’t make the company’s vehicles autonomous. It last raised the cost of the system from US$10,000 to US$12,000 in January. From Sep 5, it will cost US$15,000.

Nio will speed up construction of battery swapping stations in Europe with a view to expanding sales of its cars in countries including Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark in the second half of this year.

site_title: Buy-now-pay-later tech pioneers squeezed as big banks muscle in
summary: Big banks are entering the buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) market, posing pressure on tech pioneers that have made the service popular worldwide. Banks such as NatWest, HSBC, and Barclays are launching new ways to spread purchase costs, while traditional credit providers like Visa and Mastercard are also getting in on the action. This growing competition adds to pressure on BNPL providers, which are facing rising borrowing costs and investor skepticism. Valuations for companies like Klarna and Affirm have dropped, and banks are considering acquisitions to grow in this space.

images.alt_text: Despite their stark valuation declines, BNPL companies such as Klarna, Afterpay and Affirm have shaken up the e-commerce sector with customer-friendly apps and popularity with 18-24 year olds, forcing many traditional banks such as Natwest Group to launch competing offers.

site_title: 57 manufacturing companies to receive IP training, tools from UN agency under MOU
summary: The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) to provide intellectual property (IP) training and tools to 57 SMF member companies. Under the agreement, WIPO will offer IP Diagnostics Toolkit and IP for Business guides to help companies understand IP from a business perspective. The partnership aims to support the growth of small and medium enterprises in the manufacturing sector by leveraging innovation and IP as a catalyst for jobs, investments, and economic development.

site_title: Noble Timeline: How Iceberg sank the commodity titanic
summary: Noble Group, an industrial and energy company, was fined S$12.6 million by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for publishing misleading information in its financial statements from 2012 to 2016. The company faced intense scrutiny after Iceberg Research released a report accusing Noble of exploiting accounting treatments to avoid impairments and fabricate profits. This led to a series of events, including restructuring, a trading halt, and a debt restructuring deal. The company's financial valuation was significantly reduced, and it was eventually suspended from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Noble fined S$12.6m for misleading financial statements
summary: Noble Group Limited has been fined S$12.6 million by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for publishing misleading financial statements from 2012 to 2016. The group incorrectly classified long-term marketing agreements as financial instruments, inflating profits and net assets. MAS also issued stern warnings to two former directors and ordered auditors of Noble Resources International to re-examine their work. The authority emphasized that material false or misleading statements have no place in Singapore's capital markets, and the company is currently winding up in Bermuda.

site_title: Indonesia reviewing fuel price policy options over next 2 days
summary: Indonesia's Cabinet will present policy options for fuel prices to President Joko Widodo within the next two days amid rising expectations of a price hike to rein in a ballooning energy subsidy budget. The country has tripled its subsidy budget to 502 trillion rupiah to keep prices unchanged. A price hike is seen as a way to manage inflation and the central bank's monetary tightening, with some analysts expecting a 30% increase in gasoline prices. The decision will impact financial markets and the pace of Bank Indonesia's interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: An attendant pumps petrol at a roadside gas station in Jakarta on May 29, 2022. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)

site_title: The GOP’s now the GTP : Grand Trump Party
summary: US politics have shifted towards a "Grand Trump Party" as Donald Trump's influence has dominated the Republican Party. Maryland's gubernatorial election saw a Trump-endorsed candidate win the primary despite being far-right, while Democratic candidates are expected to perform well in the general election. Similar scenarios are unfolding in Pennsylvania, Arizona, Nevada, and Ohio, where Trumpist candidates are struggling against centrist Democratic opponents. The Republican Party's transformation has raised concerns about Trump's national appeal and his potential for a 2024 presidential run, with many experts predicting a clear majority of Republican voters will support him.

images.alt_text: donald, trump, president

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB raises target on Hong Leong Asia in anticipation of construction recovery
summary: CGS-CIMB raised its target price on Hong Leong Asia to S$1.05, up 42.9% from its current price, due to a recovery in Singapore's construction industry expected to offset weaknesses in its diesel engine segment. The brokerage expects the group's building materials segment to generate a 93% year-on-year profit increase in the second half of 2022, driven by a construction recovery. The analysts believe this will offset slower growth in the diesel engine segment, which is affected by China's economic slowdown and Covid-19 restrictions.

images.alt_text: Stephen Ho, chief executive officer of Hong Leong Asia.
Stephen Ho, Hong Leong Asia chief executive, said that the company is well-placed to take bid for contracts that require a proportion of precast products to be manufactured locally.
Worksite safety issues and dengue outbreaks have impacted the productivity of construction companies.

site_title: White House cuts FY 2022 budget deficit forecast as revenues rise
summary: The White House revised its fiscal 2022 deficit forecast to $1.032 trillion, a $383 billion reduction from its March estimate, due to stronger-than-expected revenues and new spending. The revised forecast includes legislation passed since March, including a semiconductor and research subsidy act and a tax and healthcare package. Revenues increased $504 billion, mainly due to higher individual and corporate taxes, while outlays rose $121 billion. The White House also adjusted its economic projections, cutting real GDP growth to 1.4% and inflation to 6.6%.

site_title: Sustainable finance regulators should stop chasing trophy deals: ADB specialist
summary: Asian Development Bank (ADB) specialist Mohd Sani Mohd Ismail urged regulators to prioritize marginalized groups in sustainable finance, moving beyond "first" and "biggest" prizes. He emphasized the need for holistic thinking, including municipal and provincial-level financing, and highlighted the importance of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the net-zero transition. While cost remains a major hurdle, experts suggested that governments can play a larger role, and sustainable finance options may become more accessible as costs decrease.

images.alt_text: Tan Boon Gin, chief executive of the Singapore Exchange Regulation  said that greenwashing is the “biggest threat” when it comes to the market having accurate climate information to drive decision making

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB cuts Supermax target price over bleak earnings outlook
summary: Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange-listed Supermax Corp's target price has been lowered by CGS-CIMB to RM0.50 from RM0.94 due to bleak earnings outlook. The research house believes the "worst is yet to come" after the latex glove conglomerate's latest earnings missed expectations. Weaker earnings are expected due to the current oversupply situation in the global glove industry, with a 25.3% cut in FY2023-2024 earnings per share forecast.

site_title: World at rising risk of recession as inflation hits consumers
summary: The global economy is at risk of recession due to high inflation, which has reached multi-decade highs in many parts of the world. Consumer spending is being curtailed, and business activity is contracting in various regions, including the US, euro zone, and UK. Supply chains remain damaged from the pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and central banks are tightening monetary policy aggressively, with interest rates expected to rise further. Economists predict a 45% chance of a US recession within a year and 50% within two years.

images.alt_text: Germany is rushing to reorient itself after the outbreak of war in February.
A water level indicator along the Han River in Wuhan on Aug 22.
With pandemic curbs lifted, the tourism sector, a key driver of Thai growth, is expected to see 8 million to 10 million foreign tourist arrivals this year.

site_title: Japan returns to nuclear power to stabilise energy supply
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced plans to restart idled nuclear plants and develop next-generation reactors to stabilize energy supply, citing the Ukraine crisis and soaring energy costs. This shift in policy comes a decade after the Fukushima disaster and follows a change in public opinion, with fuel prices rising and calls for energy-saving. The government aims to meet environmental goals through a "green transformation" and will extend the lifespan of existing reactors. Concrete measures are to be implemented by year's end, including promoting public understanding of sustainable energy and nuclear power.

images.alt_text: Multiple gauges showed new records and signalled broader inflation according to data released by the Bank of Japan on Tuesday (Aug 23).

site_title: Museum of the Bible returns ancient gospel looted from Greek monastery
summary: The Museum of the Bible returned a 1,000-year-old handwritten gospel to the Greek Orthodox Church, following an investigation that determined it was looted from a Greek monastery during World War I. The manuscript, which had been used in liturgical services for hundreds of years, was transferred to an Eastern Orthodox Church official in New York before being repatriated to the Kosinitza Monastery in northern Greece. This return is part of the museum's efforts to regain credibility by giving back tainted objects in its collection, following a settlement of $3 million in 2017 for looted antiquities.

images.alt_text: The Benin Bronzes are among Africa's most culturally significant artefacts.
Britain's National Railway Museum has acquired some of the photographs and is seeking to put names to the faces and tell their stories.

site_title: Ping An co-CEO defends HSBC spin-off call, says firm is not an activist investor
summary: Ping An Insurance Group's co-CEO, Jessica Tan, defended the firm's call for HSBC to spin off its Asia business, stating that it's not an activist investor but rather cares about long-term returns. Ping An, HSBC's largest shareholder with an 8.3% stake, urged the bank to explore options to increase shareholder returns, citing the lender's significant investment and 7-year holding period. Tan's comments come amid HSBC's recent pushback against the spin-off call, which could have implications for the bank's credit rating, tax bill, and operating costs.

images.alt_text: Ping An Insurance Group Co of China, China’s largest insurer by market value, reported a 3.9 per cent rise in first half net profit, the first increase over this period in three years, a filing with the Hong Kong stock exchange showed on Tuesday.
HSBC’s largest shareholder Ping An Insurance will press on with its call for the bank to spin off its Asia operations despite pushback from executives.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 2.11 points to 1,484.68. The market saw 164 gainers for every 117 losers, with a total volume of 190.88 million lots worth RM78.84 million.

site_title: China warns against monopolies, hoarding in photovoltaic industry
summary: China's industry ministry has issued a notice to promote the development of the photovoltaic industry, warning against market monopolies and hoarding. The ministry cited supply and demand mismatches, severe price fluctuations, and hoarding in the supply chain as reasons for the need to deepen industry management. It also cautioned against hoarding and reselling materials, and encouraged enterprises to develop reserves to promote peak shaving and industrial supply chain stability. The ministry vowed to "severely crack down" on illegal activities such as price bidding, monopoly practices, and the production and sale of fake products.

images.alt_text: An electricity pylon is seen above a solar power plant which is under construction on a hill in Wuhu, Anhui province, September 16, 2014. REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo

site_title: Coffee drinkers set for price pain as Vietnamese reserves shrink
summary: Vietnam's vast reserves of coffee beans are dwindling, expected to halve by the end of September and further decrease in 2022-23 due to poor harvests. This comes as global coffee consumption recovers from a virus-induced slump, with benchmark robusta prices surging 17% due to supply concerns from Brazil and Africa. The shrinking stockpiles and low planting area for "profitable" fruit trees pose a risk to Vietnam's coffee production, potentially leading to higher global prices.

images.alt_text: Vietnam’s exports in the January-July period rose 16.6 per cent from a year earlier to US$217.34 billion, while imports were up 14.0 per cent at US$216.26 billion.
An employee prepares a customer's take-away order at a Luckin Coffee outlet in Beijing.

site_title: War hit to German economy will last years: economist
summary: Germany's economy is expected to face significant damage from Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with influential economist Marcel Fratzscher predicting a 3 percentage point loss in growth this year. The war's impact will last until 2025, when Germany is expected to have freed itself from Russian gas exposure. High energy prices will also sustain inflationary pressures for a similar period, but Fratzscher rejects suggestions of wage restraint, citing weaker union strength compared to the 1970s.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on April 29, 2020 shows a customer pushing a shopping cart past the shelves during  purchases at a supermarket in Duesseldorf, western Germany, on April 29, 2020. - A surge in eurozone consumer prices, propelled even higher by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, is "very close" to reaching its peak, European Central Bank vice-president Luis de Guindos said on April 28, 2022. site_title: Asia: Markets drop as investors eye US Federal Reserve outlook
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday amid global stock declines and a weakened euro, which plummeted to a 20-year low against the dollar. The eurozone's economic activity fell for the second consecutive month, and investors await US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's speech, which may lead to further interest rate hikes. US natural gas prices hit a 14-year high, while European natural gas prices remain elevated due to Russia's energy crisis.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Shanghai dropped as investors brushed off a loan rate cut by the People’s Bank of China.

site_title: Masks no longer needed indoors from Aug 29 except for public transport, healthcare settings
summary: Singapore to lift mask mandate indoors from August 29, except for public transport and healthcare settings. Masks will still be required on public buses and trains, as well as in healthcare facilities. Private transport, school buses, and taxis will be optional. The move is seen as a significant milestone in living with COVID-19, but Singapore remains mentally prepared for potential changes due to the virus's mutation.

images.alt_text: Commuters with face masks taking the down-riding escalator at Raffles Place MRT station on May 25, 2022.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore to make mask-wearing optional indoors, except on public transport and in healthcare settings, nearly 5 months after lifting outdoor mask mandates. Auric Pacific CEO granted option to buy S$55.5 million bungalow. Straits Trading declares special dividend after strong H1 2022 results. Food prices in Singapore rose before Malaysia's poultry export ban, which has driven inflation.

site_title: Cost of living crisis dominates UK leadership campaign
summary: The cost of living crisis has dominated the UK leadership campaign, with Liz Truss and Rishi Sunak proposing differing approaches to address the issue. Truss favors tax cuts and reversing National Insurance contributions, while Sunak proposes direct help for low-income families and a cut in sales tax on energy bills. The UK's inflation rate is at 10.1%, with predictions that it could surge to 13% in October and potentially reach 18% next year. The two candidates also differ on Brexit and financial regulation, with Truss proposing to override parts of the Northern Ireland Protocol and Sunak favoring direct ports to boost growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Candidates Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss take part in the BBC Conservative party leadership debate at Victoria Hall in Hanley, Stoke-on-Trent, Britain, July 25, 2022. Jacob King/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
British energy firms this week urged the government to do more to help consumers with energy bills at a time when they’re also seeing food and fuel prices jump.

A customer shops for food items inside a Tesco supermarket store in east London. The UK economy is rapidly slipping into an inflationary recession, and analysts and economists fear that the situation is likely to worsen during the upcoming winter.

With inflation now set to peak substantially higher than the Bank of England’s 13 per cent forecast in August, its Monetary Policy Committee was likely to conclude that the risks of more persistent inflation have intensified, the note said.

site_title: Sony unveils high-end PS5 controller with parts you can mix & match
summary: Sony has unveiled the DualSense Edge wireless controller for the PlayStation 5, featuring modular components that players can customize and replace. The controller builds on the original DualSense's advances in vibration feedback and responsive analog triggers. Similar to Microsoft's Xbox Elite controller, it will serve as a premium gaming accessory for the PS5, although pricing and release date have not been specified. This move expands Sony's gaming accessories range and may indicate its intention to grow its presence in the PC gaming market.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars struggle to sustain rally as Federal Reserve stays hawkish
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are struggling to sustain their rally as the Federal Reserve remains hawkish, offsetting soft economic news. The Aussie fell to US$0.6911, while the kiwi eased back to US$0.6191. The rally was boosted by weak US services and home sales data, but the US currency recouped losses after Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari expressed concerns about understating inflation pressures. The Fed is expected to hike rates by 75 basis points to 3.0-3.25% in September, while the Reserve Bank of Australia is seen lifting its cash rate by 50 basis points.

images.alt_text: The stronger greenback pushed the US dollar index as high as 106.96, its highest since late July.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on energy and mining boost
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.6% to 7,001.7, rebounding from two consecutive sessions of falls, driven by gains in energy and mining stocks. Energy stocks surged 2.3% after oil prices jumped 4% on possible OPEC+ output cuts. Mining stocks also advanced, with Rio Tinto, BHP Group, and Fortescue Metals rising between 0.4% and 2.2%. Despite the gains, concerns over inflation and global growth weighed on risk appetite.

images.alt_text: Financials were the top laggards on the benchmark, falling for the fourth straight session after shedding 2.1 per cent. All of the so-called “Big Four” banks trading in negative territory.

site_title: Gold holds steady as investors focus on Jackson Hole symposium
summary: Gold prices held steady at $1,746.60 per ounce, as investors focused on the upcoming speech from Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell. The US dollar rose 0.2% against its rivals, making gold more expensive for buyers holding other currencies. This uptick in the dollar checked gold's gains, despite a 0.7% increase in the previous session.

images.alt_text: The dollar eased 0.1 per cent against its rivals after hitting a more than 1-month high overnight, making gold less expensive for buyers holding other currencies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.2% at the open, driven by gains in the Hang Seng Index, which reached 19,542.24. This follows Wall Street's mostly lower close due to concerns over rising interest rates. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.9%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.52%. The gains were seen as a sign that investors are shrugging off pessimism, despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: New Zealand seeks greater supermarket competition to cut prices
summary: New Zealand's government is implementing measures to increase supermarket competition and drive down grocery prices. The Commerce and Consumer Affairs Minister, David Clark, announced that the two dominant supermarkets, Foodstuffs New Zealand and Woolworths, will be required to sell products to their competitors at fair wholesale prices. Failure to comply will result in products being sold at prices determined by a regulator. The goal is to give smaller retailers and new market entrants a leg up in the market, leading to lower prices and increased competition.

images.alt_text: Outside a New World supermarket, operated by Foodstuffs New Zealand in Wellington, New Zealand. Photographer: Birgit Krippner/Bloomberg

site_title: TikTok stars boycott Amazon in activism push
summary: TikTok influencers, with over 51 million followers, have boycotted Amazon until the e-commerce giant delivers concessions to workers, including a minimum hourly wage of $30, improved medical leave, and easing of productivity requirements. The "People Over Prime Pledge" is part of a campaign by Gen-Z for Change, an advocacy group that coordinated the pledge from over 70 popular TikTok talents. Amazon has resisted unionization efforts and has invested billions in safety measures, but the group's director of strategy, Elise Joshi, dismissed Amazon's response as "boilerplate."

images.alt_text: While TikTok has banned paid political ads since 2019, campaign strategists have skirted the ban by paying influencers to promote political issues.
Amazon will acquire iRobot for US$61 per share, valuing the company at a premium of 22 per cent from the stock’s last closing price.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday as Wall Street fall continues; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.2% to 3,241.29, following falls in major global markets. The decline was led by local banks, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC trading lower. The US stock market also fell, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 closing 0.5% and 0.2% lower, respectively. European shares slipped, extending their losing streak for a third session.

site_title: Stock to watch: Olam Group
summary: Olam Group's shares ended Tuesday at S$1.48, down 0.7% or S$0.01. The company secured a US$2.9 billion facility from 16 lenders, based on the Poseidon Principles, a framework for climate-conscious lending. This development may impact trading of Olam's securities on Wednesday.

site_title: Celsius crypto lender, now bankrupt, sues ex-money manager over alleged theft
summary: Celsius Network, a bankrupt crypto lender, sued former investment manager Jason Stone and his company KeyFi over alleged theft of tens of millions of dollars in assets. Celsius claims Stone was "incapable" of deploying coins profitably, causing significant losses, and misappropriated assets to buy NFTs. Stone's lawyer denies Celsius's allegations, calling it an attempt to rewrite history and use KeyFi as a scapegoat. Both parties seek to recoup sums owed, plus compensatory and punitive damages.

images.alt_text: Celsius hopes the bitcoin mining effort will help it repair its relationship with customers, some of whom sent threats and hate mail to some company employees in the weeks before the Chapter 11 filing.

site_title: Singapore family office scene set to soar in sophistication
summary: The Singapore family office scene is poised to become more sophisticated, driven by increasing global uncertainty, geopolitical risks, and the country's attractive tax incentives. The number of family offices in Singapore has jumped fivefold since 2017, and almost doubled from 400 to 700 by 2021. Expectations include the professionalization of family offices, tapping into private capital markets, and adopting sustainable investing and philanthropy. Family offices are likely to refocus on traditional industries, explore merger and acquisition activity, and increase their allocation to direct investments and ESG (environmental, social, and governance) or impact investing.

images.alt_text: While grant-making often remains the basic tenet of a family’s philanthropic efforts, the younger generations are also exploring other social impact tools now at their disposal, such as venture philanthropy, social impact bonds and impact investing..
A private wealth boom in Asia has made family offices an important source of funds for venture capital firms and startups.

The comments give a rare insight into the strategies of the investment firms for the world’s ultra-rich, which are often able to scale up their bets at a faster pace than institutional money managers.

site_title: Nancy Pelosi’s husband pleads guilty to drunken driving in California
summary: Paul Pelosi, husband of US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, pleaded guilty to causing injury by drunken driving in California and was sentenced to five days in jail, with four days' credit for time served, and ordered to pay $6,800 in fines and restitution. He will also perform eight hours of community service instead of serving the remaining day. The charges stem from a May car crash in Napa County, where Pelosi's Porsche collided with a Jeep, resulting in no serious injuries. Pelosi will serve three years of probation and be prohibited from operating a vehicle for a year unless equipped with a DUI ignition device.

images.alt_text: US Senator Ed Markey (left) being escorted by Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DDP) legislator Lo Chih-cheng (right) upon his arrival at the Parliament in Taipei on Monday (Aug 15).

site_title: Meta reaches US$37.5m settlement of Facebook location tracking lawsuit
summary: Meta reaches a US$37.5 million settlement with a class action lawsuit alleging the company violated users' privacy by tracking their movements through smartphones without permission, despite location services being turned off. The lawsuit claims Facebook gathered data from users' IP addresses and used it for targeted advertising. The settlement covers US users who used Facebook after Jan 30, 2015, and requires a judge's approval. Meta denied wrongdoing in agreeing to settle.

Meta is working with 10 outside fact checking partners, including 5 Spanish-language organisations, to review posts and label them if they’re misleading.

site_title: China’s jobless turn to car boot sales as Covid-hit economy stalls
summary: China's jobless are turning to car boot sales as the country's economy stalls, particularly in hospitality, tourism, and after-school tutoring. With the pandemic's relentless impact, many have lost their jobs or closed businesses, forcing them to seek alternative ways to make a living. Car boot fairs have emerged in cities like Beijing, where entrepreneurs like Wang, Pan, and Liu are selling everything from coffee to liquor from the back of their vans, earning around 1,000 yuan a day. Policymakers have encouraged "flexible" employment in the informal economy, allowing these makeshift market-places to thrive.

images.alt_text: A water level indicator along the Han River in Wuhan on Aug 22.
The MSCI China Index has slumped about 12 per cent so far this quarter compared to an 8 per cent gain in a global gauge of shares.
The one-year loan prime rate (LPR) was lowered by 5 basis points to 3.65 per cent at the central bank’s monthly fixing, while the five-year LPR was slashed by 15 basis points to 4.30 per cent.

site_title: Volkswagen and Mercedes sign electric vehicle battery accords with Canada
summary: Canada has signed memorandums of understanding with Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, allowing the European automakers to tap into the country's burgeoning electric vehicle supply chains. The agreements focus on securing critical battery inputs, including lithium, nickel, and cobalt, to meet growing demand for electric vehicles. The deals aim to challenge Tesla's dominance in the market and support Germany's efforts to secure new energy supplies.

images.alt_text: The memorandum of understanding will be signed during German Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s current trip to Canada and is designed to shorten supply chains for VW’s facilities in the US and avoid difficulties linked to tariffs and tax regulations.

site_title: China’s fragile economy is being hammered by driest riverbeds since 1865
summary: China's Yangtze River is experiencing its driest levels since 1865, exacerbating a severe drought that has crippled the country's economy. The extreme heat has caused water levels to plummet, affecting hydroelectric power generation and sparking energy chaos across the country. Key cities, including Shanghai, have turned off lights and air conditioning, while factories, including those of Tesla and Toyota, have been forced to close. The drought has also hit the food supply, with rice planting areas shrinking in India and the Rhine River in Europe affected. The situation poses a risk to China's sputtering economy.

images.alt_text: Banks on Monday lowered the LPRs after the PBOC cut the MLF rate last week.

An unfinished apartment building in Shanghai earlier this year. In the country's troubled housing market, home sales continue to plunge, property investment is contracting, cash-strapped developers are struggling to complete projects and homebuyers are boycotting mortgage payments.

site_title: Nissan to cease producing cylinder heads for Renault from 2024
summary: Nissan will stop producing cylinder heads for Renault petrol vehicles at its Sunderland plant in northern England starting early 2024. The move is part of Renault's multi-year cost-savings plan, following the departure of former CEO Carlos Ghosn. Nissan does not expect job losses, but the decision may raise questions about the future of the Renault-Nissan alliance. Renault has found another supplier to take over the cylinder head production, citing the economics of the supplier market.

images.alt_text: Operating profit was 64.9 billion yen (S$663.1 million) in the 3 months ended Jun 30, Nissan said in a statement on Thursday (Jul 28).

site_title: Olam Agri takes out US$2.9b Poseidon Principles facility to refinance loans
summary: Olam Agri has secured a $2.9 billion 3-year facility to refinance existing loans and for general corporate purposes, backed by Olam Group and its subsidiaries. The loan is based on the Poseidon Principles framework, promoting international shipping's decarbonization. The facility was arranged by 16 lenders, including DBS, MUFG Bank, and Natixis, with HSBC serving as the facility agent. The move aligns with Olam Agri's purpose of transforming food and fibre for a more sustainable future, strengthening its resolve to improve carbon management in its freight business.

images.alt_text: Olam said it expects to deliver a better year-on-year performance for the full year as revised sales pricing and margin recovery gathers pace in H2.
The SGX sign on 6 April 2021.
The acquisition of Club Coffee will expand OFI’s private label capabilities in North America.
Olam to sell 35.4% stake in Olam Agri to Saudi investment fund for US$1.2b

site_title: Biggest fear is inflation will be more persistent: Federal Reserve’s Kashkari
summary: Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari expects the Fed to lift its policy rate by another two full percentage points by the end of next year, aiming for a 4.25% rate, due to concerns that underlying inflation pressures are being underestimated. Kashkari is the most hawkish of Fed policymakers and will only consider easing up on rate hikes if inflation falls towards the Fed's 2% target. This move aims to combat persistent inflation, a concern that has been a major focus for the Fed.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index increasing 0.03% or 9.72 points to 28,462.47, driven by cautious trade following modest falls on Wall Street. The Topix index also edged up 0.04% or 0.70 points to 1,972.14. The market is closely watching a central bankers' meeting in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, for its potential impact on global economic trends.

site_title: Oil jumps nearly 4% on possible Opec+ supply tightening
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 4% on Tuesday after Saudi Arabia floated the idea of Opec+ output cuts to support prices in case of returning Iranian crude and a drop in US inventories. Global benchmark Brent crude settled at $100.22 a barrel, its highest price since August 2. Opec+ production cuts may not be imminent, but would coincide with Iran's return to oil markets if Tehran clinches a nuclear deal with the West. US crude stockpiles are expected to have fallen, while fuel stocks rose, underlining tight supply.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for October settled at US$96.48 per barrel, down 24 cents, or 0.25 per cent.
Natural gas prices fluctuated amid further signs that soaring energy costs are crippling economic output, heaping pressure on politicians to resolve the crisis with winter approaching.

site_title: HSA authorises Moderna’s Spikevax Covid-19 vaccine for children 6 months to 5 years old
summary: The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) has authorized Moderna's Spikevax Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 6 months to 5 years old via the Pandemic Special Access Route. The decision is expected to be followed by a recommendation from the Health Ministry (MOH) soon. Children aged 5-11 are also recommended to receive a Pfizer-BioNTech or Comirnaty vaccine booster at 5 months after their primary vaccination series. Additionally, people aged 60 years and above are recommended to receive a second mRNA Covid-19 booster vaccine at 5 months after their first booster shot.

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence rebounds but stays near record low
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence rose to -24.9 in August, a slight improvement from -27 in July, but still near record lows due to rising inflation and energy shortages. The European economy is bracing for a recession, with activity declining for a second month. The European Central Bank is set to continue interest-rate increases despite these challenges, with officials expected to discuss their next steps at the Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole gathering.

site_title: Australia’s slumping property market raises risk of a recession
summary: Australia's rapidly rising interest rates threaten a property downturn, raising recession risk. Home prices have dropped almost 5% in Sydney in the past 3 months, with the national market weakening. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is under pressure to balance controlling inflation with avoiding a recession. Experts predict a 9-15% drop in house prices, which could hit economic growth sharply, and warn of a vicious cycle of households cutting spending and property prices falling. The RBA is expected to hike rates again, with some economists forecasting a 25% chance of recession over the next year.

images.alt_text: Austraslian Treasurer Jim Chalmers said that his department would undertake “token mapping”, or cataloguing the types and uses of digital currency owned within the country.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly lower as markets await Federal Reserve outlook
summary: US stocks closed mostly lower on Tuesday, awaiting Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech and interest rate plans. The S&P 500 slipped 0.2% to 4,128.73, while the Nasdaq Composite Index was flat. Powell's speech is expected to reiterate the Fed's message on ending rate hikes to quell inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5% to 32,909.59, amid a sharp decline in new home sales and concerns over inflation.

images.alt_text: Wall Street’s main indexes opened slightly lower on Tuesday(Aug 23) after a steep selloff in the previous session on concerns about aggressive signals from the US Federal Reserve on rate hikes, with manufacturing and services data on tap.

site_title: China’s JD.com beats quarterly revenue estimates
summary: China's JD.com beats quarterly revenue estimates, with sales in its product segment rising 2.9% and services segment jumping 21.9% in the second quarter. The company reported 267.6 billion yuan (S$54.5 billion) in revenue, beating analysts' average estimate of 262.31 billion yuan. Net income attributable to ordinary shareholders rose to 4.38 billion yuan, or 1.37 yuan per American Depository Share. The company attributed its profit beat to lockdowns in China controlling the coronavirus, boosting online shopping and its "618" shopping event.

images.alt_text: Alibaba’s strong report helped drive a rally in its tech peers, with JD.com, Pinduoduo and Baidu all gaining at least 2 per cent in premarket trading.
This year’s shopping festival growth was the slowest for JD.com, showing how consumer appetite in China has been hit by lockdowns.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip to near 1-month low on gas price surge, recession fears
summary: European shares slipped 0.4% to a near 1-month low due to rising energy prices and recession fears. The Stoxx 600 index dropped to its lowest in almost a month, extending a losing streak for a third session. Business activity in the region contracted for the second consecutive month, with Germany seeing a deeper downturn due to high inflation and economic uncertainty. The contraction was attributed to consumers cutting spending and supply constraints hurting manufacturers.

site_title: Wu Yongqiang resigns as executive chairman of Nutryfarm International

site_title: Stock market’s summer fling wasn’t the real thing
summary: The stock market's summer rally appears to have been an illusion, as the S&P 500 Index posted its largest weekly decline since July 1. Despite expectations of a relatively quiet summer, the rally was fueled by factors such as a potential change in Fed messaging and strong earnings, but underlying fundamentals have changed little. The monetary policy outlook is uncertain, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell expected to push back against the idea of interest rate cuts. The earnings outlook is also unclear, with widespread resilience in earnings season potentially masking underlying economic concerns.

images.alt_text: Amid worries over the Fed’s ongoing interest rate hikes, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped more than 640 points, or 1.9 per cent, to finish at 33,063.61.

site_title: European gas prices swing as winter supply fears stalk market
summary: European natural gas prices fluctuated amid concerns over winter supply, with benchmark futures retreating after earlier rising as much as 5.2%. The price surge has crippled economic output, stoking inflation and fueling recession fears. Russia's Gazprom will halt flows on the Nord Stream pipeline to Germany for three days of maintenance, potentially exacerbating the crisis. Gas prices could rise to 400 euros per megawatt-hour if flows stop in September, according to a gas analyst. The euro is trading near a two-year low against the dollar, with Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz facing pressure to quell soaring inflation.

images.alt_text: German economy minister Robert Habeck says the country has a critical winter ahead of it, and that it must expect Russian president Vladimir Putin to further reduce the supply of gas. The Nord Stream pipeline carrying Russian gas to Europe has been operating at only 20 per cent capacity for weeks.

site_title: China developer Shimao looks to repay US$11.8b debt over 3-8 years: sources
summary: China-based developer Shimao Group has proposed a 2-class restructuring plan to offshore creditors to repay US$11.8 billion over 3-8 years. The plan excludes US$2.3 billion offshore debt and will include a 36-72 month amortisation schedule for Class A debt and 6 tranches of new notes with maturities ranging 39-93 months for Class B debt. Offshore creditors plan to request equal treatment and an increase in repayment ratio, with some seeking a "sweetener" to enhance the credit profile of the debt.

images.alt_text: UOB alleged that Shimao and the group entities breached terms of certain loan and security agreements, according to a writ in the High Court of Hong Kong dated Jul 12.

site_title: Does clean energy deserve a place in investors’ portfolios?
summary: The clean-energy sector, despite facing supply-chain issues and volatility, still offers an attractive multi-year growth story due to the urgent need for energy security and the economic cost of relying on traditional energy sources. The sector's growth potential is driven by the increasing demand for clean energy, the under-investment in traditional energy, and the cost-competitiveness of green energy sources. However, investors must be cautious of the risks associated with sourcing critical metals and the uneven global distribution of these resources. Despite these challenges, the clean-energy sector remains a compelling consideration for investors with a risk tolerance for a multi-decade growth megatrend.

site_title: Eurozone business activity contracted for second straight month in Aug: flash PMI
summary: The eurozone's business activity contracted for a second consecutive month in August, according to the S&P Global flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI). The manufacturing sector fell to 49.7, its lowest since June 2020, while the services sector PMI slipped to 50.2, just above breakeven. Demand also declined for a second month, with the new business index at 47.7. The data suggests an economy in contraction during the third quarter, with the cost of living crisis forcing consumers to cut spending and supply constraints hurting manufacturers.

site_title: Harnessing wind power for shipping looks promising
summary: Berge Bulk, a major bulk carrier operator, plans to equip its 210,000 deadweight vessel Berge Olympus with four WindWings, a sail-assist technology that aims to reduce CO2 emissions by up to 30%. The system, developed by Yara Marine Technologies, will be installed in the second quarter of 2023. This project is part of a growing trend of companies exploring wind-assisted propulsion technology to reduce emissions in the shipping industry. Other initiatives, such as the SailLink ferry service, are also underway, and several classification societies have issued approval-in-principle for various sail-assist technologies.

site_title: Bosch-backed self-driving startup WeRide weighing IPO, sources say
summary: Chinese self-driving startup WeRide is considering an initial public offering (IPO) that could raise around $500 million, according to sources. The company, backed by the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance and Guangzhou Automobile Group, received a strategic investment from Bosch in May. WeRide is weighing venues for the listing, including the US and Hong Kong, amid challenges from Chinese regulators. The company has been valued at $4.4 billion after its latest funding round in March and may file for a first-time share sale as early as September.

site_title: Russian lender Sberbank agrees to sale of Kazakh subsidiary
summary: Sberbank, Russia's largest lender, has agreed to sell its Kazakh subsidiary to Kazakh state-owned financial holding Baiterek. The decision comes amid the current geopolitical situation and US-imposed sanctions on Sberbank, which has over 110 million customers. Sberbank cited the withdrawal as a way to act in the interests of the subsidiary's clients. Financial details of the sale were not disclosed.

images.alt_text: The decree, signed by President Vladimir Putin and published on Friday (Aug 5), immediately bans investors from countries which supported sanctions on Russia from selling certain assets.

site_title: DBS exchange says Bitcoin trading surged amid global sell-off
summary: DBS exchange reported a surge in Bitcoin trading, with buys accounting for 90% of trades, amid a global sell-off in cryptocurrencies. The number of trades more than doubled in June compared to two months earlier, with Bitcoin purchases being 4 times higher than in April. This trend reflects investors seeking safe havens for digital assets amidst market volatility.

site_title: Indonesia central bank hikes benchmark rates for first time since 2018
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.75% for the first time since 2018, aiming to combat rising inflation. The move is part of the bank's efforts to pre-empt inflationary pressures and strengthen the rupiah's stability. The rate hike is seen as a step to anchor inflationary expectations, with economists predicting further rate increases if energy subsidies are cut. The decision comes as Indonesia's inflation rate hits a 7-year high of 4.94% and the government considers raising subsidized fuel prices.

site_title: Najib goes to jail after top court upholds  sentence in 1MDB scandal
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak was sentenced to 12 years in jail for corruption in the 1MDB scandal. The Federal Court upheld the conviction and sentence after a five-judge panel rejected Najib's appeal. The verdict came four years after his party's shock election defeat in 2018, which highlighted allegations of embezzlement. Najib was found guilty of abuse of power, money laundering, and criminal breach of trust, with prosecutors claiming $4.5 billion was stolen from 1MDB. The ruling is seen as a significant blow to Najib's supporters and could lead to a period of political transition.

images.alt_text: Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak on Tuesday asked the chief justice to recuse herself from a panel presiding over his final appeal.

site_title: Taiwan warns China of 'heavy price' for invasion on battle anniversary
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen warned China of a "heavy price" for invading the island on the anniversary of a 1958 confrontation where Taiwanese forces beat back Chinese attackers. Tensions have risen since US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taipei, prompting China to stage war games near Taiwan. Tsai emphasized Taiwan's determination to defend itself and its ability to do so, stating that invaders will incur a "heavy price" and be strongly condemned by the international community.
