site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn to invest US$300m more in northern Vietnam
summary: Foxconn, an Apple supplier, has signed a US$300 million agreement with Kinh Bac City to expand its facility in northern Vietnam's Bac Giang province. The new 125-acre factory will generate 30,000 local jobs, following a move to diversify and boost production. This investment comes after Foxconn started test production of the Apple Watch in northern Vietnam and has previously invested US$1.5 billion in the country. The factory's production capacity and type of products have not been disclosed.

site_title: When titans collide: Rock-bottom Red Devils face depleted Liverpool
summary: Manchester United, currently bottom of the English Premier League (EPL) standings, faces a depleted Liverpool team in their highly anticipated match at Old Trafford. The Red Devils, still reeling from a 4-0 loss to Brentford, will look to improve their performance against their bitter rivals. Liverpool, meanwhile, is missing several key players due to injuries and suspensions, but remains the bookies' favorite to claim maximum points. The match promises to be a spectacle, with the form book likely to be disregarded in favor of a high-scoring encounter.

images.alt_text: A perceived lack of investment in Manchester United’s infrastructure, including its Carrington training ground and famous Old Trafford stadium, and frustration over poor recruitment strategy have compounded the ill will towards the Glazers.
The Premier League will be chaired by a woman for the first time when Alison Brittain takes over the role next year, the league said on Tuesday (Jul 26).
Amid a crowded content market, remains to be seen if fans will spring for StarHub's latest EPL offering.

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway cleared to buy up to 50% of Occidental Petroleum
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has received authorization from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to acquire up to 50% of Occidental Petroleum, one of the US's largest oil and natural gas producers. The commission approved the partial acquisition, stating it would not have an adverse effect on utility rates or hurt competition. Berkshire already holds over 20% of Occidental's shares, which have risen over 100% this year. The deal deepens ties between Berkshire and Occidental, which has been investing in carbon capture technology and aims to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: West Texas Intermediate has climbed 1.1 per cent to over US$89 a barrel, while Brent has jumped by 1.4 per cent to almost US$95.
Brent crude futures settled at US$96.72 a barrel, gaining 13 cents. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude ended 27 cents higher at US$90.77. Both benchmarks fell about 1.5 per cent on the week.

site_title: Monkeypox patients can recover at home from Aug 22: MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that patients with monkeypox can recover at home starting August 22, provided they are clinically stable and have a suitable residence. Those at higher risk of complications will continue to be managed in hospitals. Patients recovering at home will receive regular telemedical consultations and may be conveyed to the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) for additional reviews. Isolation orders will still be issued, and patients must remain isolated until medically assessed to be non-infectious.

site_title: Cineworld shares slump on report Regal-owner is preparing bankruptcy filing
summary: Cineworld, the world's second-largest cinema chain operator, is preparing to file for bankruptcy, according to the Wall Street Journal. The company's shares slumped 81% after warning that a lack of blockbusters would hit its liquidity. Net debt stood at $8.9 billion, and the company is considering insolvency proceedings in the UK. Cineworld has engaged lawyers to advise on the bankruptcy process and faces payment obligations to former shareholders and a potential multimillion-dollar fine in a dispute with Cineplex.

images.alt_text: James Bond becomes theatres' new hope for a box office jolt

site_title: ECB’s Nagel wants more rate hikes, says German recession likely
summary: European Central Bank Chief Joachim Nagel urged further interest-rate hikes to combat high inflation, warning that Germany faces a recession if the energy situation escalates. Nagel cited high inflation rates, just shy of 9%, and a need to keep medium-term inflation expectations stable at 2% to prevent a recession. He also expressed concerns about Germany's dependence on Russian gas and the potential impact of a prolonged dry spell on the Rhine River. Nagel expects the ECB to take necessary monetary policy measures to address the economic challenges.

images.alt_text: German imports of Chinese goods surged in value terms by 45.7 per cent year on year during first half of 2022.

German Chancellor Olaf Scholz rejected accusations of impropriety in his handling of a multibillion-euro tax fraud while Hamburg mayor at a hearing before lawmakers on Friday(Aug 19) in a case that threatens to tarnish him even as he battles multiple crises.

site_title: Indonesia’s Mitra Adiperkasa to open 400 new retail stores by year-end: CEO
summary: Indonesia's Mitra Adiperkasa plans to open 400 new retail stores by year-end, according to its CEO, V P Sharma. The company aims to maintain a double-digit contribution from online sales and invest in e-commerce, with a budget of 1.3 trillion rupiah for capital expenditure in 2022. Sharma also announced plans to develop a super-app integrating offline and online shopping, and expand its presence in regional markets, focusing on middle- to upper-class segments.

images.alt_text: Bank Permata's President-Director Meliza Musa Rusli

Although Bank Indonesia (BI), the country’s central bank, bucked the global trend of raising interest rates by keeping its benchmark rate unchanged a fortnight ago, economists and market analysts told The Business Times that they expect rates to rise later in the year.

site_title: US: Stocks fall amid worries over inflation, equity valuations
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, August 19, 2022, as concerns over inflation and equity valuations led to a 1.3% decline in the S&P 500 and a 1% weekly loss, marking its first decline in four weeks. The Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the Nasdaq dropping 2%. The decline was influenced by inflation reports from Britain and Germany, prompting analysts to expect tighter monetary policies.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 94.35 points, or 0.28 per cent, at the open to 33,904.69.

site_title: Shareholders in Brazil's Petrobras approve long-awaited board swap
summary: Brazil's Petrobras shareholders approved a long-awaited board swap, electing 6 government-affiliated nominees and 2 market-affiliated nominees. The board's balance of power remains unchanged, with the state holding 6 seats and market shareholders holding 4. Most government-affiliated board members, including Chairman Marcio Weber, were swapped out, while CEO Caio Paes de Andrade was re-elected. The election's effects are unclear, but analysts say it may not significantly impact the company's operations amid the country's presidential election.

images.alt_text: The Brazilian central bank's monetary policy committee raised the benchmark Selic rate by half a percentage point, to 13.75 per cent, in line with market expectations.
Takeaway, whose shares have lost two thirds of their value over the past year, had long been seeking to sell the iFood stake, but had been unable to reach terms.

site_title: Buyback momentum returns following earnings reports
summary: Institutions have been net buyers of Singapore stocks, with S$329 million in net inflows as of Aug 17, 2022. The Straits Times Index declined 0.9% during the period, while the FTSE China A50 Index fell 0.1%. Share buybacks by 21 listed stocks totaled S$113.6 million, with Yangzijiang Financial Holding buying 26 million shares at 36.8 cents per share. Meanwhile, director and substantial shareholder transactions included Nanofilm Technologies International's founder acquiring 500,000 shares, and Uni-Asia Group's executive chair Michio Tanamoto increasing his stake to 4.14%.

images.alt_text: Overall, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks over the first seven sessions of August with S$341 million of net inflows.

site_title: Singapore’s FinAccel seeks funds at US$1.5b value
summary: FinAccel, the parent company of Indonesian digital-credit app Kredivo, is seeking to raise about US$100 million at a US$1.5 billion pre-money valuation, down 25% from last year. The valuation reflects the current market trend of falling startup valuations. FinAccel's backers include Mirae Asset, Naver, and Square Peg Capital, and the company aims to expand into Indonesia's competitive digital banking space. This is part of a broader trend of startups gathering fresh funds, reversing years of soaring growth.

site_title: They lost crypto in the crash; now they’re trying to get it back
summary: Celsius Network, a cryptocurrency savings platform, filed for bankruptcy, leaving thousands of investors with lost funds. A group of depositors, including David, a 35-year-old engineer, banded together to hire a law firm to press their case in court. They raised $100,000 to support their claims and are seeking to recover their digital currency investments. The group is hoping to recover a significant portion of their lost savings, which accounted for more than half of one investor's net worth.

images.alt_text: Crypto investors and users of insolvent crypto platforms likely will have to hang tight as these companies work out a turnaround plan under a debt moratorium.

site_title: HBO Max pulls 200 Sesame Street episodes
summary: HBO Max has removed nearly 200 episodes of Sesame Street from its platform, mostly from the first 40 years of the show, as part of its reorganization efforts ahead of a merger with Discovery+. The move follows other recent cuts, including 36 titles and 70 staff layoffs. The removed episodes include fan favorites and notable ones from the 1980s, and it's unclear what this means for the future of Sesame Street on HBO Max. Despite the removal, Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit behind Sesame Street, remains committed to bringing the show to families' homes and has made some episodes available on the Sesame Street YouTube channel.

images.alt_text: WARNER Bros Discovery's quarterly revenue rose 13 per cent in the first set of results from the media giant forged by a US$43 billion merger between Discovery and AT&T's WarnerMedia assets.

site_title: Adam Scott tops star-filled leaderboard at BMW Championship
summary: Adam Scott leads the BMW Championship with a 2-under-par 69, carrying a 36-hole lead of 1 stroke. Scott stands at 8 under, with 15 players within 3 shots of him. World No. 1 Scottie Scheffler, Jordan Spieth, and Cameron Young are tied for second at 7 under. Scott, who played his way into the field last week, is in control but acknowledges a late double bogey on Friday could have been worse.

images.alt_text: Nitithorn Thippong of Thailand in action during final round of the International Series Singapore at Tanah Merah Country Club (Tampines Course) on Aug 14, 2022.

site_title: Tether’s second quarter lays bare impact of Terra collapse
summary: Tether Holdings reported a 20% drop in total assets to $66.4 billion in the second quarter, largely due to increased redemptions following a brief de-peg from the US dollar. Total liabilities reached $66.22 billion, with $66.2 billion related to issued digital tokens. The stablecoin operator aims to maintain a 1-to-1 redemption ratio with the US dollar using a cash and cash-equivalent reserve, but regulators have raised concerns about the quality of these assets.

site_title: Europe: Shares end week lower on recession fears
summary: European stocks ended the week lower, with the Stoxx 600 falling 0.8% on Friday, due to fears of a recession and rising energy prices. Germany's DAX lost 1.1%, its largest decline among peers, and 10-year yields rose to their highest in four weeks. The European Central Bank is expected to hike interest rates, with market bets pricing in a 50 basis point rise in September. Key stocks were affected, with travel companies declining and Just Eat Takeaway.com surging 25.8% after agreeing to sell a stake in Brazil's iFood.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, August 19, 2022.    REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 12.18 points to 1,504.44, following a 5-day rally in Singapore. Losers outnumbered gainers 426 to 395, with 2.109 billion lots traded worth RM1.533 billion.

site_title: Opec chief  blames policymakers, lawmakers for oil price rises
summary: Opec's new Secretary General, Haitham Al Ghais, blames policymakers, lawmakers, and insufficient oil and gas sector investments for high energy prices, not the producer group itself. A lack of investment post-Covid-19 has reduced Opec's spare production capacity, limiting its response to supply disruptions. Despite Brent crude reaching near-all-time highs in March, prices have declined but remain high for consumers and businesses globally.

images.alt_text: Brent futures rose US$2.94, or 3.1 per cent, to settle at US$96.59 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose US$2.39, or 2.7 per cent, to settle at US$90.50.

site_title: As UK slips into inflationary recession, consumer confidence sags to record low
summary: The UK economy is slipping into an inflationary recession, with consumer confidence at a record low of -44 points. The country's inflation rate is expected to accelerate to 13% in the coming months, causing businesses and consumers to grapple with steep increases in prices. The pound is at a 12-month low, and the FTSE 100 has recovered by 9.5% from its June lows. Analysts warn that the situation will worsen during the upcoming winter, with the real economy forecast to shrink continually until the end of 2023.

images.alt_text: British energy firms this week urged the government to do more to help consumers with energy bills at a time when they’re also seeing food and fuel prices jump.

Britain faces a “humanitarian crisis” this winter when the difficult choices forced upon low-income households by soaring energy bills could cause serious physical and mental illness, a healthcare lobby group said on Friday(Aug 19).

UK retail sales volumes, adjusted for inflation and the time of year, rose by 0.3 per cent on the month in July but were 3.4 per cent lower than a year earlier, the Office for National Statistics said.

site_title: Oil prices down 1.5% for the week on recession jitters
summary: Oil prices fell 1.5% for the week due to recession jitters and a stronger US dollar. Brent crude futures settled at $96.72 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude ended at $90.77 a barrel. Despite a brief jump in volatility, investor concerns about upcoming rate hikes and the impact on the economy limited gains. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is optimistic about oil demand in 2023, but supplies could tighten again when European buyers seek alternative supplies to replace Russian oil.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s president may announce a fuel price hike next week to reduce spending on energy subsidies, senior minister Luhut Pandjaitan said on Friday(Aug 19).

Policymakers, lawmakers and insufficient oil and gas sector investments are to blame for high energy prices, not Opec, the producer group’s new Secretary General Haitham Al Ghais told Reuters on Thursday.

site_title: Trader charged with fraud, deceit under Securities and Futures Act
summary: A trader, Pan Qi, was charged on Friday (Aug 19) under the Securities and Futures Act for engaging in a course of business that operated as a fraud on his ex-employer, Nech Capital. He is accused of making pre-arranged trades in shares of 24 companies listed on the Singapore Exchange between Jan 4, 2019 and Aug 14, 2020, using trading accounts belonging to him and his relatives.

The Federal Court has scheduled hearings through Aug 26 to hear Najib's final appeal. If it fails, Najib will probably begin his sentence immediately.
Two directors of Starburst Engineering were charged in court on Friday (Aug 5) for alleged offences involving corruption and the falsification of accounts.

site_title: Norway's power grid operator cuts its tariffs to zero to help consumers
summary: Norway's power grid operator Statnett has extended its policy of charging zero tariffs for its grid until the end of 2023, reducing electricity costs for consumers by 11 billion crowns (S$1.56 billion). The move aims to cushion customers from high electricity prices. Statnett also set another tariff to zero from September 1, 2023, affecting residential and corporate customers. The new policy aims to alleviate the financial burden on consumers amidst record-high electricity prices.

images.alt_text: The Norwegian central bank, where Norway's sovereign wealth fund is situated, in Oslo, Norway. The fund put Malaysia’s Supermax under observation for 2 years.

site_title: GM restores quarterly dividend after more than 2 years
summary: General Motors (GM) has announced it will reinstate quarterly dividend payouts after a nearly 2-year hiatus, citing confidence in its electric vehicle expansion and domestic battery manufacturing plans. The first dividend, at 9 cents per share, will be paid on September 15, 2022. GM's shares rose 2% in premarket trade. The move comes as the company continues to invest in electric and autonomous vehicles, with spending plans boosted to $35 billion through 2025. GM also plans to resume opportunistic share repurchases with an increased capacity under its existing repurchase program.

site_title: Safe-haven flows set US dollar for biggest weekly rise since April 2020
summary: The US dollar index surged 0.5% to 108.01, its highest since July 15, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid concerns of an economic slowdown. The index is on track for a 2.2% weekly gain, its best performance in over 2 years. Sterling and the euro also declined, while the Chinese yuan hit its lowest since September 2020, as worries around Britain's economic slowdown and European energy crisis intensified. Fed officials reiterated the need for higher interest rates to combat inflation.

site_title: China to boost targeted policy support for economy: state media citing Cabinet
summary: China's Cabinet announced plans to boost targeted policy support for the economy, citing a slower-than-expected growth in July. The move aims to consolidate the economic recovery and maintain a reasonable range of operations. The central bank is expected to lower benchmark lending rates and support a rebound in effective credit demand. China will also extend an exemption on purchase taxes for "new energy" vehicles until the end of 2023 to boost domestic consumption. Policymakers are under pressure to address headwinds, including a resurgence of local Covid-19 cases and a slowing global economy.

site_title: Copper heads for weekly fall on bleak global growth outlook
summary: Copper prices rose on Friday but are expected to end the week slightly lower due to traders balancing hopes for solid Chinese demand with concerns about the global economy. Inflation data from Germany and Japan, as well as statements from European and US central bankers, suggest rapid interest rate rises will continue, driving down global equities and increasing the US dollar. China is expected to lower its benchmark lending rates and provide stimulus to support its economy, but analysts predict a market surplus and slow recovery in copper prices.

images.alt_text: In the US, at least 2 steel mills have started suspending some operations to cut energy costs.

site_title: China will implement prudent financing system for property firms, regulator says
summary: China's banking regulator will implement a prudent financing system for property firms, aiming to stabilize the sector amid defaults and a slump in home sales. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) will encourage banks to extend fresh loans to developers while managing lending risks. The regulator is also coordinating with government departments to guarantee project delivery and safeguard people's livelihoods, with the goal of promoting the healthy development of the real estate industry.

site_title: Germany's Scholz denies impropriety in handling of multibillion-euro tax fraud
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz denied accusations of impropriety in handling a multibillion-euro tax fraud while Hamburg mayor, stating he exerted no influence on a local bank's tax bill. The scheme, known as "cum-ex," involved banks and investors trading shares to falsely claim tax rebates. Scholz's handling of the case threatens to tarnish him as he battles multiple crises, including public discontent over energy costs. Despite opposition lawmakers' claims of potential further testimony, Scholz maintains his integrity and calls for an end to "conjectures and insinuations."

images.alt_text: Olaf Scholz, Germany's chancellor, during his inaugural summer news conference in Berlin, Germany, on Thursday, Aug. 11, 2022. Scholz promised citizens more financial assistance, with his government working on another relief package, as Germany scrambles to deal with surging energy prices brought on by Russia's move to cut natural gas supplies. site_title: Myanmar military open to negotiations with Suu Kyi after her trial: Junta chief
summary: Myanmar's military chief, Min Aung Hlaing, said the junta is open to negotiations with ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi to end the crisis sparked by its coup. Suu Kyi, 77, has been detained since the coup on February 1, 2021, and faces decades in prison on various charges. After her trials in a junta-run court conclude, the junta will consider negotiations based on her response, according to a statement. This comes after Suu Kyi's trials have concluded, with over 2,200 people killed and 15,000 arrested in the military's crackdown on dissent since the coup.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi now faces 17 years in jail following the latest conviction.

site_title: US mortgage lenders are starting to go broke
summary: US mortgage lenders are experiencing a wave of failures as interest rates surge, with independent lenders struggling to stay afloat. Since 2016, non-bank lenders have gained market share, but many are poorly capitalized and face limited emergency funding options. The Federal Reserve's rate hike has led to a 50% decline in mortgage application volume, causing lenders to make margin calls and potentially go bankrupt. Several lenders, including Sprout Mortgage and First Guaranty, have already filed for bankruptcy, with more expected to follow.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end upward streak, won hits more than 13-year low
summary: South Korean shares fell for a third consecutive session, ending a 4-week rising streak, due to concerns over the US Federal Reserve's tightening stance on monetary policy. The benchmark Kospi index dropped 0.61% to 2,492.69, with the won touching a 13-year low against the dollar. Foreign investors sold local stocks worth 89.6 billion won, and the currency lost 1.77% against the dollar for the week, its biggest drop in 5 weeks.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 8.42 points or 0.33 per cent at 2,508.05, following a 0.67 per cent fall on Wednesday.

site_title: German dependence on China growing ‘at tremendous pace’, research shows
summary: Germany's dependence on China has grown at a "tremendous pace" in the first half of 2022, according to research by the German Economic Institute. German imports of Chinese goods surged 45.7% year-over-year, and direct investment reached 10 billion euros. China's share of German imports rose to 12.4%, and Germany's trade deficit with China reached almost 41 billion euros. Economists warn that this dependence poses a political problem, particularly if Western sanctions are imposed on China, and call for a policy turnaround towards more trade with other emerging markets.

site_title: Xiaomi posts 20% revenue fall, hurt by China Covid curbs
summary: Xiaomi Corp reported a 20% year-on-year decline in second-quarter revenue to 70.17 billion yuan, missing estimates, due to strict Covid restrictions in China. The company's net income fell 67% to 2.08 billion yuan. Smartphone sales fell 29% and unit shipments in China decreased 10% year on year. Xiaomi's stock price has tumbled nearly 40% since the start of 2022, hit by the slowing Chinese economy and weakening overseas growth.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi said the first batch of its smartphones made in Vietnam had been sent to a local distributor.

site_title: Credit Suisse top shareholder asks for investment bank overhaul
summary: Harris Associates, Credit Suisse's top shareholder, has urged the bank to overhaul its struggling investment bank unit or explore alternative options, including a sale or merger. The investment bank recorded a $1.17 billion pretax loss in the second quarter and is expected to continue losing money. Credit Suisse has recently named a new CEO, Ulrich Koerner, who aims to scale back investment banking and cut costs. If the bank cannot find a solution, it may be forced to consider drastic measures.

site_title: China demand doubts darken mood as miners baulk at energy costs
summary: China's economic slowdown and strict zero-Covid policy are casting a shadow on the global mining industry, with major companies such as Rio Tinto and Anglo American posting lower earnings and reducing shareholder payouts. The International Monetary Fund forecasts a global recession in 2023, while China's reliance on raw materials and energy-intensive operations make it vulnerable to global energy crises. The situation has led to concerns of downsizing, layoffs, and potential restructuring among mining companies, with energy costs being a major factor.

images.alt_text: Dalian and Singapore iron ore futures slumped for a fourth consecutive session on Wednesday(Aug 17), trading near US$100 a tonne, as electricity rationing in parts of China has led to steel mill shutdowns.

site_title: WHO pushes 2 Ebola treatments found to boost survival rates
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has recommended the use of two Ebola treatments, mAb114 and REGN-EB3, to boost survival rates among patients with the deadly virus. Studies have shown that these treatments significantly reduce mortality, potentially saving 230-400 lives for every 1,000 people infected. The WHO recommends administering the treatments swiftly to anyone who contracts the virus, regardless of age or health status, and has pledged to support countries in improving access to these treatments. This move marks a significant shift in the treatment of Ebola, which was once considered a near-certain killer.

site_title: Eurozone current account swings back to a surplus in June
summary: The eurozone's current account swung back to a small surplus in June, driven by an improvement in trade of services and higher primary income. The adjusted current account surplus was 4.24 billion euros, after a 6.93 billion euro deficit in May. This marks a reversal from the large deficits seen since Russia's war in Ukraine, which increased import costs. The current account surplus narrowed to 0.9% of GDP in the 12 months to June, down from 3.1% in the preceding year.

site_title: US: Tech-heavy Nasdaq leads Wall St lower at open
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.28% to 33,904.69 at the open, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.41% and 1.03% respectively. The decline was attributed to US Federal Reserve officials' statement that interest rates need to be raised to combat inflation, negatively impacting megacap growth and technology stocks.

site_title: Singapore stocks end week on a dour note, STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week with a 0.8% decline, shedding 26.97 points to close at 3,246.51. Decliners outnumbered advancers 264 to 214, with top decliners including DBS and UOB. Chief economist Clifford Bennett warned that the recent rally on Wall Street may be unsustainable, likening it to past market bubbles. Local companies from the Jardine group were among the top advancers, while companies from the finance sector were hit hard.

images.alt_text: The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite is down 12.18 points to 1,504.44 on Friday (Aug 19).

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished the week with small gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.05% to 19,773.03, driven by late bargain-buying. Despite the gains, traders remain concerned about central bank plans to hike interest rates. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.59% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 1.28%.

site_title: Adani Group gets nod for US$3.8b open offer for Ambuja, ACC
summary: The Adani Group, led by Asia's richest person Gautam Adani, has received regulatory approval for a $5.24 billion open offer to buy 26% of Ambuja Cements and 26% of ACC. The offer prices are 385 rupees per share for Ambuja and 2,300 rupees per share for ACC. The deal, which includes the acquisition of Holcim's majority stake, is set to make the Adani Group India's second-largest cement producer. The open offer was cleared by India's Securities and Exchange Board of India and antitrust regulator.

images.alt_text: Indian billionaires Mukesh Ambani (left) and Gautam Adani (right). Adani has seen his net worth surge more than anyone else in the world this year – to US$115 billion, based on data from the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: Just Eat Takeaway grabs cash, sells Brazil's iFood to Prosus for 1.8b euros
summary: Just Eat Takeaway has sold its 33% stake in Brazilian food delivery company iFood to Prosus for 1.8 billion euros, giving the investor sole control of the business. The deal provides Just Eat Takeaway with a vital cash infusion as its shares have lost two-thirds of their value over the past year. Prosus said it believes iFood has long-term potential, and the acquisition reflects the investor's confidence in the business.

images.alt_text: Deliveroo, the international delivery food app, announced on Wednesday(Aug 10) a big increase in losses as investment costs ate into rising revenues, adding it planned to exit its struggling Netherlands market.

site_title: Wild secrets I never knew about fitness trainers until I worked as one
summary:
A report from Bloomberg Pursuits delves into the world of high-end fitness trainers, revealing the inner workings of the industry. Key findings include: 

Technogym's team of elite trainers uses social media to find clients and emphasizes proper form over intense workouts. 

90% of gym-goers are doing exercises incorrectly, leading to an increased risk of sports injuries. 

Trainers often take on roles similar to therapists, addressing clients' personal issues such as relationships and marital problems. 

Designs for luxury gyms and private homes are becoming increasingly elaborate, with features like altitude rooms, bespoke dumbbells, and high-end equipment. 

Personal trainers can earn significant fees, ranging from $75 to $450 per hour, and may be hired by celebrities and high-net-worth individuals.

site_title: SAS cancels 1,700 flights due to pilot strike, late aircraft deliveries
summary: SCANDINAVIAN airline SAS has cancelled 1,700 flights in September and October due to a 2-week pilot strike and delayed aircraft deliveries. The strike, which grounded 3,700 flights, put the airline's future in doubt. SAS secured bridge financing through Apollo Global Management and has rejected a plea for more cash from the Swedish government. Denmark may write off debt and inject fresh funds if SAS secures support from new private-sector investors, despite the airline not seeing lower demand.

site_title: Philippine central bank to respond, but not match Fed rate hikes
summary: The Philippine central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), will likely continue to tighten monetary policy in response to the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes, but at a slower pace. BSP Governor Felipe Medalla stated that the bank will not match the Fed's rate hikes "point by point," leaving room for further policy adjustments. The BSP raised its benchmark interest rate by 50 basis points to 3.75% and indicated a slim chance of zero hikes in its upcoming meetings, maintaining an accommodative monetary policy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Crypto platform Hodlnaut is exploring options for users to withdraw their deposits at a discounted rate, pending judicial approval. TEE International will issue new shares worth S$7.5 million and proposes debt restructuring. Despite higher interest rates, Singapore's property market continues to defy expectations, with a shophouse up for sale at S$9.68 million. Asia's export growth is forecast to slump to negative territory in early 2023 due to slowing demand from China, the US, and Europe. Singapore shares ended the week in the red, down 0.8%.

site_title: ByteDance’s Douyin teams up with Alibaba’s Ele.me in mini programme push
summary: ByteDance's Douyin, the Chinese equivalent of TikTok, has partnered with Alibaba's Ele.me, a leading food delivery app, to bring Ele.me into its mini-programme platform. This collaboration aims to expand Douyin's ecosystem and connect users with business partners. Ele.me will be one of the biggest players to join Douyin's platform, which has over 600 million daily active users. The partnership will see Ele.me establish a presence on Douyin, leveraging the app's recommendation algorithm to suggest services to users. This move is part of a larger trend of Chinese "super-apps" creating their own ecosystems to keep users engaged.

site_title: Why Singapore is a bull’s eye for the super-rich Chinese
summary: Singapore is attracting a growing number of high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs) from Greater China, who are drawn by the country's favorable tax conditions and business-friendly environment. According to data, nearly 44% of new family offices set up in Singapore originate from China, with many more expected to follow. These younger, risk-tolerant HNWIs are uprooting themselves to do business in Singapore, taking advantage of the country's unique blend of stability and dynamism.

site_title: Jurong Port ties up with 2 partners to set up ammonia-fuelled power plant
summary: Jurong Port has partnered with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Asia Pacific (MHI-AP) and JERA Asia to set up a 100% ammonia-fuelled power plant on Jurong Island, aiming to decarbonize the maritime sector. The 60 MW class gas turbine will produce carbon-neutral electricity and stimulate ammonia demand for future bunkering. This collaboration builds on a pre-feasibility study concluded in March 2022, with Jurong Port CEO Ooi Boon Hoe citing the potential to encourage hydrogen adoption in Singapore and address the "chicken-and-egg conundrum" of infrastructure versus demand needs.

site_title: Serangoon Garden shophouse up for sale with S$9.68m guide price
summary: A 2-storey shophouse in Serangoon Garden Way, Singapore, has been launched for sale at a guide price of S$9.68 million. The property, estimated to have been built in 1960, has a 999-year lease and is eligible for purchase by foreigners. With only three shophouse transactions in the area between 2021 and 2022, it is considered a rare opportunity. The shophouse has not been gazetted for conservation, offering flexibility for future designs and renovations.

site_title: Strikes bring London’s transport network to a halt
summary: London's transport network was severely disrupted due to strikes by train and bus workers over pay and conditions, with all Underground and Overground lines suspended or partially suspended and dozens of bus routes affected. The strikes, which began on Thursday, follow a summer of labor market disputes and come as double-digit inflation continues to impact wages. The Transport Secretary warned of a potential 1970s "vicious circle" of inflation and wage increases, while the union accused the government of waging an "ideological war" against rail workers.

site_title: American CHIPS off the Chinese block
summary: The US government's plan to support the development of high-end semiconductors is being criticized as a copycat approach, mirroring China's own industrial policy. Semiconductors are crucial for various technologies and have seen rapid improvement, with Moore's Law remaining true today. The US is the world leader in chip innovation, with American companies specializing in research, design, and manufacturing. The Biden administration's decision has raised concerns that it should not be left to government planners to decide which factories to build, instead allowing the private sector to drive innovation and production.

images.alt_text: Semiconductor demand is weakening as consumers tighten their belts and companies including Apple Inc freeze hiring or cut staff.
Taiwan's economy ministry said it has not been told about a meeting for a new US-led group of major microchip manufacturers.

site_title: UK energy bills to soar near £3,600 as price cap decision nears
summary: UK energy bills are expected to surge 80% in October, reaching nearly £3,600 per year, due to soaring wholesale costs and a 15% increase in natural gas prices. The regulator, Ofgem, will set the new price cap, which will be announced next week. Energy firms have urged the government to provide more support for consumers, while the opposition Labour Party demands an early recall of Parliament to address the crisis. The price cap will likely continue to rise, potentially leading to fuel poverty and billions of pounds in support measures for the next government.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open
summary: European stocks declined at the open on Friday, August 19, 2022, with the FTSE 100 index falling 0.3% to 7,518.99 points. The eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices also dropped 0.6% and 0.5% respectively. Investors focused on interest rate hikes to combat high inflation, with US-EU trade talks also a concern.

site_title: Opportunity for S-Reits as student accommodation sector tops the class
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are gaining interest in the student accommodation sector, a previously untapped market. Ascott Residence Trust (ART) and Centurion Corp have reported significant revenue growth from their PBSA properties, with occupancy rates exceeding 95% in the US. ART's proposed acquisition of 9 properties in Singapore and its expansion into Japan's PBSA market is seen as a bullish sign. The sector's defensive nature and short supply make it an attractive opportunity for a pure-play PBSA Reit to be listed in Singapore, potentially drawing interest from investors such as GIC and Temasek.

images.alt_text: Wee Hur rises 11% on partial stake sale in student housing fund to GIC-linked entity
GIC and Greystar Real Estate Partners have agreed to buy one of the UK's largest student-accommodation businesses from Brookfield Asset Management, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: China’s yuan hits 3-month low as economic slowdown bites
summary: China's yuan hit a 3-month low against the dollar, trading at 6.8086 as of 0208 GMT, 216 pips weaker than the previous late session close. The People's Bank of China set a weakened midpoint guidance, with analysts expecting further downside due to an economic slowdown. The yuan breached the psychologically important 6.8 per dollar level, with its offshore counterpart also reaching a 3-month low of 6.8288. Currency traders attribute the decline to a firmer dollar and weaker domestic economic fundamentals.

site_title: UK retail gets boost from online shopping in July
summary: UK retail sales volumes rose 0.3% in July, adjusted for inflation and the time of year, driven by online shopping promotions, despite a weaker overall picture due to high inflation. Sales have fallen by 1.2% over the past three months and were 3.4% lower than a year ago. Online retailers, especially for household goods, saw increased spending, but the long-term trend remains downward, with the Bank of England warning of recession due to high inflation.

site_title: Factory shutdowns, showers for pigs: China’s heatwave adds to economic woes
summary: China is facing severe economic woes, exacerbated by its most intense heatwave in 60 years. Factory shutdowns and power outages, including blackouts in cities like Chongqing, have disrupted the country's supply of water and hydropower. The heatwave, which has lasted over two months, has shrunk rivers, dried up rice paddies, and caused widespread drought. Climate scientists warn that extreme weather events will increase in frequency and intensity in the coming decades, posing significant challenges for China's economy and population.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb for fifth straight week
summary: Australia's shares rose for the fifth consecutive week, driven by robust earnings, local jobs and wages data, and the central bank's cautious rate hike stance. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended 0.02% higher at 7,114.50, despite weak earnings reports from some companies. Domestic energy stocks surged 4% to close at their highest level since June 10, while heavyweight financial stocks fell 0.8%. The benchmark rose 1.2% for the week, with miners and gold stocks also firmed.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index  was last up 0.04 per cent at 7,115.5 in midday trade.

site_title: Britain faces 'humanitarian crisis' as energy costs soar, says health lobby
summary: The UK is facing a "humanitarian crisis" this winter due to soaring energy bills, which could cause serious physical and mental illness among low-income households. Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government is resisting calls for more support, despite warnings from the NHS Confederation that households may be forced to choose between heating their homes and eating. The situation could lead to outbreaks of respiratory conditions, mental illness, and increased pressure on the National Health Service.

images.alt_text: A shopper looks at a display of clothes on a stall at a market in Walthamstow, east London on February 4, 2022. - The UK government on Thursday stepped in to help the hardest-hit households struggling with the rising cost of living, announcing a £9 billion package to offset soaring energy bills. (Photo by Tolga Akmen / AFP)
Economists are growing increasingly pessimistic about the UK, with the risk of a recession now seen as far more likely than not due to rising cost pressures.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares reverse gains, investors await Fed symposium
summary: Japanese shares closed flat on Friday, reversing morning gains, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve symposium next week. The Nikkei share average ended 0.04% down at 28,930.33, while the broader Topix index rose 0.2%. The yen rose to a milestone high of 136.38 against the US dollar, its first since July 28. Investors are cautious due to mixed Fed meeting minutes and statements, with some major contributors to the index's recent rally showing weakness.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.58 per cent, or 167.65 points, to 29,109.79 in early trade on Friday.

site_title: Record jump in German producer prices adds to gloomy outlook
summary: Germany's economy stagnated in the second quarter due to the war in Ukraine, soaring energy prices, and supply chain disruptions. A record jump in producer prices, driven by high energy costs, adds to the country's gloomy economic outlook. Energy prices rose 105% compared to July 2021, with inflation reaching 8.5% in July. The government has forecast 2022 inflation at 6.1%, but updated projections will be presented on October 12. Supply chain disruptions and energy price rises are expected to weigh heavily on the economy's development.

site_title: Cathay Pilots offered extra pay for flights to China
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is offering pilots up to HK$5,000 (S$884) per flight to work on routes to mainland China, where ongoing Covid-19 curbs have made it less appealing. The Hong Kong-based airline acknowledged that its dedicated Chinese mainland operations have been "particularly onerous" due to China's strict Covid Zero policy, which has largely closed the country off from the rest of the world. The allowances are seen as a sweetener to attract pilots to these routes.

images.alt_text: Cathay’s first-half revenue rose 17 per cent to HK$18.6 billion, driven by an increase in ticket sales and persistent strong demand for air cargo.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Markets muted by uncertainty (Ep 8)
summary: Markets in Singapore remain cautious due to ongoing uncertainties. The Singapore NODX (Non-Oil and Other Developing Exports) and monetary policy by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) are being closely watched. The MAS has been adjusting interest rates, and its monetary policy decisions are expected to impact the local economy. The uncertainty surrounding global economic trends and market volatility is also contributing to the cautious market sentiment.

site_title: Gas heading for another weekly rise intensifies Europe’s pain
summary: Europe is set for the longest weekly run of natural gas price gains this year, intensifying the pain for industries and households, and threatening recession. Benchmark futures rose on Friday after closing at a record high, driven by hot and dry weather disrupting fuel transportation and limiting power production. Demand is rising, while Russian supply cuts exacerbate the crisis, with prices 11 times higher than usual this time of year. This has forced industry shutdowns and is threatening to push economies into recession.

site_title: China tycoon nabbed in Hong Kong gets 13 years jail, company fined 55b yuan
summary: Chinese-Canadian billionaire Xiao Jianhua was sentenced to 13 years in prison and fined his company Tomorrow Holdings 55 billion yuan (S$11.2 billion) for illegally obtaining public deposits, breach of trust, bribery, and the illegal use of funds. The sentence marked the end of a long-running saga since Xiao's seizure in Hong Kong in 2017. Authorities have been cracking down on illicit activities and ensuring financial stability amid eroding confidence in the financial system, with regulators seizing control of several financial firms linked to Xiao.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Less excitement on SGX amid cautious outlook
summary: Research houses have lowered their calls on Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to muted expectations on future earnings, despite the bourse meeting earnings expectations in the second half of 2022 and benefiting from rising interest rates. Analysts at CGS-CIMB, RHB, and UOB Kay Hian have downgraded their target prices and calls, citing concerns over modest growth in securities daily average value and rising cost pressures. However, some analysts, such as OCBC Investment Research, maintain a "hold" call, citing potential catalysts for growth from expanded non-equities segments and a resilient business model.

images.alt_text: Full year revenue for SGX reached S$1.099 billion, a 4 per cent increase as compared with last year’s S$1.056 billion.

site_title: UK borrows more than forecast as inflation fuels debt costs
summary: The UK government's borrowing exceeded forecasts in the first four months of the fiscal year, driven by soaring inflation that increased debt costs by 81% from last year. The total budget deficit for 2022-23 is now £55 billion, £3 billion more than initially predicted. This raises concerns about the tax cuts being proposed by candidates Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss, who have been accused of being irresponsible by the Institute for Fiscal Studies. The high inflation rate and predicted recession are putting pressure on policymakers to provide extra support for households struggling with the cost of living.

site_title: How should investors prepare for repeat inflation shocks?
summary: Investors may need to reassess their asset allocation strategy due to rising concerns about "structural" inflation. The past decade's mix of 60% stocks and 40% bonds has been a sensible approach, but recent market volatility, with stocks and bonds both declining, suggests that inflation may be a persistent issue. The recent data showing no rise in inflation on August 10, followed by a surge in stocks and short-term Treasury prices, may indicate that inflation is not as high as expected. Investors should consider diversifying their portfolios to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Indonesia may hike fuel prices next week
summary: Indonesia's president may announce a fuel price hike next week to reduce spending on energy subsidies, according to senior minister Luhut Pandjaitan. The country has tripled its energy subsidy budget to 502 trillion rupiah amid rising oil prices and a depreciating rupiah. This move comes after Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati stated that more money would be needed if fuel prices were to remain unchanged until the end of the year.

images.alt_text: President Joko Widodo said that the South-east Asian nation will shift its economy into producing more value-added goods and away from purely selling raw materials.

site_title: Taiwan says it has not been informed of ‘Chip 4’ meeting
summary: Taiwan's economy ministry stated that it has not been informed of a meeting for the "Chip 4" group, a US-led group of major microchip manufacturers. Despite cooperating closely with the US on supply chains, Taiwan's ministry expressed surprise at the lack of notice. South Korea's foreign minister confirmed Seoul's attendance in a preliminary meeting, while Taiwan emphasized its partnership with the US and its role as a major semiconductor producer, including supplier to Apple Inc.

site_title: Samsung Electronics breaks ground on new chip R&D centre, plans 20t won investment by 2028
summary: Samsung Electronics has broken ground on a new R&D centre in Giheung, South Korea, to drive leadership in chip technology. The 20 trillion won (S$20.8 billion) investment by 2028 will focus on next-generation devices and processes for memory and system chips, as well as development of new tech. The facility aims to overcome the limits of semiconductor scaling. The ceremony was attended by newly-pardoned Samsung vice-chairman Jay Y. Lee and top executives.

site_title: Crypto platform Hodlnaut explores user deposit withdrawals, lays off 80% of staff
summary: Cryptocurrency platform Hodlnaut is exploring user deposit withdrawals at a discounted rate, amid cash burn issues. The company has laid off 80% of staff, reduced interest rates to 0%, and applied for judicial management. The move aims to avoid a force liquidation of bitcoin and ethereum holdings at depressed prices, allowing the company to execute a recovery plan and rehabilitate its assets. Founders Simon Lee and Zhu Juntao are working on the recovery plan from Singapore, and the company is also involved in pending proceedings with the Singapore Attorney-general Chambers and Police Force.

Hodlnaut’s token swap feature allows users to exchange cryptocurrencies, such as from Bitcoin to Ethereum.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift as investors assess Fed outlook
summary: Asian markets drifted on Friday as investors assessed the Federal Reserve's plans to lift interest rates, with mixed data and differing opinions from bank officials providing little clarity. Despite a rally in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, Taipei, Manila, and Jakarta, Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, and Wellington fell. The Fed's determination to keep lifting borrowing costs until inflation is brought under control has caused unease, with some officials reasserting the need to continue tightening monetary policy. The market's direction remains uncertain, with the next week's central bankers symposium in Jackson Hole providing key insights into the Fed's plans.

site_title: North Korea rejects Seoul’s aid-for-denuclearisation offer
summary: North Korea's Kim Yo Jong rejected South Korea's offer of economic aid in return for denuclearization, calling it "the height of absurdity". The offer, made by South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, includes food, energy, and infrastructure help. Analysts say the deal's chances were already slim due to North Korea's reluctance to give up its nuclear program. The rejection comes as North Korea has warned of a Covid-19 outbreak in Seoul and has been preparing to mobilize its nuclear capability.

site_title: PUB sets up green financing framework, to launch green bonds under S$10b programme
summary: PUB, Singapore's national water agency, has established a green financing framework to fund its green projects, including the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. The framework, part of a S$10 billion multi-currency MTN programme, will ensure green bonds follow market best practices and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Independent reviewer Sustainalytics has verified the framework, aligning with International Capital Market Association and Asean Green Bond Standards. The green bonds will help fund projects eligible for financing, advancing sustainable water and wastewater management, and renewable energy in Singapore.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.58% to 29,109.79. Investors are awaiting cues ahead of the annual meeting of central bankers in Jackson Hole. The broader Topix index also advanced 0.49%.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices could fall 10% after HSBC and StanChart hike rates
summary: Hong Kong's home prices could fall 5-10% in the second half of 2022 due to two major banks, HSBC and Standard Chartered, raising mortgage rates by 25 basis points, the highest since 2008. The move puts buyers' purchasing power to the test, following four interest rate hikes by the de facto central bank this year. The property market has already fallen over 4% amid political tensions and strict quarantine policies. Goldman Sachs predicts a 20% slump by 2025, while all 12 economists surveyed by Bloomberg predict a rise in prime rates this year.

site_title: Thailand saw 3.78 million tourists from Jan to mid-Aug: government
summary: Thailand saw 3.78 million tourist arrivals from January to mid-August, exceeding the initial forecast of 7 million. The arrivals generated $6.8 billion in revenue, mainly from Malaysia, India, and Singapore. The government plans to extend the visa-on-arrival for nationals of India, China, and Saudi Arabia from 15 to 30 days starting in October to boost the tourism sector. Thailand expects 8-10 million arrivals this year, a significant recovery from the pandemic-induced slump of 428,000 visitors in 2021.

site_title: ‘ESG’ stripped from 23% of EU sustainable funds in fresh review
summary: A recent review by market researcher Morningstar Inc found that 23% of EU sustainable funds, classified as Article 8 under the EU's Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation, do not meet environmental, social, or governance (ESG) investing principles. This raises concerns about "greenwashing" and the need for clearer definitions and standards. The assessment coincides with a crackdown by financial watchdogs and growing investor skepticism towards Article 8 funds, leading some asset managers to remove ESG labels from their funds.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down at start of Friday’s trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.21% lower on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping to 19,722.92. Investors are concerned about the economic outlook as central banks raise interest rates to combat inflation. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.06% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.05%. The decline in Hong Kong stocks follows a global trend of stock market volatility amid concerns over US-EU trade talks and interest rate hikes.

site_title: China’s cyber watchdog wants ‘affectionate’ ties with domestic Internet firms
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) aims to build an "affectionate" relationship with domestic internet firms, according to a senior official. The agency wants to create a "healthy, get-to-the-top, can-do entrepreneurial atmosphere" while implementing rules. Despite a regulatory crackdown, the CAC remains supportive of the sector's healthy development, and its cybersecurity coordinator said that domestic firms seeking overseas listings are being supervised. The agency is also overseeing Didi Global's rectification work after the ride-hailing giant was fined $1.2 billion for violating data security rules.

site_title: The art of choosing what to do with your life
summary: A liberal arts education is essential in helping students choose their life's path by teaching them to think critically about their goals and values. Many colleges prioritize preparing students for the next step, but neglect to provide adequate guidance on the substance of their lives. By introducing students to the art of choosing, liberal education can empower them to make informed decisions and find purpose in their lives. This approach, exemplified by the authors' course using Plato's "Gorgias" and Thomas Aquinas, encourages students to consider the universal human goods and their ultimate longings, leading to a sense of empowerment and direction.

site_title: The 1% tax on share buybacks is just the start
summary: The US government has implemented a 1% tax on stock buybacks as part of the Inflation Reduction Act. Although the tax is currently small, it is expected to increase over time, potentially discouraging companies from repurchasing shares and reducing their financial leverage. Companies have historically used buybacks to boost earnings per share, but critics argue that it enriches corporate executives and is a form of stock manipulation. The tax is seen as a step towards putting buybacks on equal footing with dividends in terms of taxation, with some experts suggesting that eliminating taxes on dividends would be a better approach.

site_title: Asia’s export growth may slip into negative territory in early-2023
summary: Asia's export growth is expected to slump from mid-teens to low single-digits by year-end and fall into negative territory in early 2023, driven by slowing demand from China, the US, and Europe. Nomura's credit impulse indicator points to a continued slowdown, with China's credit impulse showing a reliable lag of about 14 months. Economists warn that export volume growth at 1.5% year-on-year in the second quarter is already weaker than value growth at 13.8%, and the export leading index is pointing south until September.

site_title: Jokowi wants to add job creation in Indonesia central bank’s mandate
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has pushed for changes to the central bank's charter to include job creation in its mandate, alongside maintaining currency and price stability. Widodo's re-emphasis on the law signals the passage of the amendments in Parliament, despite concerns over compromising central bank autonomy and striking a balance between employment and price control. Bank Indonesia has maintained a dovish stance on interest rates, citing no need to hike rates despite high inflation.

site_title: Xi, Putin expected to attend G20 summit in Bali this November

summary: Apple has issued emergency software updates to fix a vulnerability that allows hackers to seize control of iPhones, iPads, and Mac computers. The company is urging users to install the patches, which were released on Thursday and Wednesday, after discovering the flaw. The vulnerability could allow hackers to access any device data or capabilities, and Apple is aware of a report that the issue may have been actively exploited.

summary: Oxley Holdings reported a S$20.3 million loss for the second half of FY2022, more than doubling from the previous year's loss of S$9.6 million. summary: Australia's shares rose 0.04% to 7,115.5, extending a fifth consecutive weekly gain, despite weak earnings from blue chips like AGL Energy and TPG Telecom. Mining, energy, and gold stocks offset losses, with the energy sub-index jumping 3.6% and gold stocks gaining over 2%. The benchmark index has risen 1.1% for the week, while Japan's Nikkei rose 0.33% and S&P 500 E-minis futures fell 0.16%.

images.alt_text: Gold stocks were the top percentage losers on the benchmark, slumping 3.8 per cent.

site_title: Could the EV boom run out of juice before it really gets going?
summary: The global electric vehicle (EV) industry is facing a potential shortage of batteries, which could hinder its growth. Industry analysts project that demand for EV batteries will grow nine-fold by 2030, but current and promised supply from established manufacturers may not meet this demand. The shortage is driven by several factors, including China's dominance of battery production, geopolitical tensions, and environmental concerns. The EU's planned ban on new sales of carbon-burning cars by 2035 may also exacerbate the issue. Western carmakers, particularly those in Europe, are vulnerable to this shortage, and some are investing in local battery production to mitigate the risk.

images.alt_text: Ford has boosted its planned spending on EVs till 2026 to US$50 billion from its prior target of US$30 billion, and reorganised its operations into separate units focused on EVs and petrol-powered vehicles with Ford Model e and Ford Blue, respectively.
With all net growth in car sales last year coming from EVs, demand for the raw materials in batteries has ramped up suddenly.

site_title: Rare ESG debt format endorsed as key to dodging greenwashing
summary: The US$4 trillion ESG debt market is expected to adopt a hybrid debt format, combining features of green and sustainability-linked debt structures, to address concerns about greenwashing. This new structure, known as green SLBs, would tether companies to their sustainability promises and provide investors with assurance that proceeds are used for environmentally-friendly projects. With only a handful of green SLBs issued so far, the market is poised for growth, but faces hurdles such as high upfront and ongoing costs. The hybrid format is seen as a natural progression of the market, offering benefits of both worlds and aligning with the just transition environment.

images.alt_text: A general view of Shell's Pulau Bukom petrochemical complex in Singapore.

site_title: Musk targets ad tech firms in Twitter suit over takeover deal
summary: Elon Musk is seeking documents from advertising technology firms Integral Ad Science (IAS) and DoubleVerify as part of his lawsuit against Twitter over a bot and spam account issue. Musk's lawyers have subpoenaed the firms to review Twitter's user base, amid a $44 billion acquisition deal that Musk is attempting to walk away from. Musk claims Twitter is hiding information about how it calculates bot percentages, while Twitter asserts it stands by its disclosures. A trial is scheduled for October 17.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s second stock split in 2 years a welcome catalyst
Elon Musk sold about 7.92 million shares between Aug 5 and Aug 9, according to multiple filings. He now owns 155.04 million shares in Tesla.
Elon Musk (above) said early on Wednesday that he had not been serious when he tweeted hours previously that he was going to buy Manchester United, as fed-up fans urge current owners to sell up.

site_title: Japan’s inflation holds above BOJ target, price pressures broaden
summary: Japan's core consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.4% in July from a year earlier, its fastest pace in seven-and-a-half years, driven by fuel and raw material prices. This marks the fourth straight month the index breached the Bank of Japan's 2% target, indicating broadening price pressure. The core-core index, which excludes volatile food and energy costs, also rose 1.2% in July, its fastest pace since 2015. The Bank of Japan is likely to maintain ultra-loose monetary conditions, differing from other major economies.

images.alt_text: The yen’s drop to a 24-year low versus the dollar in July made imports more expensive while making exports cheaper.
Japanese companies have typically avoided boosting wages because decades of deflation made it difficult to pass on higher costs to consumers.
Investors who choose to stay strategically invested in safe-haven assets, such as cash and core sovereign bonds, will have to bear a particularly severe erosion of capital.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB lowers Q&M Dental target price; downgrades to ‘hold’
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded its call on Q&M Dental Group from "add" to "hold" and lowered its target price to S$0.44 from S$0.73 due to an earnings miss and near-term challenges. Q&M's H1 net profit of S$9.8 million was below expectations, with slower-than-expected core dental business growth and lower operating leverage. The company faces challenges including wage inflation and a tight labor market, and analysts reduced their dividend expectation for FY2022.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday against Wall Street gains; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,266.7 on Friday, tracking global market declines. The STI opened lower after Wall Street stocks rose on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.1%. Gainers outweighed losers 62 to 47, with Marco Polo Marine and Sembcorp Marine being the top performers. European shares rose, but lagged other major markets due to high eurozone inflation and potential rate hikes.

images.alt_text: This is the first quarter where contributions from recent acquisitions have positively impacted the group’s top and bottom line, said chief executive officer of Marco Polo Marine, Sean Lee.
Singpost's Q1 revenue had risen 34.7 per cent to S$475.2 million, it announced in a Friday business update.

site_title: Europe: Shares up on energy boost, but inflation caps gains
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by a 1.7% gain in energy stocks after crude futures surged. However, euro zone inflation reached a record high in July, with consumer prices rising 0.1% month-on-month for an 8.9% year-on-year increase. European Central Bank officials hinted at another large rate hike next month, citing a lack of improvement in the inflation outlook.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index fell 0.2 per cent to 7,497.88 points.

site_title: Facebook bans major US anti-vaccine group
summary: Meta has banned the influential US anti-vaccination group Children's Health Defence (CHD) from its social media platforms, citing repeated violations of misinformation rules. The group's accounts were suspended on Wednesday after it was accused of spreading Covid-19 misinformation. CHD founder Robert Kennedy Jr. criticized the move, claiming it was an attempt to silence criticism of government policies. The ban comes after CHD filed a lawsuit against Meta accusing the tech giant of infringing free speech rights.

images.alt_text: Meta is working with 10 outside fact checking partners, including 5 Spanish-language organisations, to review posts and label them if they’re misleading.
While TikTok has banned paid political ads since 2019, campaign strategists have skirted the ban by paying influencers to promote political issues.

site_title: Transition to green economy must be orderly to keep inflation in check, job market stable: MAS chief
summary: MAS managing director Ravi Menon said an orderly transition to a greener economy may help manage inflationary pressures and labour market disruption. The MAS chief cited Bank of England estimates that a disorderly transition could lead to 2% inflation by the early 2030s, whereas an orderly transition may keep inflation at 0.6 percentage points. Menon emphasized the importance of a well-planned transition to mitigate economic risks.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s inaugural green bond issue sees public offer fully subscribed at 1.06 times
A general view of Shell's Pulau Bukom petrochemical complex in Singapore.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, OCBC, Marco Polo Marine
summary: SingPost's Q1 revenue rose 34.7% to S$475.2 million, but operating profit fell 46.7% to S$10.6 million due to steeper costs. OCBC's electric vehicle loan business more than doubled since its launch in March 2021, and Marco Polo Marine's revenue grew 139.5% year-over-year in Q3. Trading halts were announced for Revez Corporation, Oxley Holdings, and Tuan Sing Holdings, pending separate announcements.
