site_title: Fitch upgrades Ukraine rating out of restricted default
summary: Fitch upgraded Ukraine's credit score from restricted default to CC, citing a two-year reprieve on foreign debt from creditors. The agreement alleviates external debt servicing pressure, but the CC rating reflects unresolved debt sustainability risks due to the ongoing war and Ukraine's stressed finances. The upgrade comes after Fitch placed Ukraine in restricted default last week, while S&P Global downgraded the country to selective default status.

site_title: S$1.8b collective sale tender for People’s Park Centre closes without bids
summary: The collective sale tender for People's Park Centre in Singapore's Chinatown closed without bids on August 18, 2022, after a reserve price of S$1.8 billion was set. The mixed-use development, launched for collective sale, has been on the market for three years, with previous attempts to sell the site also failing. ERA Realty Network will initiate private negotiations with developers over the next 10 weeks, despite the high capital requirement and potential drawbacks for developers.

images.alt_text: 位于牛车水一带的珍珠大厦（People's Park Centre）外观。

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.97 points or 0.13% to 1,514.65. The market saw 146.92 million lots traded worth RM86.74 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 165 to 130. The decline follows global market trends, with Europe's stocks also down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Zelensky rules out any ‘peace’ with Russia without troop withdrawal
summary: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky ruled out any peace with Russia without the withdrawal of its troops from Ukraine. He stated, "First they should leave our territory and then we'll see," after talks with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres. Zelensky expressed surprise at Erdogan's claim that Russia was "ready for some kind of peace."

site_title: SingPost Q1 operating profit falls 47% on higher costs, post and parcel weakness
summary: SingPost's Q1 operating profit fell 46.7% to S$10.6 million due to higher costs and challenges in its core post and parcel business. Despite a 34.7% revenue increase to S$475.2 million, driven by growth in its Australia business and higher revenue from Famous Holdings, occupancy at SingPost Centre remained high at 95.9% as of end-June. The company attributed the decline in operating profit to increased costs and weakness in the post and parcel business.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB sees SingPost’s recent guidance as an implication of weakness in the group’s domestic post and parcel (DPP) volumes, given the high fixed-cost nature of the business.
The potential impact of Tan’s claim “cannot not be quantified at this stage”, the postal service group added in a bourse filing on Monday (Aug 15).

site_title: US existing home sales fall for sixth straight month; prices remain elevated
summary: US existing home sales declined 5.9% to a 2-year low in July, falling to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.81 million units. This marks the sixth consecutive monthly sales decline, further evidence of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening campaign dampening housing demand. Despite the decline, home prices remain elevated, with the median existing house price rising 10.8% from a year earlier to $403,800. The drop in sales could help slow house price inflation, but low supply remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Residential starts dropped 9.6 per cent last month to a 1.45 million annualised rate from a revised 1.6 million pace in June, according to US government data released on Tuesday (Aug 16).
US builder confidence is tumbling as high mortgage rates exacerbate affordability challenges, on top of elevated costs of materials and labour.

site_title: India’s Reserve Bank says policy oriented toward cooling prices
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has shifted its focus to cooling prices, with inflation remaining above its target this year. The central bank has raised interest rates by 140 basis points since May to curb inflation, fueled by elevated food and global oil prices. The RBI expects inflation to fall from 7% to 5% in the April-June quarter next year, a "decisive point" in its trajectory. However, the task to guide inflation to the medium-term target of 4% may prove more challenging.

site_title: Oil up 3% on robust US fuel consumption, tight supply outlook
summary: Oil prices rose 3% on Thursday, driven by robust US fuel consumption and positive economic data, despite concerns about slowing growth in other countries. Brent futures rose to $96.59 a barrel and WTI crude rose to $90.50 a barrel. Analysts attribute the rally to tight supply outlook, with Opec stating it could cut or add production as needed. However, EU sanctions on Russian oil exports could tighten supply and drive up prices in the coming months.

images.alt_text: West Texas Intermediate has climbed 1.1 per cent to over US$89 a barrel, while Brent has jumped by 1.4 per cent to almost US$95.

site_title: Starbucks COO to depart, role to be eliminated in overhaul
summary: Starbucks COO John Culver will step down on October 3, serving as an executive adviser before departing the company at the end of 2022. The company will eliminate the COO role, with day-to-day operations reporting directly to CEO Howard Schultz. As part of a broader leadership overhaul, global supply-chain chief George Dowdie also plans to leave the company. Schultz attributed the changes to "reinventing" the leadership structure to accelerate modernized experiences. Starbucks will name a new permanent CEO in the fall.

images.alt_text: A spokesperson for Starbucks said the Seattle-based company hasn’t been served with the lawsuit and had no comment.

site_title: Treasury taps City of London again in latest push to buoy IPOs
summary: The UK government is holding informal discussions with senior bankers and finance executives to stimulate demand for listings in London's stock market. The goal is to boost the City's competitiveness after Brexit and attract more companies to list on the exchange. Ideas being considered include setting up a dedicated fund and incentivizing institutional and retail investors. The discussions are part of a broader effort to address the UK's slide in listings, which has been attributed to Brexit and listing rules perceived to be less favorable than other jurisdictions.

images.alt_text: Economists are growing increasingly pessimistic about the UK, with the risk of a recession now seen as far more likely than not due to rising cost pressures.
Six years on from the referendum, Brexit hasn't at all disappeared as a UK policy issue.

site_title: Restaurateur and rapper duo to reopen former Starbucks coffee shops in Russia
summary: A restaurateur and rapper duo, Timati and Anton Pinskiy, are set to reopen Starbucks' former coffee shops in Russia as "Stars Coffee", following the company's exit from the market in May. The chain will feature a new logo with a woman and a star. The relaunch comes after similar moves by other Western companies, such as McDonald's and Vkusno & tochka. The partnership marks a significant shift in the Russian retail landscape, with prized assets being handed over to local business people.

site_title: High-flying travel startup Pollen collapses, leaving trail of complaints
summary: Travel startup Pollen, known for luxury events featuring A-list musicians, has collapsed due to customer complaints. The company was forced to cancel dozens of events last year, citing the omicron variant of Covid-19. In response to the backlash, Pollen implemented a refund system that prioritized those who complained the loudest on social media, leading to further customer dissatisfaction. The collapse of Pollen highlights the challenges faced by high-flying startups in maintaining customer trust and satisfaction.

images.alt_text: Visitors at Pagoda Street and along Chinatown in Singapore.

site_title: UOB, Doxa sign MOU to digitalise Kimly Construction’s finance processes
summary: UOB and Doxa signed a memorandum-of-understanding with Kimly Construction to digitalize the finance processes of the latter's green project, the Singapore Institute of Technology campus at Punggol North. This is the first green trade finance transaction leveraging Doxa Connex, an online procure-to-pay platform. The collaboration aims to accelerate the digitalization of the industry and reduce manual and paper-based processes, enabling greater efficiency and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Kevin Lam, head of TMRW and group digital banking at UOB, believes that having an open mind and being ready for new ideas is key in the ever-changing banking industry.

site_title: Fed rate hike of 50 or 75 basis points ‘reasonable’ next month, Daly says
summary: US Federal Reserve President Mary Daly suggests a 50 or 75 basis point interest rate hike in September to combat inflation, positioning it as a "reasonable" move to reach neutral rates around 3% and potentially restrictive territory above 3% by the end of the year. Daly advocates for a "raise-and-hold" strategy, aiming to keep rates steady once inflation is brought under control. This stance contradicts market expectations of interest rate cuts next year and aims to avoid rapid rate increases followed by cuts, which Daly believes would create uncertainty and caution.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President Mary Daly poses at the bank’s headquarters in San Francisco, California, U.S., July 16, 2019. REUTERS/Ann Saphir/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: South-east Asia beefs up credentials as regional EV powerhouse
summary: South-east Asia is bolstering its credentials as a regional electric vehicle (EV) powerhouse with major investments from Toyota, Foxconn, Hyundai, and VinFast. The region aims to become a thriving EV hub, with governments and private sectors investing billions in manufacturing, battery production, and charging infrastructure. However, analysts note that South-east Asia still lags behind China, the world's leading EV manufacturer. Thailand and Indonesia are seen as potential production hubs, with incentives such as subsidies and tax breaks attracting Chinese EV makers. VinFast, a Vietnamese automaker, is positioning itself to compete with Chinese brands by partnering with European and American companies.

site_title: Battery boom keeps lithium recession-proof for top supplier SQM
summary: SQM, the second-largest supplier of lithium, reported record quarterly earnings and projects a 35% jump in demand for lithium this year, driven by strong electric-car sales in China. Despite concerns of a lithium supply shortage, SQM's production is expected to reach 180,000 tons, with the company forecasting a tight supply/demand balance for the remainder of 2022. This has led to high prices, which may continue throughout the year. SQM's shares have more than doubled in value this year, outperforming global peers.

site_title: Auric Pacific CEO granted option to buy Belmont Road bungalow for S$55.5 million
summary: Auric Pacific CEO Andy Adhiwana has been granted an option to buy a freehold bungalow in the Belmont Park GCB Area for S$55.5 million, approximately S$2,055 per square foot. The 27,000 sq ft property, developed in the early 2000s, was previously owned by David Chew and sold for S$34.5 million in 2019. If completed, the deal would result in a 60% gain for the seller, Woo Tsung Chwen. The sale is seen as a fair price by market watchers, considering the property's narrow road frontage and land cascading downwards.

site_title: US: Wall St steady at open as investors assess Fed minutes
summary: US stocks opened steady on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.54 points to 33,981.86. Investors assessed the Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes, which suggested a less aggressive monetary policy tightening path, leading to subdued trading. The S&P 500 opened lower by 0.91 points, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.34 points at the opening bell.

site_title: US: Stocks finish higher on Thursday after choppy session
summary: US stocks finished higher on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite Index gaining 0.2% each to close at 4,283.74 and 12,065.34, respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1% to 33,999.04. Despite a mixed earnings session, investors weighed prospects for further upward movement. Existing home sales dropped 5.9% in July, while Cisco Systems jumped 5.8% after reporting better-than-expected results, while Kohl's slumped 7.7% due to a drop in profit.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.54 points at the open to 33,981.86.

site_title: China is ramping up Swiss gold imports, signalling better demand
summary: China's gold imports from Switzerland surged to 80 tons in July, the highest in over 5 years, indicating improved demand as the country relaxed Covid restrictions. This marks a significant increase from the previous month and 8 times more than in May. China's purchases can provide a floor for gold prices, supporting them between $1,700-$1,800 an ounce despite interest-rate hikes. The increased demand signals a recovery in China's gold market, which was previously hurt by lockdowns, and could lead to higher prices.

images.alt_text: A one kilogram gold bar sits on top of silver bars at London bullion dealers Gold Investments Ltd. in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Thursday, April 4, 2013. site_title: ‘We didn’t try to be God’: Why Ant ditched its S-E Asia dream to help rivals cross borders
summary: Ant Group, a fintech affiliate of Alibaba, initially aimed to unify e-wallets across South-east Asia, but struggled with changing consumer mindsets and regulatory requirements. The company decided to acquire stakes in local payment providers, such as TrueMoney and GCash, and launched Alipay+ for cross-border mobile payments. Ant now serves over 1 billion consumers in Asia through its payment providers and has partnered with companies like ComfortDelGro to enable mobile payments. Despite regulatory challenges, Ant sees South-east Asia as its most important market outside of China, and is focusing on digital banking ambitions, including the launch of ANEXT Bank in Singapore.

images.alt_text: On Jun 6, Ant added to its regional presence with the unveiling of its long-awaited Singapore digital wholesale bank: Anext Bank.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims edge lower last week
summary: US jobless claims fell moderately to 250,000 for the week ended Aug 13, below the 270,000-300,000 range that economists consider a material slowdown in the labor market. Initial claims have drifted higher in recent weeks, partly due to companies laying off workers in response to slowing demand caused by the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening. Despite this, demand for labor remains strong, with 10.7 million job openings at the end of June.

images.alt_text: Many of those who stopped working as Covid-19 first ravaged the US economy in early 2020 have never returned.
Initial unemployment claims increased by 14,000 to 262,000 in the week ended Aug 6, Labor Department data showed on Thursday (Aug 11).

site_title: Bank of England sets out plans to sell £200m corporate bond stockpile
summary: The Bank of England plans to auction off around £200 million of corporate bonds weekly, starting from September 19, as part of its efforts to unwind its £20 billion stimulus push. The sales will be gradual and responsive to market conditions, with the goal of completing the sales by early 2024. This move is part of the BOE's plans to reduce its £844 billion government bond holdings by £80 billion over the next year.

site_title: An Indian heritage feast at Yantra
summary: Yantra, a newly reopened Indian heritage restaurant, showcases recipes from across the subcontinent. The restaurant features a range of dishes, including Ema Datshi, Chingri Malaikari, and Taka Luchi Alu Dum. Its interior design is inspired by pages from a design magazine, offering a unique dining experience. With its diverse menu and modern decor, Yantra aims to bring mod-Indian cuisine to the forefront, offering a fresh take on traditional Indian flavors.

images.alt_text: Gyu San serves a range of sandos with steak, tamago and ebi fillings.

site_title: Germany cuts sales tax on gas to ease burden from soaring costs
summary: Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a temporary cut in sales tax on natural gas to 7% from 19% to ease the burden on households and companies affected by soaring energy costs. The move, set to take effect on October 1 and expire in March 2024, aims to reduce the burden created by a new levy on gas consumers. The levy, set at 2.4 euro cents per kilowatt hour, will boost energy bills but the reduced VAT rate will be passed on to consumers, according to Scholz.

site_title: Korea’s SK invests US$100m in EV-focused startup Atom Power
summary: South Korea's SK has invested $100 million in North Carolina-based startup Atom Power, a company developing digital circuit breakers for electric vehicle charging. Atom Power's technology provides more control, flexibility, and reliability, enabling safer charging for commercial fleet operators and multi-family dwellings. The investment is driven by SK's recognition of Atom Power's core technology as the primary driver behind the decision.

images.alt_text: SK, the holding company of South Korea's second-largest conglomerate SK Group, said it made the investment with affiliate SK Innovation as part of a total US$750 million fundraising round co-led by Bill Gates.

site_title: US dollar holds its gains as Fed set for lengthy inflation fight
summary: The US dollar reached a 3-week high on Thursday, trading at 106.96, after the Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes indicated that interest rates would stay higher for longer to combat inflation. The stronger dollar pushed the pound and euro down, while the Japanese yen also declined. Analysts expect the US dollar to continue its upward trend unless the Fed pivots, citing the currency's "smile" theory that it benefits from both strong growth and being a safe haven.

site_title: Hong Kong sets up task force on South-east Asian job scams
summary: Hong Kong has established a task force to combat South-east Asian job scams, which have lured victims to countries such as Myanmar, Cambodia, Thailand, and Laos with false promises of romance or high-paying jobs. Victims have reported being held against their will and forced to work for months. The task force aims to track down and help trafficked residents, following recent outrage in Hong Kong and Taiwan over graphic photos and videos of victims being threatened and abused.

site_title: Swiss Club Road GCB on market for S$39.9m or S$1,874 psf
summary: A freehold bungalow in the Swiss Club Road GCB enclave is on the market for S$39.9 million, valued at approximately S$1,874 per square foot of land. The 10,600 sq ft house sits on 21,293 sq ft of land and is being marketed in a private treaty sale. The sale price is lower than recent transactions in the area, which have ranged from S$2,023 to S$3,017 per square foot. The GCB market has slowed due to a widening buyer-seller price gap and depressed sentiment.

site_title: South Korea to attend preliminary meeting of US-led chipmaker group
summary: South Korea is expected to attend a preliminary meeting for the US-led "Chip 4" group, a group of major microchip manufacturers including Taiwan and Japan. The meeting could heighten the stakes for South Korea as it navigates the competition between the US and China over semiconductor and micro processing technology. Semiconductors are South Korea's No. 1 export item, and the country's participation in the meeting could be influenced by the US' new $52 billion chip manufacturing and research subsidies, as well as China's opposition to the new US chips act.

site_title: China Covid cases at 3-month high as even fish get tests
summary: China has reported a 3-month high of COVID-19 cases, with 3,424 infections on August 17, mainly driven by a worsening outbreak in Hainan province. The island, dubbed "China's Hawaii," has seen 2,018 cases, with 1,231 in the resort city of Sanya. Authorities have dispatched medical workers from other provinces to assist, and the country's Covid czar has called for improved treatment and quarantine facilities. The outbreak has raised concerns about the spread of the virus through foreign trade, with Xiamen mandating daily tests for fishermen and their daily catches.

Shanghai has extended its weekly Covid-19 test requirement and extended free testing until the end of September.

site_title: World Cup ticket sales approach 2.5 million, organisers say
summary: Qatar's World Cup ticket sales have reached 2.45 million, with over half a million tickets sold in the latest sales period. The most popular games for ticket sales include Brazil's group-phase encounters and Portugal's meeting with Uruguay. More than a million visitors are expected in Qatar, a tiny Gulf state with 2.8 million inhabitants, for the first World Cup in the Middle East.

site_title: Ferrari Daytona SP3: The 2m-euro slice of revenge
summary: Ferrari's Daytona SP3, a limited-edition sports car, is a modern interpretation of the brand's 330 series of impossibly sensual racing cars. Built from carbon fibre, the SP3 boasts a 6.5-litre V12 engine with 845 horsepower. With a price tag of €2 million, the car is exclusive and sought after by Ferrari loyalists. The SP3's design pays homage to Ferrari's historic sportscars, evoking the sensations of the past without being physically exhausting. The car's unique features, such as its unblemished body and features that exploit airflow, make it a standout among modern supercars.

images.alt_text: The EQS is the first Mercedes designed from the outset as an electric vehicle.

site_title: Bursa Malaysia’s planned carbon exchange still leaves regional room for Singapore’s Climate Impact X
summary: Bursa Malaysia plans to launch a voluntary carbon market by the end of the year, aiming to address domestic needs for carbon offsets and support Malaysia's goal of becoming carbon-neutral by 2050. The market will enable companies to buy carbon credits and achieve climate targets, and will also provide an opportunity for Malaysia to develop carbon projects. While Bursa Malaysia's market may enjoy a natural scale advantage due to its proximity to Malaysia's vast natural resources, Singapore's Climate Impact X (CIX) remains a competitor in the regional market, with potential to position itself as a regional hub.

images.alt_text: Bursa Malaysia building in Kuala Lumpur . (Bloomberg)
"Carbon credits are not going to be exported. No question," said Raj Kumar Singh, Indian Minister of Power and Minister of New and Renewable Energy.
Some 46 countries worldwide are now pricing carbon through trading schemes or taxes, covering around a third of emissions, according to the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Japan’s bid to get young to drink more meets online backlash
summary: Japan's tax agency has launched a campaign, "Sake Viva!", to encourage young people to drink more and boost the country's struggling liquor industry, which has seen a decline in sales due to health-conscious consumers and changing tastes. The campaign has met fierce backlash on social media, with users criticizing the taxman for dictating people's lifestyle choices and contradicting health ministry guidance on moderate drinking. The move aims to promote the industry and encourage growth, but its effectiveness is uncertain amidst rising inflation and a shrinking population.

site_title: Twelve reasons to love California chardonnay
summary: California chardonnay, the state's most popular white grape, has long been polarizing among consumers. The style has shifted from lush and full-bodied to fresher and more refined, with many producers prioritizing finesse over power. This change in style is largely due to consumer perception and the wine's widespread availability in supermarkets and restaurants. While some still prefer the older, more powerful style, the new trend is gaining popularity, offering a fresh take on the classic California chardonnay.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ Jason Haas of Tablas Creek Vineyard, who has assailed the state of glass recycling in the U.S., which does far worse than Europe, at the vineyard in Paso Robles, Calif., Aug. 7, 2021. Glass bottles for wine have never been more of a problem than they are today, at a time of global trade disruptions and climate crisis. (Daniel Dreifuss/The New York Times)

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, August 18, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.54 points to 1,516.62. 2.513 billion lots worth RM1.951 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 486 to 364.

site_title: Xi highlights drought risk in China as power supplies threatened
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has warned of a severe drought threatening electricity supplies and economic growth in northern provinces, particularly Liaoning. Low water levels have damaged crops and caused property damage, with some factories in Sichuan province curbing production due to impacted hydropower generation. Xi reiterated China's commitment to opening its economy despite global challenges, pledging to coordinate Covid controls and economic development. Water levels in the Yangtze River, China's largest waterway, have fallen to the lowest level for this time of year, exacerbating the drought risk.

site_title: China regulator probes banks’ property loan exposure: sources
summary: China's banking regulator is investigating property sector loan portfolios to assess systemic risks amid the ongoing property sector turmoil. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) is scrutinizing banks' loan book exposure to developers to determine if credit decisions followed rules. The probe aims to measure risks to the financial system and comes as policymakers try to stabilize the property sector, which accounts for a quarter of China's economy, following a string of defaults and a slump in home sales.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine Q3 revenue up 140% on shipyard, ship chartering growth
summary: Marco Polo Marine reported a 139.5% year-over-year increase in revenue for its third quarter, driven by growth in ship repair activities, stronger demand from customers, and increased capacity following the completion of dry dock extension works. Gross profit rose 185.3% to S$9.7 million, with both shipyard and ship chartering segments experiencing "tremendous growth". The group expects a strong finish to the year, citing rising demand from customers for both segments, particularly in the offshore windfarm sector.

images.alt_text: The integrated marine logistics company's bottomline growth mainly attributed to operational improvements as well as higher gross profit margins.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Tencent shares ‘very undervalued’ as earnings poised for turnaround
summary: Tencent shares have been deemed "very undervalued" by senior equity analyst Ivan Su, with a fair value estimate of HK$741, representing a 60% upside. The technology and entertainment firm is expected to deliver a "rapid bounceback" following better-than-expected Q2 results, driven by improvements in revenue contribution from video accounts and cost structure efficiency. Analysts expect year-on-year revenue and adjusted earnings growth to start in the next quarter, with a low single-digit percentage impact from gaming licence approvals in China.

images.alt_text: Tencent, which owns 17 per cent of Meituan, has been engaging with financial advisers in recent months to work out how to execute a potentially large sale of its Meituan stake.
Tencent Holdings logged its first-ever decline in quarterly revenue, becoming the latest victim of a worsening Chinese economy.
Tencent Holdings chief strategy officer James Mitchell said a report that the company intends to sell all or much of its US$24 billion stake in food delivery giant Meituan was incorrect.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: China is encouraging developers to build homes for rent as part of President Xi Jinping's "Common Prosperity" vision. The country's first publicly traded rental property Reits were recently snapped up by investors in Shanghai and Shenzhen, providing a new financing channel for the struggling real estate sector. This move aims to increase housing affordability and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Vietnam orders tech firms to store user data onshore
summary: Vietnam's government has ordered technology firms to store user data locally, with the goal of tightening cybersecurity rules. The decree, set to take effect on October 1, requires social media companies and telecommunications operators to store data domestically. Authorities will have the right to issue data collection requests and remove content deemed to violate guidelines. Foreign firms have 12 months to set up local data storage and representative offices, with a minimum 24-month storage requirement. This move is part of Vietnam's efforts to maintain tight media censorship and control.

site_title: Art Jakarta returns after pandemic hiatus
summary: Indonesia's largest art fair, Art Jakarta, is returning after a 2-year partial hiatus due to the pandemic. The event is expected to see strong sales, driven by pent-up demand and the revival of economic activities. The fair features participation from international galleries and visitors, offering a platform for Indonesian artists to showcase their work. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, some artists have successfully monetized their work through non-fungible tokens, while others have focused on making better art or taking on alternative jobs. The event is expected to attract a large audience.

images.alt_text: Singapore Biennale 2022 will be led by co-artistic directors (from left) June Yap, Nida Ghouse, Ala Younis and Binna Choi.
Magnus Resch
National Gallery Singapore's new show Famila

site_title: UK consumer spending drops as inflation hit intensifies
summary: UK consumer spending on credit and debit cards dropped 7% over the past week, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). This decline is attributed to intensifying inflation. Spending is now at 97% of its pre-pandemic level in February 2020. The ONS reported that consumer behavior indicators showed mostly falling or stable activity. The decline in spending reflects the impact of rising inflation on consumer spending habits.

site_title: Oil rises as bullish US demand weighs against recession fears
summary: Oil prices rose as investors weighed concerns about a global economic slowdown against bullish US demand signals. West Texas Intermediate climbed 1.1% to over $89 a barrel, while Brent jumped 1.4% to almost $95 a barrel. Despite fears of a recession, a bullish Energy Information Administration report showed US crude stockpiles sank, exports rose to a record, and petrol demand climbed to the highest this year. Opec's new secretary-general expressed confidence in demand increase this year, while analysts noted the market appears "slightly too bearish" on demand.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled at US$1.31, or 1.42 per cent higher at US$93.65 per barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Koh Boon Hwee to be SGX chairman from Jan 1
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) announced that Kwa Chong Seng will step down as chairman on Dec 31, 2022, and Koh Boon Hwee will take over as chairman on Jan 1, 2023. Koh was appointed to the board in March this year and has extensive experience, including as Nanyang Technological University's longest-serving chairman. Kwa Chong Seng's contributions to SGX have been recognized, and he expressed confidence in Koh's ability to lead the exchange to even greater heights.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's Med247 raises US$4.5m from Koh Boon Hwee-led fund, biotech Mirxes
SGX will look at possibility of online voting at its future meetings

site_title: Tee International to issue new shares worth S$7.5 million, proposes debt restructuring
summary: Tee International has entered into a conditional subscription agreement with Meta5 to issue new shares worth S$7.5 million. This follows a previous plan to raise up to S$14 million that fell through. The company also proposes a debt restructuring and will issue new shares to its key management team and RSM Corporate Advisory. Proceeds will be used to repay eligible creditors, fund business growth, and provide working capital. The new subscription shares are expected to represent around 52% of the enlarged share capital.

images.alt_text: TEE International’s earlier plans to raise up to S$14 million through new share subscription and issue has fallen through after its 2 investors decided not to proceed with the proposed investor transaction, it said in an announcement on SGX on Tuesday (Aug 2).
Still, the bottom line was shored up by in gains on the de-recognition of subsidiaries upon loss of control.
Tee International to wind up Trans Equatorial Engineering on cash flow issues

site_title: Philippine central bank hikes rates by 50 basis points, keeps hawkish view
summary: The Philippine central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, raised its benchmark interest rates by 50 basis points to 3.75% and 4.25% for the overnight deposit and lending facilities, respectively. The move aims to bring inflation back within the 2-4% target range, amid a near 4-year high inflation rate of 6.4% last month. Governor Felipe Medalla stated that further monetary action is necessary to anchor inflation expectations and steer inflation towards a target-consistent path over the medium term.

images.alt_text: In the Philippines, retail investors are a massive source of financing and the government raised US$8.2 billion in March, equivalent to a fourth of its local borrowing program this year.

site_title: Swiss watch exports at near record levels as industry booms
summary: Swiss watch exports rose 8.3% in July to 2.2 billion Swiss francs, the highest value in 8 years, driven by strong demand for luxury brands like Rolex, Omega, and Vacheron Constantin. Exports to the US and China rebounded, with the US becoming the largest market after overtaking China last year. Exports of watches under 200 francs increased 5.3% due to the success of the Omega MoonSwatch collaboration, while those priced over 500 francs accounted for 95% of value, with 33% of volumes.

site_title: India’s macro stability outlook improving: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley's chief India economist Upasana Chachra says India's worst period of macro instability is behind it, with moderation in inflation and trade deficit expected to be gradual. Consumer inflation is forecast to rise to 7% in August before moderating, while the trade deficit is expected to peak at $30 billion in July. Lower commodity prices and tax rollbacks on petroleum products are expected to improve the trade balance trend, according to Chachra.

site_title: Eurozone government bond yields rise after Schnabel remarks
summary: Eurozone government bond yields rose on Thursday after ECB board member Isabel Schnabel expressed concerns about inflation, suggesting another large interest rate increase is likely. Schnabel stated the inflation outlook has failed to improve since a July rate hike, fueling fears of consumer price acceleration. German 10-year bond yields jumped 5 basis points to 1.128%, while US Treasury yields edged higher, and Italy's 10-year bond yield rose to 3.36%, its highest since July 28.

site_title: Design out of the box
summary: A unique inter-terrace home, dubbed "Raclette House" due to its round windows, has been designed to foster family bonding. Architect Paul Yeo tackled the challenges of the typical inter-terrace house design by incorporating circular windows and light wells to increase natural light. The unconventional features, such as a free-form first floor and a communal space on the second floor, have resulted in a one-of-a-kind home that exceeds its clients' expectations. Despite initial apprehension, the homeowners now appreciate the unique design, which has become a standout in the neighborhood.

site_title: Pretty Faces
summary: Three luxury watch brands, Tag Heuer, Moritz Grossman, and IWC, have released new timepieces that emphasize the aesthetic appeal of their dials. Tag Heuer's Carrera Red Dial 3 features a crimson dial with a 39mm stainless steel case, while Moritz Grossman's Date Turquoise boasts a turquoise dial with a jumping date display and guilloche finish. IWC's Portugieser Automatic and Chronograph models showcase a panda dial design with contrasting white and blue hues, improving legibility and giving them a distinctive appearance.

images.alt_text: The Aquaracer Professional 200 is slimmer than previous models.

site_title: Philippines plans first retail bond under Marcos presidency
summary: The Philippines plans to sell its first retail bonds since Ferdinand Marcos Jr. became president, aiming to raise at least $7 billion. The government will sell 30 billion pesos (S$742.2 million) of bonds due in 2028 and allow existing holders to exchange debt for new securities. The sale is expected to limit downside on local yields and may help push yields lower in the long term. This move comes as the government plans a record spending spree to boost the nation's recovery from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) lifted the overnight reverse repurchase facility rate to 3.75 per cent.

site_title: OCBC expects fledgling electric vehicle loan business to more than triple by year-end
summary: OCBC Bank expects its electric vehicle loan business to more than triple by year-end, reaching over 250% growth. The bank has seen significant demand for EV loans since launching in March 2021. OCBC teams up with NUS to study consumer behavior and nudge adoption rates. The bank's EV loan rate is 2.18% per year, with up to 9 months of free charging, compared to 2.48% for petrol or diesel cars.

images.alt_text: Motor insurance is big business in Singapore, and insurers have to enter the electric vehicle market eventually, said experts.
Outgoing SMU chairman Ho Kwon Ping (right) and his successor Piyush Gupta

site_title: Fine wagyu goes casual at Gyu San
summary: Gyu San, a new butchery-eatery in Singapore, offers a wide range of wagyu cuts, exceeding 55 prime cuts, and serves Japanese sandwiches, including fat ribeye sandos and sukiyaki sets. The restaurant, led by chef Tomoyuki Kiga and French-trained female butcher Linh Lam, aims to democratize premium wagyu by providing high-quality meat in a casual setting. Gyu San sources directly from farms, offering three brands, including Kamichiku, Kanzaki, and Hida Gyu, with prices ranging from S$20 to S$43.90 per 100g.

images.alt_text: Artisanal wagyu comes to Singapore

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Thursday with a 0.80% decline, or 158.54 points, to 19,763.91, following a sell-off across world markets due to concerns over rising interest rates. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with declines of 0.46% and 0.26%, respectively. The losses were attributed to Federal Reserve minutes that fueled fears of prolonged interest rate hikes to combat inflation.

site_title: Singapore insurers should embrace smart technology
summary: Singapore insurers can benefit from adopting smart technology to streamline the insurance purchase process, reducing current protection gaps in the country. The current process involves lengthy paperwork and can be time-consuming, leading to frustration among customers. Smart technology can help reduce this gap by automating risk classification, providing on-the-spot underwriting decisions, and using regulatory technology to simplify the application process. Additionally, it can facilitate direct electronic bank transfers, hyper-personalisation, and goal simulation, ultimately making the insurance buying process easier and more efficient.

images.alt_text: Single-premium products are seeing sustained growth and remain popular among Singaporeans.
Gleneagles Hospital operating theatre. Integrated Shield plans for private hospital cover will cost more this year.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower after Fed minutes, local jobs data
summary: Australian shares ended 0.2% lower at 7,112.80, tracking global equities weakness due to US Federal Reserve minutes suggesting more rate hikes and mixed local jobs data. Gold stocks were the top percentage losers, plummeting 3.8%. Investors' sentiment was also dented by unexpected employment growth contraction.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.4 per cent to 7,102.8 by 0022 GMT on Wednesday and was on track to snap a three-day rally.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index fell 0.96% to 28,942.14, closing lower on Thursday, August 18, 2022. The decline follows falls on Wall Street, as investors locked in profits. The broader Topix index also ended down 0.82% at 1,990.50.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians reflected on an electronic stock board outside a securities firm in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, June 9, 2017. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi

site_title: American Airlines bets on supersonic travel with Boom jet deal
summary: American Airlines has agreed to buy up to 20 supersonic jets from Boom Supersonic, becoming the second major US airline to invest in ultra-fast passenger travel. The deal, valued at about $26 billion, brings Boom's order book to 130 aircraft. The 4-engine Overture jet can fly from Miami to London in under 5 hours, cutting flight time by about half. The aircraft, designed to run on sustainable aviation fuel, is expected to start carrying passengers in 2029. The deal follows United Airlines' similar agreement last year, with American having an option to purchase 40 more jets.

images.alt_text: The cuts come after the carrier this week detailed plans to trim flight capacity as much as 10 per cent this quarter and 9.5 per cent for the year from pre-pandemic levels.

American Airlines has reported an adjusted profit of 76 US cents a share for the quarter till June in line with analysts’ expectations. It generated US$13.42 billion in revenue, topping Wall Street estimates.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mainly dip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined at the open on August 18, following overnight losses in Tokyo and on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.2% to 7,497.88 points, while the Paris CAC 40 dropped 0.1% to 6,520.45 points. Frankfurt's DAX edged up 0.1% to 13,640.88 points. The declines were attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade tensions also in focus.

site_title: Jalan Besar freehold coffee shop up for sale at S$28m guide price
summary: A 2-story freehold coffee shop in Singapore's Hoa Nam Building is up for sale at a guide price of SGD 28 million. The coffee shop, located near Farrer Park and Bendemeer MRT stations, occupies 4,510 square feet and has F&B approvals on both levels. Foreigners and companies are eligible to purchase, with no additional stamp duties. The asset class is seen as attractive due to its resilience during the pandemic and current recovery in the food and beverage sector, with 1,650 upcoming HDB build-to-order units in the vicinity.

site_title: Hot stock: iFast up as much as 11%, cites Hong Kong e-pension news as possible reason
summary: Shares of iFast Corp, a wealth management platform, surged 11.1% on Thursday, triggering a query from the Singapore Exchange. The surge is attributed to an article by the South China Morning Post on Aug 15 announcing the award of a tender for Hong Kong's Mandatory Provident Fund's e-pension platform to PCCW Solutions. iFast had previously participated in the tender as PCCW's prime subcontractor. The company stated that the article may have triggered investors to focus on its expected revenue growth.

images.alt_text: iFast is also in talks with potential buyers for “parts” of its India associate’s business, and hopes to “recoup something back” from the exit although the loss will still be significant, Lim said.

site_title: China’s first publicly traded rental property Reits snapped up by investors
summary: China's first publicly traded rental property REITs were oversubscribed 100 times among institutional investors in Shanghai and Shenzhen, raising a combined 3.8 billion yuan (S$770 million). The REITs, focused on affordable rental properties, were launched as part of President Xi Jinping's "Common Prosperity" vision. This move aims to aid the struggling real estate sector, which has been impacted by debt piles, mortgage boycotts, and sluggish sales. The REITs provide a new financing channel for the sector, offering yield-hungry investors a chance to invest in rental properties.

images.alt_text: Country Garden has been engulfed by the sector’s unravelling following regulatory crackdowns and pandemic restrictions that have pummelled housing sales.
The support from the state comes amid mounting concerns that a deepening debt crisis and defaults in the sector could impact property developers that have been regarded as financially sound.

site_title: China’s Geely Automobile first-half profit slumps 35%
summary: China's Geely Automobile Holdings reported a 35% slump in first-half net profit to 1.55 billion yuan, citing Covid-19 restrictions and semiconductor shortages. Vehicle sales fell 9% in the first half, below management expectations. Revenue rose 29% to 58.18 billion yuan, driven by better product pricing and product mix. Geely's new energy vehicle sales increased nearly fourfold, while electric vehicles accounted for one-fifth of total sales. The company expects sales to be pressured by competition and rising raw material costs through the end of 2022.

images.alt_text: With the launch, Geely becomes the second major automaker to have an allied space business.

site_title: Myanmar to import Russian oil, military says
summary: Myanmar plans to import Russian petrol and fuel oil to ease supply concerns and rising prices amid a global energy crisis. The country, under military rule, has maintained friendly ties with Russia, despite sanctions from Western countries. Fuel oil shipments are due to start arriving from September, and Myanmar may consider joint oil exploration with Russia and China. The military has set up a Russian Oil Purchasing Committee to oversee fuel imports at reasonable prices, aiming to reduce fuel prices that have surged 350% since the coup in February last year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares track Wall Street lower, won touches 1-month low
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.33% on Thursday, tracking a decline in US stocks, with the benchmark Kospi ending at 2,508.05 points. The won touched a 1-month low, while the 3-year treasury bond yield rose 4.5 basis points to 3.133%. The US Federal Reserve indicated little evidence of easing inflation pressures, leading to concerns over excessive monetary tightening. Heavyweights Samsung Electronics and LG Energy Solution were among the few gainers, while SK Hynix and other peers fell. Foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 310.2 billion won.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index fell 0.2 per cent to 7,497.88 points.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 0.96 per cent, or 280.63 points, to 28,942.14.

site_title: Bluebird’s US$2.8m gene therapy becomes most expensive drug after US approval
summary: The US FDA approved bluebird bio's gene therapy for beta-thalassemia, a rare disorder requiring regular blood transfusions, priced at a record US$2.8 million. The treatment is for the sickest patients, estimated to be up to 1,500 in the US, who need transfusions every 2-5 weeks. Despite a potential risk of blood cancer, studies showed no cases. The approval sent the company's shares 8% higher, making it the most expensive drug in the US.

images.alt_text: The US FDA said on Tuesday (Aug 16) it had received 48,000 reports associated with breakdown or suspected breakdown in the foam used in Philips respirators over the 3 months ending Jul 31, 2022.

site_title: High inflation a boon for healthcare plays: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research suggests that healthcare plays will benefit from high inflation due to inelastic demand, allowing them to pass on higher costs to consumers. Analyst Rachel Tan notes a moderate positive correlation between the Consumer Price Index and the healthcare index, citing Raffles Medical as a proxy, which outperformed the Straits Times Index during high inflation periods. DBS maintains buy ratings on IHH Healthcare and Raffles Medical, with target prices of RM7.90 and S$1.64, respectively. However, Tan warns that private healthcare spending may be seen as a luxury during economic downturns.

images.alt_text: Dr Loo Choon Yong, says that   RMG, having continued to build capabilities in the past year, is well-positioned to serve returning international and local patients as pandemic measures ease.
Gleneagles Hospital operating theatre. Integrated Shield plans for private hospital cover will cost more this year.

site_title: China’s biggest builder warns core profit could plunge 70%
summary: China's largest builder, Country Garden Holdings, warned that its first-half earnings could plummet 70% due to regulatory crackdowns and pandemic restrictions. Preliminary core profit is expected to be 4.5-5 billion yuan, down from 15.2 billion yuan last year. The developer has been engulfed by the sector's unravelling, losing its investment-grade rating after Fitch Ratings downgraded it to junk. Country Garden's housing sales have been severely impacted by the restrictions, contributing to the expected earnings decline.

images.alt_text: The support from the state comes amid mounting concerns that a deepening debt crisis and defaults in the sector could impact property developers that have been regarded as financially sound.
The focus on finishing stalled projects, rather than ensuring developers have access to greater liquidity condition, will also limit the effectiveness of the policy, some investors say.

site_title: IMF needs to be bold on Ukraine
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) should support Ukraine amid the ongoing Russian invasion, despite concerns about risks and debt sustainability. Ukraine needs $5 billion monthly to carry out basic functions, and the IMF can play a critical role in bringing together macroeconomic reforms and financing into a sustainable plan. The IMF has a mandate to support countries facing conflict and political uncertainties, and a traditional program is consistent with its mandate. The Fund should have skin in the game and contribute financing to avoid donor resources financing forthcoming Ukrainian repayments to the IMF.

images.alt_text: People line up to visit the presidential secretariat in Colombo on July 11, 2022, after it was overrun by anti-government protestors.
Ukrainian President Zelenskiy renewed his call for European Union states to ban visas for Russian nationals to keep the bloc from becoming a “supermarket” open to anyone with the means to enter.

site_title: Sri Lanka keeps rate steady as past hikes seen enough
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 15.5% as policymakers assess the impact of past hikes on inflation. Despite expecting inflation to remain elevated, the bank noted a slower pace of price gains in July compared to recent months. Headline inflation accelerated to 61% in July, but the central bank expects consumer price growth to moderate going forward. The decision aims to balance the impact of monetary and fiscal policies on the economy amid an unprecedented crisis.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, OUE Commercial Reit
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 13.2% increase in its half-year net profit to S$232.7 million, from S$205.6 million last year. OUE Commercial Reit completed a S$978 million unsecured sustainability-linked loan to refinance existing debt, increasing its unsecured debt to 70.2% on a pro forma basis. These developments may impact trading of their securities.

site_title: Tesla shortens delivery waiting time for Model Y in China to 4-8 weeks
summary: Tesla has reduced the delivery waiting time for the Model Y in China to 4-8 weeks, down from 8-12 weeks. The company has completed a major upgrade of its Shanghai plant and is increasing weekly production to 22,000 units of Model 3 and Model Y. This improvement aims to meet growing demand in the Chinese market.

site_title: South-east Asia markets slip after Fed minutes rattle traders, but STI bucks trend
summary: South-east Asian markets fell on Thursday, August 18, following the release of the US Federal Reserve's July minutes, which signaled more interest rate hikes to tackle high inflation. The minutes indicated policymakers are committed to raising rates to tame inflation, even acknowledging the risk of tightening too much and overly curbing economic activity. The Singapore market, however, bucked the trend, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.3% higher, while the Jakarta Composite Index rose 0.7%.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
London's benchmark FTSE 100 index gained 0.4 per cent to 7,535.71 points.
London’s FTSE 100 was up almost 0.1 per cent at 7,541.33 points despite official figures showing inflation surging to 10.1 per cent last month, a fresh 40-year high.

site_title: HSBC, Citigroup and the end of global banking
summary: HSBC and Citigroup, two of the world's largest banks, are scaling back their global ambitions, shifting focus to core markets. HSBC has reduced its global footprint to 64 countries from 88, while Citigroup has exited 13 markets and is selling its Mexican business. This marks a significant shift from their previous strategies, which aimed to build a presence across Asia, North America, and Europe. The move is attributed to the decline of globalization and the rise of regional trading blocs, as well as stricter post-crisis regulations and declining profitability in outposts.

images.alt_text: HSBC’s largest shareholder Ping An Insurance will press on with its call for the bank to spin off its Asia operations despite pushback from executives.

site_title: Bank of America’s overdraft fees plunge 90% after charges eased
summary: Bank of America has seen a 90% decline in overdraft fees after implementing changes to its services, including eliminating non-sufficient funds fees and reducing overdraft charges to $10 from $35. The move comes after lawmakers and consumer activists criticized the fees, which they say "snatch billions from struggling families". The bank expects consumer overdraft fees to fall 97% next year from their 2009 level. Other major banks, such as Capital One and Citigroup, have also cut or eliminated overdraft fees.

images.alt_text: Bank of America has been fined 5.1 million euros (S$7.2 million) for delays in reporting voting rights notifications.

Wall Street investment bankers, who were neck-deep in deals last year, have seen activity slump in the first half of 2022 amid volatility in the capital markets, geopolitical tensions and a risk-off sentiment that has swept across markets globally.

site_title: Investment bank behind 32,000% IPO probed by Hong Kong regulator
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) is investigating AMTD Group, the investment bank behind a 32,000% IPO that stunned Wall Street, over deals it arranged in the Asian financial hub. The probe, which predates the US listing of AMTD Digital, focuses on small-cap IPOs underwritten by AMTD Group, including those of IntelliCentrics Global Holdings and China Bright Culture Group. The SFC is looking into underwriting arrangements and allegations of market manipulation. AMTD Group has helped arrange at least 62 IPOs in Hong Kong and the US, and its CEO, Calvin Choi, is appealing a separate SFC decision to ban him from the securities industry for 2 years.

images.alt_text: In the next 2 years, AMTD Group, its founder and chairman of AMTD Group Calvin Choi (pictured) and the executive officers of AMTD Idea Group have undertaken that they will not sell any of their owned shares in AMTD Idea Group in the open market.

AMTD Group chairman Calvin Choi has seen his fortune rise with AMTD Digital's soaring share price, but is also under increasing scrutiny as Hong Kong financial regulators seek to ban him from certain regulated activities for 2 years.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as investors digest Federal Reserve minutes; jobs data in focus
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.4% to 7,102.8 on Thursday, snapping a three-day rally, amid concerns over the US Federal Reserve's commitment to raising interest rates to combat inflation. The July employment figures will provide insight into the country's labor market, while weak gold prices and tech stocks contributed to the decline. Energy stocks rose 1% as crude prices recovered on strong export demand, but individual stocks like Origin Energy slumped 6.6% due to uncertainty around its earnings.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3 per cent to 7,127.70. The benchmark rose 0.6 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as Federal Reserve minutes cause fresh rate hike woe
summary: Asia's markets plummeted on Thursday as the Federal Reserve's minutes revealed policymakers intend to keep raising interest rates to combat inflation. Despite expectations of a potential slowdown in rate hikes by 2023, the minutes indicated rates will remain elevated "for some time." Tokyo, Hong Kong, and other Asian stocks fell, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, Shanghai, Seoul, Taipei, Wellington, and Manila stocks all down in midday trading. The sell-off was fueled by concerns about the impact of interest rate hikes on the economy.

images.alt_text: Tokyo climbed 1 per cent as GDP data showed the Japanese economy recovering after the government lifted Covid-19 curbs on businesses.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades Sea to ‘hold’ on dimmer Shopee prospects
summary: Research firm CGS-CIMB downgraded Sea's stock to "hold" from "add" due to weaker-than-expected Shopee's gross merchandise value (GMV) outlook, citing inflation, forex headwinds, and slower monetisation push. The downgrade comes after Sea suspended FY2022 revenue guidance for Shopee. However, CGS-CIMB remains optimistic about Sea's gaming segment and digital financial services segment, which it believes will drive growth. The firm lowered its price target to US$92 from US$150.

The central bank cut interest rates, while local governments plan to sell more bonds to boost spending. Economists warn of a power supply crunch and rising Covid cases, making a comprehensive stimulus package unlikely, and expect further downgrades in forecasts.

summary: Hundreds of families in New Zealand's South Island were evacuated due to severe flooding caused by a tropical storm that dumped over 30 cm of rain. summary: RBNZ Governor Adrian Orr apologized for the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's role in high inflation, acknowledging that monetary policy was too loose during the pandemic. Core inflation is currently at 4-6%, and Orr urged lawmakers to wait for the 5-yearly review of monetary policy, which is expected to conclude before the end of the year. The RBNZ raised the Official Cash Rate by a half percentage point to 3% and plans to further tighten to reach 4% by early 2023, aiming to return to its 1-3% target by mid-2024.

summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.93% to 28,949.75, and the Topix index losing 0.76% to 1,991.64. The decline followed US losses, with investors locking in profits after recent market gains.

site_title: Gold gains as dollar, yields retreat after Fed minutes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,765.89 per ounce, as the dollar slipped 0.1% against its rivals and US Treasury yields edged lower to 2.8822%. The US Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes hinted policymakers may be less aggressive on future rate hikes, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest bearing gold. Spot silver eased 0.2% to $19.80 per ounce, while platinum and palladium also changed. The retreat in the dollar and yields made gold less expensive for buyers holding other currencies.

summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.35% at the open, driven by minutes from the Federal Reserve indicating a possible slowdown in interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Hang Seng Index reached 19,991.94, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.19%. The news boosted investor sentiment, but global markets were also affected by US-EU trade tensions and declining stocks in Europe.

site_title: More winners than losers from Indonesia’s US$206b budget
summary: Indonesia's $206 billion budget prioritizes fiscal discipline and value-added goods production, shifting the economy away from raw materials. The budget is expected to boost commodities firms, such as mining companies and palm oil producers, with analysts predicting gains of up to 40% for Vale Indonesia. The healthcare sector is expected to be the least favored, with lower spending on public health. The budget's focus on fiscal discipline and infrastructure spending is also expected to boost market sentiment, despite concerns about a possible US recession.

site_title: FDA says faulty Philips device reports accelerating as CEO departs
summary: The US FDA reported a significant increase in faulty Philips respirator and sleep apnea machine reports, with 48,000 associated with breakdown or suspected breakdown of foam parts over the past three months. This is more than twice the number of reports received in the same period last year. Philips CEO Frans van Houten is departing the company, and the FDA has criticized the company's communication on the recall. Analysts warn that the company faces a credibility issue and potential financial risks, with Philips shares down 1.1% following the announcement.

site_title: US, Taiwan to start formal trade talks under new initiative
summary: The US and Taiwan agreed to start formal trade talks under the US-Taiwan Initiative on 21st-Century Trade, with the aim of reaching agreements with "economically meaningful outcomes". This move follows the Biden administration's exclusion of Taiwan from its Asia-focused economic plan, and comes as the US seeks to counter China's growing influence. The first round of talks is expected to take place in early autumn.

summary: Hong Kong has introduced climate-disclosure guidelines requiring fund managers to integrate environmental, social, and governance factors into their investments. The rules, set to take effect on August 20, apply to funds with at least HK$8 billion in assets under management. Smaller funds face a challenge in complying with the new requirements, but some expect it will attract new clients seeking ESG assets. The move follows similar regulations in the European Union and Singapore, as Hong Kong aims to become carbon neutral by 2050 and cut emissions in half by 2035.

site_title: More Japanese firms are raising wages to combat labour shortage: poll
summary: More Japanese companies are raising wages to combat labor shortages, a trend seen as a tentative sign that Japan Inc is addressing decades of flat pay. In a Reuters poll of 495 big non-financial firms, 44% said they would increase wages, up from 25% in 2017. The move comes as labor shortages worsen due to a declining population and aging workforce, prompting companies to adopt measures such as digitalization and better working environments to attract workers.

site_title: Big 3 delivery platforms launch own industry association
summary: Singapore's three largest delivery platforms, Deliveroo, foodpanda, and Grab, have formed the Digital Platforms Industry Association to strengthen frameworks, guidelines, and policies for platform workers and merchants. The association aims to tap into industry expertise, provide upskilling opportunities, and strengthen health and safety standards. It will also launch an industry code of practice and collaborate with government and industry bodies to identify areas of improvement and promote platform worker welfare. The move comes amid growing debate over platform worker welfare and follows recent consultations with government bodies and the National Delivery Champions Association.

site_title: India may delay coal plant closures in blow to climate action
summary: India's government is considering delaying the closure of ageing coal-fired power plants, potentially stalling efforts to hit climate goals. The nation aims to use only half of its electricity generation capacity from clean fuels by 2030, but plans to expand its coal power capacity to over 250 gigawatts over the next decade. This move contradicts its goal to build 500 gigawatts of clean power capacity by 2030 and could hinder investments in clean power projects. The decision would keep fossil fuel capacity higher for years and hinder climate action.

summary: OUE Commercial Reit has successfully refinanced its existing secured borrowings with a S$978 million unsecured sustainability-linked loan, which is 1.26 times oversubscribed. The loan, syndicated by 19 banks, will support the Reit's debt repayment until September 2023 and increase the proportion of unsecured debt to 70.2% on a pro forma basis. This is the largest sustainability-linked loan extended to a Singapore Reit to date, with the average term of debt lengthening to 3.2 years and weighted average cost of debt expected to remain stable.

summary: China's local governments are expected to sell more bonds in coming months to fund infrastructure projects due to squeezed government finances. Fiscal income has declined due to Covid lockdowns and a property market slump, with revenue from land sales and deed taxes plummeting 32% and 28.3% respectively. Local governments have room to issue an additional 1.55 trillion yuan in special debt and bonds, and may bring forward next year's quota to the fourth quarter of this year. This move aims to support infrastructure investment and mitigate the impact of a liquidity crisis among property developers.

site_title: US consumers show signs of resilience despite raging inflation
summary: US consumers are showing resilience despite raging inflation, with retail sales excluding price adjustments rising 0.7% in July, beating expectations. Key retailers like Walmart and Target are preparing for a healthy shopping season this fall, with consumers focusing on essential goods and services. The data suggests the Federal Reserve has more work to do in tempering demand, and the American consumer's resilience is remarkable given global economic headwinds, including China's slowing economy and Europe's potential recession.

summary: Netflix is planning to launch an ad-supported tier by early next year, which will not allow users to download shows and movies for offline viewing. This move aims to distinguish the ad-supported tier from its regular service, potentially to upsell users to higher-end tiers. The launch is part of Netflix's efforts to compete with rival services like Disney's Hulu and HBO Max, which already offer ad-supported tiers.

Recession worries and concerns over rising Russian output and exports were partially alleviated by the demand data.

summary: Invest Fair, an annual investment event, is set to return as a physical event on Aug 27, featuring topics on borderless investing. The event, themed "Investing in this Borderless Era", will cover rising interest rates and unprecedented inflation globally. Keynote speakers include experts from Knight Frank, The Smart Investor, and Phillip Securities Research, and will be joined by panellists from SGX, CIMB Private Banking, and UOB. Admission to the event is free.

Customers dine in a restaurant in Batangas City, Philippines, on Tuesday, March 8, 2022. site_title: Yellen sets 6-month timeline for IRS plan to target tax cheats
summary: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has set a 6-month timeline for the Internal Revenue Service to develop a plan detailing how it will use $80 billion in enforcement funding over the next decade. The plan aims to modernize the agency's outdated information-technology system, clear a backlog of tax returns, and boost services for taxpayers. The focus will be on targeting high-income earners and identifying complex evasion schemes, with no additional funding for middle-class households earning less than $400,000 annually. The IRS will also need to replace 50,000 retiring workers.

images.alt_text: Janet Yellen, U.S. Treasury secretary, speaks during an interview at the National Association of Business Economics (NABE) annual meeting in Arlington, Virginia, U.S., on Tuesday, Sept. 28, 2021. Yellen today warned that her department will effectively run out of cash around Oct. 18 unless Congress suspends or increases the federal debt limit, putting pressure on lawmakers to avert a default on U.S. obligations.
