site_title: China will step up policy support for economy, Li tells state media
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang announced the country will step up macro-economic policy support for the economy after growth unexpectedly slowed in July. Data showed factory and retail activity were squeezed by the zero-Covid policy and a property crisis. Authorities will thoroughly implement a package of policy measures unveiled in May, increasing the intensity of macro-economic policies to keep economic activity within a reasonable range. The government will also boost consumption and expand effective investment.

site_title: Retail firms still need to improve non-wage perks to draw workers, say industry watchers
summary: Retail firms in Singapore will face increased costs with the introduction of the Progressive Wage Model (PWM), which sets a minimum monthly gross salary of S$1,850 for retail workers starting September 1. Industry watchers say that while the wage hike alone may not be enough to attract locals, employers must also offer flexible work arrangements, career progression, and other non-wage perks to retain workers. The higher salaries could lead to increased costs for employers, which may be passed on to consumers, but economists believe the impact on overall inflation will be small in the near term.

images.alt_text: The new wage increases under the Progressive Wage Model will benefit more than 46,000 full-time and part-time resident retail employees.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq slip at open as retail earnings kick off
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened lower on August 16, 2022, as investors assessed earnings reports from Walmart and Home Depot amid concerns of a slowing global economy. The Dow Jones rose 0.04%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq declined 0.16% and 0.35%, respectively. This marks the start of retail earnings, which will continue to influence market sentiment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., August 8, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Gas surges further as Europe’s summer misery keeps piling up
summary: European natural gas prices surged as a scorching summer and hot river water levels exacerbated an energy crisis, with benchmark futures rising 11% and electricity prices reaching a record. Russian gas giant Gazprom predicted prices could reach 347 euros per megawatt-hour if the trend continues, amid a standoff over a Nord Stream pipeline turbine. Energy prices in Europe have been soaring since Russia cut gas supplies, and LNG cargoes are becoming increasingly difficult to secure due to high demand in Asia.

images.alt_text: A cargo vessel sails along a single navigable channel on the River Rhine in Kaub, Germany. An extended dry spell in the area, which is on a key hard-coal import route, risks choking Germany's energy supply further, stoking power-price volatility and elevating costs for coal-heavy generators.

site_title: China publishes draft rules on sales of ‘mystery boxes’
summary: China's market regulator has published draft rules governing the sales and marketing of "mystery boxes", which contain unknown toy figurines. The rules, set to be open to public comment until August 30, require sellers to set fair prices and encourage rational purchasing. Companies cannot sell mystery boxes to customers under 8 years old, and those selling to minors must obtain guardian permission. The move aims to bring order to a market that has seen buying frenzies.

site_title: Ikea to liquidate Russian unit as part of sanctions-led pullout
summary: Ikea has decided to liquidate its Russian unit, Ikea Dom, after shutting down its stores in March and reducing its workforce. The decision comes as part of a larger pullout from Russia due to sanctions following the invasion of Ukraine. Ingka Group, Ikea's owner, had previously stated it was open to returning to Russia but deemed the conditions not suitable. The move marks another significant exit by a major international brand from the Russian market.

site_title: Cloud hangs over US chipmakers on worries data centre growth could slow
summary: US chipmakers face concerns that cloud and data center growth may slow due to slower annual cloud revenue growth rates reported by Big Tech companies. Analysts attribute this to a prolonged economic downturn, 40-year-high inflation, and advertisers tightening their purse strings. The cloud market's recession-proof status is uncertain, and the sector's growth may be impacted by economic signals. This could be a challenge for chipmakers, which have relied on the cloud and data centers as a strong sector during the COVID era.

images.alt_text: 3D printed clouds and figurines are seen in front of the AWS (Amazon Web Service) cloud service logo in this illustration taken February 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Cooling property market could signal weaker construction demand ahead
summary: Singapore's property market is cooling, signaling potential weaker construction demand ahead. Despite improved earnings for construction companies due to relaxed Covid-19 restrictions, investors should look beyond current high earnings. Companies such as Chip Eng Seng and Lian Beng Group reported increased profits, while material suppliers like Pan-United Corporation and BRC Asia also saw gains. However, real estate agencies Apac Realty and PropNex reported declines in earnings and transaction volumes due to property cooling measures and softening demand. This weakening sentiment may impact the construction industry, with developers showing caution for large private residential development sites.

images.alt_text: Workers placing a pre-fabricated block onto the building at the Kim Keat Beacon BTO construction site on 3 March 2020.

site_title: Russia fights efforts to declare it an exporter of ‘blood diamonds’
summary: Russia is resisting efforts by the US and other countries to label its diamonds as "conflict diamonds" due to their sale potentially funding Russia's aggression in Ukraine. The US and Western nations claim that proceeds from Russian diamond mining contribute to Russia's war efforts, citing Russia's invasion of Ukraine. However, Russia objects to the labeling, calling it "political demagoguery," and argues that its diamond mining operations adhere to environmental, social, and governance standards. The Kimberley Process, an international organization aimed at preventing conflict diamonds, is considering the issue, but a consensus decision is difficult to reach due to geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Russia - which invaded Ukraine 4 months ago - holds a 33 per cent stake in Alrosa, which accounted for about 30 per cent of the world’s diamond output last year.

site_title: Asia’s manufacturers, suppliers could be unlikely winners of landmark US climate bill
summary: Asia's clean-energy industry, including Asean countries, could benefit from the US$430 billion climate and tax bill, despite protectionist language. The bill includes incentives for electric vehicles, renewable energy, and clean-hydrogen production, which could drive demand for Asian manufacturers and suppliers. Analysts predict that companies in North Asia, such as Japan and Korea, will benefit the most from the increased spending on power, industrial, and transportation projects. However, some analysts, like Pictet Asset Management's Jennifer Boscardin-Ching, suggest that the legislation may not provide significant upsides for Asian companies that solely export to the US.

images.alt_text: The House voted 220-207 along party lines to pass the measure titled the “Inflation Reduction Act” and send it on to Biden to sign into law. The Senate approved the legislation on Sunday after a marathon, 27-hour session.
Biden said he will sign the new massive investment plan, passed by Congress, into law next week.
The new credits favour companies, like Tesla and General Motors, that have been selling electric cars for years and have reorganised their supply chains to produce vehicles in the United States.

site_title: First post-blockade food aid ship leaves Ukraine for Africa
summary: The Brave Commander, a UN-chartered ship, has left Ukraine's port of Pivdennyi with over 23,000 tons of wheat, bound for Ethiopia as the first humanitarian food aid cargo since Russia's invasion. This shipment is part of efforts to increase food supplies for Africa's socially vulnerable population. The UN and Turkey brokered a deal last month to unblock Ukraine's Black Sea ports, allowing grain exports to resume. The World Food Programme (WFP) has procured 60,000 metric tons of wheat and expects the ship to reach its destination in two weeks.

site_title: Sea’s Q2 2022 revenue growth fails to stem widening losses
summary: Sea Ltd reported a 29% jump in Q2 2022 revenue to $2.9 billion, driven by Shopee and digital financial services. However, losses widened by 114.7% to $931.2 million, primarily due to increased costs and expenses. Shopee's adjusted Ebitda loss per order improved 21%, while digital entertainment segment revenue declined 12%. Sea suspended e-commerce guidance and shifted focus to efficiency and optimization for long-term sustainability. Despite this, shares closed up 1.42% on Monday.

site_title: US manufacturing production accelerates in July
summary: US manufacturing production increased 0.7% in July, exceeding expectations, driven by strong demand for goods and a rebound in motor vehicle plants. This marks a contrast to declining business confidence, with retailers holding excess inventory, particularly apparel. Despite this, manufacturing remains supported by its 11.9% share of the US economy.

site_title: Explosions shake Russian-held Crimea, Ukraine hints at role
summary: Explosions shook a Russian-held ammunition depot and disrupted trains in Crimea, Ukraine, on Tuesday, August 16, 2022. The incident, which also injured two people, has raised speculation about Ukraine's potential capability to strike deeper into Russian territory. The region, a key supply line for Russia's war in Ukraine, has seen multiple incidents in recent weeks, including blasts at a military air base. Ukraine has hinted at involvement, while Moscow has denied any cause for the explosions, which could disrupt Russia's ability to support troops in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The Middle East Eye news site cites a shipping agent as saying that a Turkish buyer has been found for the maize on board the Sierra Leone-flagged vessel Razoni.

site_title: UK pauses overseas aid payments amid overspend concerns
summary: The UK government has temporarily paused overseas development aid payments of £1 million or more due to concerns about overspending, following Russia's war in Ukraine. The freeze, which is expected to last until a new prime minister takes office in the fall, will halt payments for non-essential activities and new contracts. The move comes as the government seeks to repair its budget deficit, having previously slashed its aid budget to 0.5% of gross national income.

site_title: Thai central bank sees no surge in bad loans after policy rate hike
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) expects no surge in bad loans despite a 25-basis-point interest rate hike, citing sufficient debt support measures. Non-performing loans (NPLs) stood at 2.88% of total lending at the end of June, slightly down from 2.93% at the end of March. The BOT urges banks to gradually adjust their rates to help vulnerable groups, including low-income earners and smaller businesses, which are a concern. The banking system remains resilient with high capital, loan-loss provisions, and liquidity.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 14.77 points to 1,518.78. 2.693 billion lots worth RM2.216 billion were traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 469 to 399.

site_title: Toyota suspends operations at Sichuan plant due to power shortage
summary: Toyota has suspended operations at its joint venture plant in Chengdu, China's Sichuan province, until Saturday due to a power shortage. The move follows a province-wide electricity conservation order amid its worst heatwave in 60 years. Other industries, including fertilizer and metal production, have also been affected, with some shutting down or reducing output. The power shortage is a result of Sichuan's efforts to conserve electricity and mitigate the impact of the heatwave.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong expects Singapore's inflation to peak in Q4 and stabilize, driven by geopolitical, supply chain, and sustainability factors. Regional co-working firms merged to form The Flexi Group, aiming for an IPO. A distressed crypto platform, Hodlnaut, has applied for judicial management in Singapore. ThaiBev and Frasers Property launched a joint venture with a potential 2.2 billion baht investment. Singapore stocks fell for the second consecutive day, with the STI dipping 0.1%.

site_title: US housing starts decline to lowest since early 2021
summary: US housing starts declined 9.6% in July to a 1.45 million annualized rate, the lowest since early 2021, according to government data. This follows a revised 1.6 million pace in June. Applications to build, a proxy for future construction, also declined 1.3% to 1.67 million. The decline is attributed to builders adjusting to a pullback in demand and an increase in inventory.

site_title: Food bills rise as UK inflation hits highest level since 2008
summary: UK grocery prices have reached an 11.6% increase in the past 4 weeks, the highest level since 2008, with the average annual shop expected to rise by £533. Shoppers are opting for own-label products and store brands, with Asda's Just Essentials accounting for a third of its customers' baskets. Supermarkets are struggling with surging energy and fuel costs, as well as escalating wage bills, and are facing a challenge to maintain consumer loyalty amid the worst inflation in 40 years.

site_title: Don’t kill share buybacks
summary: Critics of share buybacks claim they divert resources from employees, investments, and R&D, but research shows buybacks' price impact is minimal, and companies use them for market timing. Deterring buybacks may lead companies to hoard cash or spend it wastefully, disrupting the alignment of interests between executives and long-term investors. A proposed 1-per cent stock buyback tax and ban on corporate executives selling company shares may not address the issue of price manipulation, and could actually create incentives for companies to increase dividends or pay executives more.

The buyback comes as Swire reported a 38 per cent increase in underlying profit to HK$1.7 billion in the 6 months ended Jun 30, mostly due to smaller losses at Cathay Pacific Airways., where it is the largest shareholder.

site_title: 'Too big for Australia', says pension fund eyeing global expansion
summary: Australia's largest pension fund, AustralianSuper, plans to quadruple in size to A$1 trillion within a decade, aiming to become a global investment powerhouse. The fund, which currently manages A$260 billion, wants to invest up to 70% of its capital offshore to avoid performance drag. CEO Paul Schroder says the organization is "too big for Australia" and considers itself a global investor with domestic beneficiaries. The fund aims to achieve this goal despite facing challenges such as inflation and economic disruption.

images.alt_text: The Sydney Opera House and city centre skyline are seen in Sydney, Australia, February 28, 2020. REUTERS/Loren Elliott/File Photo - RC208P95C6QA

site_title: Thai instant noodle makers seeking first price hike in 14 years
summary: Thai instant noodle makers, five domestic producers, are seeking a price hike of 2 baht (S$0.07) to 8 baht (S$0.23) per pack, the first price increase in 14 years. The companies have been selling their benchmark packs for 6 baht (S$0.23) each since 2008 due to rising costs, including surging wheat and palm oil prices. If approved, the price hike will offset losses in the home market and prevent the companies from exporting more noodles to offset losses.

images.alt_text: Instant noodle store an unlikely hit with Thai youth

site_title: Japan's Mizuho Securities looking at opportunities for US growth
summary: Mizuho Securities, the brokerage arm of Mizuho Financial Group, is exploring opportunities for growth in the US market, with CEO Yoshiro Hamamoto stating that the firm has room for further growth. The US business accounts for a third of the Japanese brokerage's profit and has been the highest-ranked Asian firm in US investment banking league tables for the first half of the year. Acquisitions are one option being considered to drive growth, following the firm's success in investment banking and trading.

images.alt_text: Mizuho Financial Group’s main banking unit plans to boost financing for startup firms, its chief executive said, aiming at addressing Japan’s scarcity of valuable new companies.

site_title: China unveils new perks aimed at boosting slowing birth rate
summary: China has announced various perks to encourage families to have more babies, amid a record-low birth rate and warnings that the population will shrink by 2025. The country has seen a rapidly aging workforce, slowing economy, and weakest population growth in decades since ending its "one-child rule" in 2016. Despite allowing couples to have three children last year, birth rates have slipped over the past five years, prompting the government's new measures to address the looming demographic crisis.

images.alt_text: China's uncompromising “zero-Covid” policy of promptly stamping out any outbreaks with strict controls on people’s lives may have caused profound damage on their desire to have children, demographers say.

site_title: Time to turn commitments on saving the world’s oceans into actions
summary: Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs, Vivian Balakrishnan, emphasized the need for urgent action to protect the world's oceans and mitigate climate change at the recent UN Ocean Conference in Lisbon. The minister stressed the importance of international cooperation, data-driven decision-making, and multilateral agreements to address ocean conservation and plastic pollution. Over 150 countries collectively agreed to scale up science-based actions to address the ocean emergency, with nearly 700 commitments registered, following a successful conference that highlighted critical issues and generated new ideas and commitments.

images.alt_text: Safeguarding the world’s oceans will be fundamental to tackling global warming, US climate envoy John Kerry told AFP on Tuesday.

site_title: Crypto hacks soar as North Korea targets DeFi
summary: Cryptocurrency hacks have surged this year, with around $1.9 billion stolen in hacks through July, a 58% increase from the same period in 2021. Decentralized-finance protocols, particularly cross-chain bridges, have become a target for attackers due to their reliance on open-source code. North Korea-affiliated groups have stolen approximately $1 billion of cryptocurrency from DeFi protocols this year. While illicit activity in other areas of crypto has decreased, hacks continue to pose a significant threat, with no indication of reversing the trend.

site_title: Zinc surges as Trafigura-owned smelter to halt production
summary: Zinc prices surged 7.2% on the London Metal Exchange after Trafigura-owned smelter Nyrstar announced it would halt production from September 1 due to Europe's energy crisis. The move follows warnings from top zinc producer Glencore that the crisis poses a substantial threat to supply. Local LME stockpiles have fallen to near zero, and analysts expect capacity juggling and potential imports to meet demand. The energy crisis affects not only Europe but also China, with soaring temperatures and power crunches impacting aluminum production.

Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Cycle & Carriage were among the top gainers, while DBS, UOB, and OCBC were among the biggest losers. summary: A Chinese military survey ship, Yuan Wang 5, docked at Sri Lanka's Hambantota International Port on August 16, 2022, raising tensions between India and China amid concerns over Beijing's expanding influence in the region. The 99-year lease on the port, which China holds, has deepened Sri Lanka's bind navigating two giant rivals. The docking request comes as Sri Lanka struggles to pull the country out of virtual bankruptcy. Indian leaders have grown increasingly alarmed by China's presence in the region, sparking concerns about regional stability.

summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 1.05% to 19,830.52, marking the latest losses. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Wall Street bonuses are too small for many
summary: Wall Street bonuses remain too small for many employees, exacerbating pay disparities and increasing the risk of mistakes. A widening pay divide is attributed to office politics and the focus on top performers, leaving mid-level employees feeling undervalued. The lack of "skin in the game" can lead to a lack of motivation and oversight. As banks continue to prioritize high-performing employees, they risk losing experienced staff, particularly those in their 40s, who are often pushed out to make way for younger, less expensive talent.

site_title: China supports several private developers with bond guarantee: sources
summary: China's state-owned China Bond Insurance Co will provide guarantees for onshore bond issuance by several private property developers, including Longfor Group and CIFI Holdings, amid concerns about a deepening debt crisis and defaults. The support aims to protect financially sound developers from potential defaults. Shares of Longfor, CIFI, and Country Garden surged over 15% following the news, with the Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index rising 9.2%. China Bond Insurance Co will provide "full amount, unconditional and irrevocable joint liability guarantee" to medium-term notes issued by these developers.

site_title: 3 APAC co-working firms merge, eye IPO
summary: Three APAC co-working firms, The Hive, Common Ground, and The Cluster, have merged to form The Flexi Group, aiming for an initial public offering (IPO). The merger was backed by Singapore-based Catcha Group and Malaysia's Emissary Capital. CEO Chris Edwards sees the fragmented co-working industry as an opportunity for consolidation and expansion, with plans to add up to 100 locations in the next three years. The Flexi Group has 45 locations across 12 cities and 9 countries, taking an asset-light approach by partnering with landlords on joint ventures.

site_title: Founders of Singapore rubbish collector 800 Super close to sale deal: sources
summary: The founders of Singaporean rubbish collector 800 Super Waste Management, Lee Koh Yong and Lee Hock Seong, are nearing a deal to sell the business valued at around US$300 million. Private equity firm KKR & Co and Australia's Macquarie Asset Management are among the final bidders. KKR funded 800 Super's 2019 management-led buyout and owns a minority stake in the company. The sale could close as early as this month, with 800 Super having expanded its services and secured contracts with major clients such as Changi Airport Group and Marina Bay Sands.

site_title: Tencent plans to divest US$24b Meituan stake: sources
summary: Tencent Holdings plans to divest its US$24 billion stake in Chinese food delivery firm Meituan, a move aimed at appeasing domestic regulators and monetizing an 8-year-old investment. The 17% stake, worth US$24.3 billion as of August 15, is part of a broader effort by Tencent to reduce holdings and book profits amid a regulatory crackdown on technology giants. The sale is expected to be executed via a block trade in the public market and may be completed within the year if market conditions are favorable.

site_title: Bill Gates, South Korea expand global health partnership
summary: Bill Gates and South Korea agreed to expand their global health partnership, strengthening private and public sector cooperation in projects such as a global health research fund and vaccine production. The partnership aims to develop high-quality bio-health technologies and increase aid to lower-income countries. South Korea will train 2,000 people in vaccine production annually starting 2026, while Gates called for increasing funding for health groups and scaling up international aid to 1.3% of GDP. The partnership is seen as a response to the "crisis moment" for global health, with Gates stating it will provide new tools and resources to help those in need.

site_title: Indonesia president proposes US$206b budget for 2023
summary: Indonesia's President Jokowi proposed a 2023 budget of 3,041.7 trillion rupiah (US$206 billion), with a 2.85% deficit, the smallest since 2019. The budget aims to consolidate fiscal positions after large pandemic-era deficits, with a 5.3% economic growth target and inflation management at 3.3%. The proposal reinstates a 3% GDP deficit ceiling, waived during the pandemic, and includes assumptions for a stable exchange rate and bond yield.

images.alt_text: As head of the G20 this year Jokowi, as the president is known, has taken an increasingly active role in foreign affairs.

site_title: China facing power supply threat from drought in Sichuan
summary: A severe heat wave and drought in Sichuan province, China's most populous region, is threatening the province's power supply and economic growth. Water flows into hydropower reservoirs have dropped by 50% since the start of the month, curbing hydropower generation and impacting factories, including those producing polysilicon and lithium essential for the energy transition. The drought is primarily a threat to power generation, but could also affect river and coastal shipping, and has already caused power shortages and production curbs at major manufacturers like Foxconn and Volkswagen.

site_title: Crypto platform Hodlnaut applies for judicial management in Singapore
summary: Hodlnaut, a distressed cryptocurrency platform, has applied to the Singapore High Court for judicial management to avoid a forced liquidation of its assets. The company aims to prevent selling users' cryptocurrencies at depressed prices. Hodlnaut halted user withdrawals, token swaps, and deposits on August 8 and has withdrawn its application for a Major Payment Institution licence. Judicial management provides a moratorium, shielding the company against legal claims and proceedings. The company will provide an update on August 19 on its judicial management process.

site_title: Central banks play important role in building social capital
summary: Central banks play a crucial role in building social capital by fostering trust, stability, and predictability in the economy. Effective communication, accountability, and transparency are key to achieving this. Rebuilding social capital requires addressing emerging risks, such as digitalization and climate change, and implementing financial reforms, including completing the Basel reforms and developing a macroprudential framework. Central banks must also promote financial literacy and inclusion to reinforce social capital and demonstrate their credibility as institutions.

site_title: Inflation in Singapore expected to peak in Q4 and stabilise: Lawrence Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong expects Singapore's inflation to peak in Q4 and stabilize thereafter, with rates potentially settling at a higher level due to the geopolitical environment and supply chain issues. The government has already taken measures to dampen inflation and support vulnerable households, including a S$1.5 billion support package. Wong also mentioned that the government is concerned about the impact on economic growth next year and will continue to monitor the situation closely.

site_title: The Mar-a-Lago quandary
summary: The FBI searched former President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate, retrieving 20 items and boxes, including 11 sets of classified documents. The search was approved by Attorney General Merrick Garland, who defended it as a "faithful adherence to the rule of law." The incident raises concerns about Trump's behavior and potential obstruction of justice charges, which could be "legally and politically explosive." Republicans are criticizing the search as politically motivated, while Democrats may face challenges in defending the action amidst the mid-term elections.

summary: Indonesia's energy minister Arifin Tasrif announced the government is reviewing a potential fuel price hike, with a decision expected to be made soon. The review is part of revising a presidential regulation on subsidized fuels distribution. Tasrif stated that the government needs time to communicate the plan to the public.

site_title: Malaysia top court rejects Najib’s bid to add evidence in appeal
summary: Malaysia's highest court dismissed former Prime Minister Najib Razak's second bid to add new evidence in an appeal against his conviction in a case linked to 1MDB. The court ruled there's no basis to suggest a conflict of interest in the employment of the judge who initially convicted Najib. Najib faces 12 years in jail and RM210 million in fines if he fails in his final appeal. His legal team had requested to add evidence, but the court rejected the request, leaving Najib's conviction intact.

site_title: Buy now, pay later firms switch from Gen Z shoppers to businesses
summary: BNPL companies, such as Klarna and Afterpay, are shifting their focus from Gen Z shoppers to businesses, targeting the $700 billion industry of short-term loans for companies. Startups like Billie and Mondu offer BNPL solutions to businesses, allowing them to split payments into instalments, and may gain market share from traditional banks due to their ability to move faster and offer more flexible credit products. Despite valuation declines, these firms believe they can win over market share in the B2B sector, particularly in Europe and the US.

site_title: UK’s hot labour market cools and inflation eats pay
summary: The UK's hot labor market has shown signs of cooling, with the unemployment rate remaining unchanged at 3.8% in the 3 months to June, close to a half-century low. However, wages fell by record 2.5% in the same period due to soaring inflation. This comes despite Bank of England warnings that the economy is likely to slip into recession later this year. The number of people in work grew by 160,000, but less than expected, indicating a slowdown in hiring.

site_title: S-E Asia spends US$3.7b on bubble tea in 2021, Indonesia tops list: report
summary: The South-east Asian bubble tea industry reached a $3.7 billion market in 2021, with Indonesia leading with a $1.6 billion turnover. Thailand followed with $749 million, and Singapore came in fourth with $342 million. Despite high margins, few players have achieved continuous profitability. Chinese brands are entering the market, posing competition to local players. The industry's growth is driven by consumers' love for bubble tea, with Singapore consumers having the highest purchasing power.

site_title: Why the growth-inflation trade-off is lower than you think
summary: Asia's inflation is more moderate than previously thought, driven by cost-push factors rather than strong aggregate demand. Commodity prices have fallen, and core-goods inflation has peaked, with demand-supply balances being restored. Labour market conditions are not tight, and wage growth is still below pre-Covid trends. As a result, the interest rate threshold needed to bring inflation under control is lower than expected, with most of the region's economies expected to have inflation within their central banks' comfort zones by Q2 2023, leading to a more manageable growth slowdown.

site_title: A bull navigating a China shop
summary: China's economy, despite being under-represented in global indices and equity portfolios, holds long-term opportunities due to its structural growth drivers and unique positioning. The People's Bank of China's accommodative monetary policy and government initiatives support a gradual reopening and infrastructure development. However, investors face geopolitical and sovereign risk premia, and recent volatility in Chinese equities may persist. A selective approach to investing in China, focusing on policy beneficiaries, reopening plays, and infrastructure-related industries, is recommended. Long-term investors should tolerate short-term volatility and focus on access to longer-term growth in China.

These efforts aim to reinvent giving by going beyond monetary sponsorships to improve the lives of Singaporeans.

site_title: Unique selling points underpin the enduring love for Singapore homes
summary: Singapore's unique selling points for home ownership, including control and the government's efforts to grow the economy, may contribute to its enduring popularity. Investors can also consider alternative options, such as real estate investment trusts (Reits) and shares of established property groups, which may offer higher yields and lower risks. As Singapore's safe-haven status grows, the pool of interested buyers may expand, supporting capital appreciation and liquidity.

site_title: Sri Lanka collapsed first, but it won’t be the last
summary: Sri Lanka's economic collapse is attributed to a Western-dominated neoliberal system that keeps developing countries in debt-fuelled colonization. The country's debt problems were exacerbated by former president Gotabaya Rajapaksa, but the economy was structurally unsound across administrations. Sri Lanka is just the canary in the coal mine, and the pain will be widespread as other countries face similar peril. Around 60% of low-income nations and 30% of middle-income ones are in debt distress or at high risk, with big economies like Europe and the US also suffering.

site_title: UK job vacancies fall in early sign labour market may weaken
summary: The UK job market has shown a decline in job vacancies for the first time since August 2020, with 19,800 fewer positions available as of July. This marks an early sign that the labour market may be weakening due to the ongoing cost-of-living crisis and inflation. The number of jobs created in the second quarter was 46% less than the previous quarter, and wages excluding bonuses and adjusted for inflation fell by 3% in June, the largest drop since records began in 2001. This easing of the labour market tightness may prompt the Bank of England to continue raising interest rates.

summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo hailed his country's growing global stature, stating it has reached the "pinnacle of global leadership." He was the first Asian leader to meet with Ukrainian and Russian counterparts, and Indonesia has been accepted as a "diplomatic bridge" between the two nations. site_title: Philippines’ key rate to rise to 4% this quarter, survey shows
summary: The Philippine central bank is expected to raise its benchmark interest rate by another 75 basis points to 4% by the end of September, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) and Frasers Property have established a 50:50 joint venture (JV) company in Thailand, Must Be Company Ltd, with an initial registered capital of 50 million baht. site_title: Why it is hard to lose when you invest in stocks
summary: Investing in stocks can be challenging, but the likelihood of success increases with a longer time horizon. Contrary to popular misconceptions, short-term trading is not the key to winning big. Instead, investing for the long term can yield positive returns. According to historical data, the S&P 500 outperforms bonds 60-92% of the time over 1-30 year periods. Successful investors focus on "good longs" or stocks that can be held for the long term, and develop skills such as financial statement analysis and investor psychology. By adopting a long-term approach and being a lifelong learner, investors can increase their chances of success and apply valuable skills to other areas of their lives.

summary: Pandora, the world's largest jewellery maker, is launching a collection of lab-made diamonds in North America, marking its transition away from mined diamonds. The collection, featuring 269 stores in the US and Canada, aims to attract younger shoppers with cheaper and more sustainable stones. Lab-grown diamonds have seen demand growth and price decreases relative to natural-mined diamonds, with the average polished price declining to 30% of natural prices. site_title: RBA signals further rate hikes, reiterates not on pre-set path
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) signaled further interest-rate hikes in the period ahead to combat spiraling consumer prices, joining global counterparts in tightening policy. The RBA expects to normalize monetary conditions, but will adjust the pace based on economic data and inflation outlook. The cash rate has been raised to 1.85% with potential future hikes, aiming to keep the economy balanced. Despite weakening consumer confidence, the RBA expects domestic demand to hold up due to low unemployment and pandemic-era savings.

site_title: South Korea to supply 2.7m homes over 5 years
summary: South Korea's new government plans to supply 2.7 million new homes over the next five years, including 500,000 in the Seoul area, a 50% increase from previous years. This aims to address a short supply in high-demand cities, blamed for price rises. The government will provide financial and administrative advantages to young people and lower-income earners when buying or renting homes. This move follows President Yoon Suk Yeol's promise to increase home supply in high-demand areas, criticizing his predecessor's policy.

site_title: Angel investors building portfolios, not just passively investing: AngelCentral report
summary: A report by AngelCentral found that angel investors in South-east Asia are predominantly male, aged 41-55, and invest mainly out of their net worth rather than income. 59% invested in over 5 startups, with 12% having a portfolio of over 30 startups. The typical first cheque size is between $20,000-$50,000. Most expect a high return on investment, with 41.3% aiming for over 25% internal rate of return. Angel investors also diversify their investments across asset classes and are actively involved in learning and interacting with founders, but rarely in the operational aspects of the startups.

site_title: HRnetGroup expands to Kaohsiung, commits S$1m to grow flexi staffing business
summary: HRnetGroup, a recruitment and consulting business, has expanded to Kaohsiung, Taiwan, with a new branch under its subsidiary RecruitFirst (Taiwan). The company has committed S$1 million to grow its flexible staffing business, RFT, which has achieved a 113% compound annual growth rate in revenue. This expansion aims to capitalize on existing strengths and serve clients in Kaohsiung with call centre operators, technicians, and engineers.

site_title: EU denounces Myanmar’s ‘unjust’ sentencing of Suu Kyi
summary: The European Union's foreign policy chief Josep Borrell condemned Myanmar's "unjust" sentencing of Aung San Suu Kyi to 17 years in jail following her latest conviction. Suu Kyi faces additional 6 years for corruption, bringing her total jail time to 23 years. Borrell called for her immediate release and urged the Myanmar regime to release all political prisoners and respect the people's will. Suu Kyi, a Nobel laureate, was detained after the 2021 coup, which sparked widespread protests and unrest in the country.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.33% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 66.28 points to 20,107.14, driven by weak US data that may prompt the Federal Reserve to slow interest rate hikes. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains.

site_title: Chipmakers’ pandemic boom turns to bust with recession looming
summary: The semiconductor market is experiencing a significant downturn, with chipmakers facing a record-setting decline in sales and a growing inventory surplus. The industry's boom during the pandemic has given way to a painful pullback, driven by a weakening global economy and a decline in demand from major customers such as automakers and personal computer makers. The sector is also seeing increased competition from governments subsidizing domestic production, which could disrupt the drive towards efficiency and lead to overinvestment in production capacity. Despite this, executives remain bullish on long-term demand, with some predicting the industry will reach $1 trillion in total revenue by the end of the decade.

site_title: Asia exports slip into deeper downturn as tech boom goes ‘plop’
summary: Asia's export boom is showing signs of a deeper-than-expected downturn, according to HSBC Holdings and Nomura Holdings' research notes. The trade surge that powered Asia through the pandemic is at a turning point, with key indicators showing a slump in new orders for made-in-Asia electronics. This signals a slowdown in global growth, with Asia often serving as a bellwether for global economic trends.

site_title: Terra founder Do Kwon says he ‘never’ has been in touch with South Korea authorities
summary: Terra co-founder Do Kwon denies having contact with South Korean authorities, stating in a taped interview that no charges have been filed against him. Despite South Korean prosecutors raiding the home of Terraform Labs co-founder Daniel Shin and requiring Kwon to notify authorities upon return, no arrests have been made. Kwon expressed willingness to cooperate when the time comes, saying "Life is long" in response to potential jail time. Authorities have banned current and former Terra employees from leaving the country, but no further details on the investigation have been disclosed.

site_title: Russia, planning to go it alone, unveils model of new space station
summary: Russia's national space agency Roskosmos unveiled a model of its planned space station, dubbed "ROSS," which will be launched in two phases, with the first phase starting in 2025-26. The station, designed to accommodate up to 4 cosmonauts and scientific equipment, will not have a permanent human presence but will be staffed twice a year. Russia's decision to abandon the International Space Station (ISS) comes as the country seeks to reduce its dependency on Western nations and forge ahead on its own, amid ongoing tensions with the West over sanctions and a military operation in Ukraine.

site_title: ESG funds face SEC probe over ceding votes on social issues
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating whether managers of sustainable investment funds are trading away their right to vote on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues by lending out shares to other firms. The probe aims to determine if firms are making proper disclosures to investors and meeting their promise of helping combat societal ills. The SEC has set up a task force to focus on the issue, which has led to concerns over greenwashing and the environmental and societal benefits of investments being exaggerated.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower while Wall Street rally continues; STI down 0.2%

The STI dropped despite positive global market trends, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.5% and the S&P 500 climbed 0.4%. European shares hovered near two-month highs, and Asian markets followed suit, with Tokyo shares up 0.55% and the Nikkei 225 index at 28,703.65.

site_title: Snap reaches 1 million premium subscribers in bid for new revenue
summary: Snap, the parent company of Snapchat, has reached 1 million subscribers for its Snapchat+ premium subscription, a new source of revenue. The subscription, launched in June, costs $3.99/month and offers 11 exclusive features, including new app icon designs and increased message visibility to celebrities. This move aims to diversify revenue streams for the company, which faces a weakening ad market due to inflation. The service is expanding to 25 markets, including Saudi Arabia, India, and Egypt.

site_title: India inflation may remain elevated despite July dip: analysts
summary: India's consumer inflation decreased to 6.71% in July, primarily due to slower increases in food and fuel prices. However, analysts predict the inflation rate will remain above the central bank's upper tolerance range, necessitating further interest rate hikes in the coming months. Nomura economists forecast inflation to remain around 6% until February 2023, with core CPI inflation expected to stay sticky at 5.9% for the remainder of the fiscal year.

summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group exceeded quarterly revenue estimates, driven by a surge in paying music users to 82.7 million and a 18% increase in music subscription revenue. summary: BHP, the world's largest miner, posted its highest-ever full-year profit of $23.8 billion, driven by record commodity prices. Despite pressure from competitors, the company aims to capitalize on opportunities in clean energy and electric vehicle supply chains. BHP plans to expand its iron ore production to 330 million tons and assess options to boost copper and nickel volumes. The company expects China to remain a stable source of demand for commodities, and will continue to assess growth opportunities, including a new potash mine in Canada set to begin production in 2026.

site_title: Apple sets return-to-office deadline of Sept 5 after Covid-19 delay
summary: Apple sets a Sept 5 deadline for corporate employees to work in the office at least three days a week, shifting from its original plan of Mondays, Tuesdays, and Thursdays. The new policy requires employees to work from the office on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and a regular third day determined by individual teams. This marks Apple's latest return attempt after Covid-19 spikes delayed its plans several times, following previous two-day-a-week schedules.

site_title: JPMorgan, BofA are among banks moving back into Russian bond trading
summary: Several major Wall Street banks, including JPMorgan Chase & Co and Bank of America, are resuming trading in Russian bonds, despite US sanctions. Barclays and Jefferies Financial Group have also offered bids to investors. site_title: China needs more stimulus to boost growth, PBOC paper says
summary: China's economic growth is expected to slow, and the country needs more stimulus to boost growth, according to Financial News. The People's Bank of China unexpectedly cut policy interest rates, and authorities should focus on expanding domestic demand, stabilizing employment, and prices. New pro-growth policies, fiscal stimulus, industrial policies, and local property market measures are crucial to drive the recovery. The youth unemployment rate hit a record 20%, highlighting the pressure to stimulate growth and maintain stability. China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers to implement effective stimulus measures.

This move aims to compete with Amazon's Prime, which has around 200 million subscribers. Walmart+ membership costs $12.95/month or $98/year and already offers free shipping and discounts. site_title: UK labour shortages see mass of food go to waste

summary: South Korea's labor shortage has led to an increase in elderly workers in the workforce, as firms scramble to find labor. Unemployment has hit a near-record low of 2.9%, forcing companies to widen their search for workers. Younger Koreans are reluctant to take up blue-collar jobs, and the pandemic has diminished the pool of foreign labor, leading to the hiring of older workers in factories, despite less-than-ideal working conditions. This trend is expected to continue as companies face a persistent labor crunch.

summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.3% on Monday, near two-month highs, as investors turned to defensive sectors amid signs of a slowing Chinese economy. Healthcare stocks, including AstraZeneca's 2.3% gain, and food and beverage stocks led gains, while China-exposed automakers and miners fell. Investors await euro zone flash GDP and inflation data, and US retail sales data, amidst concerns of a possible recession and inflation.

site_title: BP is exiting its Mexican oil assets in shift towards renewables
summary: BP is exiting its Mexican oil assets as part of its shift towards renewable energy, following a challenging political climate in the country. The company has sold off its participation in exploration contracts or is returning the blocks to the National Hydrocarbons Commission. BP's decision comes amid a rise in nationalism and a reduction in competition with private players, and is part of a broader trend among oil majors to reduce their carbon footprint and invest in renewables.

site_title: Thailand targets 2.2 trillion baht investment in industrial east over 5 years
summary: Thailand aims to attract 2.2 trillion baht (S$85.3 billion) in investments in its industrial east over the next 5 years through the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) plan. The 2023-2027 plan includes investments in electric vehicles and medical technology, with the government expecting 400-500 billion baht in annual investments. This is expected to boost the economy's growth rate to 5% per year from 2024, surpassing the current 2018-2022 plan's 1.8 trillion baht investment.

site_title: Iran says to deliver ‘final’ nuclear talks proposal on Monday
summary: Iran's foreign minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian announced that Tehran will deliver its "final" proposal to revive the 2015 nuclear accord with world powers on Monday, following Washington's acceptance of key demands. The US had verbally accepted two demands from Iran, and if the proposal is accepted, Iran is ready to conclude and announce the accord at a meeting of foreign ministers. The talks, which began in April 2021, aim to curb Iran's nuclear program in return for sanctions relief.

site_title: Oil settles lower on weak economic Chinese economic data
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Monday after disappointing Chinese economic data renewed concerns of a global recession, reducing fuel demand. Brent crude futures dropped 3.1% to $95.10 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 2.9% to $89.41 a barrel. The Chinese central bank cut lending rates to revive demand, but the country's refinery output slipped to a 12-month low. Weak Chinese data and a potential increase in US dollar value also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Heathrow extends capacity curbs until end of October
summary: Heathrow airport has extended its daily capacity cap of 100,000 departing passengers until October 29 to support "more reliable and resilient passenger journeys." The measure, introduced to address a prolonged labour shortage at ground-handling firms, has led to fewer last-minute cancellations, better punctuality, and shorter wait times for bags since its implementation. The cap may be lifted early if staffing levels improve, but it may remain in place through next summer.

site_title: Retail investors temper optimism, but interest in meme stocks remains high
summary: Retail investors are pulling capital out of higher-risk equities and crypto platforms, shifting to steady stocks as optimism wanes. Despite this, interest in meme stocks like Palantir and Tesla remains high, with some brokerages reporting continued interest in these stocks. Trading volumes have decreased, but some platforms, such as Tiger Brokers and moomoo, have seen higher trading volumes year on year, with investors piling into these stocks despite concerns over valuation.

site_title: Saudi prince made US$500m Russia bet at start of Ukraine war
summary: Saudi Arabia's Kingdom Holding invested over $500 million in Russian energy companies Gazprom, Rosneft, and Lukoil between February and March, despite Western sanctions on Russia following its invasion of Ukraine. This move may have been an attempt to acquire undervalued assets, but it contradicts the country's stated neutral stance on the conflict. The investment highlights Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal's risk-taking approach to investing and Kingdom Holding's focus on new opportunities.

site_title: Nexstar to buy CW Network from Warner Bros Discovery, Paramount
summary: Nexstar Media Group is acquiring a 75% stake in the CW Network from Warner Bros Discovery and Paramount Global. Nexstar already owns many CW affiliates and will retain the network's original scripted content producers, Warner Bros Discovery and Paramount Global retaining 12.5% of the business each. The purchase underscores Nexstar's commitment to traditional broadcasting amidst the shift to online services.

site_title: Citi sues Revlon over lender status after US$900m mistake
summary: Citi sues Revlon over lender status after mistakenly wiring $900 million to the cosmetics giant's lenders in 2020. Citi claims it became a lender to Revlon and is seeking repayment under the Revlon term loan. Revlon may challenge Citi's status as a creditor, prompting the lawsuit. The bank claims it had no obligation to pay down Revlon's debt and that its status as a creditor is legitimate.

site_title: Singapore goes from crypto hub to crypto restructuring hub
summary: Singapore, once a prominent crypto hub, is transforming into a restructuring hub for troubled cryptocurrency platforms. The island nation's favorable laws and the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act 2018 are attracting crypto companies looking to restructure and avoid bankruptcy. site_title: US: Stocks gain on Monday, shaking off early weakness
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, pushing higher despite early weakness due to weak Chinese economic data and a gloomy manufacturing reading from the New York Federal Reserve. The S&P 500 climbed 0.4% to 4,297.14, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.6% to 13,128.05. Analysts say the market's resilience may be due to the expectation that the Federal Reserve could pivot more quickly to slow interest rate hikes, potentially reducing inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.5% higher at 33,912.44, extending a positive trend that began in July.

site_title: Trade more, trade smarter – Lessons from Malaysia’s chicken ban for Singapore
summary: Malaysia's planned lifting of its chicken export ban after August 31 is a welcome relief for Singapore, which imports 90% of its food. The ban was imposed due to Covid-19 pressures and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, leading to food inflation in Singapore reaching 5.4% in June 2022. The episode highlights Singapore's vulnerability to external disruptions to its food supply, emphasizing the need for import diversification and trade agreements to strengthen trade. The Singapore government is exploring ways to improve its food security, including increasing domestic production and promoting intra-regional trade.

site_title: Russia's 2022 parallel imports hit 4% of 2021 overall imports
summary: Russia's parallel imports reached $16 billion in 2022, accounting for 4% of 2021 overall imports. The scheme, launched in March to circumvent sanctions, allows Russian companies to buy goods from foreign companies, with prices potentially higher due to extra logistics. The figure was announced by Industry and Trade Minister Denis Manturov, who also stated that parallel imports reached $6 billion in the May-July period. The scheme shields consumers from business isolation and disruptions caused by sanctions and logistics issues.

site_title: Third Point re-invests in Disney, pushes for changes including ESPN spinoff
summary: Billionaire investor Daniel Loeb's hedge fund Third Point has re-invested in Walt Disney, pushing for changes including a potential spinoff of ESPN, share buybacks, and new board members to improve the company's fortunes. Loeb's firm had previously liquidated its Disney stake in the first quarter, but has since repurchased a significant stake. Loeb's letter to Disney CEO Robert Chapek outlines the firm's suggestions to boost Disney's performance.

site_title: Unity Software rejects AppLovin's takeover offer, to stick with ironSource
summary: Unity Software has rejected a US$17.54 billion takeover offer from AppLovin, opting instead to proceed with its US$4.4 billion acquisition of ironSource. The deal would see Unity's platform used for developing mobile, console, and computer games, while ironSource's platform focuses on mobile game publishing and scaling. Unity's CEO, John Riccitiello, stated the ironSource transaction is compelling and will deliver long-term value, citing it as not in the best interest of shareholders.

site_title: Bankers should keep an open mind, stay agile in digital age: UOB’s Kevin Lam
summary: Bankers should adopt an open-minded and agile approach to navigate the rapidly changing banking industry, according to Kevin Lam, head of TMRW and group digital banking at UOB. Lam emphasizes the need to test and learn from new ideas, experiment, and be willing to acknowledge when something is not working. With the rise of digital banking, Lam notes that traditional models are being disrupted, and banks must adapt to provide personalized services, such as hyper-personalization, to remain relevant.

site_title: Key European power price doubles in 2 months as crisis deepens
summary: European power prices have doubled in 2 months, reaching a fresh record, amid concerns over tight natural gas supplies and low nuclear capacity. Germany's electricity rates have surged 3.2% to 475 euros (S$667.4) per megawatt-hour, while the UK's wholesale price is set to almost double at the start of October. Rising energy costs are driving inflation, straining infrastructure, and impacting economies. European governments are exploring measures to ease the pain, but analysts predict further price climbs unless notable bearish signals are received.

site_title: US homebuilder confidence hits worst slump since 2007 collapse
summary: US homebuilder confidence has hit its worst slump since the 2007 housing market collapse, falling 6 points to 49 in August, according to the National Association of Home Buyers/Wells Fargo gauge. The decline is attributed to high mortgage rates, elevated material and labor costs, and a decrease in buyer traffic. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes have exacerbated these challenges, with builders responding by reducing prices to boost sales. Despite this, Fed officials see the slowdown as a sign of their policies working, with long-term interest rates stabilizing in recent weeks.

site_title: Ola founder plans locally produced electric car by 2024
summary: Bhavish Aggarwal, founder of India's top ride-hailing app Ola, plans to launch an electric car in the summer of 2024, priced under $50,000. Ola Electric Mobility Pvt will build its own battery technologies, aiming to reduce costs and achieve self-reliance in local production. This move comes as India aims to become the world's third-largest auto market by 2030 and the government sets ambitious electrification goals. The launch is seen as a significant entry into the electric car market, competing with local giants and global automakers.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open as weak China data sparks slowdown fears
summary: US stocks opened lower on August 15, mirroring global markets, due to weak economic data from China sparking concerns of an economic slowdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 50.35 points, or 0.15%, to 33,710.70. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 down 10.78 points, or 0.25%, and the Nasdaq down 50.56 points, or 0.39%. The decline follows recent record highs and amid ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Hong Kong watchdog investigates Evergrande over deal audits
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Reporting Council is investigating Evergrande's accounts and audits, the second review in 9 months. The watchdog is looking into the company's 2020 and 2021 financial statements, specifically questioning the classification of restricted bank deposits and pledge guarantees. Evergrande is facing challenges due to China's real estate crisis, including a defaulted restructuring plan and concerns about repaying investors. The investigation is part of a broader regulatory crackdown on excessive borrowing in the sector.

site_title: Malaysia's top funds say banking sector ripe for consolidation
summary: Malaysia's top investment funds say the country's banking sector is ripe for consolidation, citing opportunities to cut costs and compete with new entrants. The sector's top five banks command a combined market share of about 48% and have about 26 firms, with the need for investments in core systems and technology to upgrade to digital platforms. Executives from Permodalan Nasional Bhd, Employees Provident Fund, and Khazanah Nasional see benefits from further consolidation, with some considering mergers and others noting the need for timing and pricing.

site_title: Yum China applies to add primary listing in Hong Kong
summary: Yum China Holdings, which operates KFC and Taco Bell in China, has applied for a primary listing in Hong Kong to avoid delisting from the New York Stock Exchange amid US regulatory scrutiny. The move comes amid an audit dispute between China and the US, with hundreds of Chinese companies at risk of being kicked out. The conversion is expected to be completed in October, subject to shareholder approval, and will make Yum China dual primary listed on the NYSE and Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How to combat obsolete wealth management models (Ep 125)
summary: The Business Times podcast "BT Money Hacks" discusses outdated wealth management models with Adam Reynolds, CEO of Saxo Markets Singapore. Obsolete models include robo advisors, which lack individualized plans. Reynolds emphasizes the importance of tailored advice for the mass affluent. The conversation also touches on the feasibility of an individualized plan and the drawbacks of robo advisors. The outlook for 2H 2022 is also discussed, with no specific details provided.

site_title: Oil sinks to 6-month low on China outlook, Iran supply boost
summary: Oil prices plummeted to a 6-month low, dipping 5.7% to $86.84 a barrel, amid concerns over Chinese demand and a potential boost in Iranian supply. China's oil demand last month fell 10% year-over-year, while a nuclear deal with Iran appears closer after announcements. Traders weigh these factors as oil prices have retreated since China's interest rate cut and amid economic slowdown concerns.

site_title: US dollar jumps on safety flows after China data, yuan slips on rate cut
summary: The US dollar rose 0.6% to 106.3 against a basket of six peers, driven by disappointing Chinese data and a surprise rate cut by the People's Bank of China. The yuan slipped to a 2-week low of 6.7719 per US dollar after the rate cut. Global recession worries were bolstered by China's industrial output, retail sales, and fixed-asset investment falling short of analyst estimates. The euro eased 0.6% against the US dollar, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars dropped by more than 1%.

site_title: Keppel subsidiary wins US$2.9b Petrobras FPSO contract
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has secured a US$2.9 billion contract from Brazil's Petrobras to build a floating production storage and offloading vessel (FPSO) called P-80. The contract is expected to add over S$4 billion to Keppel O&M's orderbook and be completed in H1 2026. The P-80 will have a production capacity of 225,000 barrels of oil per day and is structured on progressive milestone payments, making it cashflow neutral during its execution lifecycle.

images.alt_text: Keppel O&M's wholly-owned subsidiaries, Keppel AmFELS, Inc and Keppel Shipyard Ltd have been awarded contracts worth around S$75 million.

site_title: Fed needs to resist opting again for quick and easy
summary: The Federal Reserve should resist the temptation to adopt a "soft landing" narrative, as it has done before, and instead prioritize defeating inflation. Despite recent strong job and inflation numbers, inflation has persisted and become more deeply embedded in the economy, with drivers broadening. The Fed's cautious tone and determined policy narrative are necessary to mitigate the risk of recession and protect economic activity. The Fed's previous mistakes have left it without a first-best policy approach, making it crucial to stay the course and put the inflation genie back into the bottle.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: OCBC and GovTech launched a digital payment service on the LifeSG app to simplify government payments in Singapore. Since its launch in November 2021, GovWallet has seen 900,000 transactions worth S$41m. Retail workers will see their wages rise up to 8.5% under the Progressive Wage Model, and new private home sales rose in July.

site_title: China bonds rally as rate cut reinforces split with Treasuries
summary: China's sovereign bonds rallied after the central bank unexpectedly cut interest rates, with the 10-year yield dropping to its lowest level in over 2 years. The rate cut, seen as a sign of prioritizing growth over curbing leverage, boosted foreign investor demand, with overseas investors buying a net 3.3 billion yuan of Chinese debt in July. The move contrasts with the US Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes and may attract leveraged buyers back into Chinese bonds.

site_title: Indonesia plans fuel price hike to control ballooning subsidies-media
summary: Indonesia plans to hike fuel prices to control ballooning energy subsidies, with the price hike to be complemented by rules on subsidized fuel sales set to be issued this month. The country has tripled its energy subsidy budget to 502 trillion rupiah, but officials say it may not be sufficient due to rising fuel demand. The government has not previously announced plans to hike fuel prices, but a senior party member suggests the first hike could be made by late August to manage the increasing fiscal burden.

site_title: Crypto firm Prime Blockchain, 10X SPAC end US$1.25b merger deal
summary: 10X Capital Venture Acquisition Corp II has mutually ended its US$1.25 billion merger deal with Prime Blockchain, a crypto mining and infrastructure company. The termination comes amid receding enthusiasm for special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) due to market volatility and recession fears. The companies did not provide a reason for the termination, which is the latest in a series of SPAC deals being pulled due to market conditions.

site_title: UK approves updated Moderna vaccine targeting Omicron variant
summary: The UK's drug regulator, MHRA, has approved the updated Moderna vaccine, Spikevax bivalent Original/Omicron, for adult booster doses targeting the Omicron variant and the original 2020 virus. The vaccine met the regulator's standards for safety, quality, and effectiveness, and prompted a strong immune response against both variants. The approval is the first "bivalent" Covid-19 vaccine to be approved by the British regulator, providing a "sharpened tool" in the fight against evolving virus strains.

site_title: Malaysia's bourse to launch voluntary carbon market by year-end
summary: Bursa Malaysia, Malaysia's stock exchange, plans to launch a voluntary carbon market by year-end. The exchange will adopt the Verified Carbon Standard to ensure the integrity of carbon credits, allowing companies to buy credits to offset their emissions. The market will encourage investments in high-quality offsetting projects, such as reforestation or fuel switching. The move aims to increase transparency and support Malaysia's net-zero greenhouse gas emissions aspiration, as well as the private sector's voluntary climate commitments.

site_title: Rio Tinto’s offer to take over giant copper mine  rebuffed
summary: Rio Tinto's US$2.7 billion offer to buy out Turquoise Hill Resources, which owns a majority stake in the Oyu Tolgoi copper mine in Mongolia, has been rejected. Turquoise Hill stated that the offer does not fairly reflect the project's strategic value. The rejection blocks Rio's efforts to gain control of the mine and is a setback for CEO Jakob Stausholm, who aims to rebuild the company's reputation.

site_title: Myanmar junta court jails Suu Kyi for 6 years for corruption
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar's ousted leader, has been jailed for an additional 6 years for corruption, bringing her total prison time to 17 years. Suu Kyi, 77, has been detained since the military coup in February last year and faces decades in jail if convicted on all charges. The junta court sentenced her under 4 anti-corruption charges, following previous convictions for corruption, incitement, and breaching COVID-19 rules. The international community has criticized the trials, with analysts describing them as an attempt to erase Myanmar's democratic past.

site_title: China publishes innovation action plan
summary: China has published an innovation action plan to encourage innovation, focusing on hard technology areas such as semiconductors and new energy. The plan aims to guide companies towards national needs and includes support for platform companies. The Ministry of Science and Technology and Ministry of Finance released the statement, outlining the plan's objectives and strategies. This move is part of China's efforts to drive technological advancements and strengthen its position in the global innovation landscape.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on August 15, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.67% to 20,040.86, due to Chinese economic data for July coming in worse than expected. The zero-Covid policy stifled economic activity. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index inched down 0.80 points to 3,276.09, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.47% to 2,217.44.

site_title: Key Brexit legacy issues may come to head for Truss
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss faces significant Brexit challenges as she takes office, including new trade barriers and strained EU relations. Truss, a strong Brexiteer, has pledged to review EU laws and potentially reform the European Convention on Human Rights. Her plans to override the Northern Ireland Protocol could lead to a trade war and EU sanctions. Truss's predecessor, Boris Johnson, declared Brexit "done," but the UK's economic performance lags behind other major nations. The EU is wary of Truss's ambitions, and a major bust-up between Brussels and London is possible, with the Irish protocol bill set to be debated in the Lords in H2 2022.

summary: China's central bank unexpectedly cut key lending rates to revive demand as data showed the economy unexpectedly slowing in July. Industrial output grew 3.8% and retail sales rose 2.7%, missing forecasts. The move aims to counteract the impact of Beijing's zero-Covid policy and a property crisis. Economists predict further economic weakness, with some downgrading their projections, and warn that the central bank's room for policy easing may be limited due to capital outflows.

summary: Singapore-based gaming chair company Secretlab has successfully expanded into the North American and European markets, driven by a focus on research and development and strategic partnerships. site_title: South Korea’s SK invests US$250m in Bill Gates’ TerraPower for nuclear power tech
summary: South Korea's SK Group has invested $250 million in TerraPower, a US-based nuclear power tech company co-founded by Bill Gates, as part of a $750 million fundraising round. site_title: AstraZeneca says data confirms Enhertu benefit in breast cancer patients
summary: AstraZeneca announced that data from a late-stage trial confirmed the benefit of breast cancer drug Enhertu in patients with HER2-low breast cancer who have been previously treated with another therapy. summary: In Singapore, buying new homes off-plan can be a winning proposition for developers and buyers. site_title: China’s Yangtze river shrinks as heatwave, drought threaten crops
summary: China's Yangtze River is experiencing severe drought and heatwaves, with rainfall 60% lower than normal in August. Temperatures have exceeded 40C (104F) in the middle and lower reaches of the river, threatening the autumn harvest. The agriculture ministry has deployed teams to protect crops, and regions are using pumps and cloud-seeding rockets to mitigate the effects of the drought. site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open

site_title: Panic in Ikea as Shanghai locks down store on remote Covid-19 risk
summary: Health authorities in Shanghai locked down an Ikea store on August 13 after a close contact of a 6-year-old boy with an asymptomatic COVID-19 infection visited the store. The lockdown led to panic among shoppers, with many fleeing the building before the doors were locked. Authorities imposed temporary control measures, requiring everyone at the store to quarantine for 2 days and undergo 5 days of health surveillance. This is part of China's COVID Zero strategy, which has led to numerous scenes of panic nationwide.

summary: Indonesia's trade surplus widened to $4.2 billion in July, beating forecasts, but Statistics Indonesia warns that the country's export gains may dwindle due to stagnant export volumes and declining commodity prices. The nation's export boom since May 2020 is largely driven by rising prices, not volume growth, and this trend may reverse if commodity prices return to normal. The trade surplus is expected to narrow in the remainder of 2022, putting pressure on Indonesia's foreign exchange reserves.
