site_title: SPH Reit appoints 3 new directors to board
summary: SPH Reit's manager appointed 3 new directors to the board, effective August 15, including Jennie Chua as deputy chairman and lead independent director Eugene Lai, and non-independent director Gerald Yong. Chua will also serve on the nominating and remuneration committee, while Lai will serve on the audit and risk committee. Soon Tit Koon, chairman of the audit and risk committee, will retire after 9 years. The appointments follow Chua Hwee Song's resignation from the board in June.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, SPH Reit's Paragon property saw marked recovery following the relaxation of restrictions in March/April 2022 as tenant sales for the quarter grew 45 per cent year-on-year and exceeded pre-Covid levels.
SPH Reit's manager attributed the improved performance to high Covid-19 vaccination rates and the easing of safe distancing measures.
Chua Hwee Song was the chief financial officer of SPH, which has since been delisted.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines signs provisional deal for 20 Airbus A330neos
summary: Malaysia Airlines has signed a provisional deal to acquire 20 Airbus A330neos, with 10 planes to be purchased from Airbus and the remaining 10 leased from Avolon. The deal includes a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. The planes, equipped with Rolls-Royce engines, are scheduled for delivery from 2024 to 2028, aiming to modernize the fleet, enhance operational efficiency, and meet environmental targets. The airline also plans to collaborate with Airbus on sustainable aviation fuel, training, and maintenance.

site_title: Saudi inflation rises to 2.7% in July on higher food prices
summary: Saudi Arabia's consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.7% in July from a year earlier, mainly driven by higher food prices. The food and beverages segment increased 3.9%, with meat prices rising 5.1%. Inflation is now at or close to a peak and will gradually fall back over the rest of the year and next. Experts expect food inflation to drop back and the government's cap on fuel prices to contain energy inflation.

site_title: Thai Q2 GDP notches fastest growth in a year on eased pandemic curbs
summary: Thailand's economy expanded at the fastest pace in a year in the second quarter, growing 2.5% annually, driven by eased pandemic curbs and boosted tourism. The government revised its growth forecast to 2.7-3.2% for 2022, citing increased consumption and exports. However, multi-year high inflation and China's slowdown remain a drag on the economy, and the Bank of Thailand is expected to raise interest rates to tackle inflation.

images.alt_text: Visitors are seen rising to 30 million people next year, still shy of the 40 million who travelled to the country in the year before Covid spread.

site_title: Troubled crypto exchange Zipmex granted 3-month moratorium extension
summary: Singapore's High Court has granted a 3-month extension to crypto exchange Zipmex's moratorium until December 2, amid concerns about the company's engagement with creditors, particularly those in Thailand. The extension was granted despite Justice Aedit Abdullah's concerns about insufficient engagement with creditors, following a town hall meeting that has yet to be held. Zipmex has received investment proposals from three investors, aiming to inject capital and revive customer withdrawals. The company must report its management accounts to the courts and creditors monthly and may establish a creditor committee for Thailand.

images.alt_text: Hodlnaut’s token swap feature allows users to exchange cryptocurrencies, such as from Bitcoin to Ethereum.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.18 points to 1,504.01. The market saw a volume of 2.545 billion lots worth RM1.728 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 496 to 319.

site_title: Meme coins Dogecoin, Shiba Inu jump as Ethereum optimism spreads
summary: Cryptocurrency meme coins Dogecoin and Shiba Inu experienced significant gains, with Dogecoin up 14% and Shiba Inu up 40% over the past 5 days, amid optimism about Ethereum's upcoming software upgrade, known as Merge, now expected around September 15. The market's total cap has recovered to around $1.2 trillion, following a drop to $875 billion in June. Experts attribute the rally to retail investor enthusiasm and lower-than-expected US inflation prints, which may lead to a decrease in interest rate hikes and a boost for riskier assets like crypto.

images.alt_text: Retail investors are going to be a "fundamental" piece of the success for crypto and blockchain adoption, and institutions will be the next leg of growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo's stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.14% to 28,871.78, driven by growing risk appetite among investors expecting the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening to slow down. The broader Topix index also rose 0.60%.

site_title: Ascott Trust plans to buy 9 overseas properties; launches private placement to raise S$150m
summary: Ascott Residence Trust plans to acquire 9 overseas properties, including serviced residences, rental housing, and student accommodation, for S$215.2 million. The trust also launched a private placement to raise S$150 million, with the proceeds to partly fund the acquisition and future potential deals. The acquisition is expected to increase the trust's distribution by S$9.2 million and its pro forma FY2021 distribution per stapled security by 2.8%. The deal is subject to securityholders' approval and is expected to be completed by November.

images.alt_text: Slated for opening in June 2023, Ascott will refurbish the asset into a 140-unit co-living property named lyf Ginza Tokyo.

site_title: Taking corporate governance to the next level
summary: The Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) reached a new all-time high of 70.6, surpassing 70 for the first time. This marks an improvement in companies' disclosure, shareholder engagement, and financial transparency. However, critics argue that the current regime is sub-optimal and that regulators must take stronger, firmer action to maintain momentum and push governance standards upwards. The need for swift and firm disciplinary action against errant companies and individuals is emphasized to instil discipline and strengthen confidence in the local financial market.

images.alt_text: The trio of local banks were still ranked in the top 10 companies on the Singapore Governance and Transparency Index in 2022.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as investors await key earnings reports, RBA minutes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 7,064.30 on Monday, driven by a strong finish on Wall Street and anticipation of key earnings reports and Reserve Bank of Australia policy meeting minutes. Major miners such as BHP Group, Santos, and Core Lithium surged, while technology stocks and Steel producer Bluescope Steel also gained. Energy stocks, however, fell due to weaker oil prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to release its policy meeting minutes on Tuesday, and unemployment numbers are expected on Thursday, with markets awaiting these events for further guidance.

site_title: Oil demand forecasts aren’t as bullish as they seem
summary: Recent oil demand forecasts from the International Energy Agency, US Energy Information Administration, and Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries show revisions that may not be as bullish as initially thought. Despite a 520,000-barrel-per-day increase in oil demand forecast by the IEA, the revisions are largely in line with previous estimates, and global oil demand growth is rapidly evaporating. The IEA's forecast boost is attributed to increased demand for oil in power generation in the Middle East and Europe, but these factors may not sustain demand into the cooler months, as Europe rapidly replenishes its natural gas stockpiles ahead of winter.

images.alt_text: Oil settles up as IEA hikes 2022 demand growth forecast

Brent crude futures fell US$1.45, or 1.5 per cent, to settle at US$98.15 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell US$2.25, or 2.4 per cent, to settle at US$92.09 a barrel. Both contracts gained more than 2 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Recession anxiety: How much more downside in markets?
summary: Investor anxiety has shifted from inflation fears to recession worries, with many predicting a global recession. However, the US economy remains strong, with the job market producing over 300,000 jobs a month and a broadest measure of unemployment at an all-time low. Despite weak equity and bond markets, corporate earnings have been resilient, and the US is unlikely to enter a recession. The data points to a soft landing, but risks include the Fed tightening too much or China's economic fallout. Historically, when traditional economic indicators deteriorate, the second half of the year has seen significant bull markets.

images.alt_text: In the writer's view, US stocks continue to trade at a premium versus other markets, reflecting stronger corporate profitability, better return on equity, and more robust growth in comparison to equity markets  elsewhere.
US consumer sentiment rose in early August to a three-month high on firmer expectations about the economy and personal finances.

site_title: Southern hemisphere to get first mRNA vaccine facility
summary: Moderna has announced plans to open an mRNA vaccine manufacturing facility in Melbourne, Australia, marking the first for the southern hemisphere. The facility, based at Monash University, will produce 100 million vaccine doses annually for Covid-19, influenza, and other diseases. Construction begins this year and is expected to be complete by 2024. The facility is seen as a "show of faith" in Australia by Moderna and will also boost national security, following the country's experience with vaccine shortages during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Britain’s health ministry said that the pandemic had shown mRNA technology as one of the fastest routes to develop new vaccines, and could be applied to other areas, such as cancer, flu, dementia and heart disease.

site_title: Alibaba, ByteDance share details of prized algorithms with Beijing for first time
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) has published a list of 30 algorithms used by internet giants such as Alibaba and ByteDance to gather user data and tailor content recommendations. The list, which includes descriptions of how the algorithms work and their applications, is the first public disclosure of such tools by Chinese tech firms. The move aims to curb data abuse and provide regulators with more information to investigate allegations of data violations. While the list does not reveal the actual code, it marks a significant step in China's efforts to regulate the tech industry and set it apart from countries like the US.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans will be able to buy Market Kurly's ready-to-cook and ready-to-eat meals from Wednesday via the app, owned by Alibaba unit Lazada.
Next week, Tencent will seek to assure investors about its outlook during second-quarter results.
Alibaba reported revenue of 205.6 billion yuan ($30.4 billion) in the June quarter, enough to beat projections of 204 billion yuan.

site_title: Japan plans fresh package to cushion blow from rising living costs
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has instructed his ministers to draw up additional measures to cushion the economic blow from rising living costs. The government plans to hold off on raising the price of imported wheat in October, which would essentially subsidize households. The government aims to compile the package of measures early next month and tap state reserves worth 4.7 trillion yen (S$48 billion). This move is aimed at mitigating the impact of rising global commodity prices, particularly after the Ukraine war.

images.alt_text: Japan's economy expanded an annualised 2.2 per cent in the April-June period to mark the third straight quarter of expansion.

site_title: Retail workers to see wages rise up to 8.5% under Progressive Wage Model from Sep 1
summary: Singapore's government has accepted tripartite recommendations for a Progressive Wage Model (PWM) for retail workers, resulting in a 8.4-8.5% annual wage increase from September 1, 2022, to August 31, 2025. The move benefits over 46,000 full-time and part-time retail employees, with the largest impact on local lower-wage workers. The PWM sets out minimum pay and training requirements for workers at different skill levels, with a 6-month "run-in period" for employers to adjust to the new requirements.

images.alt_text: Higher pay, career pathways for up to 3,000 workers with Progressive Wage Model for waste management sector
Landscape workers to see annual wages rise by 6.3% on average under Progressive Wage Model

site_title: New private home sales up in July, driven by AMO Residence transactions
summary: New private home sales in Singapore rose month-over-month in July, driven by strong sales at AMO Residence in the outside central region. A total of 834 units were sold, excluding executive condominiums, with 402 units launched. This represents a 70.9% month-on-month increase. Analysts attribute the surge to a lack of new home supply in the suburbs and significant pent-up demand. Despite rising interest rates, homebuyers are not deterred, with 40.6% of transactions in the outside central region priced above S$2 million. Experts predict continued demand and price growth for private homes, with some forecasting a 8% increase in prices for the year.

images.alt_text: HDB flats, condominiums, and CBD skyline as viewed from Block 79D Toa Payoh Central on Mar 17, 2022.
AMO Residence is the first notable launch in the Outside Central Region (OCR) this year, as well as the first major project in Ang Mo Kio in over eight years.

ST20211117_202146255160 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of private housing in Holland Road with the backdrop of D'Leedon condominium towering over properties in the central part of Singapore on 17 Nov 2021.

site_title: Jokowi set to unveil strict budget plans amid soaring subsidies
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is set to unveil a strict budget plan amid soaring subsidies, aiming to restore fiscal discipline and sustain growth. The 2023 budget proposal includes reducing the deficit to below 3% of GDP, cutting pandemic stimulus, and increasing infrastructure spending to relocate the capital to a new city on Borneo. The government will also cut subsidies, which doubled to 502 trillion rupiah this year, and use unspent cash to reduce its financing plan.

images.alt_text: Holding all things constant, senior economist at RHB Bank Barnabas Gan hypothesized in a report on Friday (Aug 12) that a uniform decline in commodity prices of coal, vegetable oils, metals and gas by 10 per cent will reduce annual export value by an approximate 4.0 per cent and affect 0.6 per cent of Indonesia’s gross domestic product (GDP).
Economists kept their expectation of 50 basis-point central bank rate hikes in the third quarter, and another 25 basis-point hike in the last quarter of this year.

site_title: China home prices fall for 11th month as mortgage crisis deepens
summary: China's home prices fell for an 11th consecutive month in July, with new home prices declining 0.11% and existing-home prices dropping 0.21%. The mortgage boycott, which began in early July, has reduced consumer confidence and is affecting the US$2.4 trillion new-home market. The government's efforts to curb the real estate crisis, including urging banks to lend more and cutting mortgage costs, have shown little success. The property slowdown weighs on China's economy, which barely expanded last quarter, and is causing tension in other areas, including developer protests.

images.alt_text: Chinese manufacturers will find it difficult to make up for the overseas shortfall in their home market.
China's builders have lost about US$55 billion in share value since 2022 began.

site_title: Castes in California: Tech giants confront ancient Indian hierarchy
summary: US tech giants, including Apple, IBM, Amazon, and Google, are updating their policies to address India's ancient caste system, which segregates Indians for generations. Apple, the world's largest listed company, added "caste" to its general employee conduct policy in 2020, prohibiting discrimination based on the category. However, some companies, including Google, say caste discrimination falls under existing bans on national origin, ancestry, and ethnic discrimination. The issue remains contentious, with some companies hesitant to explicitly mention caste in their policies, fearing potential complaints and increased HR caseloads.

images.alt_text: 15 current and former Apple employees reported either being retaliated against or getting a disappointing or counterproductive response from the company.

site_title: Nikkei 225 erases year's loss as Japan outperformance continues
summary: The Nikkei 225 index erased its 2022 losses, rising 0.9% to nearly 28,812, as Japan's economy continues to outperform peers. A weaker yen and Bank of Japan's stimulus helped drive gains, while a 4-week US rally also boosted sentiment. Strategists see tailwinds ahead, including a potential pickup in money supply and consumer confidence, but some warn of significant downside risks. The Nikkei has still fallen about 14% in dollar terms for foreign investors.

images.alt_text: Neo served as chief commercial officer of Nikkei FT ScoutAsia Limited (Hong Kong) until the business was transferred to the parent company Nikkei Inc. earlier this year.

site_title: ‘Bullet Train’ stays on top of a slow-moving North America box office
summary: The US box office experienced a slow weekend with only one film, "Bullet Train", reaching $10 million in ticket sales. The Brad Pitt-led action-thriller has generated $54.4 million at the box office after two weeks, staying on top for the second consecutive weekend. New releases, such as "Bodies Bodies Bodies" and "Fall", failed to crack the top 5, with "Fall" barely landing in 10th place. The box office slowdown is attributed to the summer vacation season, with no major new releases on the horizon until September.

images.alt_text: Pitt attending the the Los Angeles premiere of Bullet Train  on Aug 1.
As the streaming field gets more crowded, the biggest media companies have turned to giants in other industries to find new subscribers.

site_title: A day of high drama on a tough Tampines golf course
summary: A day of high drama unfolded at the International Series Singapore golf tournament at Tanah Merah Country Club's Tampines course. Thai golfer Phachara Khongwatmai, one of the joint leaders, sat in an empty chair in the clubhouse lobby, asking to sit quietly and think about his next putt. The unusual request came after a dramatic penultimate day of competition, with Khongwatmai and Malaysia's Gavin Green sharing the lead. The event was part of the Asian Tour's US$1.5 million International Series.

images.alt_text: A mission to ensure golf can thrive for the next 50 years

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.70 points or 0.05% to 1,505.49. The market saw a higher volume of 233.20 million lots worth RM120.99 million, with 192 gainers outnumbering 139 losers.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CSG-CIMB downgrades Riverstone Holdings on weakening demand
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded Riverstone Holdings to "hold" with a lower target price of S$0.80, citing weakening glove demand and lower plant utilization in H2 2022. Analysts expect healthcare glove ASPs to fall further to US$25 in Q3 2022. Despite lower Q2 net profit, Riverstone's management aims to return excess cash to shareholders, with a potential dividend payout of 18 sen DPS. The downgrade follows a similar downgrade of larger Malaysian-listed peers, with Riverstone's focus on higher-margin cleanroom gloves seen as a differentiator.

site_title: UK property asking prices fall the most in more than 2 years
summary: UK property asking prices fell 1.3% in August, the largest drop in almost 2.5 years, as a traditional summer lull combined with economic concerns. The decline reduced the annual pace of growth to 8.2% from 9.3% and was driven by the most expensive homes and London. A shortage of properties and strong demand are expected to keep prices from plummeting, with buyer demand increasing 20% since 2019.

images.alt_text: Britain is bracing for already-high energy bills to more than triple this year, with charities warning that millions of people could be forced into poverty if the government does not launch a multi-billion pound support package to soften the blow.
The closely-watched survey showed sales expectations for the next 12 months are at the lowest level since March 2020.

site_title: Trek 2000 founder pleads guilty to falsifying accounts, forgery and deceiving auditors
summary: Henn Tan, founder of Trek 2000, a company that invented the thumb drive, pleaded guilty to 5 charges of falsifying accounts, forgery, and deceiving auditors. Tan, 66, conspired with former CFO Gurcharan Singh to make false entries in financial statements from 2006 to 2011, and later inflated revenue by $3.2 million. The case was discovered by auditors Ernst & Young, who reported the matter to the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority. Tan will be sentenced on September 22, after being in remand for 1.5 months.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks: Once bitten, twice shy
SGX RegCo reprimands former Trek 2000 executives
SGX RegCo reprimands Trek 2000's former executives for breaches of listing rules

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday despite global market gains; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dipped 0.2% to 3,264.08 at the open on Monday, despite global markets gaining on Friday. The STI fell 5.19 points, with Oceanus being the most actively traded counter, dropping 5.9%. Local banks traded mixed, with UOB and DBS declining, while OCBC rose. The US and European markets ended on a high on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq posting their fourth straight week of gains.

images.alt_text: Stocks to watch: UOL Group, ComfortDelGro, Singpost, Dasin Retail Trust, Medtecs International

site_title: Gold steadies near US$1,800/oz on lower dollar, yields
summary: Gold prices held steady near US$1,800/oz, supported by a weaker US dollar and declining Treasury yields. Spot gold remained unchanged at US$1,800.09/oz, while US gold futures were flat at US$1,815.10. Rising US interest rates are seen as a hedge against inflation, but dulling the appeal of non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields also rebounded to 2.7860 per cent, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest bearing gold.

site_title: National digital payment service on LifeSG app sees 900,000 transactions worth S$41m since November
summary: Singapore's digital payment service, GovWallet, on the LifeSG app has seen 900,000 transactions worth S$41 million since its launch in November 2021. The platform, jointly developed by OCBC and GovTech, aims to make government payments simpler and more sustainable. It has also been used by three government agencies to administer payment schemes paper-free. The service will be used for the disbursement of GST vouchers in August, with Singapore aiming to go cheque-free by 2025.

images.alt_text: By November, 5 of the region’s biggest economies, including the Philippines, are set to sign a deal to integrate their network, said Bank Indonesia governor Perry Warjiyo.
Sparrow will now be able to provide digital payment token services under the Payment Services Act 2019.

site_title: Asia's best currency is driven by tourists pouring into Thailand
summary: The Thai baht has surged 4.6% to around 35.30 to the US dollar, driven by optimism over tourism-led growth and a narrowing current-account deficit due to falling oil prices. Analysts forecast the economy to grow 3.1% in Q2, with tourism expected to attract 30 million visitors in 2023, surpassing pre-pandemic levels. The baht's rebound has led to gains in Asia, with some predicting further upside, while others caution against jumping in at current levels.

images.alt_text: The bank’s monetary policy committee on Wednesday(Aug 10) decided to increase the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 0.75 per cent.
The consumer price index (CPI) accelerated 7.61 per cent in July.

site_title: Russia unplugs foes, rewards friends in latest market reboot
summary: Russia has unveiled a 2-tier system to mobilize domestic capital and cater to friendly jurisdictions, allowing trading in debt securities for investors from non-sanctioned countries starting August 15. The move reverses restrictions imposed since the invasion of Ukraine, with foreign banks and energy companies from "unfriendly" countries still subject to capital controls. The plan aims to restore normalcy and is seen as a sign of Russia taking an increasingly hard line in sorting friend from foe, with policymakers looking inward for funding sources and exploring innovations to support the financial system.

images.alt_text: The transit fee payment agreement covers only flows to Slovakia and Hungary, not the Czech Republic, according to Slovnaft, part of Mol Group.
Russia is a major source of oil, gas, coal and agricultural commodities for China.
The decree, signed by President Vladimir Putin and published on Friday (Aug 5), immediately bans investors from countries which supported sanctions on Russia from selling certain assets.

site_title: What the Japanese bubble  taught me
summary: The author reflects on the 1989 Japanese economic bubble, a period of sustained prosperity and strong corporate profits. The author, a fund manager, recalls extravagant lifestyles, including high-end dining and club-hopping, during this time. The article serves as a commentary on the lessons learned from past economic bubbles and the importance of fighting one's "flawed DNA" to avoid getting sucked into the crowd, referencing recent events such as China's fine of ride-hailing giant Didi for alleged data security violations.

site_title: Hot stock: Straits Trading up as much as 10.1% on special dividend cheer
summary: Straits Trading shares rose 10.1% to a 4-month high of S$3.37 after the company declared a special dividend following strong H1 results, driven by the divestment of ARA Asset Management to ESR Group. Eligible shareholders can choose to receive 145 ESR shares or 180 new Straits Trading shares for every 1,000 Straits Trading shares owned. The dividend distribution is a result of the company's successful divestment, valued at S$1.1 billion.

site_title: Indonesian MSME software startup majoo raises US$10m Series A round
summary: Indonesian MSME software startup majoo has raised US$10 million in a Series A round led by an undisclosed global technology investor. Existing investors AC Ventures, Quona Capital, BRI Ventures, and Xendit also participated. The startup will use the capital to expand its customer reach and initiate partnerships. majoo has processed over 166 million transactions worth US$970 million for MSMEs in Indonesia, with customers including barbershops, laundromats, and convenience stores.

site_title: Economy unlikely to help the Democrats
summary: US economic news has been positive, with falling unemployment, rising wages, and lower inflation in July, but the public's focus remains on inflation concerns. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) fell 8.5% in July, driven by a 4.6% drop in energy prices. However, gas prices are still 30% higher than last year, and grocery prices rose 1.3% in July. The Biden administration's efforts to combat inflation are unlikely to yield significant results before the November midterm elections, with the Federal Reserve's monetary policy likely to play a more significant role. The president's low job approval rating and the Democrats' struggles in upcoming elections remain a concern.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 crossed a closely watched technical level of 4,231 points, indicating the benchmark index has recouped half its losses since tumbling from the all-time peak in January. A 50 per cent retracement for some signals a bull market.
US consumer sentiment rose in early August to a three-month high on firmer expectations about the economy and personal finances.

site_title: Bank of England to deliver another bumper 50 bps lift in Sept as prices soar: poll
summary: The Bank of England is expected to deliver a 50 basis point interest rate hike in September, followed by a 25 basis point increase in November, according to a Reuters poll. The central bank aims to combat inflation, which is forecasted to reach 11.4% in the fourth quarter, despite the UK economy contracting 0.1% last quarter and a recession predicted later this year. Economists expect borrowing costs to reach 2.50% by the end of the year, with a potential cut in 2024.

images.alt_text: The drop would mark a pause in the recovery from the pandemic and the start of a more protracted downturn, which the Bank of England expects to last into early 2024.

Ramsden said the BOE would keep selling bonds from the Asset Purchase Portfolio it built up during the quantitative easing policy over the last decade even if officials eventually lower interest rates.

site_title: South Korea offering large-scale aid package for North’s nukes
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol announced a large-scale aid package to North Korea in exchange for denuclearization, a deal considered non-starter for Pyongyang. The proposal includes food, energy, and infrastructure modernization aid. However, analysts say the chances of North Korea accepting the offer are slim due to its significant investment in nuclear programs. The move comes amid a record-breaking blitz of North Korea's weapons tests, with officials warning of a possible seventh nuclear test. Yoon's proposal aims to improve North Korea's economy and people's livelihoods, but its success is uncertain.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol speaks during a ceremony to celebrate Korean Liberation Day from Japanese colonial rule in 1945, at the presidential office square in Seoul, South Korea, August 15, 2022. Ahn Young-joon/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Japan’s economy rebounds from Covid-19 jolt, global slowdown clouds outlook
summary: Japan's economy expanded 2.2% in the April-June period, marking the third straight quarter of growth, driven by solid private consumption. However, the outlook remains uncertain due to a resurgence in Covid-19 infections, slowing global growth, and rising raw material prices. Private consumption rose 1.1% and capital expenditure increased 1.4%, beating market forecasts. Despite this, policymakers remain cautious due to the uncertainty of companies hiking salaries amid slowing global demand.

images.alt_text: The overhaul comes at a time when Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's support rate is falling.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise, China data shows slowdown
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday as investors took heart from cooling US inflation data, with Tokyo climbing 1% and Sydney and Taipei also gaining ground. However, Hong Kong and Shanghai fell as China's economic data showed a slowdown due to Covid-19 restrictions and a slumping property market. China unexpectedly cut interest rates and warned of a risk of stagflation, while oil prices declined.

site_title: Tokyo seeks to take lead as green ‘transition’ finance hub
summary: Tokyo aims to become a global leader in green "transition" finance, helping heavy carbon-emitters reduce their footprint, as part of its goal to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. The city is developing a market to enable financing of manufacturers across Asia, strengthening Japan's supply chains and economic security. European financial institutions are increasingly unwilling to invest in carbon-intensive industries, making it harder for Asian manufacturers to reduce their emissions. Tokyo's Organization of Global Financial City Tokyo is working on a proposal to address this issue, which will be included in the government's economic plan for next year.

images.alt_text: Total sustainable fund assets in Asia, excluding Japan, slid 1.3 per cent quarter on quarter to US$61 million in the second quarter.

Asia will be pivotal to the net-zero industrial revolution.; transforming industrial parks to become net-zero will play a vital role in enabling the region, industries, and companies to achieve the emissions reduction they need, says Envision CEO, Lei Zhang.

site_title: China's popular EV companies enter crucial earnings season
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) companies, including Nio, XPeng, and Li Auto, are set to release earnings reports amid a months-long buying frenzy that may be losing steam. Investors will closely monitor the reports for signs of improved margins, as raw material costs and supply chain disruptions have put pressure on the sector. If the companies demonstrate profitability improvements, their shares may regain momentum, particularly as demand for cleaner cars is expected to reach a record this year, potentially giving the sector a second wind.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s trade ministry held a meeting with automaker Hyundai Motor Co and battery makers LG Energy Solution, Samsung SDI and SK. The companies asked Seoul to support them so that the bill would not put them at a competitive disadvantage in the US market, according to the statement.
The bill makes any electric vehicles assembled outside North America ineligible for tax credits, which has brought criticism from the European Union, South Korea and many automakers.

The company, 51 per cent owned by Didi (above) while 49 per cent held by Li Auto, submitted the bankruptcy application to Beijing No 1 Intermediate People's Court on Thursday (Aug 11), a statement on a website run by the Supreme Court showed.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Monday after Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Monday, following gains on Wall Street, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.55%, while the Topix index gained 0.22%. The gains were attributed to slowing inflation data in the US, which may lead to reduced interest rate hikes.

site_title: China surprises with rate cut as data shows 'alarming' slowdown
summary: China's central bank unexpectedly cut its key interest rates, lowering the 1-year policy loan rate to 2.75% and the 7-day reverse repo rate to 2%, in an effort to support the economy amid a slowdown. The move follows disappointing July data showing a slowdown in retail, investment, and industrial production. The 10-year government bond yield fell to 2.675%, the lowest level since May 2020. The move aims to stimulate the economy, which has been weighed down by Covid lockdowns and a deepening property downturn.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the open on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.68% to 20,038.48. The decline was attributed to investors awaiting China's key economic data release and monitoring US-China tensions, including a US congressional delegation's visit to Taiwan. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with decreases of 0.26% and 0.18%, respectively.

site_title: No distributable income for Dasin Retail Trust as it posts S$56.4m loss
summary: Dasin Retail Trust reported a loss of S$56.4 million for the first half of 2022, compared to a profit of S$2.9 million in the same period last year. No distribution per unit was declared, and the trust's loss per unit increased to 7.13 cents. Revenue and net property income fell 7.1% due to lower consumer sentiments in China. The trustee-manager retained distributable income to conserve cash and continue refinancing efforts amid Covid-19 uncertainties.

site_title: AUDUSD expected to see further upside
summary: The AUDUSD currency pair is expected to see further upside after forming an inverse head and shoulders pattern and displaying bullish signals from the Relative Strength Index (RSI) and Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicators. Prices have bounced off 0.6681 in mid-July and currently hover around 0.709. A technical target of 0.7368 is expected if the pair breaches immediate resistance at 0.7137.

site_title: 'Now hiring': US employers struggle to find enough workers
summary: US employers struggle to fill over 10 million job openings due to a worker shortage caused by the pandemic, early retirements, and restrictive immigration laws. Despite a frenzy of consumer spending, fewer than 6 million people were seeking work. The US Chamber of Commerce stated, "We have a lot of jobs, but not enough workers to fill them." The issue highlights the ongoing challenges faced by the US economy in recovering from the pandemic.

site_title: Crypto says institutions are back, though retail's got cold feet
summary: Institutional investors, such as BlackRock, are returning to the cryptocurrency market, partnering with exchanges like Coinbase to provide services for their institutional clients. This move is seen as a sign of continued institutional interest in digital assets, with Bitcoin prices showing signs of recovery. However, retail investors remain hesitant, with many still recovering from the 70% plunge in Bitcoin's value since November. Experts believe that retail investors will play a crucial role in the success of crypto and blockchain adoption, and that institutions will follow, creating a network effect that can drive growth.

site_title: Malaysia ex-PM Najib begins final bid to set aside 1MDB conviction
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak is appealing his 2020 conviction in a corruption case linked to the 1MDB scandal. He faces 12 years in jail and a $50 million fine for allegedly stealing $4.5 billion from the state fund. Najib, 69, has pleaded not guilty to dozens of charges and claims a conflict of interest with the trial judge. The Federal Court will hear his appeal through August 26, which could potentially clear his name and allow him to seek re-election to parliament.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on upbeat earnings, Wall Street optimism
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6% to 7,071 on Monday, tracking a strong Wall Street finish and upbeat earnings from blue-chip companies. Corporate earnings are expected to pick up pace this week, with investors focusing on BHP Group, Santos, and CSL. Energy stocks fell 0.5% due to a decline in crude oil prices, while tech stocks gained 1.7%, led by Megaport's 3.6% rise. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index gained 0.6% to 11,802.23.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.5 per cent lower at 7,032.5 after jumping more than 1 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Putin says Russia and North Korea will expand bilateral relations: KCNA
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has written a letter to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, stating that Russia and North Korea will expand their bilateral relations, citing mutual benefits for both countries' security and stability in the Korean peninsula and northeastern Asian region.

site_title: Australia 'done' with outsized interest-rate hikes, Eslake says
summary: Veteran economist Saul Eslake says Australia is done with outsized interest-rate hikes, expecting the Reserve Bank to shift to quarter-point hikes in September. He rejects the need for further 50-basis point increases to slow inflation, citing inflation forecasts and a possible rapid transition to low-carbon and renewable energy sources. Eslake expects the peak interest rate in this cycle to be around 2.5%, lower than initial predictions.

site_title: Biden calls India an ‘indispensable partner’ on 75th anniversary of independence
summary: US President Joe Biden congratulated India on its 75th anniversary of independence, calling the US-India partnership "indispensable" and highlighting the shared commitment to democracy, human freedom, and dignity. Biden also praised India's democratic journey, guided by Mahatma Gandhi's message, and acknowledged the contributions of the Indian-American community to the US. The statement was made on the eve of India's Independence Day celebrations.

site_title: Beijing's pet lovers turn to acupuncture to treat their furry friends
summary: In Beijing, a growing number of pet owners are turning to traditional Chinese medicine, specifically acupuncture, to treat their animals. Veterinarian Li Wen founded his practice in 2016, and says animal acupuncture is centuries old in China. Pet owners report fewer side effects and reduced suffering compared to conventional treatments, with some pets experiencing relief from pain, paralysis, and other ailments. As education and incomes rise, the market for animal acupuncture is gaining popularity, with many owners seeking alternative and more humane treatments for their pets.

site_title: Westpac’s capital position weaker at quarter-end
summary: Westpac's capital position weakened at the end of June, with a CET1 capital ratio of 10.75% compared to 11.3% at the end of March. The bank attributed this to payment of an interim dividend and higher risk-weighted assets due to interest rate hikes. Total assets with exposure to default rose to A$1.213 trillion, up from A$1.184 trillion at the end of March. The bank did not disclose a profit figure, citing offsetting deductions for capitalised software and regulatory costs.

site_title: China factory orders shrink in ominous sign for global outlook
summary: Chinese manufacturers are facing a significant decline in overseas orders, with a 30% drop in demand for items like buttons and zippers in July and August. This sudden decline is attributed to soaring inflation and cautious consumer spending worldwide. The overseas shortfall is expected to be difficult for Chinese manufacturers to make up for in their home market, signaling a potential slowdown in global consumer sentiment. This trend adds weight to warnings about a potential global recession, highlighting the need for policymakers to take action.

site_title: New Zealand set to stay in vanguard of tightening to cool prices
summary: New Zealand's central bank is set to deliver its fourth consecutive 50 basis-point interest rate hike, bringing the Official Cash Rate to 3% at its policy meeting on August 17. The move aims to anchor inflation expectations amid a near-full capacity economy. This would be the most aggressive cycle since New Zealand pioneered inflation targeting over 30 years ago, exceeding the Federal Reserve's 2.25 percentage points of increases. The rate hikes are part of a global tightening cycle to rein in spiraling inflation.

images.alt_text: The reversal in house prices comes as the Reserve Bank pursues aggressive policy tightening to damp demand and curb inflation.

site_title: Medtecs slides into red for H1 2022 on lower average selling price for PPE and face masks
summary: Medtecs reported a loss of US$3.7 million in H1 2022 due to a 63% decline in revenue to US$31.6 million, attributed to lower average selling prices of PPE and face masks. The company's demand for these products is expected to continue declining as the world recovers from pandemic-related lockdowns. Medtecs has completed vertical integration of its face mask production facility in the Philippines and is set to start commercial operations of its nitrile glove manufacturing facility in Cambodia in Q3 2022.

site_title: Bitcoin trades above US$25,000 for first time since mid-June
summary: Bitcoin has traded above US$25,000 for the first time since mid-June, reaching a high of US$24,882, following a 1.6% gain. This marks a significant milestone for the cryptocurrency, which is still down 46.5% year-to-date.

site_title: Q&M Dental H1 2022 earnings fall 45% on lower revenue
summary: Q&M Dental reported a 45% drop in H1 2022 earnings to S$9.8 million due to lower revenue from its medical laboratory and dental supplies segment. Revenue fell 4% to S$90.9 million, with the medical segment contributing 28% less. The company plans to expand its dental clinics in Singapore, Malaysia, and South-east Asia, but faces challenges from a tight labour market. Shares closed down 2% on Friday.

site_title: SingPost to ‘defend itself’ in arbitration over share purchase dispute; financial impact not known yet
summary: SingPost will defend itself in arbitration against Tan Ho Sung's claims over a share purchase agreement and shareholders' agreement with Famous Holdings and its subsidiaries. The arbitration primarily revolves around a put option exercised by Tan and a sale and purchase of shares by SingPost. The company has not completed the sale of the remaining 37.5% of shares and will make further announcements as material developments occur. The potential financial impact of Tan's claim cannot be quantified at this stage.

site_title: Under-insuring against climate change: small businesses most at risk
summary: Small businesses, particularly those in low-income countries, are most at risk of being under-insured against climate change, leaving them vulnerable to financial and economic losses. According to Munich Re's natural disaster review, floods, earthquakes, and storms caused $65 billion in losses in the first half of 2022, with insurance coverage remaining stagnant. Experts, including Munich Re's chief climate and geo scientist, Ernst Rauch, emphasize the need for further innovation in products, processes, and distribution to reach previously uninsured consumers and risks.

site_title: Banks reeling in startups in hopes of hooking high-growth customers
summary: Banks in Singapore are actively seeking to partner with startups, offering fee waivers, lower minimum balance requirements, and specialized services to attract and retain these high-growth customers. The largest local bank, DBS, has scrapped its 2-year startup program and now offers targeted services to its startup customers, while Maybank and UOB have launched initiatives such as mentorship and coworking space to support startups. As a result, banks now consider startups a significant part of their SME business, with UOB seeing 50% of its new business accounts come from startups.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M narrows H1 2022 losses
summary: Aoxin Q&M narrowed its losses to 3.4 million yuan in H1 2022, down from 6.1 million yuan, due to a share of associate results. Revenue fell 20.8% to 65.1 million yuan, mainly impacted by temporary Covid-19 closures. CEO Shao Yongxin expects the business environment to remain challenging for the rest of 2022, citing potential Covid-19 resurgence in China.

site_title: Strong profits for most insurers’ Integrated Shield portfolios, but brace for premium hikes
summary: Five of seven Integrated Shield insurers in Singapore will raise premiums this year, mostly for private-hospital plans and riders, due to an ageing population and higher healthcare inflation. Insurers such as Income, AIA, AXA, Prudential, and Singlife with Aviva will increase premiums, while Great Eastern and Raffles Health Insurance (RHI) will not. Insurers attribute the need for premium hikes to rising medical inflation in private hospitals, expected to reach 9.5% in Singapore, and increasing healthcare consumption due to an ageing population. Premium increases are expected to be single-digit percentage adjustments.

site_title: US congressional delegation visits Taiwan
summary: A US congressional delegation led by Senator Ed Markey visited Taiwan on August 14, 2022, amid heightened tensions with China. The 2-day trip aims to discuss bilateral relations, regional security, and other issues with senior Taiwanese leaders. The visit follows House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's earlier trip, which drew a strong response from China, including military exercises around the island. The US delegation's visit risks maintaining high tensions with China, raising concerns about the region's stability and global security.

site_title: Chelsea, Spurs coaches red carded as Kane snatches last-gasp draw
summary: Harry Kane scored a 96th-minute equalizer for Tottenham in a 2-2 draw against Chelsea in the English Premier League. Both Chelsea manager Thomas Tuchel and Tottenham manager Antonio Conte were red-carded for their second physical altercation of the match. The match marked a dramatic turnaround for Tottenham, who showed character and resilience to fight back from 2-0 down. The draw sees Tottenham escape with a point against their former club, while Chelsea's new chairman Todd Boehly welcomed a huge banner from the Chelsea support despite the team's disappointing result.

site_title: World embraces dirtier fuels as gas hits exorbitant heights
summary: High natural gas prices, exacerbated by Russia's stranglehold on supplies, are driving buyers to dirtier alternatives like liquefied natural gas (LNG), high-sulfur fuel oil (HSFO), and coal. The EU Commission will enable increased coal power generation this year and next, while the International Energy Agency (IEA) expects a surge in oil demand growth, with 1.5 million barrels per day expected to be switched from gas to oil this winter. This shift is a setback for the global push for cleaner energy, as dirtier alternatives will make it harder for nations to reach their climate goals.

site_title: China’s property woes bleed into the economy
summary: China's property woes, driven by maturing debt and refinancing challenges, are threatening to spread beyond the sector to the wider economy. Close to $50 billion of Chinese property bonds will mature from August to December 2022, while developers face challenges including huge bond maturities, refinancing risks, and ongoing US-China tensions. Fitch Ratings warns that distress in the property market could impact sectors beyond the property sector, including asset management companies, privately-owned engineering and construction companies, and smaller steel producers. The Chinese government is seeking to mobilize up to $1 trillion in loans to end the property downturn.

images.alt_text: China’s economic growth for the second quarter came in below consensus estimates, prompting some economists to cut again their full year projection for the world’s second largest economy, even as the big miss may be the bad news needed to spur more policy support.

Singapore is increasingly favoured as it is less connected to Beijing from a regulatory, political, and financial perspective.

site_title: Rushdie off ventilator and condition improving
summary: Salman Rushdie, 75, has been taken off a ventilator and his condition is improving after being stabbed in the neck at a public appearance in New York state. The suspect, Hadi Matar, 24, pleaded not guilty to charges of attempted murder and assault. Rushdie's agent said the road to recovery will be long due to severe injuries, but his condition is headed in the right direction. Rushdie's usual sense of humor remains intact, and he was able to say a few words after being taken off the ventilator.

summary: Businesses face headwinds due to rapidly changing consumer mindset, driven by the internet and mobile phones. Consumers are better and worse informed, leading to unpredictable behavior and disrupted markets. To survive, businesses must change fundamentally or adapt to new circumstances. The author argues that businesses should redefine their purpose beyond making money, focusing on creating value and contributing to society. This requires a shift in governance and education to promote global cooperation and intellectual development, ultimately enabling businesses to lead and serve humanity as a whole.

site_title: Tourists in Chinese beachside resort city protest Covid lockdown
summary: Thousands of tourists stranded on China's Hainan island due to Covid lockdowns may soon be able to return home, but with restrictions. Provincial authorities announced the resumption of commercial flights on Monday, subject to no new cases in tour groups and hotels within the last 7 days. Travelers will be quarantined at home for 3 days, followed by 4 days of health monitoring. The move comes after days of frustration among visitors over lack of information from hotel management and the government on when they can leave.

images.alt_text: Shanghai has extended its weekly Covid-19 test requirement and extended free testing until the end of September.

site_title: Drought sows doubts over future of traditional English gardens
summary: English gardeners are advised to adapt to the country's evolving climate by prioritizing water conservation. According to Claire Price, owner of Reuthe's woodland oasis, gardeners should "look forward" and focus on future planning, rather than emulating past styles. With a hosepipe ban in place, Price's approach is seen as more effective in withstanding the increasingly arid conditions, as her garden appears better maintained than traditional English gardens with lawns and flower beds.

site_title: Taiwan still central to Singapore chipmakers despite geopolitical tensions
summary: Taiwan remains a crucial supply chain link for semiconductor firms in Singapore, despite tensions in the Taiwan Strait, with China's military drills having no immediate impact. While the situation may fuel a long-term trend of risk diversification, Taiwan's integral role in the sector and its 25% global semiconductor production make it unlikely to be suddenly shifted. Companies, including Micron and Infineon, have seen no immediate disruption and plan to continue operating as usual. Analysts note that diversification efforts have been underway for years, driven by factors such as the US-China trade war and supply chain bottlenecks.

site_title: China crisis wipes out US$90b of developer market value
summary: China's property developers have lost approximately $90 billion in market value this year, with shares down 27% and junk dollar bonds at record lows. The sector's debt crisis and bursting housing bubble threaten to inflict further pain, with pessimism becoming more entrenched. Beijing's focus on stabilizing the housing market, rather than supporting developers, has exacerbated the crisis. Experts predict a long-term decline in the industry, with a shift towards a more state-dominated business model and potentially lower property prices.

site_title: The rise of the side startup
summary: Remote workers are starting new businesses while maintaining their full-time jobs, taking advantage of a tight labor market. This trend, known as the "side startup," has increased in recent years, with more Americans starting their own businesses and a growing number of founders working for someone else. Remote work has enabled this, providing flexibility and time to pursue passions. Many side startup founders believe they can maintain the quality and quantity of work for their employer while working on their startups. However, some employers are wary, and the situation raises questions about who owns a worker's time and intellectual property.

site_title: ‘Enough is Enough’ kicks off rallies across UK to protest against rising cost of living
summary: The "Enough is Enough" campaign kicks off rallies across the UK to protest the rising cost of living, with transport workers holding strikes and rallies to advocate for higher wages. The strikes, starting with a train driver walkout on Aug 13, will continue through the week, coinciding with a rally in South London on Aug 17. The UK faces a cost-of-living crisis, with inflation at its highest in 40 years, and the strikes are seen as a major challenge to the government ahead of the Conservative Party leadership election.

site_title: VMware chief defends Broadcom deal as means of merging hardware and software
summary: VMware's CEO Raghu Raghuram defends the company's $61 billion deal with Broadcom, citing opportunities for collaboration and innovation in merging hardware and software. Despite concerns over cost-cutting and antitrust issues, Raghuram emphasizes VMware's research and development trajectory, including its 2-year research effort with semiconductor vendors. The deal is expected to be completed in October 2023, and VMware's stock has risen 27.4% since the announcement. Raghuram also highlights the benefits of transitioning to a subscription-based model, which will allow for faster innovation and improved customer experience.

site_title: Struggling Scandinavian carrier SAS gets US$700m loan
summary: Scandinavian airline SAS has secured a $700 million loan from Apollo Global Management to help it recover from financial struggles. The loan follows a 15-day pilot strike in July that cost the carrier $9-12 million a day. SAS filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the US and plans to implement a restructuring plan aimed at ensuring its survival. The airline's board chairman stated that the loan will enable SAS to continue meeting its obligations during the restructuring process, allowing it to focus on accelerating its cost-cutting plan, "SAS Forward".

site_title: Asia pivotal to the net-zero industrial revolution: Envision CEO
summary: Envision CEO Lei Zhang says Asia will be pivotal to the net-zero industrial revolution, with the region's industrial sector accounting for 35% of annual carbon-dioxide emissions. Envision plans to build 100 net-zero industrial parks worldwide, including in Asia, over the next decade, aiming to reduce global carbon emissions by 1 billion tons per year. The company has already built a net-zero industrial park in China, featuring a comprehensive clean energy solution, and believes countries in Asia, such as Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia, have vast potential for developing net-zero industrial parks.

site_title: Malaysia’s GDP growth to quicken on pent-up demand: finance minister
summary: Malaysia's GDP expanded 8.9% in the April-June period, beating the 7% median estimate, driven by pent-up demand and a boom in overseas trade. Finance Minister Zafrul Aziz attributed the growth to private consumption and low unemployment, but warned that the outlook will be more challenging in 2023 due to global slowdown fears. Malaysia's inflation pressures are expected to remain contained, but the government will need to rely on revenues and borrowing to offset a subsidy bill of RM80 billion.

site_title: More US home purchase deals fall through
summary: US real estate purchase deals are experiencing a rise in cancellations, with nearly 15% of deals falling through in June, the highest rate since the pandemic peak. This is attributed to rising mortgage interest rates, which can increase monthly payments and stretch the journey from accepted bid to closing day. The locations with the highest percentage of cancelled deals include Las Vegas, Lakeland, and Cape Coral, primarily in the south and southwest. The significant rate increases in 2022, from 3.79% to 5.3%, have been a major factor in the cancellations.

summary: Saudi Aramco reported a record-breaking Q2 profit of US$48.4 billion, driven by high crude prices and production. Revenue rose 80% to US$150 billion, beating analyst estimates. The company expects oil demand to continue growing despite economic pressures, and plans to use the windfall to reduce debt and invest in production capacity expansion. Aramco kept its quarterly dividend unchanged and reduced gearing to 7.9% from 14.2%. The company's shares have gained 25% this year, valuing the company at US$2.4 trillion.

Data centre, industrial, and diversified S-Reits led the sector's performance, with top performers including Digital Core Reit (18.3%), Daiwa House Logistics Trust (18%), and EC World Reit (16.7%). summary: Magnus, a nutritional drinks company, has voluntarily recalled several products, including oat drink Oatly, Optimum Nutrition protein powder, and Glucerna shakes, due to potential microbial contamination. The recall affects 89 products and was prompted by "root cause analysis" showing the products did not meet commercial sterility specifications. The recalled products include varieties of Organic Valley milk and Stumptown Cold Brew Coffee, and consumers are warned not to consume them due to the risk of Cronobacter sakazakii and Clostridium botulinum contamination.

Total sustainable fund assets in Asia, excluding Japan, slid 1.3 per cent quarter on quarter to US$61 million in the second quarter.
Shareholder activists need to write better climate proposals – ones that are sensible, rather than premature or overzealous.

site_title: Golden Agri H1 earnings rise to US$389.7 million amid palm oil price rally
summary: Golden Agri-Resources, a palm oil plantation company, reported a net profit of US$389.7 million for the first half of 2022, more than doubling the previous year's earnings. The company's topline increased by 23.3% due to the appreciation of crude palm oil prices. Despite recent price corrections, Golden Agri's CEO, Franky Widjaja, stated that the company's solid fundamentals and vertically integrated model protect it from market volatility. The company declared an interim cash dividend of S$0.008 per share and expects low to mid single-digit production growth if weather conditions are normal.

images.alt_text: Golden Agri-Resources said it achieved record Q1 performance on the back of a 32 per cent year-on-year increase in revenue.
CGS-CIMB has downgraded its call on Golden Agri-Resources to “hold” from “add”, as profit margins of the palm oil producer could take a hit from Indonesia’s palm oil export bans.
First Resources and Golden Agri-Resources were among the potential winners named by CGS-CIMB.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Happier days ahead for markets? (Ep 7)
summary: Global markets may be entering a period of improvement, according to a podcast by The Business Times. The episode, "BT Market Focus: Happier days ahead for markets?" (Ep 7), discusses market trends and analysis from SGX and The Business Times newsdesk. The podcast touches on US market performance, Singapore-specific updates, and company-specific news, despite heightened geopolitical tensions. The episode aims to provide general information and is not intended to be investment advice.

images.alt_text: Why geopolitical tensions didn't affect global markets much this week.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia rides wave of demand for more homes
summary: Hong Leong Asia posted a 4.5% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$42.6 million for the first half of the year, driven by a 26.5% revenue rise in its building materials unit. The company expects to benefit from Housing Board's plans to increase the supply of new flats, and its newly built Integrated Construction and Prefabrication Hub will allow it to manufacture locally precast building materials, a distinct advantage in the market.

images.alt_text: Stephen Ho, chief executive officer of Hong Leong Asia.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine falls 6.7% to a week-low after narrowing H1 losses
summary: Sembcorp Marine posted a net loss of S$142.9 million for the half year ended Jun 30. The company's shares fell 6.7% to a week-low of S$0.111, but recovered slightly to S$0.112. The loss narrowed from previous periods due to increased revenue recognition from floater projects and new contributions. Despite this, the company expects to book a net loss for the financial year 2022.

site_title: Malaysia economy expands 8.9% in Q2, exceeding majority of forecasts
summary: Malaysia's economy expanded 8.9% in Q2, exceeding forecasts of 5-8.5%. The growth was driven by domestic demand, improving labor market, and resilient exports. The central bank governor attributed the boost to the border reopening in April, particularly in the manufacturing and services sectors. GDP growth is expected to continue in the third quarter, with forecasts ranging from 5.3% to 6.3% for the full year. The central bank has maintained its accommodative stance, with interest rates remaining low, and has taken steps to secure consumer data following a potential breach by payment gateway service provider iPay88.

images.alt_text: Economists are positive on Malaysia's economic growth in the 2Q2022 as the impact of border reopening will reflect in its GDP growth in April-June.

site_title: Hong Kong growth hopes crumble under Covid-19 policy weight
summary: Hong Kong's population fell 1.6% to approximately 7.29 million in the year ended June 30, attributed to Covid-19 restrictions, resulting in a record brain drain. The city's economy is expected to struggle with Covid restrictions, trade slump, and global headwinds, leading to a potential downgrade of its GDP growth forecast for the year. This would be the second downgrade, following a May cut to a 1-2% growth range.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has seen a decline of 121,500 residents in the year ended Jun 30, leaving the population at about 7.29 million.
Recent data show that the Chinese economy is emerging from its trough in early 2022 and gaining momentum.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon pardons Samsung leader Jay Y. Lee
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol granted a pardon to Samsung Electronics vice-chairman Jay Y. Lee, who was serving an 18-month parole for bribery. The pardon is largely symbolic, as Lee had already been released from jail. Lee's case was related to his time leading the world's largest smartphone and memory-chip maker. The pardon does not necessarily exonerate Lee, but rather reflects a gesture of goodwill from the president.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as traders contemplate more rate hikes
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, with most cities experiencing slight losses, as traders anticipated continued interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The US Federal Reserve's warnings on inflation and interest rates tempered optimism following the release of inflation reports, which showed improvement but not a victory over runaway inflation. The Fed's San Francisco chief, Mary Daly, suggested a potential half-point interest rate hike next month and held out the possibility of a third consecutive three-quarter-point increase.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Seoul, Taipei and Manila stocks all rose more than 1 per cent, while Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington and Jakarta were also up on Thursday.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit H1 DPU rises 2.3% to 8.695 euro cents
summary: Cromwell E-Reit reported a 2.3% increase in its half-year distribution per unit (DPU) to 8.695 euro cents, driven by 8.5% growth in gross revenue and 4.7% growth in net property income. Portfolio occupancy reached an all-time high of 95.4% at end-2021. The Reit manager expects to grow its portfolio at a slower pace due to market volatility but anticipates no further debt maturity until November 2024. Despite macro headwinds, Cromwell E-Reit's long-term attractive fundamentals remain intact.

images.alt_text: Cromwell E-Reit has acquired its third logistics asset in the UK for £18.9 million (S$31.6 million) from a third-party vendor.
The Europe-focused Reit also reported gains in gross revenue and net property income.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, rebounding from gains on Wall Street, as US economic data showed inflation may be slowing. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.44%, and the Topix index climbed 1.07%, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 reaching 28,221.05.

site_title: Robinhood must face manipulation claims over meme trading: judge
summary: A US federal judge has allowed some market manipulation claims against Robinhood to proceed, ruling that the platform's January 2021 decision to halt purchases of GameStop Corp. shares and other meme stocks raised "interesting legal questions." The judge dismissed claims that Robinhood misled investors about liquidity issues, but allowed investors to pursue claims that the platform's actions were intended to push them into selling shares. The ruling is preliminary and doesn't address the merits of the litigation, with Robinhood maintaining that its actions were necessary due to extraordinary market conditions.

site_title: Twitter's plan to fight US midterm misinformation falls short: voting rights experts
summary: Twitter has unveiled a plan to combat election misinformation ahead of the US midterm elections, but civil rights and online misinformation experts say it falls short. The plan relies on labeling or removing posts with misleading content, but experts argue that more emphasis should be placed on removing false and misleading posts. Critics also say Twitter should take a stronger stance against world leaders who spread misinformation, and that simply pointing users to reliable resources is not enough to combat the issue.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, First Resources, Olam, Nanofilm, Straits Trading
summary: Stocks to watch on Friday included ST Engineering, which fell 0.5% after posting a 5.4% drop in net profit for the first half, while First Resources rose 1.4% despite lower sales volumes. Sembmarine narrowed its losses to S$142.9 million, and Nanofilm Technologies saw a 5.1% year-on-year increase in net profit. Olam Group reported a 1.8% growth in net profit, and The Straits Trading Company's real estate segment posted a 448.9% increase in net profit.

site_title: Sasseur Reit posts 1.6% dip in Q2 DPU on Covid-19 impact in China
summary: Sasseur Reit posted a 1.6% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.588 Singapore cents in Q2, impacted by Covid-19 lockdowns in China. Despite this, the Reit's overall H1 performance was more upbeat, with DPU rising 1.1% to 3.41 Singapore cents. Portfolio occupancy improved to 96% in Q2, returning to pre-Covid levels. The Reit's chairman expressed confidence in the long-term growth potential of the economy, citing the government's efforts to boost domestic consumption.

images.alt_text: Despite global economic headwinds, the group remains focused on disciplined capital deployment and sustainable growth, as well as value creation for its shareholders, said executive chairman of Straits Trading, Chew Gek Khim.
IReit Global inked a 6-year lease extension for the entire Bonn Campus in Q2.
Recent data show that the Chinese economy is emerging from its trough in early 2022 and gaining momentum.

site_title: Asian Pay TV Trust posts S$0.0025 DPU for Q2 as broadband segment gains speed
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust posted a 49.7% increase in Q2 net profit to S$11.5 million, driven by the broadband segment's 16.4% revenue growth to S$16 million. The trust declared a distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.0025 Singapore cents, reaffirming its 2022 full-year guidance of 1 cent per unit. Despite lower basic cable TV revenue, the broadband segment's success reflects the company's strategy to target the broadband-only segment.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine H1 performance improves as losses narrow to S$142.9m
summary: Sembcorp Marine's losses narrowed to S$142.9 million for the half year ended Jun 30, from a net loss of S$647.2 million last year, driven by "significantly higher revenue recognition" from floater projects. Turnover increased 29.7% to S$1.1 billion, while the net order book improved to S$2.52 billion. The company attributes the recovery to rising oil prices and energy security concerns. Despite the improvement, Sembmarine still expects a net loss for the financial year 2022.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit H1 DPU falls 4.6% on absence of year-ago items
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported a 4.6% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.91 US cents for the first half of the year, due to lower income top-ups from its sponsor and a one-time compensation stipulated damage income. However, excluding these items, DPU would have been 13.4% higher. The Reit's gross revenue rose 18.5% to $31.8 million, with net property income and distributable income also increasing. Despite a 10% rise in property operating expenses, the Reit's leverage ratio remains stable, and it is exploring refinancing options for debt maturing next year.

images.alt_text: Robert Schmitt, CEO of the manager of United Hampshire US Real Estate Investment Trust (UHREIT), believes its portfolio of properties offers essential goods and services that consumers will need to purchase regardless of the state of the economy.

site_title: ST Engineering faces short-term headwinds as it grapples with chip shortages
summary: ST Engineering reported a 5.4% drop in net profit for the first half of 2022, to S$280 million, due to higher transaction and integration expenses related to its Transcore acquisition and the tax-exempt effect of the Job Support Scheme. Despite this, revenue grew 17% to S$4.3 billion, driven by higher contributions from all business segments. The company expects to mitigate the impact of global headwinds, including chip shortages and supply chain disruptions, through cost-saving measures and supply chain reconfiguration.

images.alt_text: The Air distributed mission trainer (ADMT), a light simulation training system that lets pilots of different aircraft participate in the sametraining scenario at the same time, such as advanced lighter operations and mission rehearsals.

site_title: German regulator fines Bank of America 5.1m euros for delays in reporting
summary: Germany's financial market regulator BaFin fined Bank of America 5.1 million euros (S$7.2 million) for delays in reporting voting rights notifications. The fine was imposed after Bank of America failed to submit the required notifications on time. The bank declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: NTUC to engage 20,000 people through feedback exercise
summary: NTUC plans to engage 20,000 Singaporeans in a feedback exercise titled #EveryWorkerMatters Conversations, aimed at shaping the country's social compact around work and employment. The exercise, launched by labour chief Ng Chee Meng, seeks to address three key questions: how to support workers in the new economic environment, how to provide stronger financial support for job-seekers, and how to protect vulnerable workers. The NTUC will gather feedback through surveys, focus group discussions, and workshops before releasing recommendations in mid-2023.

images.alt_text: In a May Day message unveiled on Saturday (Apr 30), labour chief Ng Chee Meng said the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) needs to look at the needs of the workforce of Singapore's future beyond representing workers.

site_title: Truss rules out fresh UK windfall tax; Sunak open to idea
summary: Liz Truss has ruled out a fresh windfall tax on energy companies if she becomes UK Prime Minister, while Rishi Sunak has proposed finding up to £10 billion to help households pay soaring power bills. Truss argued that profit is not a dirty word and that energy giants should be held accountable, while Sunak's plan includes levying more funds from power companies, identifying savings, and increasing borrowing. Truss has also vowed to review the regulation of utilities, including water companies, and has expressed support for fracking and other alternative energy sources.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars buoyed by softer Federal Reserve hike views
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are experiencing their strongest weekly gains of the year due to softer US economic data, which has lowered expectations of faster interest rate hikes. The Aussie rose 0.14% to US$0.7095, while the kiwi increased 0.05% to US$0.6431. The weaker US dollar is attributed to a decrease in inflation expectations and lower-than-expected jobless claims. However, economists warn that risks remain to the downside, and the currencies' recovery is unlikely to be sustained, with a less hawkish Federal Reserve in September potentially leading to a decrease in interest rates.
