site_title: Germany plans reconstruction conference for Ukraine in October
summary: Germany is set to host an international conference in October to discuss the reconstruction of Ukraine following Russia's invasion. The conference, co-hosted by Chancellor Olaf Scholz and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, will focus on how to best spend a promised 9 billion euro emergency aid package. The European Union, which has committed to contributing 500 billion euros, is still negotiating how to raise the funds. The conference aims to provide a roadmap for rebuilding Ukraine's infrastructure, with Chancellor Scholz stating that the package will be bigger than the Marshall Plan.

images.alt_text: McDonald’s had 109 restaurants in Ukraine, but did not specify how many it planned to reopen. It sold most of its 850 restaurants in Russia to one of its local licensees in May.

site_title: Chinese screenwriter vows to seek retrial after losing harassment case
summary: A Chinese screenwriter, Zhou Xiaoxuan, 29, has vowed to seek a retrial after losing a harassment case against a well-known host on state broadcaster CCTV, Zhu Jun. Zhou accused Zhu of groping and forcibly kissing her in 2014, allegations he denies. A Beijing court rejected her appeals, upholding the original judgement, but Zhou plans to apply for a retrial despite slim chances of success, citing the case as a blow to China's #MeToo movement.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower after global markets closed mixed; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to 3,282.93, with 67 losers outnumbering 64 gainers. Yangzijiang Financial Holding dropped 1.3%, Thaibev lost 2.9%, while DBS rose 0.4%, OCBC slid 2.5%, and UOB dipped 0.1%. The decline followed mixed global markets, with the Dow Jones Industrial rising 0.1%, the S&P 500 closing down 0.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropping 0.6%.

images.alt_text: Estee Lauder Cos Inc on Monday forecast full-year revenue and profit above Wall Street expectations, putting to bed concerns of slowing demand in China due to trade tensions and Hong Kong protests as sales of its luxury skin care products soared, propelling its shares to a record high.

site_title: Shortages of some chips drag on even amid signs of industry rout
summary: Industry-wide chip shortages persist despite shrinking delivery times, with lead times averaging 26.9 weeks in July. Supply of power management parts and microcontrollers remains tight, and prices of some products continue to rise. Demand for components used in personal computers and smartphones is declining, but industrywide shortages persist, costing companies billions of dollars in lost revenue.

site_title: FBI agents condemn threats against agency after Trump raid
summary: The FBI Agents Association condemned threats against the agency after a raid on former President Donald Trump's home, calling them "unacceptable" and contributing to an atmosphere where violence against law enforcement is acceptable. The threats followed Trump's claims of a "corrupt" and "politicised" FBI. Attorney General Merrick Garland defended the agency, saying the threats were "unfounded." Meanwhile, an armed man was involved in a pursuit with law enforcement in Cincinnati, Ohio, after targeting the FBI office.

site_title: ST Engineering posts 5.4% drop in H1 profit due to Transcore acquisition
summary: ST Engineering reported a 5.4% drop in H1 net profit to S$280 million due to higher transaction and integration expenses for its Transcore acquisition. Revenue grew 17% to S$4.3 billion, driven by contributions from all business segments. Earnings per share fell 5% to S$0.0899. A second interim dividend of S$0.04 was approved for the quarter ended Jun 30. Despite this, shares of ST Engineering fell 0.5% to S$4.07.

site_title: Germans brace for colder apartments, dim streets this winter
summary: Germany prepares for a long, cold winter amid an energy crisis caused by Russia's war on Ukraine. The country's reliance on natural gas from Russia, which accounts for 55% of its imports, has been significantly reduced by 80% via the Nord Stream 1 pipeline. Germans are bracing for the consequences, including hardware stores selling out of electric heaters and cities implementing measures to reduce energy consumption, such as dimming streetlights and turning off warm water in public buildings. The government is urging citizens to save energy, but experts warn that the situation is serious and that a short-term alternative to coal is needed to prevent a gas shortage.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial H1 profit falls 30.6% on fair value loss amid weak markets
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding, a recently spun-off company, reported a 30.6% decline in H1 net profit to S$136.4 million due to a S$19 million loss from fair value changes. Total income fell 27.3% to S$173.8 million, mainly due to the company's diversification into offshore investments and reduction in debt investments in China.

site_title: Olam H1 profit up 1.8% to S$429.1m; declares S$0.04 interim dividend
summary: Olam Group reported a 1.8% increase in net profit to S$429.1 million for the first half of fiscal year 2022, driven by strong Ebit growth and higher prices across products and commodities. Revenue rose 24.6% to S$28.4 billion. Finance costs expanded 36.7% due to high interest rates and taxes. Olam declared an interim dividend of 4 cents per share and remains cautiously optimistic about its prospects for the rest of the year.

site_title: Crypto lender tied to Chinese rig giant throws miners a lifeline
summary: Bitmain, a Chinese Bitcoin mining rig giant, is offering low-interest loans to miners through its ties with industry financier Antalpha to help them reduce borrowing costs and repay nearly $4 billion in loans. The loans, which can have interest rates as low as 6.6%, will be secured by the Bitcoin miners produce and will not require margin calls. This move aims to alleviate some of the pressure on miners during the cryptocurrency market downturn, which has seen Bitcoin prices fall and energy costs soar due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Europe: Shares tick higher; Aegon shines on forecast raise
summary: Europe's shares rose 0.1% on Thursday, driven by a strong rally in the previous session on signs of US inflation cooling. Aegon climbed 8.9% after raising its full-year forecast, while oil stocks led gains. Healthcare shares fell, however, amid declining shares of GSK, Sanofi, and Haleon. The Stoxx 600 index is down about 10% this year, compared to a 11% decline for the S&P 500.

site_title: We are still in a race against the coronavirus
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing, with the US facing potential 100,000-250,000 annual deaths from endemic cases. Scientists argue that human ingenuity may not be able to keep pace with the virus's rapid evolution, which has led to the emergence of variants like Omicron. To combat this, genomic epidemiology, a field that tracks changes in viral genomes, is crucial. However, gaps remain in sequencing surveillance, particularly in low- and middle-income countries, and investments are needed for better vaccines, antiviral drugs, ventilation systems, and air filtration. The world needs more scientific leadership and funding to address these challenges and prevent further suffering.

site_title: Hong Kong population drops by record as people flee Covid curbs
summary: Hong Kong's population dropped by a record 1.6% in the year ended June 30, reaching 7.29 million, with 121,500 residents fleeing strict Covid-19 restrictions. This marks the third straight year of declines and the biggest drop in at least 6 decades. The decline is attributed to the city's continued impact of Covid-19, stringent border control, and quarantine measures, as well as a national security law. The population has only seen a few instances of decline since 1961, with recent declines swelled amid the city's tight pandemic controls and campaign against dissent.

images.alt_text: People arriving in Hong Kong from overseas will need to spend 3 days in hotel quarantine and can then serve their 4 days of health monitoring.
Business groups, who have pushed the government for months to scrap quarantine requirements altogether, responded negatively to Monday’s announcement.

site_title: ThaiBev defers brewery unit listing, cites ‘challenging’ market
summary: ThaiBev has deferred the initial public offering (IPO) of its brewery unit in Singapore, citing "prolonged challenging market conditions". The company will continue to monitor market conditions and explore opportunities to maximize shareholders' value, potentially reviewing the proposed spin-off listing at an appropriate time. The IPO, which could be Singapore's biggest since 2017, was set to raise up to 20% of the unit. The decision comes just months after the firm announced plans to resume the listing and conduct a public offering.

site_title: Sri Lanka's ousted president arrives in Thailand for temporary stay
summary: Former Sri Lankan president Gotabaya Rajapaksa arrived in Thailand on a chartered flight from Singapore, seeking temporary shelter after fleeing amid mass protests. He resigned from office following the country's worst economic crisis in 7 decades. Thai authorities stated Rajapaksa has no intention of seeking asylum and will only stay temporarily, with a 90-day diplomatic passport. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha said Rajapaksa could not participate in any political activities while in Thailand.

images.alt_text: Mr Gotabaya Rajapaksa boarded a flight from Singapore to Bangkok on Thursday morning.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed as Wall Street loses momentum
summary: US stocks ended the day mixed on Thursday, as a Labor Department report showed a sharp decline in wholesale prices and inflation. The producer price index (PPI) fell 0.5% in July, with a 9% drop in energy prices. Despite this, the market lost momentum, with the S&P 500 closing down 0.1% and the Dow Jones Industrial rising 0.1%. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates, but uncertainty remains.

site_title: Debt issuers wonder if ESG label is worth it as skepticism spreads
summary: Bonds issuers are reevaluating the benefits of tapping the Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) debt market amid growing skepticism about the accuracy of ESG claims. Some issuers, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, are rejecting ESG debt pitches due to concerns over greenwashing. The regulatory crackdown on greenwashing has shifted focus from asset managers to the finance industry, with issuers facing reputational risks and scrutiny over the accuracy of their ESG metrics. As the market tightens, issuers are taking a more cautious approach, weighing the costs and benefits of ESG labeling.

site_title: Credit Suisse applies to kick-off London Softbank lawsuit
summary: Credit Suisse has filed a request with a London court to start a lawsuit against SoftBank Group, blaming the Japanese bank for losses suffered by clients due to the collapse of finance firm Greensill Capital in 2021. The Swiss lender is seeking to reclaim $2.7 billion in overdue loan payments from borrowers, including US-based construction company Katerra. SoftBank denies allegations, stating that Credit Suisse's poor investment decisions are to blame. The lawsuit is the latest in a long-anticipated legal battle between the two banks.

site_title: Hong Fok H1 net profit jumps 80% to S$9.1m
summary: Hong Fok Corporation reported an 80% increase in net profit to S$9.1 million for the first half of 2022, driven by a 30% rise in revenue to S$55.6 million. The property developer attributed the increase to higher sales of Concourse Skyline residential units and rental income from its hotel, Yotel Singapore Orchard Road. However, a decrease in property management income partially offset the gains. Earnings per share rose to S$0.0138, and the company expects stable occupancy rates for its other properties and continued strong demand for residential units.

site_title: Centurion Corp’s H1 earnings surge to S$33m on higher revenue, one-off fair-value gains
summary: Centurion Corp posted a 277% surge in earnings to S$32.9 million for the first half of the year, driven by higher revenue and one-off fair-value gains. Core business earnings rose 42% to S$29 million, while group revenue increased 40% to S$90.5 million. The company attributed the growth to stronger contributions from purpose-built workers' and student accommodations in Singapore, Australia, and the UK.

images.alt_text: Centurion noted a net fair value gain in H1 2022 as compared with a net fair value loss of approximately S$14.5 million in H1 2021, in relation to its investment properties.

site_title: Nanofilm H1 net profit up 5% to S$18.8 million; board proposes S$0.011 interim dividend
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a nanotechnology solutions provider, reported a 5.1% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$18.8 million in the first half of 2022. Revenue rose 15.2% to S$111.3 million. The company proposed an interim dividend of S$0.011 per share, citing its strong financial position and cash-generating operations. Despite a challenging operating environment caused by Shanghai's Covid-19 lockdown, the company's business unit-driven strategy delivered positive results, with deeper application expansion of its nanotechnology solutions.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB and DBS have maintained their “add” and “buy” calls respectively, remaining positive on Nanofilm’s long-term growth prospects.

site_title: First Resources H1 profit rises 293% to US$128m; declares S$0.025 interim dividend
summary: First Resources, a palm oil producer, reported a 293% increase in H1 profit to US$128m. The company harvested 1.63 million tonnes of fresh fruit bunches, down 0.6% from last year. Crude palm oil production declined 6.6% due to reduced third-party crop purchases. Shares ended Thursday S$0.02 lower at S$1.43. The company expects stockpiles in Indonesia to normalize in the coming months.

site_title: Xiaomi has 140 vehicles across China testing autonomous driving: CEO
summary: Xiaomi is testing 140 autonomous electric vehicles in China, marking a significant step in the company's entry into the competitive EV sector. CEO Lei Jun announced the development, which involves 500 staff and a 3.3 billion yuan investment. The company aims to bring its cars to mass production in the first half of 2024. This move follows other Chinese companies, including Didi Global and Baidu, which are also investing in self-driving technology. Xiaomi's foray into EVs is seen as a challenge to established brands and younger tech companies.

images.alt_text: Jidu Auto, a joint venture set up by Baidu with China automaker Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, is sounding out potential investors and could seek a valuation of about US$3.5 billion in the round.

site_title: US mortgage rates swing back up, hitting 5.22% in volatile market
summary: US mortgage rates surged to 5.22% for a 30-year loan, the first increase since July 21, according to Freddie Mac. The rate rise puts pressure on the cooling housing market, with potential buyers struggling to find affordable properties. The housing market is stabilizing, with home inventory increasing and homebuilders facing rising unsold properties. Experts say the market is transitioning from pandemic-era frenzy to a more balanced market, with a welcome change for buyers.

site_title: Oil settles up as IEA hikes 2022 demand growth forecast
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Thursday as the International Energy Agency increased its forecast for oil demand growth in 2022, citing soaring natural gas prices. Brent crude futures gained $2.20 to $99.60 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose $2.41 to $94.34. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) cut its forecast for 2022 oil demand growth due to the impact of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and high inflation. The US dollar's decline against other currencies also contributed to the price increase.

site_title: J&J to end global sales of talc-based baby powder
summary: Johnson & Johnson will stop selling talc-based baby powder globally in 2023, following its US sales halt in 2020 due to consumer safety lawsuits claiming the product caused cancer from asbestos contamination. The company denies allegations, citing decades of scientific testing and regulatory approvals. The decision comes after J&J assigned its talc claims to subsidiary LTL Management, which filed for bankruptcy, and faced $3.5 billion in verdicts and settlements. The company will transition to an all cornstarch-based baby powder portfolio.

images.alt_text: Nets has appointed DBS's Singapore country head Shee Tse Koon to its board of directors, effective Aug 13.
Johnson & Johnson will stop selling talc-based baby powder globally in 2023, the drugmaker said on Thursday.

site_title: McDonald's to start reopening restaurants in Ukraine
summary: McDonald's plans to reopen its 109 restaurants in Ukraine over the next few months, marking an early sign of western businesses returning to the country despite the ongoing conflict with Russia. The decision follows the closure of all McDonald's restaurants in Ukraine and Russia in March after Moscow's invasion. The company sold most of its 850 Russia restaurants to a local licensee in May. This move indicates a gradual return to normal operations for the global fast-food chain.

images.alt_text: McDonald's global same-store sales jumped nearly 10 per cent in the second quarter compared with expectation of a 6.5 per cent rise.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia H1 net profit up 4.5% to S$42.6 million despite lower revenue
summary: Hong Leong Asia's net profit rose 4.5% to S$42.6 million in the first half of 2022, driven by a 26.5% increase in building materials unit revenue. However, revenue declined 26.1% to S$2.1 billion due to lower sales volume in the diesel engines segment, primarily affected by renewed Covid-related lockdowns in China. The company remains cautiously optimistic about its business units' resilience in the second half of 2022, citing efforts to innovate and improve productivity.

images.alt_text: Hong Leong Asia H2 net profit falls 26% to S$19.4 million

site_title: UK says energy firms agreed to do more to help people as bills surge
summary: The UK government has agreed with energy firms to work together to help households struggling with rising energy bills, which are expected to more than triple this year. The government will evaluate extraordinary profits in the electricity generation sector and consider support measures. Charities warn that millions could be forced into poverty if no multi-billion pound support package is launched. Foreign Secretary Liz Truss has also promised to work with energy companies to bring down prices if she becomes prime minister.

site_title: Singapore’s inaugural green bond issue sees public offer fully subscribed at 1.06 times
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced its inaugural green bond issue, which saw a public offer fully subscribed at 1.06 times, with 1,749 applications totaling S$52.9 million. The S$50 million green bond was fully allotted to 1,720 applicants, while 21 applicants were each given S$228,000. The bonds, priced at 3.04% yield, will be used to finance the Singapore Green Plan 2030, including new MRT lines.

images.alt_text: Headline inflation in the Philippines quickened to 6.4 per cent on year in July, outstripping estimates for a 6.1 per cent gain.
The proceeds raised from these bonds will be used to finance expenditures in support of the Singapore Green Plan 2030, including 2 new MRT lines — the Jurong Region Line and the Cross Island Line.

site_title: Airlines cancel about 600 flights in US as thunderstorms hit operations
summary: Airlines in the US cancelled approximately 600 flights on Thursday due to thunderstorms in Dallas, affecting operations at the DFW International Airport. This is part of a larger trend, with 1,213 flights cancelled across the country on Wednesday. The cancellations were attributed to "unexpected and heavy" thunderstorms at American Airlines' largest hub, leading to disruptions in air travel.

site_title: SK Hynix to break ground on new US chip packaging plant early next year: sources
summary: SK Hynix plans to break ground on a new US chip packaging plant in the first quarter of 2023, with an estimated cost of "several billions" and expected to employ around 1,000 workers by 2025-2026. The plant will be located near a university with engineering talent and will package SK Hynix's memory chips with logic chips designed by US companies for machine learning and AI applications. The move is part of a $22 billion US-based investment package announced by SK Group, which includes $15 billion for the semiconductor industry.

images.alt_text: The new SK Hynix plant would ramp up to mass production by 2025-2026 and employ about 1,000 workers, one of the sources said.

site_title: Maverick winemakers in Bordeaux
summary: Newcomers are bringing a fresh perspective to the tradition-bound wine region of Bordeaux. Penfolds, a leading Australian wine producer, has partnered with Dourthe, an established Bordeaux name, to create Penfolds II, a red wine blend. The collaboration, dubbed "Wine of the World," brings together new ways of thinking and inventive winemaking. Independent vignerons like Loic Pasquet, who produces wines using old varieties and ungrafted rootstock, are also contributing to the region's diversity. The partnership aims to promote new horizons for fine wine and Bordeaux, and experts believe it will lead to further advances and understanding of fine wine making.

images.alt_text: Designated a UNESCO world heritage site, the historic centre of Bordeaux has more protected buildings than any other French city except Paris.

site_title: Riverstone posts 80% drop in H1 earnings to RM209m amid glove oversupply
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a Malaysian glove manufacturer, reported an 80% drop in H1 earnings to RM209m, down from RM1.04 billion in the same period last year. The company attributed the decline to an oversupply of gloves and inventory due to extensive investments in production expansion by the market and new players. Despite this, Riverstone plans to build new cleanroom facilities to maintain its market leadership in the cleanroom gloves segment and increase capacity to 12 billion by end 2022.

images.alt_text: Average selling prices of healthcare gloves have come off historic highs seen in Q1 2021, Riverstone Holdings noted in its bourse filing on May 10.

site_title: Yanlord Land‘s H1 earnings jump 67% to 1.4b yuan on higher profit margin
summary: Yanlord Land Group, a Chinese property developer, reported a 67.2% increase in earnings to 1.4 billion yuan (S$279.6 million) for the first half of 2022, driven by a 8.9 percentage point rise in gross profit margin to 35.6%. Despite a 14% decline in revenue, gross profit rose 14.6% to 4 billion yuan, mainly due to higher average selling prices. The company attributed the challenging period to the COVID-19 outbreak and increasing debt defaults in the Chinese developer sector.

images.alt_text: Updated photo of 79 Anson Road, Singapore 079906 taken on 1 July 2022.

site_title: BlackRock launches spot bitcoin private trust for US clients
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, has launched a spot bitcoin private trust for US institutional clients, offering direct exposure to the price of bitcoin. The trust tracks the performance of bitcoin despite a slump in the digital asset market. This move follows a partnership between BlackRock and Coinbase Global to provide institutional clients with access to crypto trading and custody services. The development highlights the growing interest of traditional institutions in crypto assets, which have been battered by recent price downturns.

site_title: Budding talent needs time to blossom at Ce Soir
summary: Singaporean chef Koh Han Jie's French restaurant, Ce Soir, offers an elaborate floral setting and promising dishes, but execution falls short. The young chef's technical skills are evident, with sauces and meats cooked to perfection, but flavors lack nuance and complexity. The menu often feels one-dimensional and literal translations of dishes found elsewhere. Despite this, the restaurant's pricing is well-suited for the high-quality ingredients used. With potential and room for growth, Ce Soir earns a 6.5 rating, with the chef needing to drop the fake flowers and explore wider influences to reach his full potential.

images.alt_text: Reve's tasteful interiors.

site_title: EU says US tax credits for electric cars ‘discriminatory’
summary: The European Union expressed concern over US tax credits for electric vehicle purchases, stating they are discriminatory against European carmakers. The US Senate approved a $7,500 tax credit for electric vehicles from North American factories with US-made batteries, potentially harming non-US companies. The EU urges the US to remove discriminatory elements and ensure compliance with the World Trade Organization. This move comes as the US seeks to reduce supply dependencies on China, the world's largest lithium-ion battery maker.

site_title: Straits Trading H1 net profit surges 448.9% to S$673m on contributions from real estate segment
summary: Straits Trading Company reported a net profit of S$673 million for the first half of 2022, surging 448.9% from the previous year, driven by strong contributions from its real estate segment. The real estate segment delivered a net profit of S$676.1 million, largely due to the sale of its stake in ARA Asset Management to ESR Group. Despite global economic headwinds, the company remains focused on disciplined capital deployment and sustainable growth, with earnings per share rising 5.2 times.

images.alt_text: Lockheed Martin (above, its office in Florida) also has an office in Gloucester. The company is a current tenant in one of the 9 properties acquired by Straits Real Estate, a unit of mainboard-listed Straits Trading.

site_title: US producer prices fall in July, underlying inflation slows
summary: US producer prices fell 0.5% in July, marking a decline after a 1.0% increase in June. This drop was largely due to a decrease in energy product costs. Underlying producer inflation appears to be slowing, with the core PPI increasing 0.2% in July. The Federal Reserve is considering a potential rate hike to combat demand and bring inflation back to its 2% goal, following a 225 basis point increase since March.

images.alt_text: Food is one component of the CPI that remained elevated in July, rising 1.1 per cent last month after climbing 1.0 per cent in June.

site_title: HSBC oversold risks of US$35b Asia spin-off, investor Ping An thinks: source
summary: HSBC, a major bank with a significant presence in Asia, has been pressured by its largest shareholder Ping An Insurance Group to consider spinning off its Asian business, potentially worth up to $35 billion. Ping An believes this move would increase shareholder returns, but HSBC has argued it would bring immediate risks and a long-term hit to its credit rating and operating costs. The dispute highlights HSBC's challenges in navigating geopolitical tensions and criticism from lawmakers over its activities in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Ken Lui is seeking to build on an effort from 2020 when he gathered about 3,000 local investors to protest HSBC's move to stop paying dividends as the Coronavirus erupted.

In a sign of growing confidence in its ability to improve profitability despite the global economic uncertainty, HSBC raised its near-term return on tangible equity goal to at least 12 per cent from 2023 onwards.

Ping An Insurance Group Co of China Ltd, the bank’s biggest shareholder, called on London-headquartered HSBC in April to explore strategic options such as spinning off its mainstay Asian business to unlock greater shareholder value.
In a notice published on HSBC's website this month inviting investors to the informal meeting, the bank said it would provide attendees with an "update on group strategy".

site_title: US dollar slides further after US inflation surprise
summary: The US dollar fell 0.2% against major currencies, its biggest daily drop in 5 months, after softer-than-expected US inflation data. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike expectations were tempered, with traders now betting on a half-point increase instead of a 75-basis-point hike. The euro and Japanese yen gained against the dollar, while sterling dipped 0.2%. The US inflation data showed prices were unchanged in July, after advancing 1.3% in June, suggesting inflation may have peaked.

site_title: Top China chipmaker defies US sanctions as earnings beat estimates
summary: China's largest chipmaker, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), has defied US sanctions by posting a net income of $514.3 million in the second quarter, beating estimates. The company's advances in technology helped cushion the impact from US sanctions, which have curbed China's chip ambitions. SMIC's revenue was $1.9 billion, and the company reported progress in developing alternative silicon technologies. However, industry experts caution that these advancements may not meet the same standards as larger rivals. The company's stock performance remains uncertain due to worsening electronics demand and global market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's national security officials want to persuade Apple Inc’s supplier Foxconn to unwind an US$800 million investment in Chinese chipmaker Tsinghua Unigroup.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 25.18 points, or 0.08 per cent, at the open to 32,807.36.

site_title: IReit Global posts 1.4% dip in H1 DPU; distributable income up 20.4%
summary: IReit Global, a European-focused real estate investment trust, reported a 1.4% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.41 euro cents for the first half of 2022, due to 100% payment of management fees in cash. However, income available for distribution rose 20.4% to 18.2 million euros, driven by the acquisition of French and Spanish portfolios. Portfolio occupancy remained stable at 95% and weighted average lease expiry improved to 4.7 years, with key lease extensions contributing to a 1 billion euro portfolio valuation.

images.alt_text: This is not Chua’s first time in the new position, having been the CFO of CapitaLand Commercial Trust management and Daiwa house asset management previously.

site_title: US jobless claims rise again, near highest since November
summary: US jobless claims rose by 14,000 to 262,000 in the week ended Aug 6, near the highest level since November, according to Labor Department data. Continuing claims for state benefits increased to 1.43 million. The rise in jobless claims is attributed to companies, particularly in the tech sector, announcing layoffs and freezing hiring due to economic uncertainty. Despite this, employers are trying to hold onto existing staff amid labor shortages, following the July jobs report's strong showing.

site_title: Gotabaya Rajapaksa leaves Singapore for Thailand after short-term visit pass expires
summary: Former Sri Lanka President Gotabaya Rajapaksa left Singapore for Thailand after his short-term visit pass expired on August 11. He boarded a flight from Singapore to Bangkok, following a request from the current Sri Lankan government for a visit due to humanitarian reasons. Rajapaksa's stay in Thailand is temporary, with no intention for political asylum, according to the Thai government.

images.alt_text: Former Sri Lankan president Gotabaya Rajapaksa has requested entry into Thailand for a temporary stay in a second South-east Asian country after fleeing his island nation last month amid mass protests, the Thai foreign ministry said on Wednesday(Aug 10).

site_title: US: Wall St rises on more signs of cooling inflation
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 142.00 points, or 0.43%, to 33,451.51. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, driven by fresh signs of cooling inflation, which strengthened expectations of a smaller interest rate hike. The rally comes amid uncertainty over US-EU trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., August 8, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: GHY Culture & Media tumbles into net loss of S$1.4m in H1
summary: GHY Culture & Media reported a net loss of S$1.4 million for the six months ended June 2022, down from a net profit of S$3.5 million in the same period last year. Group revenue fell 53% to S$20.6 million, and earnings per share dropped to S$0.0013. The company attributed the decline to foreign-exchange losses and delays in contract signings due to tightened Covid-19 measures in China. However, it expects its TV and film-production business to ramp up in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: GHY Culture & Media posts S$3.5m net profit, down 73%

site_title: Frencken’s H1 earnings fall 17% to S$26.1m despite higher revenue
summary: Frencken Group reported a 17% decline in first-half earnings to S$26.1 million, despite a 3.6% increase in revenue to S$388.9 million. Higher orders for front-end semiconductor equipment from Europe and Asia drove the revenue growth, while increased operating costs, weaker automotive segment performance, and expansion costs contributed to the earnings decline. Gross profit decreased 7% to S$60.8 million, with a 1.8 percentage point drop in gross profit margin.

images.alt_text: RHB had previously downgraded the mainboard-listed company to “neutral” on higher costs which hampered net profit growth and the devaluation of global tech stocks.

site_title: NSL back in the black with H1 earnings of S$5.8m
summary: NSL, an industrial group, has posted a net profit of S$5.8 million for the first half of the year, reversing a net loss of S$3.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 39% to S$174.9 million, driven by a 45% rise in its Precast & Prefabricated Bathroom Unit division. Earnings per share rose to S$0.0156, up from a loss per share of S$0.0098 in the previous year.

site_title: STI up 0.5% as Asia stocks rally on cooler-than-expected US inflation data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to 3,301.96, following a regional rally, as traders reacted to cooler-than-expected US inflation data, which fueled bets that the Federal Reserve may pivot to a less aggressive pace of interest rate hikes. The US inflation data showed decelerating inflation, leading to a boost in Asian stocks, with major indexes in Hong Kong, Australia, and South Korea rising between 1.1 and 2.4%.

images.alt_text: West Texas Intermediate was below US$92 a barrel after ending 1.6 per cent higher on Wednesday (Aug 10) following softer-than-expected US inflation data.
The worst may be over for emerging Asian currencies as slower-than-expected US inflation eases pressure on the Federal Reserve to aggressively raise interest rates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 13.23 points to 1,505.56. A total of 2.549 billion lots worth RM1.970 billion were traded, with 628 gainers outnumbering losers 260-1.

site_title: China’s Didi EV joint venture with Li Auto applies for bankruptcy: court
summary: China's Didi EV joint venture with Li Auto has applied for bankruptcy, citing the end of a 4-year-old partnership to make electric vehicles. The company, 51% owned by Didi and 49% held by Li Auto, submitted the bankruptcy application to the Beijing No 1 Intermediate People's Court on August 11. Didi and Li Auto did not respond to requests for comment. This marks the end of a partnership aimed at producing electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: The fine amounts to more than 4 per cent of Didi's US$27.3 billion total revenue last year.

site_title: Crypto is failing where digital yuan may succeed
summary: Cryptocurrencies face increasing pressure from law enforcement and governments, with even decentralized currencies not immune to monitoring and regulation. The US Treasury's sanctions against Tornado Cash, a cryptocurrency mixer service linked to North Korean money laundering, is a recent example. This trend suggests that cryptocurrencies are unlikely to gain traction despite the economic Cold War and sanctions. However, central bank digital currencies, such as China's e-yuan, may play a significant role in the future, potentially disrupting the US dollar's hegemony and creating new zones of conflict.

images.alt_text: FILE — Coinbase employees gather in Times Square to see the launch of the company’s initial public offering displayed on the Nasdaq tower, April 14, 2021. Crypto companies are laying off staff, freezing withdrawals and trying to stem losses, raising questions about the health of the ecosystem. (Gabby Jones/The New York Times)

Do Kwon, co-founder and chief executive officer of Terraform Labs, in the company's office in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, April 14, 2022. Kwon is counting on the oldest cryptocurrency as a backstop for his stablecoin, which some critics liken to a ginormous Ponzi scheme. Photographer: Woohae Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: UOB Kay Hian H1 earnings slide 44% to S$51.8 million as trading volumes contract
summary: UOB Kay Hian reported a 44.3% decline in earnings to S$51.8 million for the first half of 2022, down from S$93 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 30.8% to S$235.2 million, mainly due to lower trading volumes. Commission and trading income decreased 35.6%, while other operating income dropped 27.4%. The drop in revenue reflects the contraction of trading volumes in major markets operated by the firm.

images.alt_text: Comparing month on month, total market turnover value fell 30 per cent while total market turnover volume dipped 36.8 per cent, according to SGX data released on Thursday (Aug 11).

site_title: Geo Energy achieves record H1 net profit of US$105m, up 118%
summary: Geo Energy achieved a record first-half (H1) net profit of US$105 million, up 118% from US$48.1 million in the same period last year. Despite a coal export ban in January 2022, the company's EBITDA increased to US$162.6 million and revenue rose 67% to US$368.3 million. The company's coal sales decreased to 5.2 million tonnes, but the average Indonesian Coal Index price increased to US$85.89 per tonne. Geo Energy declared a second interim dividend of S$0.02 per share, representing a 39% pay-out ratio on its H1 2022 net earnings.

images.alt_text: A generic photo of coal being unloaded in Indonesia. Geo Energy said the average selling price rose to US$62.34 per tonne in Q1 2022, from US$38.83 a year ago.

site_title: Philippines to stop permits for new virtual asset service firms
summary: The Philippine central bank will close its regular application window for new virtual asset service provider licenses for 3 years, starting September. The regulator aims to strike a balance between promoting innovation and managing associated risks. Existing central bank-supervised institutions can still apply for a license to expand their offerings to virtual-asset services. The decision will be reassessed based on market developments.

site_title: London businesses next to face water restrictions amid drought
summary: London businesses may face water restrictions due to the ongoing drought, with temperatures expected to hit 32.5°C on Thursday and rise further. Thames Water Utilities has warned that a hosepipe ban for residential consumers may not be enough, and further restrictions on industrial supplies are possible if the drought continues. The UK has recorded its driest July in almost 90 years, with extreme heat expected to persist across England and Wales. Water companies are also working to address leaks in the system, which have been widely criticized.

images.alt_text: A large area of parched grass in Greenwich Park in front of a view of skyscrapers in the Canary Wharf financial, business and shopping district in the Greenwich district of London, Aug 3, 2022.

site_title: China's July auto sales extend recovery, jump 30 per cent as Covid curbs ease
summary: China's auto sales surged 29.7% in July to 2.42 million units, extending a recovery from eased Covid curbs and government incentives. New energy vehicle sales increased 120% in July, driven by higher oil costs and battery prices. Despite this, annual sales of petrol cars are expected to fall for the fifth straight year in 2022. Commercial vehicle sales fell 21.5% in July, indicating China's slow resumption of logistics and infrastructure development.

site_title: Ho Bee Land’s H1 profit up 42% to S$149.9m
summary: Ho Bee Land's net profit increased by 42% to S$149.9 million in the first half of 2022, driven by higher rental income, sales, and realised divestment gains. Revenue grew 13.3% to S$178.3 million, while earnings per share rose to S$0.2257. The acquisition of The Scalpel in London and higher sales from the Sentosa Cove projects contributed to the growth. Despite a decrease in the group's share of profits from associates, the company remains optimistic about its financial performance, expecting to remain profitable for the year despite rising interest rates and inflation.

images.alt_text: At the launch of the Trash-Sure campaign on Aug 1 are (left to right) Gardens by the Bay chairman Niam Chiang Meng; Ho Bee Land CEO Nicholas Chua, Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean, UBS Asia-Pacific president Edmund Koh, and artist Bordalo II.

site_title: Cyber risk - The board must drive the focus
summary: Boards of directors must recognize their critical role in strengthening organizations' security postures due to increased dependence on digital systems. They should oversee cyber risk management strategy, lead cybersecurity-focused culture, and prepare for inevitable breaches. This includes reviewing incident to crisis management plans, creating a rapid response team, and maintaining distance from cyber response operations. The board must also invest strategically in cybersecurity, aligning spending with risk appetite and business activities, and evaluate future investments to ensure resilience.

images.alt_text: Not only are the potential avenues of cyber attack growing, the potential consequences and costs of such attacks are also expanding significantly

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's official full-year growth forecast has been narrowed to between 3% and 4%, with Q2 growth revised to 4.4% year on year, down from the earlier 4.8% estimate. Tax revenue surged 22.4% to S$60.7 billion in FY2021/22, driven by a low base. Condo and HDB rental prices continued their ascent, but growth slowed in July. US petrol prices fell below US$4 for the first time in months, giving relief to drivers.

site_title: Johor Corp picks banks for IPO of US$1b palm oil unit Kulim: sources
summary: Malaysia's Johor Corp has picked banks for an initial public offering (IPO) of its US$1 billion palm oil unit, Kulim Malaysia. The IPO is expected to be valued at up to US$1 billion and could take place in Kuala Lumpur next year. The listing will be managed by RHB Bank, Affin Bank, AMMB, CLSA, and CIMB Group. The move comes as crude palm oil prices have cooled, but are still trading 30% above their 5-year average.

images.alt_text: A palm oil plantation in Johore, Malaysia.Photographer: Joshua Paul/Bloomberg

site_title: Economists ponder if Singapore’s trade growth upgrade driven by inflation or external demand
summary: Singapore's trade growth outlook has been upgraded to 15-16% for total merchandise trade and 5-6% for non-oil domestic exports, exceeding initial projections. However, the Ministry of Trade and Industry's GDP forecast has been narrowed to 3-4%, reflecting a more cautious view of the real economy. Economists differ in their interpretations, with some attributing the trade growth upgrade to rising prices rather than demand, while others see it as a sign of export resilience.

images.alt_text: Watchers do not expect Singapore to enter a technical recession in 2022, though they are not ruling the scenario out entirely.

site_title: Swire to buy back HK$4m worth of shares; stock surges
summary: Swire, a 206-year-old Hong Kong conglomerate, plans to buy back up to HK$4 billion of shares, sending its stock surging 10.4% in trading. The move comes after the company reported a 38% increase in underlying profit to HK$1.7 billion in the 6 months ended June 30, driven by smaller losses at Cathay Pacific Airways. Despite challenges from Hong Kong's Covid outbreak and lockdowns in China, Swire remains committed to the company's medium and long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index jumped 2.40 per cent, or 471.59 points, to 20,082.43.

site_title: Climate risks dwarf Europe's energy crisis, space chief warns
summary: European Space Agency Director General Josef Aschbacher warned that climate change risks dwarf Europe's energy crisis, citing extreme heatwaves, wildfires, and droughts that have caused significant damage to agriculture and industries. He stated that climate change is a "much bigger magnitude" issue that requires urgent action, and that the economic damage from these extreme weather events could be more significant than the current energy crisis. Aschbacher emphasized the need for swift action to address climate change, which he believes could cost hundreds of trillions of US dollars this century if left unchecked.

site_title: China property think tank apologises for high vacancy rate report
summary: A Chinese property think tank, Beike Research Institute, apologized for a report warning of oversupply in China's property market due to high vacancy rates, stating its assessment may not be accurate. The report, published on August 5, found that the average housing vacancy rate in 28 major cities is higher than in the US, Canada, France, Australia, and Britain, with 7% in tier-one cities like Beijing and 12% in tier-two cities. Beike will recheck the data with local housing authorities to improve accuracy.

images.alt_text: Under-construction apartments are pictured from a building during sunset in the Shekou area of Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China November 7, 2021. Picture taken November 7, 2021. REUTERS/David Kirton/File Photo/File Photo
China Evergrande Group has been at the centre of China's property crisis, in which many such companies have defaulted as a result of government moves to deleverage the sector.
China Evergrande will return the land-use rights to the Guangzhou Municipal Planning and Natural Resources Bureau, from which it had acquired the rights in April 2020.
Most of the developers that enjoyed such low funding costs in July were state-owned firms.

site_title: US petrol prices fall below US$4 for first time since March
summary: US petrol prices have fallen below $4 per gallon for the first time since March, according to the American Automobile Association. The national average price for regular unleaded petrol dropped to $3.990 a gallon on August 11. This decline follows a peak of $5.02 in June, which was attributed to market fears of severe supply restrictions since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February. The drop in prices is seen as a relief to drivers, the US's largest consumers of petrol.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.09, or 1.1 per cent, to US$97.40 a barrel on Wednesday, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained US$1.43, or 1.6 per cent, to US$91.93.

site_title: Vicom posts 9.2% rise in H1 earnings to S$13.1m from higher revenue
summary: Vicom, a Singapore-based inspection and technical testing services provider, posted a 9.2% increase in first-half earnings to S$13.1 million, driven by higher demand for its services amid the improving Singapore economy. Revenue rose 8.5% to S$53.3 million, while operating profit climbed 10.6% to S$16.5 million. The company attributed the growth to its non-vehicle testing business, which is dependent on the recovery of various sectors. Vicom declared an interim dividend of S$0.0332 per share, payable on August 26.

images.alt_text: Vicom FY2021 net profit up 1.2% to S$24.8 million

site_title: Europe: Stocks mostly rise at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the open on Thursday, August 11, with Frankfurt's DAX index up 0.2% to 13,728.70 points and Paris's CAC 40 jumping 0.5% to 6,558.05. London's FTSE 100 index remained flat at 7,504.04 points. The rise was driven by US inflation slowing from a 40-year high, boosting sentiment.

site_title: ‘Worst likely over’ for emerging Asia currencies as Fed hike bets ease
summary: Emerging Asian currencies are experiencing a relief rally after slower-than-expected US inflation eased pressure on the Federal Reserve to aggressively raise interest rates. The Thai baht and Indonesian rupiah led gains, with the Thai baht rising 0.9% and the Indonesian rupiah strengthening 0.7%. A weaker dollar is expected to ease pressure on Asian central banks to raise borrowing costs, supporting economic growth in the region. Optimism for emerging Asian assets has been building, with fund inflows increasing, and some analysts predict the worst is over for Asian currencies.

images.alt_text: China, the biggest emerging market of all and the top-ranked nation for currency reserves, remains on a different course to the rest of region.

site_title: Sotheby’s returns to Singapore after 15-year absence
summary: Sotheby's, the world's oldest auction house, returns to Singapore after a 15-year absence with its first Modern & Contemporary Art sale on August 28. The sale will feature works by prominent artists from Asia, including Indonesia's Hendra Gunawan and Singapore's Georgette Chen. The auction house notes a surge in demand from collectors in Singapore and the South-east Asian region, with the number of participants in global sales increasing by 75% in the last 5 years. The sale will be live-streamed globally and marks Sotheby's broad approach to meeting clients wherever they are.

site_title: Trendale Tower up for sale again with higher S$178m guide price
summary: Trendale Tower, a 20-storey freehold residential site in Singapore, has been put up for sale with a guide price of S$178 million, up from its previous sale price in 2018. The site, located at 79 Cairnhill Road, has 18 apartments of 298 square meters each, and a verified gross floor area of 72,691 square feet. The sale is expected to attract interest from developers due to its prime location near Newton MRT station and Orchard Road, with a tender exercise set to close on September 13.

images.alt_text: According to real estate consultancy JLL, there were nine residential en bloc deals this year for a total transacted value of about S$1.81 billion, as at July 31.
Based on the indicative price of S$285 million and a development charge payable of about S$20.89 million, this will translate into a land price of S$2,052 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr).

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.40% on Thursday, August 11, following a strong lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index jumped to 20,082.43, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also rose. The gains were driven by hopes that the Federal Reserve will slow interest rate hikes after a bigger-than-expected drop in US inflation.

site_title: South Korea makes first arrests in major crypto-linked inquiry
summary: South Korean prosecutors have made their first arrests in a probe of $3.4 billion in foreign-exchange transactions linked to cryptocurrency-related activities. Three people were arrested on charges including setting up paper companies and operating an unregistered cryptocurrency trading business. The arrests follow unusual transactions totaling 1.6 trillion won at Woori Bank and 2.5 trillion won at Shinhan Bank between 2021 and 2022. The move aims to address the damage to confidence caused by the collapse of Terraform Labs' ecosystem, which wiped out $40 billion in investor funds.

site_title: Siemens' writedown pushes company into first loss since 2010
summary: Siemens reported a shareholders' net loss of 1.66 billion euros in its third quarter, marking its first quarterly loss in nearly 12 years due to a writedown of 2.8 billion euros on its stake in Siemens Energy. Despite this, the company's revenues rose 11% to 17.87 billion euros, beating analyst forecasts, driven by strong demand in the European capital goods sector. CEO Roland Busch attributed the results to "significant opportunities" in a market environment with ongoing high demand.

images.alt_text: Siemens will bring its technology expertise in decarbonisation, while SGS provides carbon accounting competency, advisory and reporting services.

site_title: SGS, Siemens tie up to provide sustainability consulting to SE Asia companies
summary: German industrial giant Siemens has partnered with SGS to provide sustainability consulting to South-east Asia companies. Siemens brings technology expertise in decarbonisation, while SGS provides carbon accounting competency, advisory, and reporting services. The joint venture will help companies advise, audit, and measure their ESG efforts, offering recommendations to become more sustainable, safe, and efficient. This builds on SGS' existing ESG services and Siemens' experience providing sustainability consulting to enterprise customers in Singapore.

site_title: Gold retreats as Fed officials hint at big rate hikes
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to $1,788.07 per ounce on Thursday, as the dollar and Treasury yields rebounded following comments from Federal Reserve officials suggesting aggressive interest rate hikes. US inflation signs of slowing, but Fed officials expect policy rate hikes to 3.9% by year-end and 4.4% by 2023 to combat inflation. Gold is sensitive to rising US interest rates, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: Analysts polled by Reuters expect US annual inflation to have eased to 8.7 per cent in July from 9.1 per cent in June.

site_title: Living with art
summary: An architect, Khai Toh, transformed a dilapidated shophouse into a serene home for a jewellery designer, incorporating his art collection into the design. The minimalist space features a load-bearing wall converted into a linear art gallery, with concealed LED lights illuminating pottery and sculptures. The darkened wood flooring and white walls create a contemplative atmosphere, while double-glazed doors and windows minimize traffic noise. The home's layout now serves as a retirement pad, with an open-plan kitchen, a spacious living room, and an oversized bathroom that connects to an air well, providing natural light and a view into the garden.

site_title: Singapore not expected to face technical recession despite downward revision of Q2 growth
summary: Singapore's Q2 GDP growth was revised down to 4.4% year-on-year, but economists do not expect a technical recession in 2022. The country's full-year growth forecast is narrowed to 3-4% due to the global economic environment. Despite this, some sectors are expected to see continued improvement, such as aviation and tourism. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is likely to maintain policy tightening, driven by inflation concerns. Analysts expect Q3 growth to slow to 2.3% year-on-year, with full-year growth projected at 3.2%.

images.alt_text: Singapore's official full-year growth forecast has been narrowed to between 3 per cent and 4 per cent, with second quarter growth revised downwards to 4.4 per cent year on year, slower than the earlier advance estimate of 4.8 per cent.

site_title: City-fringe commercial properties for sale at guide prices from S$30m
summary: Two commercial properties in Singapore's Jalan Besar Conservation Area are up for sale. A 3-storey conservation shophouse at 301 Jalan Besar is being auctioned off at S$32 million, with a potential for redevelopment to a 6-storey building. A 5-storey building at 3 Miller Street is being offered for sale via EOI at S$30 million, with a large remaining land area and potential for redevelopment or asset enhancement. Both sites have been zoned for commercial use and are expected to draw interest from property funds and high net worth investors.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at 2-month high on boost from miners, banks
summary: Australia's shares closed at a 2-month high on Thursday, driven by gains from miners and financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.1% to 7,071.0, with BHP and Fortescue Metals advancing 1% and nearly 2%, respectively. A softer-than-expected inflation data raised bets on a less hawkish tone from the US Federal Reserve, contributing to the rally. Local energy stocks and heavyweight Santos also gained, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia falling 0.3% despite a 1% gain from three of its "Big Four" banks.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.9 per cent to 7,056.20 by 0036 GMT on Thursday, its highest level since June 9.

site_title: Credit Suisse’s top shareholder Harris discloses 10% stake
summary: Credit Suisse's largest shareholder, Harris Associates, disclosed a 10.1% stake in the bank after converting shares to American depositary receipts. This is a significant increase from the bank's annual reports, which previously listed Harris as holding around 5.2% of the total shares. Despite a 78% decline in the bank's stock since 2013, Harris has maintained its stake, with no major changes in ownership.

site_title: Singapore life insurance sales dip 1.9% to S$2.63b in H1
summary: Singapore's life insurance sector recorded S$2.63 billion in weighted new business premiums for the first half of 2022, a 1.9% decline from the previous year. Single-premium products, however, saw a 12.5% increase, driven by sustained growth among Singaporeans. Total weighted annual premiums for annual-premium products fell 15.1% to S$1.19 billion. Despite challenges, the industry remains resilient and has maintained a stable mix of product classifications, with 44% of new sales attributed to par products.

site_title: 3 late artists with inclusive visions
summary: National Gallery Singapore has launched a new exhibition, "Familiar Others," showcasing the works of three late South-east Asian artists who depicted marginalized communities with dignity and respect. The exhibition features Yeh Chi Wei's paintings of Bornean indigenous peoples, Emiria Sunassa's portraits of Indonesian archipelago communities, and Eduardo Masferre's photographs of the Cordillera region in the Philippines. The artists' work predates modern concepts of "decolonization" and "otherness," offering a powerful counter-narrative to the marginalization of these communities. The show runs until February 19, 2023.

site_title: The greening of urban spaces
summary: Singapore is transitioning from a "Garden City" to a "City in Nature," aiming to balance urbanization with environmental sustainability. The city-state has made significant strides in greening its spaces, with efforts including planting creepers on concrete structures, adding green spaces to parks, and re-naturalizing waterways. Since 2019, over 250 hectares of greenery have been added, and the government has implemented measures such as replacing lost greenery with rooftop or mid-level sky terraces. This approach has helped Singapore stay cool, with the city being 1 degree Centigrade hotter than it was in 1950, and has contributed to its transformation into a healthier and more sustainable environment.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB downgrades Apac Realty to ‘neutral’, expects 50% drop in H2 net profit
summary: RHB downgrades Apac Realty to "neutral" from "buy" with an unchanged target price of S$0.75 due to a 50% drop in H2 net profit expected, driven by lower transaction volumes and rising interest rates. Analyst Vijay Natarajan projects a 30-40% decline in new sales transaction volumes and 10-15% decline in secondary real estate market volumes. Despite this, Natarajan raised FY2022 to FY2023 net profit estimates by 1-2%.

site_title: The problem with wine bottles
summary: Glass bottles for wine have become a significant problem due to global trade disruptions and the climate crisis. Despite their inertness and suitability for aging, the US has a low glass recycling rate, making wine bottles a major issue. A pilot program at a Brooklyn vineyard failed due to low customer returns of bottles intended for reuse. The 750-milliliter bottle size, ideal for two people, poses a challenge for efficient recycling. The problem highlights the need for improved recycling infrastructure and consumer awareness to address this environmental concern.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value slips 28% to S$18b in July
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) securities turnover value dropped 28% to S$18 billion in July, with total market turnover volume falling 36.8%. Securities daily average value decreased 22.7% to S$901 million, while derivatives-traded volume rose 1% year-over-year. The Straits Times Index advanced 3.5% month-over-month, and ETF market turnover volume fell 35% year-over-year.

images.alt_text: Singapore bourse was a stark outlier on Wednesday as it bucked the regional trend and finished higher

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Mary Daly says it’s too early to ‘declare victory’ on inflation fight: FT
summary: US Federal Reserve President Mary Daly warned it's too early to declare victory in the fight against inflation, despite a sharp drop in petrol costs causing US consumer prices to remain unchanged in July. Daly stated that inflation remains too high and not near the Fed's price stability goal. This reprieve in consumer price pressures is seen as a sign of relief for Americans who have watched inflation climb over the past two years.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest gain in over 3 weeks
summary: South Korea's Kospi index rose 42.90 points, or 1.73%, to close at 2,523.78, its biggest gain in over 3 weeks. The benchmark gained as slower-than-expected US inflation data sparked views the Federal Reserve may take a softer pace to interest rate hikes. Technology giant Samsung Electronics and battery maker LG Energy Solution rose 1.35% and 3.06%, respectively. Foreigners bought shares worth 133.7 billion won, and the won strengthened against the dollar, with a 0.57% increase.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi fell 22.58 points or 0.90 per cent to close at 2,480.88 as of 6.30 am GMT, its biggest decline since Jul 12.

site_title: Economists see inflation spike in Indonesia for rest of 2022
summary: Economists predict Indonesia's inflation will spike to 5% and 5.15% in the third and fourth quarters of 2022, respectively, as global inflation and monetary tightening take effect. Central bank rate hikes of 50 and 25 basis points are expected, raising the key rate to 4.25% by year-end. Full-year 2022 inflation outlook is revised up to 4%, while 2023 is forecasted at 3.71%. The country's economic growth outlook remains unchanged at 5.2% for the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Thursday
summary: Japan's financial markets were closed on Thursday for a public holiday, resuming trading on Friday, August 12. Meanwhile, global markets experienced fluctuations, with US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats, and Europe's shares rising due to mining and healthcare sectors. In Asia, traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally, and Singapore's stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Atome Financial enters into US$100m debt facility with HSBC
summary: Atome Financial, a buy now, pay later (BNPL) player, has entered into a US$100 million debt facility with HSBC Singapore. The company, which also has a US$500 million financing deal with Standard Chartered, is navigating rising interest rates and inflationary pressures impacting consumer spending. Despite market challenges, Atome Financial's parent company, Advance Intelligence Group, recently raised a US$400 million Series D round, valuing the company at over US$2 billion. The debt facility with HSBC is seen as a testament to the bank's trust in Atome Financial's mission to drive financial inclusion across Asia.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street rally as soft US inflation boosts rate hopes
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday as investors reacted to the US inflation data, which showed a below-forecast reading, giving the Federal Reserve room to slow interest rate hikes. Hong Kong, Seoul, Taipei, and Manila stocks rose over 1%, while Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, and Jakarta also saw gains. The US dollar dropped against peers, and Wall Street surged, pushing the Nasdaq into a technical bull market. The rally was attributed to a sharp drop in energy costs and provided a boost to risk assets.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were all down in early trade on Wednesday.

site_title: Grab commits US$1m for scholarships, adds new centre for merchants
summary: Grab is committing US$1 million annually to its GrabForGood Fund, awarding over 2,000 university scholarships and bursaries in South-east Asia. The GrabScholar programme, launched in partnership with Yayasan Benih Baik Indonesia, aims to support underprivileged children and provide internship opportunities to tertiary students. Grab also announced a new GrabMerchant Centre in Singapore, offering personalized business consultation services and workshops for small and medium-sized enterprises, with over 680,000 SMEs across the region already joining GrabFood and GrabMart.

site_title: Satellite imagery shows Antarctic ice shelf crumbling faster than thought
summary: Antarctica's ice shelves are crumbling at a faster rate than previously thought, with a 12-trillion-ton loss since 1997, doubling the previous estimate. Satellite imagery shows that the continent's coastal glaciers are shedding icebergs more rapidly than they can be replenished, accelerating global sea level rise. The study, led by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, warns that Antarctica's ice sheet may not be able to return to pre-2000 levels by the end of the century if greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 9.80 points higher, or 0.66%, at 1,502.13 on Thursday. The index saw 324 gains and 99 losses, with a trading volume of 139.89 million lots worth RM290.82 million.

site_title: Oil steadies as traders count down to Opec, IEA market outlooks
summary: Oil prices steadied ahead of Opec and IEA market outlooks, with West Texas Intermediate ending 1.6% higher at US$92 a barrel following softer-than-expected US inflation data. Despite higher crude inventories and production, the advance came as flows along the Druzhba network resumed after a payment dispute was settled. Oil retreated to a 6-month low earlier this month due to concerns of an economic slowdown, but the gains since Russia's invasion of Ukraine have been erased despite sanctions.

images.alt_text: Petrol prices peaked at a record US$5.02 in June. That high cost curbed spending, and prices have also dropped as market fears of severe restrictions on supply have ebbed since Russia first invaded Ukraine in February.
The market for prompt oil supplies has slowed, traders told Reuters, with offers slumping for West African, North Sea, Mediterranean and Middle East crudes.

site_title: Healthtech startup raises US$4.3m in seed funding co-led by East Ventures, Sequoia
summary: Indonesian healthtech startup Diri Care has secured US$4.3 million in seed funding from East Ventures and Sequoia Capital India and Southeast Asia. The funding will be used to expand access to its on-demand digital clinic for skin, hair, and intimate health conditions. Diri Care has recorded over 13,000 consultations and reported revenue growth of over 600% since its online beta launch in March. The platform aims to provide rapid health assessments and personalized treatment prescriptions by certified physicians.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars notch up big gains on softer US inflation
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars maintained strong gains following US inflation data, which showed a slower-than-expected 8.5% increase in consumer prices. The Aussie rose 1.7% to its highest level since June, while the kiwi surged 1.8% to its largest daily gain this year. The softer inflation data lifted risk assets, with investors hopeful for a less aggressive interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Despite this, economists warn that more similar readings are needed to confirm the end of the inflation emergency.

images.alt_text: A strong US inflation print would damage the case that the Fed will pivot away from its focus on curtailing inflation with interest rate hikes and instead worry more about a recession, and so potentially raise rates more slowly.

site_title: Binance says it is winning crypto clients thanks to inflation
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, is seeing a surge in clients due to rising inflation worldwide. According to Maximiliano Hinz, the company's head in Latin America, more people are seeking cryptocurrency like bitcoin as a way to protect themselves from inflation. This trend is particularly evident in Argentina, where annual inflation is at 90%, making it one of Binance's top markets, along with Brazil and Mexico. The company's clients are seeking a hedge against inflation, which is expected to continue globally.

summary: CapitaLand Investment, a real estate investment manager, saw its shares fall 7.6% to S$3.82 after posting a 38.3% decline in H1 profits to S$433 million. The decline was attributed to lower asset recycling activities, while H1 revenue rose 29.1% to S$1.35 billion, boosted by fee income-related business and real estate investment. The company made its debut on the Singapore Exchange in September last year.

site_title: US rethinks steps on China tariffs in wake of Taiwan response: sources
summary: The US is reevaluating its China tariffs amid China's military response to US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan. The Biden administration is considering eliminating some tariffs, launching a new investigation into potential additional tariffs, or expanding tariff exclusions to aid US companies affected by the duties. The decision has been delayed due to the complex geopolitical situation and China's refusal to take reciprocal actions on trade. The tariffs, imposed in 2018-2019, aim to pressure China on intellectual property theft, but their removal could ease inflation and benefit US industries struggling with rising costs.

site_title: China's central bank warns of inflation risks as CPI climbs
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), warned of inflation risks as consumer inflation accelerated to 2.7% in July, the highest level in 2 years, driven by food prices and pork costs. The PBOC pledged to safeguard the economy against inflation threats without resorting to massive stimulus or excessive money printing. Consumer inflation is expected to exceed 3% in some months during the second half of the year, but the PBOC aims to keep full-year inflation around 3% in 2022. The central bank will maintain low-profile, accommodative monetary policy and focus on targeted tools to boost lending and credit growth.

images.alt_text: Rising pork prices and an improving economic picture, though, are expected to push up CPI this year and may test the government's ability to deliver more stimulus.

site_title: China's provinces vow to meet GDP targets despite growth slump
summary: China's provincial-level jurisdictions have vowed to meet their GDP growth targets despite a slump in economic growth, with at least 17 provinces pledging to achieve their goals. Economic powerhouses like Guangdong aim to expand their economy by "around 5.5 per cent" this year, despite reaching only 2 per cent in the first half. Several provinces have pledged efforts to stabilize the economy, while others will keep their goals in mind and strive to do their best. The national target of "around 5.5 per cent" growth has been downplayed by top leaders amid repeated Covid outbreaks and a property market slump.

images.alt_text: Rising pork prices and an improving economic picture, though, are expected to push up CPI this year and may test the government's ability to deliver more stimulus.

site_title: Cheaper, changing and crucial: the rise of solar power
summary: Solar power technology is rapidly evolving, with costs plummeting 85% since 2010 and efficiency increasing by 1/5. Experts predict that solar energy could make up half of the world's electricity system by mid-century. New materials and hybrid cells are being developed, which could expand where solar energy can be harvested and increase efficiency. Additionally, solar panels can generate energy at night using heat from the Earth, and researchers are exploring ways to integrate solar energy with agriculture, such as using solar panels as protective roofs for crops.

site_title: New Zealand housing market decline gathers pace as prices drop
summary: New Zealand's housing market experienced its first annual decline in 11 years, with the Real Estate Institute's price index dropping 2.9% from the previous year. This marks the fifth consecutive monthly decline. The Reserve Bank's aggressive policy tightening, including a potential fourth straight half-percentage point interest-rate hike, is believed to be the cause of the decline. The Official Cash Rate is expected to reach 3% next week, signaling further interest-rate increases to curb inflation.

images.alt_text: The central bank is forecast to deliver a fourth consecutive half-percentage point hike at next week's meeting, taking the Official Cash Rate to 3 per cent.
Labour shortages and capacity constraints are contributing to soaring inflation in New Zealand, prompting the Reserve Bank to rapidly remove monetary stimulus.

site_title: Olivia Newton-John to get state memorial in Australia
summary: Olivia Newton-John, a British-born actress and singer, will receive a state memorial service in Australia, her adoptive homeland, after her death in Southern California. The 73-year-old star, known for her role in the 1978 hit musical "Grease," spent three decades fighting breast cancer. The memorial service aims to honor her contributions to cancer research and awareness, as evident from the pink lights illuminating the Sydney Opera House on August 10, 2022, in her memory. The service will serve as an upbeat sendoff for the late Grammy-winning actress.

images.alt_text: Olivia Newton-John, who gained worldwide fame as high-school sweetheart Sandy in the hit musical movie "Grease," died on Aug 8, 2022, her family said. She was 73.

site_title: Apple ramps up its in-house podcasting efforts with studio deal
summary: Apple has signed an agreement with Pulitzer Prize-winning studio Futuro Studios to fund the development and production of original podcasts, which could potentially be turned into shows on its Apple TV+ service. This deal is part of Apple's efforts to increase its original content offerings, with the company having already announced podcasts with other studios. The investments are led by Apple's TV studio, rather than its podcast division, and are seen as a welcome sign for podcast producers seeking funding, as other companies such as Spotify and Amazon have been pulling back on their budgets due to softening ad growth and declining stock prices.

images.alt_text: Apple, which has a market value of about US$2.7 trillion, surpassed oil giant Saudi Aramco again in July to become the world's largest company.

site_title: Hafary doubles H1 profit to S$10.4m, with greater demand from resale flat buyers
summary: Hafary Holdings, a Singapore-based tile specialist, reported a net profit of S$10.4 million for the first half of 2022, more than double the S$5.1 million net profit in the same period last year. Revenue rose 21.9% to S$71.3 million, driven by robust demand from resale flat buyers seeking certainty over construction delays. The company expects strong construction demand in 2022, with the Building and Construction Authority projecting S$27-32 billion in total construction demand.

images.alt_text: The Hafary Gallery, located in Eunos, showcases over 4,000 of surfacing materials and bathroom wares and fittings sourced from around the world. The company invested in a revamp of its showroom to showcase the use of large-format porcelain tiles.

site_title: Food giant Cargill backs Singapore startup ProfilePrint in Series A extension
summary: Cargill invests in Singapore startup ProfilePrint, a food profiling company, in a Series A1 round. ProfilePrint's AI-driven food profiler can predict quality and profile of a food sample within seconds, reducing the resource-intensive process of physical grading. The startup aims to establish a common digital standard for food fingerprinting and will use the capital for product development and talent acquisition. Cargill has completed pilots with ProfilePrint and sees the technology as a potential game-changer for the global food ingredient supply chain.

site_title: Singapore secured S$6.3b in fixed asset investment commitments in Q2
summary: Singapore secured S$6.3 billion in fixed asset investment commitments and S$2.1 billion in total business expenditure in Q2, according to the Economic Survey of Singapore. Manufacturing investments accounted for 45.7% of fixed asset investment, with electronics and biomedical clusters attracting the largest shares. Services investments were the second-largest, with infocommunications and media attracting the most. Investors from Europe contributed the most to fixed asset investment, while those from the "others" region led total business expenditure commitments.

site_title: First Ukraine grain ship docks in Turkey after being turned away
summary: A Ukrainian grain ship, Razoni, docked in Turkey's port of Mersin after being turned away from the Lebanese port of Tripoli due to a cancelled deal. The ship, carrying 26,000 tonnes of corn, had been delayed for five months due to Russia's invasion. A Turkish buyer has been found for the maize, allowing the ship to unload its cargo. This marks the first grain ship to leave Ukraine under a UN-backed deal, which aims to establish safe corridors through mines laid by Kyiv to ward off amphibious assault by Moscow.
