site_title: China orders up 3,000 hospital beds in Tibet on 28 Covid case
summary: China has ordered the construction of 3,000 hospital beds in Tibet in response to 28 new Covid-19 cases, its first reported cases since the start of the pandemic. As part of its Covid Zero strategy, China mandates isolation of positive cases and their close contacts in government-built temporary hospitals. The move comes as the country grapples with flareups in multiple tourism hotspots, with 952 new infections reported on Tuesday, the highest tally in almost a month. China's National Health Commission has warned that high-altitude regions are more prone to chronic respiratory diseases, putting residents at greater risk of serious illness from Covid.

images.alt_text: Those who have recovered are singled out during regular mass testing, which people in big cities must undergo at least every 3 days.

site_title: Singapore stocks track global gains to open Thursday higher; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,294.66 at 9:01 am on Thursday, following global markets' positive close overnight, driven by better-than-expected US inflation data. Gainers outnumbered losers 118 to 30, with Sembcorp Marine, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, and Genting Singapore among the top gainers. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose, while US stocks surged, with the Dow Jones Industrial up 1.6% and the S&P 500 up 2.1%.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Global physical oil market weakens as recession jitters mount
summary: Global physical oil market has weakened due to recession jitters, with prices sagging alongside futures. Offers for West African, North Sea, Mediterranean, and Middle East crudes have slumped, reflecting less concern over Russian-led supply disruptions and a possible global economic slowdown. Lower-than-usual US petrol demand and contracting factory activity in China indicate high prices cut consumption, contrasting with last month's physical market activity. Crude futures have retreated below $100 a barrel, and backwardation has narrowed, implying less tight prompt supply.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.09, or 1.1 per cent, to US$97.40 a barrel on Wednesday, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained US$1.43, or 1.6 per cent, to US$91.93.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge out of the gates
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.17% at the open on August 11, 2022, driven by a slowdown in US inflation, which boosted hopes for a slower pace of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The Hang Seng Index rose 229.73 points to 19,840.57, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained. The rally followed a slowdown in US inflation, which has been a key factor in interest rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore upgrades 2022 trade forecast again amid higher forecast for oil and electronics trade
summary: Singapore upgraded its 2022 trade forecast to 15-16% growth, up from the previous 8-10% forecast, driven by better-than-expected Q2 performance in oil and electronics trade. Total merchandise trade is projected to grow, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) up 5-6%. Higher oil prices and robust global semiconductor demand are expected to support growth, but uncertainty remains due to inflation, a China slowdown, and the Russia-Ukraine war.

images.alt_text: A container vessel anchored out past the Pasir Panjang terminal port behind cable car cabins.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit over two-month high
summary: Australian shares reached a two-month high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 0.9% to 7,056.20 on Thursday, its highest level since June 9. The gain was driven by banking and mining stocks, following signs of decelerating US inflation that raised hopes for reduced interest rate hikes. This follows a day after US stocks also hit fresh records despite tariff threats.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.4 per cent to 6,998.60 by 0031 GMT on Wednesday, with most sub-indexes down.

site_title: Hot stock: Hafary up 7.5% after doubling H1 profit
summary: Hafary Holdings saw its shares rise 7.5% after reporting a doubling in its H1 profit to S$10.4 million. The company benefited from the resale flat market, with revenue in its general segment increasing 22.3% to S$46.6 million. However, a rising interest-rate environment may weigh on earnings due to higher refinancing costs and reduced spending on renovations.

images.alt_text: The Hafary Gallery, located in Eunos, showcases over 4,000 of surfacing materials and bathroom wares and fittings sourced from around the world. The company invested in a revamp of its showroom to showcase the use of large-format porcelain tiles.

site_title: MTI narrows Singapore’s full-year growth forecast; Q2 growth revised down to 4.4%
summary: Singapore's full-year economic growth forecast has been narrowed to 3-4% by the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI), with Q2 growth revised down to 4.4% year on year. The narrowed forecast takes into account the country's economic performance in the first half of 2022 and the latest global and domestic economic developments. Despite the revision, growth is expected to return to a "slight positive" in the third and fourth quarters, with no technical recession anticipated. The revised forecast comes amid a weakened global economic environment and potential risks including the Russia-Ukraine conflict and supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: Stacks of containers sit in the Tanjong Pagar terminal port in Singapore on June 17, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Singapore firms are much less optimistic about business prospects than they were a quarter ago, according to the latest quarterly BT-SUSS Business Climate Survey.
Recent manufacturing growth downgrades were likely a shock for economy watchers, who typically expect Singapore to upgrade – not cut – preliminary gross domestic product data.

site_title: Manulife core profit drops on asset management, Asia sales challenges
summary: Canada's largest life insurer, Manulife, reported core earnings of C$1.56 billion (S$1.7 billion) in the second quarter, slightly beating analyst estimates but down from a year earlier. The decline was due to market volatility affecting its asset management unit and lingering Covid-19 restrictions in Asia. Core earnings declined 14% in its global wealth and asset management unit, 4.6% in the US business, and 2.5% in Asia. The company's Canadian earnings rose 8.5% due to growth in new business value.

site_title: Surging inflation puts Asia's deal-hunting bond buyers on hold
summary: Inflation in Asia continues to outpace expectations, with the Philippines' 6.4% year-over-year rate in July exceeding forecasts. This has led investors to delay their plans to call the bottom in emerging Asian bonds. Higher yields in shorter-dated bonds are attributed to hawkish rate expectations, fueled by the US economy's strong jobs report and policymakers' continued signals of tightening. As a result, investors remain cautious, suggesting that inflation may not have peaked yet.

EPA-EFE/Bagus Indahono
China, the biggest emerging market of all and the top-ranked nation for currency reserves, remains on a different course to the rest of region.

site_title: UK house sales decline as soaring inflation cuts into demand
summary: The UK housing market experienced a decline in sales and buyer demand in July, with sales expectations for the next 12 months at the lowest level since March 2020. New buyer inquiries fell for the third consecutive month, while measures of current sales also declined. Despite a "severe" lack of stock, buyers bid up house prices, and estate agents predict further gains over the next year. The decline is attributed to higher interest rates and soaring inflation, which have taken a toll on the property market.

images.alt_text: Britain is bracing for an 82 per cent rise in energy bills in October, with charities warning that millions of people could be forced into poverty if the government does not launch a multi-billion pound support package to soften the blow.
The think tank said rampant inflation is expected to wipe out more than 40 per cent of the planned real-terms increase in funding for public services over the next 3 years.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, CDL, OUE, SBS Transit, Haw Par
summary: Singapore-listed property developers OUE Limited and City Developments Limited posted strong first-half earnings, with OUE's earnings nearly tripling to S$88.7 million and CDL's net profit reaching a record S$1.1 billion. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Investment Limited reported a 38.3% drop in profit to S$433 million, citing lower asset recycling activities in China. Other companies, such as SBS Transit and Haw Par Corporation, also reported earnings, with SBS Transit down 5% and Haw Par seeing improved year-on-year earnings.

images.alt_text: Major indexes in Hong Kong, Japan, Australia and South Korea fell between 0.5 per cent and 2 per cent, but the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.5 per cent or 15.35 points higher at 3,286.33.

site_title: Europe: Shares bounce after US inflation data calms nerves
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Wednesday, their best session in nearly two weeks, after US inflation data showed a slower-than-expected rise in July, providing relief to investors. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index jumped, with rate-sensitive tech stocks, miners, retailers, and travel & leisure among the gainers. However, analysts noted that supply and demand risks, including energy shortages, may impact European markets, and the European Central Bank is expected to raise interest rates in September.

images.alt_text: London's benchmark FTSE 100 index fell 0.1 per cent to 7,483.52 points.

site_title: Ja Rule joins celebrity NFT ranks with HBCU donation
summary: Rapper Ja Rule has joined the NFT market with his "Black is Beautiful" collection, featuring 1,000 illustrations by Florida artist Nick Davis, intended to depict the complexities of being Black in America. The collection will donate $50,000 to historically Black universities, including Jackson State and Morgan State, and Ja Rule's entertainment company will match an additional $25,000. The initiative aims to empower the next generation of creative minds and provide access to education and insights for communities of color.

images.alt_text: Demand in the NFT market has slumped in recent months, with resale value performing poorly alongside wider industry turmoil that has wiped around US$2 trillion from the crypto sector's total value.
OpenSea is the top NFT marketplace by trading volume, having done more than US$31 billion in sales all-time.

site_title: Ripple Labs interested in bankrupt crypto lender Celsius' assets
summary: Ripple Labs, a blockchain payments company, is interested in purchasing assets of bankrupt crypto lender Celsius Network, according to a spokesperson. Ripple is actively looking for mergers and acquisitions to strategically scale the company, despite being valued at around $15 billion. Celsius filed for bankruptcy with a $1.19 billion deficit, listing digital assets, loans, and cryptocurrencies as assets. Ripple's interest in Celsius comes as the company continues to grow through the crypto market turmoil.

images.alt_text: Celsius hopes the bitcoin mining effort will help it repair its relationship with customers, some of whom sent threats and hate mail to some company employees in the weeks before the Chapter 11 filing.

site_title: AMP’s profit drops as margin pressure squeezes banking division
summary: AMP's half-year profit fell by nearly a quarter to A$117 million due to margin pressure in its banking division, where net interest margin declined to 1.32% from 1.62%. The decline was attributed to growth in fixed-rate loans, but margins started to recover with interest rate hikes. AMP has been working to repair its reputation since 2018 after a public inquiry exposed wrongdoing. The company's underlying NPAT for AMP Bank fell 45.2% to A$46 million.

site_title: Old world, new wines in Bordeaux
summary: New winemakers are bringing fresh perspectives to Bordeaux, a traditional French wine region. Winemakers such as Penfolds are incorporating New World influence into their wine-making process. Independent vigneron Loic Pasquet's 2015 vintage, made using ancient techniques, commands a high price of 30,000 euros per bottle. This shift in winemaking styles is adding a modern twist to the region's old world wines.

site_title: North Korea’s Kim declares victory in battle against Covid-19
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un declared victory in the battle against Covid-19, lifting maximum anti-epidemic measures imposed in May. Despite limited testing capabilities, North Korea reported no new suspected cases since July 29. Analysts believe the declaration could lead to restored trade and potentially clear the way for a nuclear weapon test. North Korea's official death rate of 74 is considered an "unprecedented miracle" compared to other countries. The World Health Organization has cast doubts on North Korea's claims, citing a lack of independent data.

images.alt_text: Children at the new East Coast Park Precinct in Hong Kong.  Hong Kong currently allows children as young as 3 years old to get Sinovac shots; those aged five and up can get the vaccine developed by BioNTech and its partner, Pfizer.

site_title: Russia resumes oil flow towards Ukraine as fee is paid
summary: Russia resumed oil flows through a pipeline to central Europe, specifically to Slovakia and Hungary, after Hungary's refiner paid the transit fee to Ukraine. The halt had raised concerns about a supply crunch in the region, but the resumption is expected to alleviate some pressure on fuel supplies. The agreement covers flows to Slovakia and Hungary, not the Czech Republic.

site_title: Indian companies swapping US dollar for Asian currencies to buy Russian coal
summary: Indian companies are increasingly using Asian currencies to pay for Russian coal imports, avoiding the US dollar and reducing the risk of breaching Western sanctions. In June, 44% of Russian coal imports were paid for using currencies other than the US dollar, with the yuan accounting for 31% and the Hong Kong dollar for 28%. This shift is seen as a way to cushion India from the effects of sanctions and secure raw materials at discounts. The Reserve Bank of India has approved payments for commodities in the Indian rupee, which is expected to boost bilateral trade with Russia in its own currency.

images.alt_text: A strong US inflation print would damage the case that the Fed will pivot away from its focus on curtailing inflation with interest rate hikes and instead worry more about a recession, and so potentially raise rates more slowly.

site_title: Disney+ raises streaming price by 38%, offers plans with ads
summary: Disney+ raises its streaming price by 38%, introducing an ad-supported tier to boost subscribers and generate more revenue. The ad-supported version will be available on December 8, and the price of the ad-free option will increase to $11 per month. This move aims to reverse investor sentiment and help the company meet its ambitious fiscal 2024 target of up to 260 million subscribers. The company reported strong third-quarter results, with 14.4 million new Disney+ subscribers and a 26% jump in sales.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney could lose as many as 20 million of its Disney+ subscribers after being outbid for the streaming rights to Indian Premier League cricket matches this week.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment H1 profit slips 38.3% on ‘lower velocity in asset recycling activities’
summary: CapitaLand Investment Limited (CLI) reported a 38.3% drop in profit for the first half year ended June 30, to S$433 million, due to lower velocity in asset recycling activities, particularly in China. Despite a 29.1% gain in revenue to S$1.35 billion, the group's earnings per share fell 66.4% to S$0.084. CLI's funds under management (FUM) remain flat at S$86 billion, with the group focusing on executing its fund strategies and maintaining a healthy balance sheet. The company expects the Chinese market to be stronger in the second half and plans to leverage domestic capital to fund its growth.

site_title: Apple inches closer to erasing 2022 losses as inflation cools
summary: Apple is close to erasing its 2022 losses as inflation cools, with its shares surging 2.6% to $169.24, driven by a risk-on rally in the stock market following softer-than-expected inflation data. This move puts Apple within reach of turning positive for the year, with its market value surpassing oil giant Saudi Aramco to become the world's largest company, valued at around $2.7 trillion.

images.alt_text: Apple supplier Foxconn reported a higher-than-expected 12 per cent jump in April-June net profit, driven by strong demand for its smartphones and cloud products.
Apple CEO Tim Cook maintains that the company is on the prowl, but won’t just make a purchase to bulk up on revenue. Apple wants talent or technology that helps its strategy, he said.

site_title: Facebook use plunges among US teens: survey
summary: US teens have significantly reduced their use of Facebook over the past 7 years, with only 32% of teens surveyed logging on to the platform, down from 71% in a similar survey 7 years ago. Instead, YouTube and TikTok have emerged as top social media platforms, with 95% of teens using YouTube and 67% using TikTok. This shift has implications for Facebook-owner Meta's multi-billion dollar ad-driven business, as the company competes with TikTok for social media primacy.

site_title: JPMorgan gold traders found guilty in Chicago spoofing trial
summary: JPMorgan Chase executives Michael Nowak and Gregg Smith were found guilty in a Chicago trial for manipulating precious-metals markets through "spoofing" orders from 2008 to 2016. The jury deliberated over 8 days after a 3-week trial, convicting the former head of JPMorgan's precious-metals business and his top gold trader. This conviction marks a significant win for the US government in its crackdown on market manipulation.

images.alt_text: Michael Nowak (centre), who ran precious metals trading at JPMorgan for over a decade, is being tried in Chicago along with colleagues Gregg Smith and Jeffrey Ruffo for conspiring to manipulate gold and silver markets.

Christian Trunz is the third former trader to testify at the fraud and racketeering trial of Smith and 2 senior employees at JPMorgan's precious-metals desk: managing director Michael Nowak and hedge-fund salesman Jeffrey Ruffo.

site_title: Oil rises on renewed petrol demand, weak US dollar
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures up 1.1% to $97.40 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 1.6% to $91.93, driven by increased petrol demand and weak US dollar. US crude oil stocks rose by 5.5 million barrels, exceeding expectations. The price rebound comes after losses earlier in the session and is seen as a response to lower-than-expected US inflation data.

site_title: Boeing delivers first 787 in a year
summary: Boeing delivered its first 787 Dreamliner to American Airlines on August 10, 2022, after US air safety regulators cleared the company to resume deliveries following changes to its production process. The aircraft's production issues began in late 2020 and led to a year-long delay in deliveries. Boeing has delivered over 1,000 787s since its introduction in 2004, with the company facing significant costs due to the delays. The delivery marks a significant milestone for the company and comes as airlines face delays and cancellations due to the shortage of aircraft.

images.alt_text: Boeing will be allowed to resume deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner aircraft “in the coming days”, after the company made changes to its manufacturing process, US air safety regulators said on Monday.
Airbus meanwhile booked a major order for almost 300 jets from state airlines in China, announced last month, along with a handful of orders from a quiet Farnborough Airshow.

site_title: US: Stocks surge on easing US inflation
summary: US stocks surged on Wednesday with the Dow gaining over 500 points, driven by better-than-expected inflation data that raised hopes for easing interest rate hikes. The annual consumer price index dipped to 8.5% in July from a 40-year high of 9.1% in June, and monthly CPI was unchanged. Despite economists warning that inflation remains high, the data could persuade the Federal Reserve to move more gradually. The Dow Jones Industrial, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all closed with big gains, with individual stocks such as Disney and Netflix also seeing significant increases.

images.alt_text: Wall Street rose sharply at the open on Wednesday as data showed a slower-than-expected rise in inflation last month prompted traders to cut their bets on a third straight 75-basis-point interest rate hike in September.

site_title: BT Podcast: Hope for your disrupted supply chain
summary: DHL Express Singapore's managing director, Christopher Ong, advises small businesses to build a resilient, diversified, and green supply chain in response to ongoing disruptions. Key takeaways include overcoming limitations and incorporating sustainability initiatives. The conversation highlights the importance of seizing opportunities in digital and green economies, as well as optimizing supply chains for the post-pandemic world. DHL provides advice on effectively incorporating initiatives and overcoming challenges in the supply chain.

site_title: Gaming industry's fortunes fade as spending squeeze follows pandemic bump
summary: The gaming industry is experiencing a slowdown in demand due to rising prices, a lack of hit titles, and supply-chain delays. US consumer spending on video games fell 11% in June and is expected to decline 8.7% this year. Major game publishers like Activision Blizzard and Electronic Arts have reported smaller-than-expected profits, while console makers like Microsoft and Sony have also taken a hit. Despite this, analysts expect the industry to grow above pre-pandemic levels, driven by the launch of delayed titles and easing of parts shortages.

site_title: SoftBank to gain US$34b from cutting Alibaba stake
summary: SoftBank Group will book a gain of US$34.1 billion from cutting its stake in Alibaba Group Holding to 14.6% from 23.7%. The move aims to shore up its cash reserve amid a market downturn. SoftBank booked a US$50 billion loss at its Vision Fund arm in the first half of the year. The company settled prepaid forward contracts, eliminating concerns about future cash outflows and reducing costs. The transaction does not impact the market, as the shares were hedged at the time of the original monetization.

images.alt_text: Masayoshi Son said on Monday that he is in discussions to sell asset manager Fortress, without commenting on a valuation.

site_title: Tiger, CDPQ join US$105m round for software firm CleverTap
summary: CleverTap, a software platform for e-commerce and consumer firms, has raised US$105 million in a round led by the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec (CDPQ) and including Tiger Global. CDPQ invested US$75 million, while India's IIFL Asset Management and Sequoia Capital's India unit also participated. CleverTap, founded in 2013, helps large brands retain customers and improve revenue through its software, which uses artificial intelligence. The funding doubles the company's valuation to US$385 million, following a US$385 million valuation in 2019.

site_title: Cars@Expo automotive show returns after 2-year hiatus
summary: Cars@Expo, a 2-year hiatus, is returning with 29 exhibitor booths and 36 brand names, featuring electric vehicles from Polestar, MG, BYD, and others. The 2-day event will take place from Aug 13-14 at Singapore Expo Hall 3B and 4, with free admission. Organiser SPH Media aims to bring a bigger and better event with attractive deals and goodies, marking its first consumer event since the pandemic.

site_title: Indonesia’s Bank Permata plans to have more balanced portfolio, says top executive
summary: Bank Permata, a Jakarta-based financial institution majority-owned by Bangkok Bank, aims to rebalance its portfolio to become more "universal" with a focus on corporate, SME, and retail banking. Currently, 60% of clients are in corporate banking, while 23% is in SME banking. The bank's new President-Director Meliza Musa Rusli wants to shift the focus to have corporate banking comprise half of the portfolio, with the other half being a combination of SME and retail segments. Rusli cited the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict and global economic uncertainty as factors affecting credit giving.

site_title: Is global inflation nearing a peak?
summary: Global inflation may be nearing its peak, with some measures cooling in the US and China. The US saw no rise in consumer prices for July, while China's factory-gate inflation slowed to a 17-month low. Central bankers now expect inflation to decelerate in the second half of the year, with some predicting a peak in the third quarter. However, European energy bills are unlikely to decrease, and wages are pointing up, which could initiate a vicious circle of price increases.

images.alt_text: Food is one component of the CPI that remained elevated in July, rising 1.1 per cent last month after climbing 1.0 per cent in June.

site_title: Top Citigroup UK dealmaker Jan Skarbek resigns
summary: Jan Skarbek, a top Citigroup UK dealmaker, has resigned from the firm amid an ongoing probe into allegations of misconduct. Skarbek, who spent about 28 years with Citigroup, was co-head of its banking, capital markets and advisory business in the UK and Ireland. The investigation, sparked by a complaint about comments made to a female employee, is still ongoing. Skarbek's resignation comes after he was promoted last year and advised on several high-profile deals, including the £2.9 billion sale of William Hill to Caesars Entertainment.

site_title: Far East Orchard reverses out of the red with H1 earnings of S$8 million
summary: Far East Orchard has reported a net profit of S$8 million for the first half of 2022, reversing a net loss of S$1.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 15.9% to S$63.7 million due to stronger operating performance in the hospitality segment, driven by international travel recovery and government isolation contracts in Singapore. The group plans to launch two Australian hospitality brands in Singapore in the second half of 2022 to diversify its source markets and attract Australian inbound tourists.

images.alt_text: Featuring 735 beds, The Elements in Sheffield is one of Far East Orchard's 12 student accommodation properties in the UK. The new development at Plot 6 Silverthorne Lane in Bristol will be the group's 13th.

site_title: OUE’s earnings nearly treble to S$88.7m in H1
summary: OUE Limited reported earnings of S$88.7 million for the first half of the year, nearly tripling from S$30.1 million a year ago. Revenue increased 30.7% to S$198.7 million, driven by growth in the healthcare and hospitality segments, particularly from Crowne Plaza Changi Airport. The company also recorded higher gains from investments and declared an unchanged interim dividend of S$0.01 per share.

site_title: CDL swings back into the black with record S$1.1b profit in H1
summary: CDL, a Singaporean property developer, reported a record net profit of S$1.1 billion for the first half of 2022, reversing a net loss of S$32.1 million in the same period last year. The profit was driven by divestment gains and the group's deconsolidation of CDL Hospitality Trusts. CDL has proposed a special interim dividend of S$0.12 per share and is actively discussing share buybacks. The group's revenue rose 23.5% to S$1.5 billion, driven by hotel operations and property development segments. CDL plans to build up its exposure to the "living sector" and is exploring opportunities in the private rented sector, senior housing, and affordable housing.

site_title: In-form Patrick Reed ready to rumble at Tanah Merah
summary: Patrick Reed, a former Masters champion, is set to compete in the Asian Tour's US$1.5 million International Series golf tournament at Tanah Merah Country Club's Tampines Course in Singapore. Reed, who has played just 27 holes in practice rounds, displayed focus and concentration to bag 7 birdies for a seven-under 65 in the pro-am event. He is paired with South Korean golfers Sihwan Kim and Bi-o Kim, and Indian golfer Gaganjeet Bhullar, in the first round, which begins on Thursday.

Fifteen-time major champion Woods has always made clear his opposition to the LIV series which is threatening to tear golf apart and triggered accusations of Saudi "sportswashing".

site_title: Need for speed as the world moves towards net zero
summary: The world is moving towards net zero, but progress has been slow. With the global average temperature rise hitting 1.1 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, governments and corporations are pledging to net-zero emissions. However, countries such as the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, and Indonesia rank in the bottom half of the list of 76 countries in terms of building a low-carbon future. Asia, home to 5 of the 10 largest carbon-emitting countries, lags behind in its transition to a low-carbon economy. To accelerate decarbonisation, more public-private partnerships, tighter government regulation, and a stop in funding for fossil fuels are needed. The market is already seeing opportunities for companies to innovate and develop cost-effective decarbonisation solutions, and a 25% net gain in global growth by 2040 is expected if measures to mitigate climate change are taken.

images.alt_text: To turn carbon ambitions into reality, leaders must be adaptable in their strategies; address investor dissonance; decarbonise with the customer in mind; be focused in collaboration; and empower middle management.
Oil tanks and pipes at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal. With their outsize production and reserves, such state-owned oil giants hold the key to the world's energy transition.
Some 46 countries worldwide are now pricing carbon through trading schemes or taxes, covering around a third of emissions, according to the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: US wholesale inventories gain revised lower in June
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 1.8% in June, lower than the initially reported 1.9% increase. This decrease is attributed to businesses slowing down stock replenishment amid softening consumer spending. Wholesale inventories excluding autos increased 1.7% and motor vehicle inventories rose 2.6%. The data suggests a more moderate pace of inventory accumulation by businesses, contributing to the US economy's unexpected contraction in the second quarter.

site_title: Sri Trang Agro-Industry Q2 earnings tumble 77% as glove slowdown pummels profit margin
summary: Sri Trang Agro-Industry (STA) reported a 77.4% decline in Q2 earnings to 1.14 billion baht due to a slowdown in glove demand and lower average selling price. Group revenue fell 6.1% to 27.97 billion baht, with gloves revenue halved to 6.42 billion baht. However, revenue from natural rubber products rose 28.4% to 21.54 billion baht. Net profit margin plunged 12.8 percentage points to 4.1%, while gross profit margin was more than halved to 15.2%.

site_title: Fed now seen delivering 50 bp hike in Sept after inflation eases
summary: The US Federal Reserve is now expected to deliver a 50-basis-point interest rate hike in September, down from a previously anticipated 75-basis-point increase, following data showing US inflation slowed in July. Consumer prices remained unchanged from June, marking the slowest monthly inflation in over two years. The Fed's current policy rate target is 2.25-2.5%. This shift in expectations comes after traders reacted to the Labor Department's report on US inflation.

site_title: US will operate around Taiwan, despite China’s pressure
summary: The US will continue to operate in the Taiwan Strait, ignoring China's pressure, with the Biden administration vowing to maintain freedom of navigation and conduct air operations in the region. China's military drills, deemed a long-term strategy to intimidate Taiwan, have hardened anti-China attitudes on Capitol Hill. The US has assessed that China's military advantage may diminish as the US arms Taiwan, and President Xi Jinping seeks to establish control over the island's 23 million people. The US will continue to fly, sail, and operate in the Taiwan Strait, with officials stating China's actions are "coercive" and will not be taken lightly.

images.alt_text: The People's Liberation Army's Eastern Theatre Command said on its official Weibo account its troops will keep a close eye on changes in the situation in the Taiwan strait.

site_title: Malaysia asks anti-graft body to expedite probe into LCS project
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob has asked the nation's anti-graft commission to expedite its investigation into the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) project, which has faced criticism over its lack of progress despite a significant budget allocation. The Cabinet has agreed to declassify a 2019 forensic report and will prosecute those responsible if evidence is found. The investigation will not impact the government's decision to proceed with the project, which has cost RM6 billion. The government remains committed to completing the project for the nation's navy and armed forces.

site_title: China's central bank warns of inflation risks as CPI climbs
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has warned of inflation risks as consumer prices rose to 2.7% in July, the highest level in 2 years, driven by food prices. The bank expects consumer inflation to exceed 3% in some months during the second half of the year. To mitigate this, the PBOC will safeguard the economy against inflation, avoiding massive stimulus and excessive money printing, while providing stronger support to the real economy. The bank aims to keep full-year inflation around 3% in 2022.

images.alt_text: In annual terms, coal mining and washing industry prices rose 20.7 per cent, slowing 10.7 percentage points from June, while the oil and gas extraction industry jumped 43.9 per cent, down 10.5 percentage points, according to a separate statement from NBS.

site_title: Samsung unveils new foldable smartphones to stay ahead
summary: Samsung unveiled its latest foldable smartphones, the Galaxy Z Flip4 and Galaxy Z Fold4, with prices starting at $999.99 and $1,799.99 respectively. The devices feature 5G connectivity and 7.6-inch main screens. Samsung aims to maintain its leadership in the expanding foldable market, with the company's president stating that the category has transformed from a "radical project" to a "mainstream device lineup enjoyed by millions worldwide."

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics' operating profit rose to 14.1 trillion won (S$14.9 billion) for the quarter ended June 30 from 12.57 trillion won a year earlier, its highest second-quarter profit since 2018.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as bets on big rate hikes ease after inflation data
summary: US stocks rose sharply at the open on Wednesday as inflation data showed a slower-than-expected rise, prompting traders to cut bets on a third straight 75-basis-point interest rate hike in September. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with gains of 1.09%, 1.42%, and 2.40%, respectively.

site_title: Sri Trang Gloves sees H1 net profit fall 90% on lower selling prices in market
summary: Sri Trang Gloves Thailand reported a 90.4% decline in net profit to 1.67 billion baht (S$64.8 million) for the first half of 2022, down from 17.33 billion baht in the same period last year. Lower average selling prices due to increased supply in the market led to a 51.9% fall in revenue to 13.66 billion baht. Despite a 32.6% year-on-year increase in sales volume, the company attributed the decline to normalizing demand after the COVID-19 pandemic. Sri Trang aims to achieve 57 billion pieces in annual installed production capacity by 2024.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Sri Trang Gloves ready for the next pandemic

site_title: India central bank tightens scrutiny over digital lending apps
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has issued guidelines to increase scrutiny over digital lending apps, requiring regulated entities to disburse and collect loan repayments directly. Only banks and shadow banks are allowed to engage with digital lending apps, with the lender bearing the fee. The guidelines also address data collection, requiring need-based data, clear audit trails, and explicit borrower consent. Automatic credit limit increases and interest rate communication are prohibited without explicit consent. The move aims to curb malpractices and ensure borrower protection.

site_title: AMTD’s story is not just about what it has done, but what it hasn’t
summary: AMTD Digital's meteoric rise to a 21,425.6% share price increase within two weeks of listing on the NYSE has drawn attention to its parent company, AMTD Idea. Despite holding an 88.7% stake in AMTD Digital, AMTD Idea's share price gains were limited, and the US-listed counter has since fallen. The company's chairman, Calvin Choi, is under scrutiny for alleged misconduct, including a ban from certain regulated activities in Hong Kong. AMTD Idea's activities in Singapore, including a failed bid for a digital bank license, have been largely overshadowed by the controversy surrounding Choi and AMTD Digital.

images.alt_text: The rally has raised eyebrows from New York to Hong Kong, given AMTD Digital reported just US$25 million in revenue for the year ended April 2021.
Seven of the 10 US listings from China and Hong Kong this year have now experienced similarly unusual price action.

site_title: Investor activists need to sharpen their nous to get climate proposal buy-ins
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest fund manager, saw a significant drop in support for climate-related shareholder proposals, voting in favor of just 24% this year, down from 43% last year. The quality and quantity of proposals also declined, with total shareholder support for environmental and social proposals falling to 27% from 36% in the previous season. This trend is concerning, as it suggests investors are not prioritizing climate action. BlackRock's goal is to retain and improve the value of its investments, which may not align with climate goals.

images.alt_text: WSP Global is raising about C$800 million in new equity - half of it coming from Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board.

site_title: US consumer price growth unchanged for July
summary: US consumer prices remained unchanged in July, marking the first notable sign of relief from rising inflation over the past two years. The 1.1% rise in food prices was the only component to show an increase, while petrol costs dropped sharply. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) was unchanged after a 1.3% rise in June, with underlying inflation pressures still elevated. The Federal Reserve is expected to consider another interest rate hike in September, despite the drop in petrol prices.

site_title: Singapore’s GIC, Quebec’s Caisse back deal spree by WSP Global
summary: WSP Global, a Canadian engineering firm, has raised C$800 million in new equity, with half coming from Singapore's GIC, Quebec's Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board. The deal is backed by the trio of institutional investors for the acquisition of UK consulting firm RPS Group, valued at £625 million. This is the second major deal for WSP in the past 3 months, following its £2.3 billion purchase of John Wood Group's environment and infrastructure business. The deal is expected to boost WSP's workforce to 23,000 and contribute to its strategic action plan.

site_title: Sri Lanka's ousted president seeking entry to Thailand after weeks in Singapore
summary: Former Sri Lankan President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has requested entry into Thailand for a temporary stay, following his departure from Singapore amid mass protests and economic crisis in Sri Lanka. Rajapaksa fled the country on July 14 and resigned as president, becoming the first to quit mid-term. He is expected to leave Singapore and head to Bangkok on Thursday, holding a diplomatic passport allowing a 90-day stay. Rajapaksa denies seeking political asylum in Thailand, stating he will travel to another country afterwards, amid concerns about potential war crimes investigations and his family's handling of the economy.

images.alt_text: A protester sits in a camp site, after police asked them to leave from a seafront tent camp that became the focal point of months-long nationwide demonstrations, amid Sri Lanka's economic crisis.

site_title: SBS Transit posts 5% drop in H1 earnings to S$34.6m on absence of one-off tax exemption
summary: SBS Transit reported a 5% drop in first-half earnings to S$34.6 million due to a jump in tax expense and absence of a one-off tax exemption from the Job Support Scheme. Revenue rose 14.3% to S$732.4 million, driven by higher service fees and rail fare revenue. Group operating costs grew 14.4% to S$689.4 million due to high energy prices and a competitive labour market. Underlying group operating profit rose 12.6% to $43 million.

images.alt_text: Net proft after tax for Q1 2022 fell despite an increase in revenue by 8.5 per cent from the corresponding quarter last year.

site_title: Tencent-backed China health information unicorn censored online
summary: A Chinese health information provider, DXY, backed by Tencent, had at least 5 of its Weibo social media accounts frozen after publishing an article questioning the effectiveness of a traditional Chinese medicine, Lianhua Qingwen, in treating Covid-19. The move comes 3 months after the article's removal and criticism from the public. DXY's accounts have 8.69 million followers and carry notices stating they are prohibited from posting due to "violating relevant laws and regulations." This is not the first instance of censorship against DXY, with another executive's Weibo account banned for criticizing the lockdown in Shanghai.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines to acquire 20 Airbus A330neos: sources
summary: Malaysia Airlines is set to announce a deal to acquire 20 Airbus A330neo wide-body jets, replacing 15 A330-300s and six A330-200s. The airline will likely lease around half of the upgraded planes and purchase the rest directly from Airbus. The deal is expected to be announced on August 15.

site_title: US Senate vote advances fight against climate change
summary: The US Senate has passed a $370 billion bill aimed at moving the US away from fossil fuels and towards renewable energy sources, a historic move in the fight against climate change. The bill, if passed by the House of Representatives and signed into law by President Biden, would cut the nation's greenhouse pollution by 40% below 2005 levels by the end of the decade. The legislation provides tax incentives for electric vehicles and zero-emission energy sources, and offers billions of dollars in tax perks for businesses switching to clean energy.

images.alt_text: The bill will allow Medicare to begin negotiating in 2026 with the pharmaceutical industry over prices on a limited number of prescription drug prices as a way of reducing costs.

site_title: Hong Kong extends national security arrests to civil servants
summary: Hong Kong authorities have expanded their national security crackdown to civil servants, arresting two government workers under colonial-era sedition laws for promoting "ill-will and enmity" on social media. The arrests follow a wave of similar cases, with at least 213 people, including 42 under the dormant sedition law, already detained. The move comes after Beijing's national security law was imposed in 2020, carrying sentences of up to life in prison for acts of secession, subversion, and colluding with foreign forces.

site_title: Delfi H1 earnings up 57.6% on stronger sales performance; declares interim dividend of US$0.0158
summary: Delfi H1 earnings surged 57.6% to US$19.4 million, driven by a 17% year-on-year revenue increase to US$246.3 million, surpassing pre-Covid-19 levels. The Indonesian segment saw a 16.1% increase, while regional markets improved by 18.9%. CEO John Chuang attributes the growth to the gradual easing of Covid-19 restrictions, leading to higher social and economic activities and improved consumer sentiment.

site_title: China military ‘completes various tasks’ around Taiwan, will conduct regular patrols
summary: China's military has completed its series of war games around Taiwan, but will continue regular patrols, signaling a possible end to days of drills. The drills, sparked by US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taipei, included ballistic missile launches and simulated attacks. China claims Taiwan as its own territory, while Taiwan rejects these claims. The US maintains that China will not invade Taiwan in the next two years.

images.alt_text: China has withdrawn a promise not to send troops or administrators to Taiwan if it takes control of the island, an official document showed on Wednesday (Aug 10).

site_title: UK consumer energy debt already at record levels: survey
summary: The UK is facing a record-high energy debt of £1.3 billion, with 6 million households owing an average of £206 to providers. Energy bills are set to rise by 82% in October, potentially forcing millions into poverty. The government is under pressure to launch a multi-billion pound support package, with Foreign Secretary Liz Truss and former finance minister Rishi Sunak facing criticism for not providing adequate support. A windfall tax on energy producers is being kept under review.

site_title: Haw Par H1 earnings up 45.8% to S$77.2 million; board proposes S$0.15 dividend
summary: Haw Par Corporation reported a 45.8% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$77.2 million for the first half of FY2022, driven by improved consumer demand for healthcare products. Revenue rose 45.1% to S$95.5 million, and earnings per share improved to S$0.349. The group attributed the growth to easing of domestic Covid-19 measures and border restrictions. A dividend of S$0.15 per share is proposed for the period, with the company maintaining a cash balance of S$599.9 million.

site_title: Why the next UK prime minister faces troubled time as British leader
summary: The UK is set to elect a new prime minister, with Liz Truss likely to prevail. However, whoever wins will face significant domestic and external challenges, including managing a divided Conservative party. The leadership contest is also marked by the legacy of Margaret Thatcher, with both Truss and Rishi Sunak seeking to invoke her triumphant spirit. The new prime minister will face a range of issues, including high inflation, a cost-of-living crisis, and the Ukraine war, as well as a more difficult domestic political environment and the need to manage the party's internal divisions.

images.alt_text: British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said on Thursday she would not impose further windfall taxes on oil and gas companies.
Rishi Sunak appeared to score a surprise win with a studio audience at a key debate with frontrunner Liz Truss in the race to become Britain’s next prime minister.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.35 points to 1,492.33. A total of 2.165 billion lots worth RM1.677 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 601 to 242.

site_title: US dollar edges down ahead of key US inflation data
summary: The US dollar edged lower ahead of US inflation data, which is expected to show a year-on-year headline inflation rate of 8.7% and core inflation of 0.5% month-on-month. A strong inflation print could damage the case for the Federal Reserve to pivot away from interest rate hikes and instead focus on recession concerns, potentially leading to slower rate increases. Market reaction will be closely watched, with traders expecting a strong core inflation figure to negatively impact the US dollar.

site_title: STI up 0.5%, bucks regional rout ahead of US inflation report
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Wednesday, defying regional declines, ahead of the US inflation report. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,286.33, with Thai Beverage and Capitaland Investment leading the gains. Analysts expect positive returns for the year despite macroeconomic concerns, driven by export growth and a strong services sector.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were all down in early trade on Wednesday.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.65 per cent, or 180.63 points, to end at 27,819.33.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Condominium resale volumes fell for the third straight month in July 2022, with 51.4% of transactions coming from the outside central region, followed by 24.6% from the rest of central region and 16.3% from the core central region.

site_title: Aviva gives lower-paid staff £1,000 to help pay energy bills
summary: UK insurer Aviva is giving 7,000 of its lowest-paid employees a one-time payment of up to £1,000 (S$1,667) to help with soaring energy bills amid the cost-of-living crisis. The payment, made to employees earning under £35,000, aims to alleviate the effects of high inflation and a potential recession. This move follows other UK financial firms, including Barclays, HSBC, and Lloyds Banking Group, which have also announced extra payments or pay rises to support staff affected by the crisis.

site_title: Hospitality hiring intensifies as visitors return to Singapore – but staff are hard to find
summary: Singapore's hotels are seeking to fill hundreds of jobs as staffing levels have yet to match the tourism pick-up, particularly after pandemic-era cuts. Resorts World Sentosa and Marina Bay Sands are among the integrated resorts looking to fill 1,500 and 1,750 positions, respectively. Despite a growing number of tourists, the industry's manpower crunch worsened during the pandemic, with Singapore's hotel workforce shrinking by 25-30% over the past two years. Hotels are employing various recruitment strategies, including job fairs, social media outreach, and partnerships with the Tourism Careers Hub.

Hotel staff, including a cleaner and a bellman walk past at the Marina Bay Sands Hotel.

site_title: China property developers' woes cast shadow over management units
summary: China's property crisis is casting a shadow over the financial prospects of property management companies, triggering a rout in their shares and making investors cautious. Defaults by developers due to government moves to deleverage the sector have led to a loss of confidence in these companies, with share prices plummeting 7% this month. The crisis has also raised concerns about the dependability of property managers' profits, as many of their businesses rely on revenue from management services to cash-strapped developer parents.

images.alt_text: China Evergrande will return the land-use rights to the Guangzhou Municipal Planning and Natural Resources Bureau, from which it had acquired the rights in April 2020.

site_title: China investors hedge US delisting risk with Hong Kong play
summary: Global fund managers are shifting US-listed Chinese stocks to Hong Kong-traded peers amid uncertainty over an audit dispute between the US and China. The pace of migration is expected to accelerate as more Chinese firms list in Hong Kong, potentially boosting liquidity and smoothing the transition. Key players, such as KraneShares and Pictet Asset Management, are already making the switch, with some fund managers like Thomas Masi and Adam Coons opting to maintain ADRs. A primary listing in Hong Kong could increase trading volumes and eligibility for mainland investments, but may not match the depth of US markets.

site_title: European gas prices increase as winter supply risks loom
summary: European natural gas prices rose on August 10, 2022, amid concerns over a difficult winter ahead due to potential Russian supply disruptions. Despite normal gas storage levels and steady pipeline flows, prices increased after three sessions of declines. Cities in Germany are cutting back on lighting and hot water to conserve energy. European officials are shifting focus to managing demand for energy this winter, with the UK planning for potential blackouts and the Rhine River expected to become impassable due to low water levels.

site_title: ABN Amro expects to benefit from higher rates after beating estimates
summary: ABN Amro reported a higher-than-expected profit due to improvements in its loan book, enabling it to release provisions for bad debt. The bank expects to benefit from higher interest rates in the second half of the year, joining European peers in cheering the end of negative rates. ABN Amro's shares rose 4.6% in Amsterdam trading, with a new 250 million-euro share-buyback program announced. However, analysts noted that the bank's earnings woes will drag into 2023, with higher costs and regulatory fees weighing on profit.

DUTCH bank ABN Amro beat first-quarter earnings expectations on Wednesday (May 18) but higher-than-expected costs, including new anti-money laundering provisions, weighed on the company's shares which dropped around 10 per cent.

site_title: Farrer Road’s Sutton Place up for en bloc sale at S$285m
summary: Sutton Place, a 5-storey freehold residential development in District 10, Singapore, has been put up for collective sale at S$285 million. The site can accommodate about 162 apartments at a minimum size of 915 sq ft, with a land price of S$2,052 psf ppr. The successful buyer can redevelop the site subject to approvals from relevant authorities, and the median price of new apartments in the prime districts is expected to cross S$3,000 psf in the next 1-2 years.

site_title: Deliveroo says losses grow, to exit Netherlands
summary: Deliveroo, the international delivery food app, reported a 41% increase in losses to £153.8 million, citing investment costs eating into rising revenues. Despite a 12% revenue growth, the company plans to exit its struggling Netherlands market due to a "disproportionate level of investment required to reach a top-tier market position." The company has faced controversy over treatment of its riders and challenges from stiff competition and the cost-of-living crisis. Deliveroo remains confident in its ability to adapt financially to changing macroeconomic environments.

site_title: Telkom Indonesia aims to give users shopping, travel experiences in the metaverse
summary: Telkom Indonesia plans to launch "metaNesia," a virtual world to promote Indonesian micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. The telco will invest in manpower and infrastructure to build the metaverse, hiring experts in user experience and 3D animation. The virtual world aims to attract brands, which will then set up shops, and generate revenue through commissions and advertising. Potential use cases include virtual car dealerships, concerts, and travel tours, although regulatory hurdles need to be addressed. The metaverse will be accessible via browsers and mobile devices, with initial access through Windows, Mac OS, and Android.

images.alt_text: PT Telkom Indonesia launched "metaNesia," a virtual world meant to help South-east Asia's largest economy adapt to the fast-changing online landscape frequented by its young population.

site_title: China withdraws promise not to send troops to Taiwan if it takes control of island
summary: China has withdrawn a promise not to send troops or administrators to Taiwan if it takes control of the island, according to an official document. This decision, made by President Xi Jinping, signals a shift in Beijing's stance on Taiwan's autonomy. The move comes after China's military exercises near Taiwan in response to US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit last week. The withdrawal of the promise was first made in 1993 and 2000, but was not updated, sparking concerns about China's intentions on the island.

images.alt_text: The People's Liberation Army's Eastern Theatre Command said on its official Weibo account its troops will keep a close eye on changes in the situation in the Taiwan strait.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finished sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index plummeted 1.96% to 19,610.84, following a global retreat ahead of US inflation data. Investors fear a strong reading could lead to continued interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Other Asian markets also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index sinking 0.54% and the Shenzhen Composite Index falling 0.35%. The decline was attributed to concerns over US-EU trade tensions and the impact on global markets.

site_title: Malaysia likely saw stronger GDP growth in Q2 after borders reopened: economists
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to experience stronger GDP growth in the second quarter of 2022 due to the reopening of borders in April. Economists predict a 5% year-on-year growth rate, with some forecasts as high as 6.7% year-on-year. The border reopening is expected to boost private consumption, exports, and manufacturing, with the electrical and electronics industry showing significant growth. However, some experts caution that the growth momentum may not be sustainable due to underlying risks such as debt and inflation.

site_title: Sri Lanka presents plan in Parliament to cut president’s powers
summary: Sri Lanka's government has tabled a proposal to limit President Ranil Wickremesinghe's powers, aiming to curb the country's economic chaos. The 22nd constitutional amendment, if passed, would give parliament more oversight, restore independence to commissions, and prohibit dual citizens from holding office. The move is seen as a step towards securing a bailout from the International Monetary Fund and is a win for Wickremesinghe, who has promised to implement reforms. The amendment needs the votes of two-thirds of parliament members to become law and can be challenged in court within a week.

images.alt_text: A protester sits in a camp site, after police asked them to leave from a seafront tent camp that became the focal point of months-long nationwide demonstrations, amid Sri Lanka's economic crisis.

site_title: Small Singapore businesses make big US expansion plans
summary: Singaporean small businesses Flexxon and SunGreenH2 plan to expand into the US market. Flexxon, a cybersecurity company, aims to set up a regional office in the US, its first in the Western hemisphere, within 6-12 months. The company plans to shift focus from sales to R&D and local production. SunGreenH2, a cleantech startup, plans to open a US office and evaluate the possibility of establishing a mass manufacturing facility in the country, driven by the increasing demand for green hydrogen. The companies' expansion plans come as the US Senate passed the Inflation Reduction Act, which may lower the production cost of green hydrogen.

images.alt_text: All industries, including wholesale trade, transport, as well as logistics and manufacturing continued to see growth on the back of strong cross-border trade.

site_title: Thailand hikes rate for first time since 2018 to tame hot inflation
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, raised its key interest rate by 25 basis points to 0.75% for the first time in nearly 4 years to combat surging inflation, which has reached 14-year highs. The move aims to support the economic recovery, which has lagged its neighbors due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank expects inflation to remain high for the rest of the year before gradually falling to its target range in 2023.

images.alt_text: A retail CBDC is a digital form of money issued by a central bank comparable to physical banknotes.

site_title: ZumVet raises US$3.7m to bring the dog-tor to more pets
summary: ZumVet, a Singapore-based startup offering remote pet care services, has raised US$3.7 million in Series A funding led by Quest Ventures and existing investor Pine Venture Partners. The funding will be used to expand its services across more pet species and into new markets. ZumVet provides remote care, home-based diagnostics, and self-administered treatment programmes for pet owners in South-east Asia. The company aims to bring its services to more pets and solidify its position in the region's pet care market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open, before US inflation
summary: Europe's stocks dropped at the open on August 10, 2022, as investors awaited US inflation data. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.1% to 7,483.52 points, while Frankfurt's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also declined 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. Market analyst Craig Erlam attributed the decline to apprehension over the US inflation report.

site_title: Democracies can weather prosecutions of former presidents
summary: The US has been slow to prosecute former presidents, unlike many major democracies. Brazil, France, Israel, and others have successfully held ex-leaders accountable for crimes committed while in power. The US has only prosecuted one president, Richard Nixon, who was pardoned by Gerald Ford. This reluctance is rooted in concerns about perception, propriety, and potential retaliation, with some arguing it could lead to a civil war. However, international experience suggests that prosecution of former leaders can strengthen democracy, and the US should follow the example of other democracies in holding leaders accountable for corruption.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn beats profit view, ‘cautious’ on Q3
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker and Apple supplier, reported a 12% higher-than-expected net profit for April-June, driven by strong demand for smartphones and cloud products. The company expects flat revenue growth for smartphones in the third quarter, but anticipates growth in cloud and networking products. Net profit rose to NT$33.29 billion and revenue increased 12% to NT$1.5 trillion. Foxconn reaffirmed its overall revenue growth guidance for the year, despite a downturn in major markets amid high inflation and the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Russian gas cuts will not kill the German economy
summary: Germany's economy is less vulnerable to Russian gas cuts than previously thought, according to new data. Despite importing a significant amount of natural gas from Russia, gas consumption accounts for only 0.75% of Germany's GDP, lower than the EU average. The country's energy intensity is also lower than that of the US and other industrialized nations. Germany's economy has grown despite stagnant gas consumption over the past two decades, suggesting that cheap gas imports are not a major growth factor.

site_title: Golden Mile Complex obtains sale order from strata board; legal completion by November
summary: The Golden Mile Complex, a 16-storey building in Singapore, has received a sale order from the Strata Titles Boards for its collective sale. The sale price is S$700 million, with owners set to receive gross sale proceeds ranging from S$119,000 to S$31 million. The legal completion is scheduled for November this year, and vacant possession will be handed over to the developers in May 2023.

site_title: Cathay Pacific narrows loss but Covid rules on crew cloud outlook
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways narrowed its first-half loss to HK$5 billion, driven by revenue growth of 17% to HK$18.6 billion, despite strict Covid-19 rules limiting crew availability. The airline expects passenger capacity to reach up to 25% of pre-pandemic levels by year-end, and plans to hire over 4,000 staff to restore operations. Cathay's rival, Singapore Airlines, reported a net profit of S$370 million in the June quarter, while the company's shares rose 3.3% following the results.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post sharpest decline in a month ahead of US inflation data
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index fell 22.58 points, or 0.90%, to 2,480.88, its largest decline since July 12, amid cautious investor sentiment ahead of US inflation data. Tech stocks led the decline, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix falling 1.50% and 3.47%, respectively. The Korean won weakened, and foreign investors sold shares worth 102.2 billion won, while the benchmark bond yield rose.

site_title: China's factory inflation hits 17-month low, consumer prices speed up
summary: China's factory-gate inflation eased to a 17-month low in July, slowing to 4.2% year-on-year, despite global cost pressures. Consumer prices, however, rose 2.7% year-on-year, the fastest pace since July 2020, driven by food inflation, particularly pork prices. The moderation in inflation is attributed to weaker domestic demand and a drop in commodity prices. China's policymakers have room to stimulate the economy, but may rely on targeted easing to support recovery amid global inflationary pressures and interest rate hikes in other major economies.

images.alt_text: China is already the world's largest producer of renewable energy, with the capacity to generate some 679 gigawatts of wind and solar power plus another 390 gigawatts of hydropower.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Morningstar initiates Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust with S$1.82 fair value estimate
summary: Morningstar has initiated coverage on Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) with a fair value estimate of S$1.82 and a no-moat rating, citing the trust's high occupancy rates at retail malls Vivocity and Festival Walk, and steady office rental income growth. Analyst Xavier Lee forecasts 19.5% and 19.6% CAGR in revenue and net property income over 5 years, respectively. However, the trust's office properties in China are expected to be negatively impacted by high vacancy rates.

site_title: Over half of SMEs in Asean optimistic about economic outlook: study
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in 5 major Asean markets, including Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, are optimistic about the economic outlook, with 55% expressing confidence in business growth. Indonesia's SMEs are the most optimistic, with 75% expressing confidence. The survey highlights the need for SMEs to invest in technologies to improve marketing, customer engagement, and operations, and also shows that cash flow is a key concern for many SMEs. The survey emphasizes the importance of embedding sustainability across organizations to strengthen the bottom line and gain a competitive advantage.

site_title: Singapore startups increasingly tapped to tackle national issues
summary: Singapore's startup ecosystem is thriving, ranking as the No. 1 ecosystem in Asia Pacific in 2022, with 12 unicorns and over 3,800 tech-enabled startups worth an estimated $89 billion. Startups are tackling national issues, such as food security, e-payments, and healthcare, with the government investing over $100 million in research and development. Collaborations between startups and corporations are also driving innovation, with companies like Grab and Mitsubishi Electric partnering to fight dengue fever. The government is seeking to position Singapore as a global hub for entrepreneurship, but must ensure access to financial support and talent to achieve its full potential.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, August 10, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 0.65% to 27,819.33. This follows overnight falls in US tech shares and ahead of key US inflation data release. The broader Topix index fell 0.17%.

site_title: Singapore a bright spot as APAC property deal activity slows in Q2: MSCI
summary: Singapore saw a record-high investment volume of US$5.6 billion in the second quarter, driven by global investors, particularly in the office sector. The Asia-Pacific region's property investment fell 24% to US$45.1 billion, with other economies like India and Malaysia also registering gains. In contrast, China and Hong Kong saw significant contractions, with China's investment volume tumbling 42% and Hong Kong's down 50%. The slowdown is attributed to higher borrowing costs and economic headwinds, with liquidity in the region also taking a hit.

site_title: Toshiba logs surprise quarterly operating loss on higher materials costs
summary: Toshiba reported a surprise quarterly operating loss of 4.8 billion yen in the April-June period due to higher material and logistics costs, and a global chip shortage. The loss, Toshiba's first in 2 years, was attributed to a 9.4 billion yen decrease in operating earnings. Despite the loss, Toshiba maintained its full-year profit forecast of 170 billion yen, and a potential buyout could value the firm at up to $22 billion. The company is exploring going private and has received bids from various investors.

images.alt_text: Toshiba said on Tuesday (Jul 19) it had selected multiple bidders to proceed to due diligence, without naming them.
Toshiba, which is exploring strategic options, said this month it had received 8 initial buyout proposals and 2 for capital alliances that would see it remain listed.

site_title: Japan cabinet shift indicates ongoing BOJ easing, economists say
summary: Japan's cabinet reshuffle is expected to maintain the Bank of Japan's monetary easing policy, keeping interest rates low to support the economy. The overhaul, announced at a time when Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's support rate is falling, will retain key figures such as Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki and Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno. The move is seen as a bid to firm up public support and address rising prices and a resurgence of coronavirus cases, which threaten the fragile economy. Analysts predict the BOJ will stick to its easing policy framework until the end of April, with possible changes to the central bank's leadership.

images.alt_text: Support for Kishida's Cabinet totalled 46 per cent, down from 59 per cent in the previous survey 3 weeks ago, while the disapproval rating rose to 28 per cent from 21 per cent over the same period, NHK said.

site_title: Vietnam needs US$8b-14b power investment a year through 2030: minister
summary: Vietnam requires an annual investment of $8-14 billion from 2023 to 2030 to develop new power plants and expand its grid, with 75% going towards new plants and 25% towards grid expansion. The country aims to increase installed power generation capacity by 10% annually to support its growing economy and population. Vietnam plans to raise its offshore wind capacity to 7 GW by 2030 and 65 GW by 2045, while cutting coal's share in the energy mix.

images.alt_text: The Asean SME Transformation Study 2022 found that SMEs in Indonesia are the most optimistic, with 75 per cent expressing confidence in the economy.

site_title: UK inflation leaves departments needing £44b cash boost
summary: The UK government faces a £44 billion funding shortfall to offset inflation's impact on public services over the next 3 years. Inflation is expected to wipe out 40% of planned real-terms funding increases, leaving departments needing efficiency savings. Chancellor Nadhim Zahawi may need to increase funding by £8 billion this year and £18 billion in the next two years. The Institute for Fiscal Studies warns that services will face "acute challenges" unless funding is increased.

images.alt_text: One-off government payments of £650 (S$1,085) to millions of low-income British households struggling with soaring costs of living started in July, which YouGov and Cebr said could have helped boost sentiment.

site_title: Votorantim and Temasek launch US$700m fund to invest in Brazil
summary: Votorantim and Temasek Holdings have launched a US$700 million fund, 23S Capital, to invest in Brazilian companies with a focus on high-growth sectors. The investment fund aims to target long-term investments in emerging trends across the Brazilian economy. This move comes amid uncertainties in global economic growth, with Japan's SoftBank Group recently launching a US$3 billion fund to invest in technology companies in Latin America. 23S Capital's CEO, Matheus Villares, emphasizes the fund's long-term partnership approach with companies and entrepreneurs.

site_title: Alibaba helps South Korean grocery pioneer take K-food to Singapore
summary: Market Kurly, a South Korean online grocery app, is expanding to Singapore through its partnership with Alibaba unit Lazada. The app, which became South Korea's first billion-dollar online grocery app, will offer ready-to-cook and ready-to-eat meals on Lazada's RedMart platform starting Wednesday. The initial launch includes 44 products, including Korean-style snacks and meals, and will be gradually expanded to chilled food and non-food products. This marks Market Kurly's first overseas push, ahead of its planned initial public offering in South Korea.

site_title: Over New York, London and Hong Kong? Time to move on
summary: The world's financial centers, such as New York, London, and Hong Kong, are losing their appeal as workers opt for better living conditions post-pandemic. Traditional measures like regulatory robustness and capital markets size are no longer sufficient. Instead, factors like cost and quality of living, connectivity, and human capital are becoming increasingly important. The latest rankings of the Global Financial Centres Index show that human capital is the most-mentioned area of competitiveness. Cities like Dubai and Abu Dhabi are emerging as new hubs, offering attractive visa programs, housing, and incentives to attract talent.

site_title: Ex-workers at Malaysia's Brightway sue Kimberly-Clark, Ansell over alleged labour abuse
summary: Thirteen former workers of Malaysian glove maker Brightway Holdings have filed a lawsuit in the US against Kimberly-Clark and Ansell, accusing them of "knowingly profiting" from alleged forced labor practices. The workers claim Brightway paid high recruitment fees, worked long hours with few rest days, and took passports. Public reports and labour audits found by the International Labour Organization indicated Brightway's knowledge of the alleged abuses. The US had banned Brightway products due to suspected forced labor practices, and the companies were previously criticized for non-compliance with labour standards.

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation moderates on easing global commodity pressure
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation slowed to 8.6% in July from a year earlier, easing global commodity pressure. Price growth accelerated for some goods, such as food and machinery, but declined for others like petroleum and coal goods. Economists expect inflation to peak out due to declining energy costs and moderating global commodity prices. The Bank of Japan's core consumer inflation remained above its 2% target for a third straight month.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, tracking US market declines ahead of key inflation data. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.23% to 19,956.51, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also eased. The losses come as investors await US inflation data and amid concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Foxconn to build autonomous electric tractors at Ohio facility
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, will build driverless electric tractors for Monarch Tractor at its Ohio facility starting in early 2023. The production of Monarch's MK-V series tractor, powered by a battery, is scheduled to begin in the first quarter of 2023. This partnership marks Foxconn's first manufacturing contract since purchasing the Ohio facility last year, as the US agriculture industry shifts to smart farming. Monarch aims to target smaller farmers, differentiating its technology from larger manufacturers.

site_title: China's Lenovo reports slowest revenue growth in 8 quarters
summary: Lenovo, the world's largest PC maker, reported its slowest revenue growth in 8 quarters, with total revenue of $16.96 billion in the April to June quarter, up 0.2% from the same period last year. PC shipments fell 12.7% to 17.4 million units due to weak consumer demand, while non-PC business now accounts for 37% of revenue. Despite this, net income rose 11% to $516 million. Lenovo's chairman, Yang Yuanqing, expects global PC shipments to decline 10% this year, but sees improved supply chain conditions and flexibility in dealing with price fluctuations.

summary: Analyst Ng Yong Rui of Lim & Tan Securities has initiated coverage on Tianjin Pharmaceutical Da Ren Tang (TDRT) with a "buy" rating and a target price of US$1.60, citing strong economic moat, high yield, and balance sheet. The analyst believes the company's products, including over 600 items and 390 patents, will benefit from favourable macro trends such as China's ageing population and growing demand for traditional Chinese medicine. TDRT's shares rose 1.9% to US$1.05 after the announcement.

site_title: Australia: Tech stocks, a2 Milk drag shares lower ahead of US inflation data
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% to 6,998.60, dragged down by technology stocks and a2 Milk, which lost 7.2% and 6.9% respectively, ahead of US inflation data. Investors eyed the US consumer prices report for clues on further interest rate hikes. Miners dropped 0.2% and individual stocks like GrainCorp jumped 7.4% after raising its annual profit forecast.

site_title: Robot arms are replacing shelf stockers in Japan's stores
summary: TELEXISTENCE and FamilyMart are deploying AI-driven robot arms to restock shelves in 300 convenience stores across Japan. The robot arms, called TX Scara, can replace 1-3 hours of human work per day and work 98% autonomously. They use Nvidia's Jetson AI platform and Microsoft's Azure cloud infrastructure to optimize restocking tasks. The move aims to relieve store workers, who are facing a shrinking workforce, and reallocate time to customer service and shop floor enhancement. The technology is now in mass production and will be expanded to the US market.

site_title: Taiwan security officials want Foxconn to drop stake in Chinese chipmaker: FT
summary: Taiwan's national security officials are urging Foxconn to withdraw its $800 million investment in Chinese chipmaker Tsinghua Unigroup due to concerns about China's economic espionage and the potential for technology theft. The move comes amid rising tensions in the Taiwan Strait, following US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to the island. Taiwanese officials believe the deal poses a national security risk and are likely to block it, citing laws that prohibit companies from building advanced foundries in China. The deal's prospects have dimmed due to increasing tensions.
