site_title: Singapore to name the Padang as its 75th national monument on National Day
summary: Singapore will officially name the Padang as its 75th national monument on National Day, recognizing its historic significance as a site of shared memories for the nation. The Padang, despite lacking physical structures, holds great cultural and social value, and its gazette will protect it from alteration and change. This designation aims to preserve the site's character and significance while allowing it to continue as a community space for Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Six police buildings in and around Old Police Academy to be proposed for conservation

site_title: LMIR Trust posts flat Q2 DPU of S$0.0009
summary: LMIR Trust reported a flat Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0009, unchanged from a year ago, despite a 4.1% increase in gross revenue to S$51.7 million due to higher rental revenue from stabilizing Covid-19 conditions in Indonesia. Net property income rose 8.8% year-over-year to S$34.6 million. Portfolio occupancy inched up to 79.7% in Q2, but declined from 83.4% a year ago.

images.alt_text: Moody’s maintains its negative outlook on all ratings.

site_title: Oil tankers see strongest market in decades on thirst for fuels
summary: Oil tankers are experiencing their strongest market in decades due to robust demand for fuels and stretched sailing distances following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Product tankers have earned over $40,000 a day for 14 weeks, a feat not seen since 1997. The surge is attributed to disruptions in trading routes and a tight refined product market, with analysts warning that a further warping of Russian flows could add to the surge later this year.

images.alt_text: Oil tankers at a terminal of Sinopec Yaogang oil depot in Nantong, Jiangsu province. China extended record imports of low-priced Russian crude oil into June, squeezing out supplies from the Middle East and West Africa, according to tanker trackers and traders.

The number of tankers used for storing fuel oil along the Singapore Strait has risen since the Ukraine war broke out and could rise further as more of Russia’s supplies hit by sanctions head to Asia, industry sources and analysts said.
Shipbrokers said smaller tankers which are suited to shuttle cargoes out of Kozmino efficiently are now in high demand.

site_title: Apac Realty posts 2.1% dip in H1 earnings to S$16.7 million
summary: Apac Realty reported a 2.1% dip in earnings to S$16.7 million for the first half of 2022, with a 4.4% decline in total revenue to S$342.6 million. This was largely due to a decrease in brokerage income from resale and rental of properties. Despite this, gross profit inched up 0.2% to S$35.3 million. The company attributed the decline to supply chain issues and a decrease in new home sales.

images.alt_text: ERA has a “huge pool” of ultra HNWIs in its database and sees potential in the sector.

site_title: US: Wall St ticks higher at open after selloff on jobs data
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Monday, August 8, after last week's jobs data eased concerns about an economic slowdown, but maintained expectations of a hawkish Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 73.89 points, or 0.23%, to 32,877.36, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher. The gains were despite lingering concerns about US-EU trade tensions and the impact on the market.

site_title: China's Hainan expands Covid lockdowns to quell outbreak
summary: China's Hainan island province has expanded Covid lockdowns to quell a recent outbreak, with over 1,500 domestically transmitted infections reported this month. The lockdowns, aimed at China's "dynamic Covid-zero" policy, have disrupted tourism and further dampened confidence in the sector. The provincial capital of Haikou and 3 smaller towns have been locked down, with residents allowed to leave only for necessary reasons. The lockdowns have also affected tourism, with about 25,000 tourists stranded in Sanya, and Chinese stocks in tourism, transport, and consumer staples retreated on Monday.

site_title: Nvidia warns of lower second-quarter revenue on gaming weakness
summary: Nvidia warned of a 19% drop in second-quarter revenue due to weakness in its gaming business, citing a 44% sequential decline in gaming unit revenue to $2.04 billion. This follows similar concerns from Intel and Sony Group, and is attributed to consumers weighing discretionary purchases. The gaming industry, considered recession-proof, is starting to show weakness, affecting Nvidia's shares, which fell about 5% in early trading.

site_title: UK hiring slowdown hits recruitment firms' shares amid recession fears
summary: UK recruitment companies' shares fell due to a hiring slowdown amid recession fears. PageGroup warned of a slowdown citing rising interest rates and inflation, with shares dropping 11% and UK rivals Hays and Robert Walters falling 4% and 3.5%, respectively. Economists predict UK output likely contracted in the second quarter, and hiring may have been affected by the recent heat wave, with Page executives stating the impact of the slowdown will be clearer in the last couple of weeks of September.

site_title: Tesla’s second stock split in 2 years a welcome catalyst
summary: Tesla shareholders approved a 3-for-1 stock split, which will take place on August 24. The move is expected to increase trading liquidity and make the stock more accessible to retail investors. The stock has surged 50% since May, driven by better-than-expected Q2 earnings and a US$430 billion EV tax credit bill. Following the announcement, the stock closed 6.6% lower on August 5 due to profit-taking, but remains below its 52-week high of over US$1,240 per share.

images.alt_text: Tesla now expects US$6 billion to US$8 billion of capital expenditures this year and each of the next 2 years, according to its latest quarterly report.
Tesla first announced its plan for a stock split on Mar 28 via a tweet that lacked further details.
Tesla closed down 6.6 per cent at US$864.51 Friday in New York. The stock has been on an upswing over the past month, rising 28 per cent since the end of June as of Friday’s close.

site_title: UK North Sea oil needs investment to stem decline, Shell says
summary: Shell's UK head of upstream, Simon Roddy, says Britain needs to continue developing North Sea oil and gas despite rolling out major offshore wind and carbon capture projects. The UK will still need its home-produced oil and gas, which would otherwise be replaced by higher-emissions imports. Shell plans to invest £25 billion in the UK's energy system over the next decade, with three-quarters going to low-carbon projects. The firm will also develop North Sea oil and gas, but at a slower pace than in the past, citing a need to stem the decline.

images.alt_text: IHI's deep-ocean Kairyu has two counterrotating turbines.
The biggest business sector in Norway now expects to invest 167.2 billion Norwegian crowns (S$24.1 billion) in 2022, up from a forecast of 159.5 billion crowns made in February.
Oil tanks and pipes at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal. With their outsize production and reserves, such state-owned oil giants hold the key to the world's energy transition.

site_title: US: Stocks diverges from global rally as investors focus on inflation
summary: US stocks diverged from a global rally on Monday, dipping 0.1% as investors focused on upcoming US inflation data and potential interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 fell despite other global markets rising, with oil prices gaining to offset losses from last week. Analysts expect the US Federal Reserve to announce a third successive rate increase in September, driven by persistent inflation and a strong labor market. Data due this week is expected to show a slight slowdown in inflation, but it may not be enough to convince the Fed to ease up on its aggressive inflation-fighting mode.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 73.89 points, or 0.23 per cent, at the open to 32,877.36.

site_title: Qualcomm, GlobalFoundries sign pact to double chip manufacturing
summary: Qualcomm and GlobalFoundries signed an agreement to more than double their existing manufacturing deal for chips used in 5G, Wi-Fi, automotive, and IoT connectivity. The deal, valued in the billions, will see chips produced in US, German, Singapore, and French factories. This comes as the US Senate passed legislation to subsidize domestic semiconductor production, with GlobalFoundries set to expand its US manufacturing capacity. The partnership aims to support US-based manufacturing and follows similar expansion plans by Intel and GlobalFoundries.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) shares closed down 2.4 per cent, while peer United Microelectronics Corp (UMC) fell 3 per cent.
The company now expects smartphone sales to fall 5 per cent this year, compared with its prior outlook for flat growth.

In recent years, several global chip firms have announced substantial investments to expand their operations in Singapore as part of plans to ramp up production capacity amid the global chip shortage.
A rift is emerging within the chip industry itself, with some players concerned the final language of the legislation could provide disproportionate support to manufacturers like Intel.

Semiconductor Manufacturing International (SMIC), which is China's largest chipmaker by market value and faces US export curbs, gained 3.3 per cent in Hong Kong, following a 4.1 per cent jump on Wednesday (Aug 3).

STMicroelectronics, whose top clients include iPhone maker Apple and electric carmaker Tesla, strongly benefits from a surge in power-management semiconductors as the auto industry moves to low-emission vehicles, and from automation in multiple industries.

site_title: UAE government's operating surplus doubles, thanks to oil price surge
summary: The UAE government's net operating surplus more than doubled in the first quarter to 36.4 billion dirhams (S$13.7 billion) due to surging oil prices, boosting public revenue. Government spending rose to 87.4 billion dirhams, a 20% increase from the first quarter of 2021. The economic growth is attributed to high oil prices and increased production, as well as a continued recovery from the pandemic's impact.

images.alt_text: The increase of 100,000 bpd will be one of the smallest since Opec quotas were introduced in 1982, Opec data shows.
Dubai, as part of its long-term efforts to diversify its economy away from oil, wants jobs in the metaverse.

site_title: Revenue-rich Indonesia braces for tighter finances in 2023
summary: Indonesia is bracing for tighter finances in 2023 due to a weakening global coal and palm oil market, which has generated significant revenue for the country. The resource boom has brought in 279 trillion rupiah in commodity tax revenues and 48.9 trillion rupiah in export levies this year. The government expects to maintain a budget surplus, but with reduced state revenue, it will focus on spending priorities such as improving human resource quality, infrastructure development, and preparing for elections. The 2023 annual budget is set to be presented by President Joko Widodo on August 16.

site_title: Pfizer to buy Global Blood Therapeutics in US$5.4b deal
summary: Pfizer has agreed to acquire Global Blood Therapeutics in a US$5.4 billion deal. Pfizer will pay US$68.50 for all outstanding shares, a price double that of the stock on August 3. The acquisition aims to bolster Pfizer's rare-disease business, particularly its sickle-cell disease therapy, Oxbryta, which sold US$195 million last year. The deal is part of Pfizer's strategy to accelerate top-line growth and target US$25 billion in risk-adjusted revenue by 2030. The boards of both companies have unanimously approved the transaction.

site_title: US dollar edges lower as currency markets pull back on Friday's moves
summary: The US dollar fell 0.1% to 106.51 against a basket of peers on Monday, losing some of its gains from Friday's higher-than-expected US employment figures, which strengthened the dollar as traders anticipated potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve to combat inflation. Analysts expect US inflation data on Wednesday to further influence the dollar's movement, with some predicting a 75 basis point rate hike by the Fed in September.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit posts 1.5% rise in H1 DPU to S$0.0706
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 1.5% increase in its half-year distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0706, driven by higher rent from its Singapore properties and the acquisition of three nursing homes. The Reit's gross revenue rose 1% to S$60.2 million, while net property income grew 1.1% to S$56.0 million. The company's Singapore properties, comprising Mount Elizabeth Hospital, Gleneagles Hospital, and Parkway East Hospital, accounted for 60.6% of its net property income.

images.alt_text: First Reit’s Indonesia hospital operator, PT Siloam International Hospitals Tbk reported stable quarter-on-quarter performance for Q1 2022 despite the impact of the Omicron variant.
OUE's net profit of S$113.8 million from the same period the year before was boosted by a one-off S$110 million gain from a shareholder loan conversion.

site_title: ECB pumping billions into weaker eurozone debt markets, says FT
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) injected €17 billion into Italian, Spanish, and Greek debt markets between June and July, focusing on weaker economies. This move aims to cap borrowing costs and prevent yield surges. The ECB's net purchases ended in March, and it is now reinvesting maturing bonds on bloc's weaker members. The move follows interest rate hikes and aims to mitigate the widening gap between strong and weak economies.

site_title: Crypto.com expands in South Korea, looks beyond market route
summary: Crypto.com has expanded in South Korea by acquiring payment service provider PnLink and virtual-asset exchange OK-BIT, securing registrations under the Electronic Financial Transaction Act. The company aims to bring its offerings to the Korean market and partner with local gaming and entertainment companies. South Korea's high crypto adoption levels make it an attractive market for digital-asset firms, but the sector's downturn has shaken retail investor faith. Crypto.com also received in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to provide digital payment token services in the city-state.

images.alt_text: MAS has awarded 3 more in-principle approvals for its much-coveted digital payment token licence.
Singapore-headquartered Crypto.com announced layoffs of about 260 staff, or 5 per cent of its workforce.

site_title: Singapore’s safe haven status amplified as geopolitical risks rise
summary: Singapore solidified its status as a safe haven for investors amid increasing geopolitical tensions and US-China relationship uncertainties. Unlike other Asian countries, Singapore is not directly integrated into China's economic system, offering a unique proposition for companies and investors seeking strategic autonomy. This allows Singapore to maintain a balance between its close ties to Asia and limited connections to Beijing, making it an attractive destination for those seeking to navigate turbulent markets. As a result, Singapore's safe haven status has been amplified, attracting wealthy investors and companies.

images.alt_text: The number of family offices in Singapore jumped fivefold between 2017 and 2019, and almost doubled from 400 at the end of 2020 to 700 a year later.

AS myriads of China’s high-net-worth (HNW) individuals look to relocate, over 500 of them are expected to come to Singapore — bringing with them at least US$2.4 billion worth of capital inflows for the city-state.

site_title: EtonHouse group of schools doubles annual revenue to S$200m with overseas expansion
summary: EtonHouse International Education Group, a Singapore-based enterprise, has doubled its annual revenue to S$200 million after expanding globally, primarily through partnerships. The group, which started with three pre-schools in 2003, has established 120 schools in 11 countries, mostly in Asia, and serves 20,000 students. EtonHouse credits partnerships and collaborations with its success, citing the importance of finding the right local partners to drive expansion. The group is also investing in digital education, launching a curriculum licensing and school management platform to cater to new markets and accelerate growth.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump's administration on Monday finalised rollbacks to key provisions of the Endangered Species Act, a law supported by a large majority of Americans and credited with saving the gray wolf, bald eagle and grizzly bear.
EtonHouse's Ng Yi-Xian's tip for companies entering new markets: Find the right partners and listen to their feedback.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Insurers have reassured policyholders that annual bonuses for with-profits plans will not be cut despite muted returns in 2021. Play-to-earn blockchain games have seen declining investments and disappointed investors, while hoteliers prepare for post-pandemic demand. A South Korean waste management company is being acquired by Keppel Asia Infrastructure Fund for S$666.1 million. The Straits Times Index ended down 0.4% amid mixed regional showing.

site_title: Siemens Energy blames wind-down of Russia business for wider 2022 loss
summary: Siemens Energy reported a wider net loss of 760 million euros in 2022 due to a 200 million euro charge related to winding down its Russian business. The company cited Russia's invasion of Ukraine and subsequent sanctions as the reason for the exit. Despite this, Siemens Energy plans to maintain turbines at the Nord Stream 1 pipeline and is in talks with Gazprom over transporting a stuck turbine. The company's wind turbine division, Siemens Gamesa, is also struggling with raw material prices and product delays.

images.alt_text: Gazprom said on Wednesday that delivery of a turbine needed to keep gas flowing to Europe via the Nord Stream 1 pipeline was “impossible” due to sanctions on Moscow.
The industrial-manufacturing giant is focusing on higher-margin, software-driven product lines to help drive returns, and has been divesting non-core businesses as part of that process.
German rail operator Deutsche Bahn and Siemens Mobility present their joint project the Mireo Plus H train in Krefeld, Germany, May 5, 2022.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended 5.5 points lower on Monday, down 3.7% to 1,496.03 points, with 463 losers outnumbering 323 gainers. The index saw 2.19 billion lots worth RM1.32 billion.

site_title: China announces fresh military drills around Taiwan
summary: China has announced fresh military drills around Taiwan, defying calls to end the exercises after US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to the self-ruled island last week. The drills, which began Monday, will focus on anti-submarine and sea assault operations and have raised concerns among security analysts and diplomats. US President Joe Biden expressed concern but downplayed the risk of escalation, while China's defence ministry defended its actions as a legitimate defence of national sovereignty and security. Taiwan's armed forces have handled the drills "calmly," according to the defence ministry, but the situation remains tense.

images.alt_text: Vessels had also been hesitant about approaching the major port of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, seeking to avoid the large drill zone located just offshore.

Taiwan said on Saturday its forces scrambled jets to warn away 20 Chinese aircraft, including 14 that crossed the median line. It also detected 14 Chinese ships conducting activity around the Taiwan Strait.
A Chinese military vessel sails off Pingtan island, one of mainland China's closest points from Taiwan, in Fujian province on Aug 5, 2022.

site_title: The US and China are decoupling, but not as fast as you think
summary: The US and China are experiencing accelerated economic decoupling, with the recent passage of the Chips and Science Act in the US Congress dashing over $50 billion in federal grants to companies building advanced semiconductor manufacturing in the US. This act requires companies to not upgrade China-based factories for a decade, increasing pressure on China. Analysts predict sharply accelerated decoupling, but constraints include fragile US ability to bring others along, corporate resistance from both sides, and a more sedate process due to lead times of 4-7 years for key supply chain points.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration has set a goal of getting 500,000 chargers in place by 2030 to ensure EVs are accessible.

site_title: India seeks to oust China firms from sub-US$150 phone market
summary: India plans to restrict Chinese smartphone makers from selling devices cheaper than US$150, aiming to push them out of the country's entry-level market and boost local manufacturers. The move, which could affect brands like Xiaomi, is aimed at addressing concerns about unfair competition and high-volume brands undercutting local companies. The Indian government has already scrutinized Chinese firms' finances and imposed restrictions on their operations, and the new policy is seen as part of efforts to promote domestic industry and reduce reliance on Chinese imports.

site_title: Taiwan July exports jump, but uncertainly ahead
summary: Taiwan's July exports rose 14.2% to $43.32 billion, the second-highest monthly figure on record, driven by strong demand for technology products and chips ahead of the year-end holiday shopping season. Exports to China, Taiwan's largest trading partner, increased 3% to $16.04 billion, easing disruptions caused by Covid-19 outbreaks. Despite a "high degree of uncertainty" for the global economy due to the war in Ukraine and inflationary pressures, Taiwan's total exports for the year are expected to exceed $500 billion.

site_title: Europe braces for heatwave as power infrastructure wobbles
summary: Europe is bracing for another heatwave, with temperatures expected to reach 36 deg C in the UK, Germany, and France this week, putting pressure on power infrastructure. The heatwave comes amid a historic energy-supply crunch due to Russia's tightened grip on natural gas flows, contributing to soaring inflation and recession risks. The crisis has led to power price records in Germany and France, with water levels on the Rhine River at risk of halting trade. The heatwave is forecast to peak at 31.5 degrees Celsius in London and 32.5 degrees in Frankfurt.

site_title: Indonesia plans large energy subsidies for 2023: Finance minister
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati announced plans to allocate "very large" energy subsidies in 2023 to stabilize prices amid rising global energy costs. The government has budgeted 502 trillion rupiah (S$46.6 billion) in subsidies and compensations this year, and expects to maintain a similar amount next year. The 2023 budget will focus on human development, infrastructure, and funding for elections, with a deficit target of under 3% of GDP. Commodity prices are predicted to decline, with crude oil prices forecast to fall to US$90 a barrel and coal prices to US$200 a tonne.

site_title: Gallant Venture stays in the red with S$16.8m loss in H1
summary: Gallant Venture, a developer and master planner of industrial parks and resorts, reported a net loss of S$16.8 million in the first half of 2022, narrowing from a loss of S$25.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 4.4% to S$75.8 million, but costs and expenses increased, leading to losses in its resort and property development segments. The company's current liabilities exceeded its current assets by S$529.2 million, and its board has not recommended dividends for the half-year period.

images.alt_text: Gallant Venture, Pacific Radiance record 3 straight years of losses

site_title: An oil windfall offers Gulf states one last chance to splurge
summary: Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states are poised to receive a significant windfall from high oil prices, potentially worth up to $1.4 trillion over the next five years. The oil boom offers a chance to diversify their economies, reduce debt, and invest in non-oil sectors. However, there is pressure to share the wealth with the public and implement mega-projects, such as Neom, a futuristic city in the desert. Gulf leaders must balance short-term spending with long-term economic diversification and mitigate the risks of failed projects. The oil windfall also gives Gulf states significant leverage to influence global economic policies and provide aid to poorer countries.

images.alt_text: Oil tanks and pipes at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal. With their outsize production and reserves, such state-owned oil giants hold the key to the world's energy transition.
Benchmark Brent crude futures settled down US$2.66, or 2.75 per cent, at US$94.12 on Thursday, the lowest close since Feb 18.

site_title: ESG investing faces a reckoning: Is there a sustainable future behind it?
summary: ESG investing, which has seen strong performance in the past, is facing scrutiny over its long-term sustainability. Despite ESG funds outperforming the market in 2020 and 2021, their performance has fizzled out in 2022, with oil prices surging due to the Russia-Ukraine war. The criticism highlights the challenges of measuring ESG impact, inconsistent standards, and the need for transparency. As the industry converges on a consistent framework, investors must weigh trade-offs between ESG factors and financial returns, and regulators are taking steps to address inconsistent reporting.

images.alt_text: Wind turbines at the Waubra Wind Farm operated by Acciona SA in Waubra, Victoria, Australia. Until green energy can be produced at scale, divestment from hydrocarbons may raise energy prices for all.

site_title: Singapore’s deeper response to inflation must be to transform: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the government to transform and boost productivity to address global economic challenges. He emphasized the need to upgrade industry skills and raise productivity to ensure Singaporeans can earn more in real terms, despite shifting international economic conditions. The government stands ready to implement deeper measures if needed to help Singaporeans.

site_title: STI down 0.4% amid mixed regional showing
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% or 11.9 points to 3,270.98 on Monday, amid a mixed regional showing. This decline comes after strong US jobs data sparked fears of another Federal Reserve rate hike to combat inflation. Local stocks were mixed, with Sembcorp Industries up 3.6% and Wilmar International down 4.9%. Regional markets also showed mixed results, with Japan's Nikkei up 0.3% and South Korea's Kospi up 0.1%.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange

site_title: China drafts rules on use of self-driving vehicles for public transport
summary: China's Ministry of Transportation has drafted rules to regulate the use of autonomous vehicles as taxis in easily controlled scenarios in low traffic situations. The draft encourages the use of self-driving vehicles in these scenarios, prioritizing safety. The ministry aims to promote the use of autonomous vehicles in public transport, but with caution.

images.alt_text: Baidu is transitioning to artificial intelligence and self-driving cars after its core advertising revenue shrank in the mobile era.

site_title: Bullet Train arrives with so-so US$30.1m debut; Easter Sunday stumbles
summary: Bullet Train, starring Brad Pitt, opened in US cinemas with a US$30.1 million debut, topping the domestic box office chart despite a US$90 million price tag. The film received a mediocre 41% approval rating from critics, citing it as overly derivative of other films. In contrast, Universal's Easter Sunday and DC League of Super-Pets performed poorly, with Easter Sunday earning just US$5.3 million and Super-Pets grossing US$11.2 million. The domestic box office has rebounded in recent months, but studios are concerned about a lack of blockbuster releases until Black Panther: Wakanda Forever's opening in November.

images.alt_text: Paramount said global streaming subscribers rose to about 64 million.

FILE PHOTO: Vanessa Bayer, Dwayne Johnson,  Jameela Jamil and Kevin Hart attend a premiere screening for "DC League Of Super Pets" at The Grove, AMC 14  in Los Angeles, California, U.S. July 13, 2022. REUTERS/Ringo Chiu/File Photo

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on lower yen, bargain hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks ended higher on Monday, August 8, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.26% or 73.37 points to 28,249.24. A lower yen and bargain hunting contributed to the gains, while the broader Topix index added 0.22% or 4.24 points to 1,951.41.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: European stocks rebounded on Monday, August 8, 2022, with London's FTSE 100 index climbing 0.7% to 7,489.13 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX index and Paris CAC 40 also rose, with gains of 1.0% and 0.7% respectively. The rebound follows pre-weekend falls as traders assess interest rate hikes aimed at cooling soaring inflation.

site_title: The unwitting winners of France's drought: salt farmers
summary: France's drought has unexpectedly benefited salt farmers in the north-western region of Guerande, where production has soared to record levels due to blistering heatwaves and drought. Sea salt production, averaging 1.3 tonnes per salt pan over the last 10 years, has nearly doubled to 2.5 tonnes this year. However, the region's salt farmers are concerned about the long-term sustainability of their work and the potential consequences of climate change on their fragile mud structures and water supply.

images.alt_text: The parched grass in Greenwich Park in front of a view of skyscrapers in the Canary Wharf financial, business and shopping district of London last week. The unprecedented heat this summer has pushed plant life, infrastructure and residents to the edge.

Boats are lying in the mud in the harbour in Beusichem, the Netherlands, 03 August 2022. The Netherlands declared an official water shortage on Wednesday (Aug 3) as the low-lying “land of water” was hit by Europe’s sweltering summer.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as strong US jobs boost Fed rate hike bets
summary: Asian markets struggled on Monday, August 8, amid a strong US jobs report that fueled bets on higher interest rates. The dollar surged and held gains, complicating the Federal Reserve's plans to tighten monetary policy. Despite a resilient US economy, the report may slow the pace of rate hikes, which had been expected to ease due to indicators pointing to a slowdown, including a technical recession.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led gains, adding more than 2 per cent on Thursday, while there were also advances in Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Jakarta and Wellington.

site_title: Indonesia says Tesla strikes US$5b deal to buy nickel products
summary: Tesla has signed contracts worth approximately $5 billion to buy nickel products from Indonesian companies, marking a significant investment in the country's nickel industry. The deals, which include a 5-year contract, will supply materials for Tesla's lithium batteries. This move aims to support Indonesia's development of electric vehicles and battery industries, with the country seeking to boost revenue and encourage domestic production of higher-value nickel products.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has the world's biggest nickel reserves and Widodo is keen to develop a nickel-based EV industry at home.
Southeast Asia's largest economy is steadily gaining momentum after a broader reopening and booming exports.

site_title: Singapore’s pandemic journey
summary: Singapore has been on a long road to recovery since the Covid-19 pandemic began, with economic growth stifled and travel curbs limiting tourism. Despite a strong manufacturing sector, the services sector was severely impacted, while unemployment rates initially spiked but have since eased. As of August 2022, 79% of the population had received a booster shot, and 1,759,575 total cases had been reported, with 1,539 total deaths. Experts predict pre-pandemic tourist arrivals will not be reached until the mid-2020s, and the country is now focusing on recovery and growth.

site_title: Baidu wins approval for China's first full driverless taxis
summary: Baidu has secured approval to operate China's first fully autonomous self-driving taxis in Wuhan and Chongqing, marking a relaxation of Chinese rules. The tech giant will begin providing fully driverless robotaxi services in designated areas, with 5 Apollo fifth-generation robotaxis operating in each city. Baidu plans to work with regulators in other cities to obtain similar permits, aiming to double its robotaxis on Chinese roads to 600 vehicles by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Apollo RT6 robotaxis are set to be mass-produced at a cost of 250,000 yuan (S$51,458) per unit.

site_title: Ships resume Taiwan routes even as China drills remain unclear
summary: Ships in the Taiwan Strait have resumed normal routes despite unclear Chinese military exercises. Over 30 vessels transited the drill zone since Sunday, with some ships diverting to alternative ports like Kaohsiung. The military exercises, sparked by US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan, are unclear to have ended. Shipping companies had previously avoided the drill zone and major port of Kaohsiung, but are now resuming their original routes. The Maritime Safety Administration warned ships to avoid a military exercise area in the Bohai Sea.

images.alt_text: Taiwan will continue to direct flights and ships away from a Chinese military drill off its eastern coast until 10 am local time on Monday (Aug 8) morning.

site_title: Property groups can champion sustainability, but may do little to build an inclusive society
summary: Singapore-listed property groups, such as CDL and CapitaLand Investment, have received recognition for their sustainability efforts, including being included in the Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations index for 13 consecutive years. These efforts focus on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, which can positively impact the wider community and contribute to the fight against climate change. However, some critics argue that these companies may prioritize financial gains over building inclusive societies, and that governments should lead efforts to create affordable public housing and promote racial integration.

images.alt_text: ESG data currently is far less available than financial data, which can be accessed through databases providers such as Bloomberg.
Sustainability is "on the verge of becoming very economically impactful", GIC's group chief investment officer Jeffrey Jaensubhakij said.

site_title: China's exports to Russia grow for the first time in 5 months in July
summary: China's exports to Russia grew 22.2% in July, marking the first increase in 5 months, amid the ongoing Ukraine war. Russian shipments to China also held steady. Oil supplies from Russia to China dropped to 21.3 million barrels in July, the lowest since February. This growth comes as Chinese buyers took advantage of lower-priced Russian supplies. site_title: Future of Singapore’s social compact rests on the shoulders of the people
summary: Singapore's social compact, a governing framework between the state and people, is under review through the Forward Singapore initiative. Led by Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, the effort aims to refresh the social compact and set a roadmap for the next decade. The compact, established in the 2000s, focuses on fairness, fair play, and justice, with key principles including affordable public housing, education, and healthcare, as well as economic restructuring to minimize income inequality. The initiative seeks to engage Singaporeans on four defined issues and foster a sense of mission, ownership, and trust among citizens.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans have a real opportunity to build on firm foundations and become more inclusive, more welcoming of talent from all over the world – because as citizens we have every reason to feel secure, cared for and appreciated.
At the launch of Forward Singapore, Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong framed the exercise as the renewal of Singapore's social compact.

Explaining the need to refresh Singapore’s social compact, Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said a social compact, broadly, is a shared understanding of how everyone in society relates to each other, as well as the respective roles and responsibilities of various groups.

site_title: China July copper imports rise on-year as price slump spurs buying
summary: China's copper imports rose 9.3% in July from the same period last year, driven by a sharp drop in copper prices and low domestic inventories. Copper prices plunged by one-third from March to mid-July due to China's Covid-19 control measures and fears of a global economic recession. July's imports totaled 463,693.8 tonnes, down 13.8% from the previous month. The price slump sparked buying appetite, as copper prices currently trade at around 4,400 yuan per tonne.

images.alt_text: Prices of London copper, which is used as a gauge of economic health by investors, were weighed down on Tuesday by weaker demand outlook in top consumer China, firm US dollar and fears of a global recession.

site_title: Newly-listed Lincotrade aims to leverage tourism rebound with hotel upgrading works
summary: Lincotrade & Associates Holdings, a Singapore-based interior fit-out company, listed on the Singapore Exchange after a reverse takeover of Fabchem China. The company aims to capitalize on the tourism rebound by upgrading hotels, with a 30-year experience in the industry and a recent completion of its largest project, Citadines Raffles Place Singapore. Revenue increased 99.4% year-over-year to S$37.3 million, while net profit reversed from a loss of S$1.6 million. The company has an order book of S$76.7 million and expects to fill it in the next two years, giving it an advantage over peers that exited the market during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: More construction firms set up than wound up despite pandemic

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: Tanker and dry bulk market rates continued to decline, with VLCC rates falling another 1.5 points to WS57.5. The Capesize market saw rates drop below $15,000, while the North Atlantic rates softened at a slower rate. In contrast, the USG MR market saw significant gains, with TC14 and TC18 rising to WS369.17 and WS475, respectively. The Suezmax market fell heavily, with rates losing 26 points to WS182, while the Aframax market dropped almost 20%. Despite some gains, the overall market trend remains downward.

site_title: Sustainable packaging in Singapore: the potential & opportunities
summary: Singapore's packaging industry faces significant waste management challenges, with 1.82 million tonnes of domestic waste incinerated in 2021, contributing to 11 million kgCO2e emissions. To address this, businesses must rethink their packaging processes and systems, collaborating with the government, supply chains, and consumers. The Singapore Environment Council found that price is a major factor in consumers choosing sustainable packaging, but 53% would only purchase sustainable packaging if it doesn't cost more. Upstream players, such as manufacturers and suppliers, have opportunities to disrupt the industry with innovative business models, while the government can support with incentives and policies.

images.alt_text: Just 14 per cent of the plastic packaging used globally is recycled, while 40 per cent ends up in landfills and 32 per cent in ecosystems, with the remaining 14 per cent incinerated.
Launch of the pilot programme

Mobilising capital for waste management - which has traditionally relied on government budgets and bilateral and multilateral development aid - is a key priority for developing markets in the region, says Jacob Duer, president and CEO of the Alliance to End Plastic Waste.

Investors have the opportunity to help solve the plastic waste issue, fight climate change and capture the economic value of plastic,” says Rob Kaplan, chief executive officer and founder of Circulate Capital.

site_title: Renault on right track with new electric vehicle: CEO
summary: Renault's CEO Luca de Meo stated the company is on the right track with its turnaround, citing the success of its new Megane E-Tech electric vehicle model. The model sold 25,000 units in three months, making it the best-selling EV in France. De Meo believes the democratization of electric cars will occur in Europe with affordable prices, but rising battery material costs pose a challenge. Renault aims to take on rivals like Volkswagen and Stellantis with new EV models, despite facing headwinds such as semiconductor shortages and inflation.

images.alt_text: The Spectre is on track to be the first hyper-luxury EV on the market with no direct competition.

site_title: US CEOs blame remote workers for slow sales, earnings shortfalls
summary: US CEOs are blaming remote workers for slow sales and earnings shortfalls, citing a sluggish rate of returning to offices, or "RTO". Companies such as Shake Shack and Kimberly-Clark Corp have reported lower-than-expected sales growth due to low office occupancy rates, averaging 44% in major metro areas. Experts estimate that cities are experiencing a "donut effect", with central business districts becoming hollowed out while suburbs become denser. Average NYC office workers plan to reduce their time at desks by nearly half, leading to a spending shortfall of $6,730.

images.alt_text: Companies need to have better ways to onboard new workers and get them involved in corporate culture. They also need to ensure improved promotion prospects for purely remote workers and the ability to go completely remotely from one firm to another.
US economic productivity during the pandemic was driven entirely by firms with remote work capacity, according to a new study co-authored by Robert Gordon of Northwestern University.
Younger workers may find it less productive to be in the office, and find it just as possible to manage social relations in cyberspace as in the real world.

site_title: London's Horniman Museum to return Benin Bronzes to Nigeria
summary: The Horniman Museum in London will return 72 artefacts, including 12 Benin Bronzes, looted by British soldiers in 1897 to the Nigerian government. The Benin Bronzes, created from brass and bronze in the 16th century, are culturally significant artefacts from the Kingdom of Benin. This decision follows a request from Nigeria's National Commission for Museums and Monuments and comes as other Western institutions, such as Cambridge University and the Quai Branly museum in Paris, have also returned similar artefacts. The returns are expected to increase pressure on the British Museum's largest collection of Benin Bronzes.

images.alt_text: The United Nations says honey plays a “vital role” in Yemen’s economy, with 100,000 households dependent on it for their livelihoods.

site_title: Former AMP chairman and BT regional editor Yang Razali Kassim dies
summary: Yang Razali Kassim, a former chairman of AMP and regional editor of The Business Times, has passed away at 67 due to a serious infection that caused complications, including breathing problems. A founding member of AMP, he served as chairman from 2004 to 2006 and was a senior fellow at the S Rajaratnam School of International Studies for 18 years. Kassim was known for his bold views and was an experienced journalist, producing measured papers for AMP that were appreciated by many, including at the political level.

images.alt_text: Yeo was appointed senior counsel of the Supreme Court in 2000 at the age of 37.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding H1 net profit from continuing operations rises 32% to nearly 1.2b yuan
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 32% increase in net profit from continuing operations to 1.2 billion yuan for the first half of 2022, driven by higher revenue and gross profit from shipbuilding and shipping segments. The company delivered a record 35 vessels in the first six months of the year and secured new order wins of $1.09 billion for 18 vessels. Despite a 17% decline in inclusive net profit due to discontinued operations, the company's annualized return on equity rose to 14%.

images.alt_text: Ren Letian, chief executive officer of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding

site_title: Commonwealth Games: Veteran paddler Feng reclaims singles title in comeback win
summary: Veteran table tennis player Feng Tianwei, 35, reclaimed her Commonwealth Games singles title after coming back from 3 games down to beat Zeng Jian 4-3. Feng, who won the title in 2010 and 2014, overcame injuries to wrist, shoulder, and knee to secure the win. This is Singapore's third and fourth table tennis medals at the Games, following the women's team gold and men's team silver. Feng and Zeng will compete in the women's doubles semi-finals on Sunday.

images.alt_text: Nine athletes and a manager vanished after completing their events, an official has said.

site_title: Blockchain tech: the answer to what ails the carbon-credits market?
summary: Blockchain technology can simplify the carbon-credits market by eliminating middlemen and increasing transparency, potentially reducing inflated prices. By storing information on a decentralized public ledger, project developers can mint and sell carbon offsets directly to buyers, cutting out intermediaries and ensuring 100% of the sale price goes to the project developer. This approach enhances credibility and makes auditing easier, but requires rigorous standards to ensure its effectiveness in funding carbon reduction and removal efforts.

site_title: China’s export growth gains steam despite weakening global demand
summary: China's export growth unexpectedly accelerated to 18% in July, the fastest pace in 2022, beating analyst expectations of 15% growth. This boost came despite weakening global demand and a contraction in China's official manufacturing survey, raising concerns about the economy's recovery. Imports, however, remained sluggish at 2.3% growth, suggesting domestic consumption remains soft. China's trade surplus reached a record $101.26 billion, supporting the country's economic growth despite downward forecasts from the International Monetary Fund.

images.alt_text: Petroleum exports were the highest on record at US$29.1 billion, but petroleum imports also hit an all-time high of US$27.8 billion.

Semiconductor Manufacturing International (SMIC), which is China's largest chipmaker by market value and faces US export curbs, gained 3.3 per cent in Hong Kong, following a 4.1 per cent jump on Wednesday (Aug 3).

site_title: Play-to-earn blockchain games have disappointed, but some see new applications emerging
summary: The popularity of play-to-earn blockchain games, such as Axie Infinity, has waned due to gameplay issues and a decline in cryptocurrency values. Investors have also pulled out, mirroring the trend in the startup scene. While some critics argue that blockchain technology is not suitable for gaming, others see this as a natural life cycle of a technology. The decline in activity and pricing is being seen on other platforms as well, with data showing a sharp decline in play-to-earn gamers and a slower pace of new game launches. The focus on earning has been criticized, with some calling for a shift towards entertainment value.

images.alt_text: Moving from play-to-earn to play-to-own
Gaming for a living: Are NFT games a fair gig or low-wage exploitation?

site_title: Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance to buy US reinsurance broker for US$400m
summary: Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance Company plans to acquire US reinsurance broker Transverse for approximately $400 million, with an additional $150 million possible depending on earnings. The deal aims to gain expertise in the reinsurance broker business, which could aid in expanding an insurance market specializing in cybercrime fields.

images.alt_text: The company’s China unit wants to set up an asset-management company to help find better investment opportunities and build a pension-fund operation.

site_title: Corporate VC is booming, but is it what your startup needs?
summary: Corporate venture capital (CVC) is booming, with a record 1,317 deals in Q1, but startups must carefully evaluate the potential benefits and drawbacks. CVCs offer funding, resources, and strategic support, but may struggle with industry norms, impatient decision-making, and conflicting interests with parent companies. Startups should screen potential partners thoroughly, considering factors such as the CVC's objectives, structure, and expectations. Four types of CVCs exist: strategic (long-term growth focus), financial (maximizing returns), hybrid (strategic and financial focus), and in transition (may shift objectives). Entrepreneurs should conduct due diligence, speaking with key executives and existing portfolio companies, to determine whether a CVC aligns with their needs and goals.

images.alt_text: Singtel has upped its capital commitment to CVC arm Innov8 from US$250 million to US$350 million
The corporate venture capital conundrum in Singapore

site_title: Over 80,000 tourists trapped in Sanya after Covid outbreak
summary: Over 80,000 tourists are stranded in Sanya, China, after a Covid flare-up led to strict travel restrictions. All flights out of the city were cancelled, and tourists must test negative in 5 PCR tests over 7 days to leave. Hotels have been asked to offer a 50% discount to guests until the restrictions ease. The latest outbreak comes during peak tourism season in Sanya, a popular surfing spot, and is part of China's ongoing zero-Covid strategy.

images.alt_text: Authorities have changed the so-called circuit-breaker mechanism for airline bans, cutting to 1 week the period that incoming flights will be suspended if they carry 5 Covid-positive passengers.

site_title: Taiwan says flights through its airspace resuming after Chinese military drills
summary: Taiwan's transportation ministry announced that flights through its airspace have resumed, with most notifications for Chinese military drills near the island being "no longer in effect". However, flights and ships will still be directed away from a Chinese military drill off Taiwan's eastern coast until 10 am local time on Monday morning. This decision aims to ensure safety and avoid potential disruptions.

site_title: Hainan starts mass Covid testing, imposes more lockdowns
summary: Hainan, China, has started mass Covid-19 testing and imposed more lockdowns as local infections rise to over 1,100 this month. The island province reported 182 new infections on Sunday, boosting the total. Lockdowns have been imposed in the city of Wanning and the beach resort city of Sanya, stranding tourists and disrupting holiday plans. The measures come as the virus outbreak sweeps across Hainan, affecting thousands of people and causing flight cancellations. Authorities are taking strict measures to control the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: Tourists who want to leave Sanya must test negative in 5 PCR tests over 7 days.
Authorities have changed the so-called circuit-breaker mechanism for airline bans, cutting to 1 week the period that incoming flights will be suspended if they carry 5 Covid-positive passengers.

site_title: SGTI 2022 shows more S-Reits reporting non-financial metrics
summary: Singapore-listed Reits and business trusts saw a marginal increase in their Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) 2022 scores to 85.3 points, up from 85.0 points last year. Top performers included Ascott Residence Trust, Ascendas Reit, and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit, with notable improvements in practices for interested person transactions and sustainability-related disclosures. The mean score of the Reits and business trust category increased by 0.3 points year on year, with a 0.7-point increase in mean bonus points for good disclosure practices.

images.alt_text: There are fewer people as usual outside Ngee Ann City and along Orchard road on 7 Apr 2020, as Singapore enter Day 1 of 'Circuit breaker' mode to deal with the current coronavirus situation.

site_title: Bonds of Temasek-linked corporates look attractive amid sell-off, analysts say
summary: Temasek-linked corporate bonds are seen as attractive investments amid market uncertainty, with yield curve inversion presenting buying opportunities in the shorter-duration space. DBS analysts note that indicative ask prices for these bonds are at "historical depressed levels" following a recent bond market sell-off. This is attributed to global central banks tightening monetary policy and inflation concerns. Investors seeking safe havens may consider putting their money into these bonds, which are indirectly owned by Temasek.

images.alt_text: The proceeds raised from these bonds will be used to finance expenditures in support of the Singapore Green Plan 2030, including 2 new MRT lines — the Jurong Region Line and the Cross Island Line.
Asia-Pacific issuers are diversifying into SLBs from traditional green bonds.
There is a huge appetite for assets that provide 3-in-1 benefits: security, income and liquidity.

site_title: Koh Brothers H1 net profit rises 151% to S$5m
summary: Koh Brothers Group, a Singapore-based construction, property development, and engineering solutions provider, reported a 151% increase in net profit to S$5 million for the first half of 2022, driven by increased construction activities and sales of its Van Holland private residential project. Revenue rose 13% to S$158.9 million, while earnings per share increased to 1.21 cents. The company will not pay an interim dividend, citing the need to conserve cash.

images.alt_text: Oiltek International bags RM49.2m in new contracts for year to date

site_title: US dollar posts broad gains after unexpectedly strong jobs data
summary: The US dollar surged against other currencies, posting its largest daily percentage gain since mid-June, following a stronger-than-expected jobs report that suggested the Federal Reserve may continue to raise interest rates. The US dollar index rose 0.8% to 106.57, while the dollar was up 1.5% against the yen. The report showed non-farm payrolls increased by 528,000 jobs, exceeding economists' expectations, indicating the Fed may not pivot on rate hikes.

site_title: Trio of amateur golfers set to light up US$1.5m International Series at Tampines
summary: Singapore amateur golfer James Leow is set to compete in the US$1.5 million International Series at Tampines, following recent victories in the Thunderbird Collegiate event, Arnold Palmer Cup, and Pacific Coast crown. Leow's success has drawn comparisons to Thailand's Ratchanon Chantananawat, who finished third in the same event last year, earning bragging rights despite not receiving prize money as an amateur. The series is expected to feature a strong lineup, with Leow looking to make a strong showing alongside other amateur golfers.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Island Country Club's The New Course. An event on Aug 4-5 aims to promote golf to the masses by allowing people to play at all 10 local golf clubs.

site_title: From ‘Tower of Terror’ to brutalist icon: A London landmark abides
summary: London's Trellick Tower, a 1972 brutalist public housing project designed by Erno Goldfinger, has become an icon after initially being viewed as an "eyesore." Residents have rallied to preserve its unique design, which includes a thin service tower connected to the main block by "sky bridges." Despite being granted landmark status in 1998, the council has proposed a 15-storey tower near the site, sparking fears of gentrification and loss of community character. Residents gathered over 3,000 signatures and secured a meeting with local government representatives, leading to the withdrawal of the plans, but concerns remain about future development.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England in the City of London. The central bank forecasts a protracted recession that will last as long as 15 months, causing the UK economy to shrink by 2.1 per cent during that time.

site_title: Lambo dealers are keeping warm despite crypto winter
summary: Despite the recent crypto crash, luxury car sales, particularly Lamborghinis, remain strong. The demand for supercars suggests owners are wealthy enough to be unaffected by market fluctuations. Sales of Lamborghinis have doubled to $12 million in the past year, with some owners using cryptocurrency to purchase vehicles. The value of Lamborghinis has held steady, while cryptocurrency prices have plunged. This trend is attributed to the fact that luxury cars are less volatile than digital currencies, and some owners are seeking physical assets to diversify their portfolios.

images.alt_text: A Rolex Group Daytona watch.
A Lamborghini on display at the Motor Valley Fest in Modena, Italy in May 2022. The Italian luxury sports car manufacturer had a record year for sales in 2021.
Superwealthy revving up Bugatti and other exotic car sales in Singapore
Among key recent developments in the watch industry is the extraordinary growth of the strongest brands such as Rolex, Patek Philippe, Cartier (pictured) and Audemars Piguet.

site_title: Chinese and Taiwanese warships shadow each other as drills due to end
summary: Chinese warships shadowed Taiwanese counterparts in the Taiwan Strait ahead of the scheduled end of 4-day military exercises launched in response to US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan. About 10 warships from each side sailed close quarters, with some Chinese vessels crossing the median line, an unofficial buffer separating the two sides. Taiwan scrambled jets to warn away 20 Chinese aircraft, including 14 that crossed the median line, and detected 14 Chinese ships conducting activity around the Taiwan Strait. The exercises, which focused on land-strike and sea-assault capabilities, were described by the US as a significant escalation in China's efforts to change the status quo.

images.alt_text: Taiwan will continue to direct flights and ships away from a Chinese military drill off its eastern coast until 10 am local time on Monday (Aug 8) morning.
A Chinese military vessel sails off Pingtan island, one of mainland China's closest points from Taiwan, in Fujian province on Aug 5, 2022.

site_title: 10 Sri Lankans vanish from Commonwealth Games
summary: Ten Sri Lankan athletes and a manager have vanished from the Commonwealth Games in Birmingham after completing their events, with a top sports official suspecting they want to remain in the UK to get employment. The 160-strong team's management had held passports to ensure their return, but the athletes' decision to leave prompted a police complaint. British police located the first three who disappeared, but no action was taken due to their valid visas. The official believes the remaining seven are still in the UK, but their whereabouts are unknown.

images.alt_text: Athletes for Team Sri Lanka take part in the opening ceremony for the Commonwealth Games at the Alexander Stadium in Birmingham, central England, on July 28, 2022. (Photo by Glyn KIRK / AFP)

site_title: Pfizer in advanced talks to buy Global Blood Therapeutics for US$5b: sources
summary: Pfizer is in advanced talks to acquire Global Blood Therapeutics for approximately $5 billion, aiming to seal a deal in the coming days. The deal would bring in billions in annual sales by the end of the decade, following Pfizer's recent acquisitions of Biohaven Pharmaceutical and others. Global Blood's Oxbryta, a blood disorder drug, has seen significant sales growth, with a 44% surge in shares after the report. The acquisition would add to Pfizer's portfolio of treatments for rare and genetic diseases.

images.alt_text: Apart from Platinum Orchid, a subsidiary of the United Arab Emirates’ biggest sovereign wealth fund ADIA, and GIC, new investors included state-owned China Life’s private equity arm - China Life Private Equity Investment - and Cinda Kunpeng (Shenzhen) Investment Management Co.
AstraZeneca on Friday (Jul 29) topped analyst expectations for second-quarter profit and revenue, helped by higher demand for its cancer medicines.

site_title: Tesla accused of false autopilot advertising by California DMV
summary: The California Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) has accused Tesla of disseminating false statements about its "Autopilot" and "Full Self-Driving" features, misleading customers into believing they are more advanced than they are. The DMV claims Tesla violated California law by making untrue or misleading statements, and is requiring the company to provide more accurate terms and descriptions. Tesla has 15 days to respond to the accusations.

images.alt_text: Tesla closed down 6.6 per cent at US$864.51 Friday in New York. The stock has been on an upswing over the past month, rising 28 per cent since the end of June as of Friday’s close.

site_title: Stock-buyback tax revival in Senate bill leaves Wall Street unfazed
summary: A tax on stock buybacks, potentially levying a 1% excise tax, is set to become law, aiming to slow the practice of boosting share prices through buybacks. Market players downplay the effect, citing larger macroeconomic issues such as interest rate hikes. Analysts predict the tax will shift companies to opt for dividends, which are taxed when issued, and potentially cause a price drop. The tax's impact is seen as a factor, not a game-changer, in the overall market, driven by business cycles and Federal Reserve actions.

images.alt_text: Equity hedge funds posted gains of 2.89 per cent, underperforming the S&P 500, which went up 9.11 per cent last month. For the year, equity hedge funds were down 9.2 per cent.
For the week, the S&P 500 rose 0.4 per cent, the Dow fell 0.1 per cent and the Nasdaq added 2.2 per cent.

site_title: China eases rules for international Covid flight suspensions
summary: China has eased rules for international Covid flight suspensions, cutting the period that incoming flights will be suspended to 1 week if they carry 5 Covid-positive passengers (4% of total passengers). Flights with 8% infected passengers will be halted for 2 weeks. The change aims to promote personnel exchanges and cooperation while maintaining epidemic prevention and control. This move follows China's reduction of quarantine times for inbound travellers by half in June. The change is seen as a step towards easing virus-control measures for international travellers, following Hong Kong's recent lifting of its flight-ban system.

site_title: US Senate Democrats fend off amendments to US$430b climate and drug bill
summary: US Senate Democrats successfully repelled amendments to a $430 billion climate and drug bill, paving the way for its passage before the August recess. The bill aims to reduce prescription drug costs for the elderly, lower energy prices, and cut carbon emissions by 40% by 2030. It includes a Medicare negotiation with pharmaceutical industry over prices and a $2,000 cap on out-of-pocket medication costs. The bill's passage is seen as a key victory for President Joe Biden and Democrats ahead of the midterm elections, despite Republican opposition to the legislation's new spending and revenue.

images.alt_text: One recent win for United States President Joe Biden is the passage of the US$280 billion Chip and Science Act, which had the support of many Republicans despite that party’s strong opposition to the notion of “industrial policy”.

site_title: The humbling of Coinbase
summary: Coinbase, the US's largest cryptocurrency exchange, has struggled in the past year after a triumphant public offering. The company, led by CEO Brian Armstrong, has faced cost-cutting measures, layoffs, and a decline in trading due to the crypto market's downturn. Despite its early start, Coinbase has failed to establish a strong hold in the international market, with competitors like Binance dominating. The company's expansion into India was met with uncertainty and criticism, and its NFT marketplace launch was delayed and poorly received. Coinbase has laid off 18% of its staff and has struggled to compete with nimbler competitors, leading to concerns that the company may squander its head start in the industry.

images.alt_text: Coinbase's success has made it a lightning rod for enforcement.
Crypto lender Vauld has received a 3 month extension on its moratorium from the Singapore courts as its creditors called for the platform to allow withdrawals
The exchange was launched in September 2019 and is based in Singapore and Thailand.
Coinbase has repeatedly sparred with the agency over how it oversees the industry, and the firm last week called on the SEC to propose clearer rules.

The arrest of Ishan Wahi, who helped oversee listings for a Coinbase unit focused on investment products, follows a sweeping probe involving the Southern District of New York and the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The hype around crypto startups made the sector seem briefly immune to the economic turmoil.

site_title: China’s IPO market trounces the world with record US$57.8b boom
summary: China's IPO market has seen a record-breaking $57.8 billion in initial public offerings (IPOs) so far in 2022, surpassing the global total. Despite rising interest rates and economic uncertainty, China's IPOs have defied headwinds, with companies rushing to list and shares averaging a 43% gain over listing price. The tech sector has been particularly active, with companies seeking to build up home-grown capabilities. China's share in global IPO proceeds has more than tripled to 44% this year, with companies like China Mobile and CNOOC listing at home after being kicked out of the US.

images.alt_text: In Indonesia, the central bank has so far bucked the global tightening wave to keep rates at a record low, providing growth support as a commodities export boom offers a tailwind.

site_title: US lawmakers urge joint use of funds for broadband, EV charge stations
summary: US lawmakers have urged the Biden administration to use joint funds to build electric vehicle charging stations and broadband internet infrastructure, particularly in underserved areas. The lawmakers, led by Representatives Doris Matsui and Anna Eshoo, cited the need to address multiple national priorities simultaneously and avoid duplicative efforts. The Biden administration has set a goal of getting 500,000 chargers in place by 2030, and Congress has allocated $42.45 billion for broadband expansion and $5 billion for EV charging under the $1 trillion infrastructure law.

images.alt_text: Electric buses in Singapore. The International Finance Corporation estimates that cities in emerging markets in Asia could attract around US$20 trillion in climate-related investments to 2030 in green buildings, public transportation, electric vehicles, waste, water, and renewable energy.

site_title: Kylie Minogue mixes her signature cocktail
summary: Kylie Minogue, 54, recently created her signature cocktail, the Pink Pearl, at Bemelmans Bar in the Carlyle Hotel in New York. The pop star mixed the drink to her own beat, shaking it with a cocktail shaker in hand. Minogue shared her experience with the barman, Abdul Rashid, and expressed her enthusiasm for her creation. This marks a refined relationship with liquor for Minogue, who has drawn from her early experiences of casual drinking to create a unique cocktail.

images.alt_text: Cheers for Kylie Minogue after making her Pink Pearl cocktail at Bemelmans Bar at the Carlyle Hotel in New York, June 8, 2022. At the hotel, the pop star shook her newly created cocktail to her very own beat. (Gabby Jones/The New York Times)

site_title: Analysis: Banks are Twitter deal escape hatch Musk would struggle with
summary: Elon Musk's attempt to back out of his $44 billion Twitter acquisition faces significant hurdles, with the banks involved standing to lose hundreds of millions of dollars. The Delaware Court of Chancery has set a high bar for acquirers to abandon deals, and most experts favor Twitter. Musk would need to prove the banks refused to deliver on debt commitments, which would be challenging given his public statements against the deal. If the banks succeed in backing out, they would face reputational damage and the prospect of selling the debt at a loss.

images.alt_text: In a filing, Twitter rejected counter claims made by Elon Musk as he fights to walk away from the deal he inked in April to buy the San Francisco-based company.
Musk declared his takeover bid for Twitter on Apr 14, but said the deal was "on hold" barely a month later.

site_title: Carlyle, GIC back green ammonia with investment in Eneus Energy
summary: Carlyle Group and Singapore's GIC have made a strategic investment in Eneus Energy to support the development of green ammonia projects. The deal allows them to invest over US$3 billion in Eneus Energy's projects over the next 5 years, backing the company's efforts to develop global projects involving renewable energy-based ammonia production. This investment is part of the growing trend of investors betting on technologies that aim to reduce emissions and support a transition to renewable energy.

site_title: Russia bans Western investors from selling banking, key energy stakes
summary: Russia has banned investors from Western countries that supported sanctions on Russia from selling shares in key energy projects and banks until the end of the year. The decree, signed by President Vladimir Putin, prohibits sales of assets in production sharing agreements, banks, strategic entities, and energy equipment. This move escalates the sanctions stand-off with the West, which has imposed financial restrictions on Russia since its invasion of Ukraine in February.

images.alt_text: Russian central bank said it would introduce additional measures aimed at reducing banks' operations in US dollars and euros.

Liberia-flagged Turkish bulk carrier ship Osprey S is seen anchored off shore in Istanbul, Turkey, Aug 4, 2022. The Osprey S is expected to arrive in Ukrainian Black Sea port of Chornomorsk on Aug 5 and will be the first vessel to arrive at a Ukranian port since Russia's military invasion.

site_title: Google sued for nixing free workspace software to early adopters
summary: Google has been sued by an early adopter of its Workplace cloud productivity software, alleging the company reneged on a promise to provide free access to the program for life. The Stratford Company claims Google started charging legacy users $12/month in 2022, despite earlier excluding non-business users. The lawsuit seeks class-action status and damages, estimated to be over $5 million. Google has not commented on the allegations, which Stratford Company claims illustrate Google's abandonment of its "don't be evil" motto.

images.alt_text: Monday's complaint seeks an injunction against further anticompetitive conduct, plus triple damages for violating federal antitrust law and California state laws.

Google, Meta Platforms and Apple are among nearly 70 companies filing a brief with the US Supreme Court in support of affirmative action programmes being challenged at Harvard and the University of North Carolina.

site_title: Raffles Medical chair ups stake following H1 2022 results
summary: Raffles Medical Group executive chairman Loo Choon Yong increased his stake in the private healthcare provider after acquiring 353,800 shares at S$1.23 per share. The shares now account for 10.84% of his direct interest in RMG, which has grown from 51.93% at the end of 2014. RMG reported H1 2022 revenue of S$382.3 million, with healthcare division revenue up 24.1% and hospital services division revenue down 11.4%. The company remains in a net cash position with S$288.0 million in cash.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida to reshuffle cabinet as Covid, Taiwan in focus
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced a cabinet reshuffle to address mounting issues including the coronavirus, inflation, and Taiwan affairs, set to take place next week. The reshuffle comes after Kishida's conservative coalition government increased its majority in the upper house of Parliament following the death of former premier Shinzo Abe. Defence Minister Nobuo Kishi, who has been dealing with health issues, is expected to be replaced, and other key officials, including Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki and Industry Minister Koichi Hagiuda, are likely to retain their positions.

site_title: Maersk buys Danish project logistics company for US$61m
summary: Maersk, a global container trade leader, acquired Danish project logistics company Martin Bencher Group for $61 million, expanding its land-based operations. The acquisition is part of Maersk's strategy to boost profit margins by building out its logistics business. Maersk has raised its 2022 profit forecast to a record $31 billion due to bottlenecks in key trade lanes. The company aims to capitalize on higher profit margins in land-based logistics.

site_title: Sri Lanka considering restructure of local and sovereign debt: president
summary: Sri Lanka is considering restructuring both local and sovereign debt as the country battles its worst financial crisis since independence in 1948. President Ranil Wickremesinghe said the government is working with financial advisers to finalize a plan to restructure overseas debt, including $12 billion owed to bondholders. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that restructuring local debt could have far-reaching consequences, citing the impact on domestic banks. The IMF has previously stated that restructuring domestic debt is like surgery, only done if necessary and with caution.

Sri Lanka on Tuesday (Aug 2) brushed aside Indian concerns over a scheduled visit by a Chinese ship to its Hambantota Port, saying it was coming only to refuel and replenish supplies.

site_title: Once-beleaguered Pacific International Lines delivers US$2.6b earnings for FY21
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL), a Singapore-based carrier, has achieved a significant turnaround, reporting a net earnings of US$2.6 billion for FY21, reversing from a US$44.7 million loss in 2020. The company generated a topline of over US$5.8 billion, driven by pandemic-fuelled e-commerce and maritime congestion. PIL fully repaid US$1 billion in debt, marking a substantial improvement from 2018 when it logged hundreds of millions of losses despite billions in revenue. The company's earnings reflect a strong recovery in the shipping industry.

site_title: Tiny IPO spikes 1,150% in US debut in wake of AMTD Digital’s surge
summary: Hong Kong's Magic Empire Global surged 2,325% in its US IPO debut, closing at $97 after starting at $4. The IPO is the seventh this year by a Chinese or Hong Kong company to experience unusual price action, following AMTD Digital's 14,000% surge. Magic Empire's market cap reached $1.9 billion. The unusual price action stands out amidst muted IPO activity due to market volatility and reduced public valuations.

site_title: Top-performing Asian stock markets shrug off Fed, China risks
summary: Asian stock markets, particularly Indonesia and India, are defying the global trend of slowing growth and rising interest rates, with the Jakarta Composite Index and NSE Nifty 50 Index gaining 8% and 10% respectively in 2022. Domestic demand and a commodities export boom are driving growth, while China's economic struggles are contributing to investors' preference for these markets. Foreign investors are also returning to India, and Indonesia's central bank has kept rates low, providing growth support and a tailwind for the economy.

images.alt_text: Equity hedge funds posted gains of 2.89 per cent, underperforming the S&P 500, which went up 9.11 per cent last month. For the year, equity hedge funds were down 9.2 per cent.

site_title: UBS whistleblower retaliation win overturned on appeal
summary: A federal appeals court in New York has overturned a jury verdict in favor of a former UBS senior strategist, Trevor Murray, who claimed he was illegally fired in 2012 for refusing to sugarcoat his reports for clients. The court ruled that Murray's lawyer failed to prove that UBS took retaliatory action against him, as required by the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. A new trial has been ordered, and UBS was previously ordered to pay Murray over $900,000.

site_title: India freezes assets of Binance-linked WazirX
summary: India's Enforcement Directorate has frozen assets worth 646.70 million rupees (S$11.2 million) of WazirX, a crypto exchange linked to Binance, as part of an investigation into suspected foreign exchange regulations violations. The agency is looking into WazirX's role in laundering crime proceeds through its platform. Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao denied his company owns shares in WazirX's parent company Zanmai Labs, stating it only provides wallet services. The investigation is part of a broader money-laundering probe targeting several fintech companies backed by Chinese funds.

site_title: Chinese tourist hot spot Sanya imposes Covid lockdown
summary: Sanya, a popular Chinese tourist destination, has imposed a lockdown due to a severe COVID-19 outbreak, with 263 cases reported on Friday. The Omicron subvariant BA.5.1.3 was detected, and authorities have restricted public transport and restricted people's movements. The lockdown, which started on Saturday, affects about 80,000 tourists, mainly residents, who are allowed to leave with negative PCR tests. The measures are in place during the peak tourist season and come after the city started imposing lockdown measures on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Macau, a Chinese-ruled former Portuguese colony, on Tuesday reopened public services and entertainment facilities and allowed dining-in at restaurants.

Hong Kong currently requires everyone arriving in the city to test negative for Covid within 48 hours of departure and on arrival, and then spend a week isolated in a hotel to ensure an infection was not missed during the incubation period.

site_title: India's Paytm Q1 loss rises on higher expenses
summary: Paytm, India's largest digital payments firm, reported a wider first-quarter loss of 6.45 billion rupees, a 69% increase from the previous year, due to higher marketing and employee benefit expenses. Despite this, the company targets achieving operational profitability by September 2023, citing better cost leverage. Total income rose nearly 88% to 17.81 billion rupees, and the firm disbursed loans worth 55.54 billion rupees in the quarter.
